webTitle: Jump and jet ski - then sleep in a wagon

fields.headline: Jump and jet ski - then sleep in a wagon
fields.standfirst: Jacqui MacDermott gets a taste for adventure on South Island
fields.trailText: Jacqui MacDermott gets a taste for adventure on South Island.
fields.body:
Join the jet set
Careen down a canyon in a jet boat, narrowly missing the jagged rocks jutting out from either side. It's like a fairground ride, only real, and takes a great deal of skill from the driver. Particularly exhilarating are the 180° turns where, trust me, you will get wet. Best hangover cure ever. £25 for 30 minutes. reservations@shotoverjet.co.nz.

Walk with a dinosaur
Meet Henry the tuatara, described by Longman's encyclopaedia as 'the last survivor of the Rhynchocephalia from the early Mezozoic era', or a living dinosaur, as he is called in NZ. Green, scaly and around 2ft long, Henry was born around 1880 (yes, really) and could live until the latter part of this century. Tuataras exist only in a tiny part of New Zealand but you can encounter some at Southland Museum, Invercargill - and chat with Lindsay Hazley, who breeds them. office@southlandmuseum.co.nz

Love in
Spend a romantic night at Larnach Castle - not a castle at all but a Gothic Revival mansion built by a rich, eccentric banker in 1867. It has been tastefully restored with glorious gardens and offers good food in a fabulous setting. Ask for the Goldrush Room where the bed has been converted from an old cart, complete with massive wheels, and the walls are a mural of the night sky. Then pretend you are 'making out' under the stars. Larnach Castle, Camp Road, Dunedin, NZ. www.larnachcastle.co.nz

Take a running jump
Fling yourself off a tiny platform with nothing but latex rubber cord around your ankles. Yes, Queenstown is the bungee capital of the world and you can choose jumps from a mere 43 metres to the bowel-loosening 134m at Nevis, the world's highest. Nevis jump £47, including certificate and T-shirt. bungyjump@ajhackett.co.uk

Row, row, row...
South Islanders love sea kayaking and it is offered at various spots on the Otago Peninsula and Stewart Island. Once you get used to the rubber 'skirt' that connects you to the kayak it's easier than you'd think, can be surprisingly relaxing and is a good way to admire the scenery. If you don't fancy going solo, double kayaks are fun and allow you to natter as you paddle. Details from any South Island tourist office.

P-p-p-eek at a penguin
Get up before dawn to spot rare yellow-eyed penguins on the beaches around Dunedin. From a concrete hide you'll be able to watch them shuffling from their nests with their mates, and splashing into the sea. As the sun comes up, you can also admire lazy, sleepy fur seals and wary sealions waking up. Then go and eat a big, hot breakfast. ericshelton@clear.net.nz

Just wing it
See the magnificent albatross in the wild at the world's only mainland colony, at Taiaroa Head. As they measure up to 12ft wingtip to wingtip, watching these seabirds gliding on the thermals over your head is an awesome experience. From April to September you can also watch them feed their fat, ungainly chicks. Otago Peninsular Trust, Dunedin, NZ. albatross@es.co.nz

The cod father
Have lunch at The Beach in Riverton, NZ's first recorded settlement. This small, unpretentious restaurant specialises in blue cod, a thicker and more succulent variety of our own favourite fish. Order the medley and you can sample it plainly grilled and smoked over manuka wood, with some of the South Island's famous green-lipped mussels and Stewart Island's smoked salmon on the side. Even better, chat to the chef who cooked for Bill Clinton on his visit to NZ and has some revealing anecdotes, such as how the waitresses were given time off to avoid embarrassing photo ops of The Prez with pretty young ladies. beachhouse@xtra.co.nz

Miles of style It's smart, chic - and home to Neighbours. Mike Bradley guides you around elegant Melbourne.

Sydney sensations Mike Bradley tastes five alternatives to city life.

Secrets of a sunshine city It's not just the breadth of a continent that separates Perth from the East coast. Mike Bradley tours the cosmopolitan capital of a state with blissful beaches, unique wildlife and Aboriginal culture.

It's like a fairground ride, only real, and takes a great deal of skill from the driver. Particularly exhilarating are the 180° turns where, trust me, you will get wet. Best hangover cure ever. £25 for 30 minutes. reservations@shotoverjet.co.nz. webTitle: The players are there - at last England have a coach who can use them properly.

fields.headline: The players are there - at last England have a coach who can organise them properly
fields.standfirst: The art of keeping it simple on the pitch
fields.trailText: Ian Ridley on the art of keeping it simple on the pitch
fields.body:
Watching England over the past couple of years has sometimes reminded you of that old Morecambe and Wise sketch where Ernie persuades a reluctant Andre Previn to conduct Eric essaying Grieg's piano concerto. 'You're playing the wrong notes,' says an exasperated Previn at one point. 'Listen, sunshine,' Eric replies. 'I'm playing the right notes. Just not necessarily in the right order.'

So it was with Kevin Keegan and, as major tournaments usually do, Euro 2000 graphically exposed all the flaws. There were all the right notes out on the field, they were just being played in the wrong order.'

Those of us who insisted that there remained a host of good players in the English game, that it simply needed a coach, a technician, of tactical acumen to organise and empower them, were frequently derided. 'You can't blame Keegan,' went some of the phone-in arguments. 'We haven't got the players.' '

So hurrah for Sven-Göran Eriksson. Yes, it was only a friendly, yes the majority of the Spanish players had last night's Real Madrid v Barcelona game on their minds, and yes most England managers have been gifted eminently winnable inaugural games. Here was a coach, though, who helped previously vilified players to perform well with a simple, sensible strategy - and that is what coaching is all about.'

Had Keegan picked the same side - all that Neville-gazing and 31-year-old left-backs making their debuts - he would probably have been ridiculed. After his false dawn at home to Poland, Kev played his own wacky Warsaw Concerto in the return when Steve McManaman ended up looking like a wally rather than the world-beater we had seen under Terry Venables. '

What spared Eriksson was his understated ability to make the most of the talent available, to make the whole add up to its parts. On a night when he made all the right noises, too, he first thanked his coaches, Peter Taylor and Steve McLaren, whose expertise on the training ground allowed him more profitably to observe.'

What had he learnt from the week and the game? 'It confirmed that there are many good football players in this country,' he replied. At last. It has taken an outside eye, as this commentator always believed it would, to stop lamenting the influx of foreign players and dearth of domestic talent and recognise what we still produce. It is a bit like the city of Bath; residents grumble about how much of its splendour has been eroded, visitors marvel at how much remains.'

Not that Eriksson would have been much encouraged by the previous night's under-21 shambles against an admittedly gifted Spanish side. Howard Wilkinson does seem to have an unfortunate knack of taking good players and making them look less, though even then Eriksson took modest blame. 'The fault is mine,' he said. 'I took too many under-21 players from Howard.''

Even the opening 20 minutes of the senior game must have given Eriksson misgivings. Paul Scholes gave Michael Owen a similar pass to the one he received from David Beckham before scoring that goal in St Etienne, but this time Owen laid the ball off to Andy Cole. Nicky Barmby had to cut back to cross with his right foot. Rio Ferdinand, the best ball-playing defender in the country, could not deliver a pass 10 yards to the feet of the admirable Chris Powell.'

But, gradually, belief, then confidence, through sense and simplicity kicked in. Whereas under Keegan, England were frequently stretched, the man in possession of the ball given few, if any options, and the team straggling with a them-and-us feel between defenders and attackers, now they moved as a unit, utilising the dastardly Manchester United ploy of supporting the player with the ball. In the second half, Frank Lampard looked particularly comfortable in protecting possession.'

When you have the ball, you should pass it quickly. To wait is too late,' said Eriksson, 90 minutes after the game. 'Keep the team short, very compact.' And therein was the crux of the difference between his and Keegan's offerings. Later in the game, we even saw Cole looking more like an international player, his touch more certain. Previous managers have doubted him, notably Venables and Glenn Hoddle, but Eriksson has not brought the baggage of domestic perception. 'If he is not a top-class international forward, where do you find them?' he mused.'

In that, he brought to mind all those quizmasters on television. Hoddle was the fearsome Anne Robinson (David Beckham, you are the weakest link - goodbye), Keegan more like Jim Bowen (super, smashing, great). Eriksson resembles Chris Tarrant; all supportive, non-judgmental and really wanting you to do well.'

Later in the game, too, we also saw Emile Heskey - a player also developing through Gérard Houllier's enlightened coaching at Liverpool - attempting his Zinedine Zidane impression. Let's hope it will be permitted to flourish, for one early concern is that Eriksson's sides develop into merely functional, organised units - though at this stage it is churlish, premature criticism. Last Wednesday was all about back to basics and glimpses of optimism. We were offered shafts. Once the system settles down, then we hope to see the players who can make England more than run-of-the-mill competitive again. Soon the time must be right for Joe Cole to bring his quick eye and feet to bear and add some subtlety and flexibility.'

First things first, though. In building for more significant games against Finland and Albania, Eriksson has swiftly restored a belief that enough talent is available to survive injuries and prosper, as long as the thinking is clear and the execution enabled. England coaches are usually appointed because they are the antidote to what has preceded them. Graham Taylor was upright but muddled, Venables sharp but elusive, Hoddle decent but dour, Keegan fun but naive (Eric Morecambe when it came to playing the piano). Eriksson - his shortcomings not yet evident - is clearly shrewd and knowing. Chopsticks came easy. Now for Chopin.

webTitle: Sven passes where others have failed - Paul Wilson on a winning start

fields.headline: Sven passes where others have failed
fields.standfirst: Less than 10 minutes into their first game under new coach Sven-Göran Eriksson, England strung together an 18-pass move. Could this be the start of something special?
fields.trailText: Less than 10 minutes into their first game under new coach Sven-Göran Eriksson, England strung together an 18-pass move. Could this be the start of something special? Paul Wilson on subtle changes that made a difference as England beat Spain 3-0
fields.body:
Amid all the breast-beating and xenophobic ranting that greeted the appointment of Sven-Göran Eriksson as England coach, one comment from an exceptionally shrewd and well-qualified observer cut through the nonsense to the heart of the matter. 'At last,' said Brian Clough. 'England have a manager who speaks better English than the players.'
There is a growing realisation within the media that he is not going to speak much of it - Italian journalists dubbed him 'the rubber wall' because every teasing question came bouncing back - but even at this early stage it is evident the new man communicates effectively with his players.
'They are a very educated group,' Eriksson said, selecting a compliment unlikely to have been volunteered by any of his English predecessors. 'I found their attitude very professional.'
The players will not worry that Eriksson does not talk the hind leg off a donkey like Graham Taylor, chew the fat like Terry Venables, or talk himself into trouble like Glenn Hoddle and Kevin Keegan. To a greater or lesser degree, all those managers were pursued and eventually pilloried by the media, a fate from which Eriksson may not be immune if England drop vital points in the next two World Cup qualifiers. Everything is sweetness and light after the impressive 3-0 victory over Spain, though one only has to think back to the rapture that greeted Keegan's opening 3-1 win against Poland to appreciate how quickly the picture can change.
Eriksson understands that, of course, but he also understands that the language of international management is not always transferable to newsprint. The papers may find his quotes anodyne, but the mark of a clever manager is not necessarily what he says. It is also what he does not say.
Erikkson is certainly the cleverest England manager since Venables, whose celebrated cuteness was based on a solid grasp of technicalities and an easy familiarity with players and media alike. Yet even Venables, who presided over a series of yawnful friendlies before Euro 96, might have struggled to dispel the gloom surrounding English football as quickly and deliberately.
Maybe this is to claim too much for Eriksson. February friendlies against teams from warm countries are never reliable guides, and it is possible it is merely the uniqueness of Eriksson's situation that has enabled him to make a fresh start. There cannot be an English manager anywhere in the league, for instance, who could have predicted two weeks ago that Eriksson would start his first game with Phil Neville and Chris Powell at full back. Similarly, there were times against Spain, notably when England had four strikers on the field in Nick Barmby, Andy Cole, Emile Heskey and Michael Owen, when the thought occurred that Keegan would never have dared risk such an attacking line-up. Mainly because he would have had to have Alan Shearer out there as well.
Significantly, Eriksson apologised afterwards for using Heskey slightly out of position, wide on the right. Keegan was undone by playing people out of position. He tried a variety of square pegs in the gaping round hole of left wing, and famously could not think of an alternative left-back to the right-footed Phil Neville. Wild horses could not drag an iota of criticism of previous regimes from the scrupulous Eriksson, but he was surely making a statement by starting with the younger Neville in his true position on the right while simultaneously including a plethora of left-backs. Both Powell and Michael Ball played extremely well, and there would appear no need to look beyond that duo and Jamie Carragher for the foreseeable future. Problem position? Problem solved.
The selection of Powell was such a masterstroke one might have suspected it to be a crowd-pleasing stunt had not the Charlton player performed so ably. The general perception beforehand was that even if Powell played he would turn out to be a one-cap wonder, but obscurity might have to wait a while for a player who briefly managed to make Gaizka Mendieta look foolish.
Eriksson can take quiet satisfaction at turning a negative into a positive, and though Alan Curbishley pointed out last week that Charlton were having a good enough season to warrant international inspection, the same can hardly be said of Everton (who supplied Ball) or Middlesbrough (Ugo Ehiogu). The lack of prejudice in Eriksson's selections is all the more welcome because as, an outsider new to the scene, he could easily have gone the other way and played safe by sticking to big clubs and players he had heard of. Eriksson deserves credit for watching every Premiership club and a few Nationwide ones. He will be watching Ipswich v Bradford this afternoon.
It was the same story of more options than previously imagined right through the team. Andy Cole grew in confidence, Barmby played one of his best games for England, Gavin McCann's first touch was excellent and Nicky Butt and Frank Lampard looked the part. This was all in addition to solid performances from regulars like Sol Campbell, Paul Scholes and Michael Owen, and England still had Wes Brown, Robbie Fowler and Joe Cole on the bench.
Perhaps most pleasing was that this was achieved without any moaning from the manager about a shortage of left-sided players, an absence of creative midfielders or too few English players to choose from. By not complaining about anything, by simply picking 31 players and trusting 18 of them to startling effect, Eriksson eloquently chided his immediate predecessors without opening his mouth. An ordinary manager might have felt relieved or elated enough to give the press pack what they wanted by striking a triumphalist note. But the whole point of Eriksson is that he is not an ordinary manager.
Are England any more than an ordinary side? Only time will tell, though if they play as neatly and intelligently in their next two fixtures they should pick up the points necessary to put World Cup qualification back on course. Spain's Jose Camacho complained his side had been beaten by three ordinary goals (a goalkeeping error and two from corners), which was a trifle harsh considering England's passing and movement had looked good for most of the night, and especially for the opening goal. 'Both teams passed well, but while we only passed the ball around, England played effective football,' Camacho eventually conceded. 'They played as a unit.'
That is praise indeed, considering where England had just come from. When Adam Crozier and his FA colleagues took soundings from Premiership managers before appointing Keegan's successor, the near-unanimous verdict was that at no time during Euro 2000 had England resembled a team. And Eriksson, clever fellow that he is, has achieved this new cohesion by doing nothing. 'I tried not to change very much, because you can't change players in three days,' he said. 'All we had before this game were two and a half practices, and that barely gives you time to get to know players, let alone change the way they play.'
That might be true on a personal level, though Eriksson certainly tweaked the way England play. It is unwise to make judgments on the strength of one match, but it must say something that within the first 10 minutes at Villa Park the players Keegan claimed were incapable of passing the ball had strung together 18 consecutive passes without losing possession. Eriksson has made a promising start and is already looking forward to the World Cup games. As can we all. 'There is never quite enough time,' he explained. 'But we get five practices before Finland.'

fields.standfirst: The risk of catching dengue fever on the Thai island of Phuket is higher than usual this year, health officials have warned
fields.trailText: The risk of catching dengue fever on the Thai island of Phuket is higher than usual this year, health officials have warned
fields.body:
The risk of catching dengue fever on the Thai island of Phuket is higher than usual this year, health officials have warned. This viral infection is transmitted in daytime mosquito bites. It causes a fever for up to five days, intense headache, muscle and joint pain, gastro-intenstinal disturbances and a rash. Recovery can leave prolonged fatigue and depression.

Cases have been found earlier than usual in the Muang and Thalang districts. There are mroe of them in Seremban, south of Kuala Lumpur, in Malaysia, and in the Jakarta, Padang and Surabaya areas of Indonesia. Travellers should use a repellant on exposed skin.

fields.headline: Backpack manager reveals all
fields.standfirst: Rodney McDonald, owner and manager of Hilltop Backpackers, Papatowai, New Zealand
fields.trailText: Rodney McDonald, owner and manager of Hilltop Backpackers, Papatowai, New Zealand.
fields.body:
How did Hilltop start?

I started the business seven years ago. I had purchased the land some time before with the intention of opening some sort of accommodation, and then I relocated an old villa from TeAnau 200 kilometres to the West. Once the renovation was complete, Hilltop's doors opened.

What sort of people stay at Hilltop?

We get people from all corners of the world coming to Hilltop. It is a unique place, and there is a real feeling of staying in a friend's home. There are a few luxuries not normally associated with backpackers' accommodation, as well as a fantastic view. A couple of trends that I have noticed are that the numbers are increasing, people are travelling for longer and there is a more mature age group of backpackers.

What is the area like?

We are situated on a hillside overlooking the beautiful Tahakopa Bay, on the Catlins coast, in one direction and native forest and farmland in the other. New Zealand's South Island has an incredibly diverse landscape. There are fjords, mountains, glaciers, lakes and river, magnificent forest, crystal clear ocean and great people.

What do you suggest for a day out?

There are lots of activities they can do, such as boogie-boarding, sea kayaking, canoeing, hiking, mountain biking or even feeding the sheep. In terms of local highlights there are three fantastic waterfalls nearby: Purakaunui, Matai and McLean. The Cathedral Caves are in the cliffs near the ocean and Nugget Point is a wild and windswept peninsula from which you can spot dolphins, penguins and sea lions. Also, don't miss the fossilised forest, which was formed millions of years ago.

What do people do in the evenings?

Most just sit on the deck with a nice glass of New Zealand wine and chill out. It's very enjoyable. Probably the best part of my job is meeting people from all over the world: I have been lucky enough to make some great friends.

What is the most important thing backpackers should pack?

The good old Swiss army knife.

Ever tempted to start a luxury hotel?

Yes, I've been thinking about building my own!

 Hilltop Backpackers reservations: 00 64 3415 8028 or email hilltop@ihug.co.nz. Dormitory beds are $20 (£5.80) and double rooms are $45 (£13), including linen and a sea view.

webTitle: Comment: Foot and mouth; not many voters lost

fields.headline: Foot and mouth; not many voters lost
fields.standfirst: We'll know that politicians are serious about reforming the way we eat if their interest in farming is still alive when the pyres go out
fields.trailText: We'll know that politicians are serious about reforming the way we eat if their interest in farming is still alive when the pyres go out.
fields.byline: Andrew Rawnsley, columnist of the year
fields.body:
I very much doubt that Tony Blair is capable of sexing a chicken. And I'm equally sceptical that William Hague can diagnose the difference between swine fever and foot and mouth. The current emergency demands that they pretend to possess a longstanding and developed comprehension of animal husbandry, but food is usually of interest to most politicians only when it is presented on a menu. As an issue, it rarely tingles the taste buds of the governing class.

People of ambition and talent do not enter the House of Commons plotting to bring their career to a pinnacle with a spell wading around in manure, being shouted at by angry farmers. So puny is the standing of the Minister of Agriculture in the Westminster animal kingdom that the holder of the post does not even enjoy the dignity of being called Secretary of State. Successive Prime Ministers, reflecting the indifference of the electorate to how their daily grub is produced and delivered, have treated the position as the nether end of the Cabinet's biological chain. The department is traditionally regarded as a holding pen in which to park older and declining colleagues before they are finally carted off to the knacker's yard.

I have spent some years listening to the private lusts and fears of Members of Parliament, conversations which often occur over lunch or dinner. Not once has a politician stopped munching to declare a burning desire to take control of the commanding heights of Maff. You might expect the muddier tracts of Britain not to greatly interest urban New Labour, but it is also broadly true of the farmers' supposed party, the Conservatives. Only last week, I was discussing his prospects with one of the brighter lights of the Tory front bench. He candidly acknowledged the vast odds against his party returning to power in the foreseeable future, but he still saw satisfaction from being in Opposition. There was only this qualification: 'If William asked me to do Agriculture, I'd tell him I had other plans for the rest of my life.'

The present incumbent, Nick Brown, has had to live with colleagues branding his rump for speedy dispatch to the Westminster slaughterhouse. He was the most important victim of Tony Blair's first reshuffle, mainly on account of his tightness with his ally and namesake, Gordon Brown. The Prime Minister exiled Nick Brown from the role he loved, that of Chief Whip, to the Siberian tundra of Agriculture. According to some believable accounts, this was punishment so cruel that it reduced Mr Brown to tears. It was widely assumed that, in the cull of the Cabinet that will follow the election, he was tagged for the Downing Street equivalent of the one-shot bolt to the head.

That view is now being revised. The Agriculture Minister's handling of the foot-and-mouth emergency has drawn praise even from his opponents. Apart from one lapse, when he suggested that he had better things to do than answer to Parliament, he has impressed. That stolidly bovine face, his patient and technical explanations of what has to be done to control and eradicate the disease, along with his evident dedication to the task, have made Mr Brown a more reassuring character to have in charge of this episode than some of the Cabinet's flashier figures.

Overall, the Government has had a reasonably good crisis so far. The brutal truth, pitiless though this must seem to the farmers who are heaping their livestock on to the funeral pyres, is that the only aspect of this emergency for the countryside that truly terrifies Ministers is the threat of shops in the towns running out of food. The urgency with which they have implored urban shoppers not to panic-buy indicates their own panic about the shelves being empty of meat. So long as the crisis is confined to rural areas, where it has deep effects but only on a tiny proportion of the population, it will swing few, if any, votes among the vast majority who dwell in suburb and city. The prospect of food shortages has already receded with Friday's announcement that livestock licensed as disease-free can be moved about.

I think it highly unlikely that the cordons sanitaires thrown around some farmland will influence either the timing or the outcome of the election. It will take an outbreak of bubonic plague to budge New Labour off the 3 May battle grid. Nor is there any indication that the glowing night skies in the countryside will have any impact on the result. The Conservatives have searched, and thus far failed, to find ways of making political capital. At Question Time, William Hague was reduced to interrogating the Prime Minister about the adequacy of the stocks of disinfectant. I half-wondered whether, in his desperation to sound statesmanly and responsible, the Tory leader was going to move on to inquire about supplies of green wellies.

In medieval warfare, it was common practice to lob the carcasses of diseased animals into an enemy fortress. Much as they itch to deploy the same tactic against the Government, the Tories have not dared to load their catapults with blistered pig and cow for fear that the diseased animals will boomerang back on to their own lines. Before foot and mouth, Britain has already had an expensive education in the consequences of intensive, industrial agriculture. It was mad cow disease which forever destroyed the reputation of benignly bucolic Old MacDonald and replaced him in the public mind with the disease-spreading agro-businessman. And it happened under the Tories' supervision of the farm gate.

The leader of the opposition likes to strike a pose as the son of the Rother Valley, the farmers' friend. At his party's spring conference in Harrogate today, Mr Hague may be tempted to suggest a contrast between his empathy for rural folk and those metropolitan New Labourites. In a recent documentary, we saw him and Ffion rambling the Yorkshire Moors and sinking pints in country pubs. I am sure the Leader of the Opposition enjoys the fresh air. I am almost as certain that, before he became MP for a large chunk of countryside in God's own county, Mr Hague did not know one end of a pig from the other. He is the scion of a fizzy drinks manufacturer who graduated into management consultancy. Mr Hague spent his youth not coddling cows, but swotting Hansard.

I don't hold that against him. It simply means that Mr Hague is much the same as Mr Blair and the vast majority of MPs. They are urban and suburban, just like the great bulk of people in Britain. Rural folk are quite correct to say that townies are pretty clueless about what really goes on in the countryside. But I am not certain they will enjoy the consequences if the urban population becomes seriously inquiring about what happens to their food between leaving the farm and entering their mouths.

The one sliver of silver in the acrid clouds of burning carcasses is that we may finally have a searching national conversation about the high price we are paying for cheap, over-processed, chemically-manipulated, flavourless, disease-prone food. As tends to be the case with Tony Blair - and, to be fair, with most Prime Ministers - it has taken a crisis to grab his attention. He has taken a populist swipe at the rapacity of the supermarkets. The Government is suddenly buzzing with conversation that food production and distribution must be radically changed. Mr Blair declares he wants a great national debate. We will see if this commitment and interest lasts or whether it will be forgotten once the bonfires have gone out.

I will know when the political class is really interested in grappling with all the dilemmas and choices thrown up by this latest farming crisis. It will be when a thrusting politician puts down his fork, leans over the lunch table, drops his voice to a confidential whisper and declares that his consuming ambition is to reform the way we eat.

webTitle: Vote 4US 2MORO will be Labour's election message

fields.headline: Vote 4US 2MORO will be Labour's election message
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Throw away your pagers, New Labour disciples, they're OvR8d now. And if you understood that, you are a prime target for the party's newest election weapon.
fields.body:
Throw away your pagers, New Labour disciples, they're OvR8d now. And if you understood that, you are a prime target for the party's newest election weapon.

Labour is to harness the teenage craze for mobile phone text-messaging to get its election slogans, campaign instructions and encouragements to vote flashed to thousands of supporters.

It will launch its new campaign within the next few weeks. The age of X LBR IF UR UP 4 IT ('Vote Labour if you're up for it', to the uninitiated) has arrived.

'Texting' has already spawned a sub-culture - and a short-hand language - all of its own: Muslim leaders have called their congregations to prayer using it, one internet fertility service uses it to alert female subscribers to the optimum time for them to have sex, and last month a British woman was rescued from disaster at sea after texting an SOS to her boyfriend thousands of miles away.

The need to keep messages under 160 characters - the ultimate soundbite - has seen shortened phrases develop such as OvR8d for 'overrated', BCNU for 'be seeing you', or GAL for 'get a life'. Texting has even been accused of threatening children's ability to spell normally.

Now Labour has realised that it is a faster and more fashionable way of reaching thousands more young voters than traditional methods such as party political broadcasts or billboards. This election will be the first time text messaging has been used by a political party.

Messages could be flashed by a computer system to thousands of mobile users within minutes.

'You only have to look at examples of the way the big players have used it - for instance, lots of people have signed up for Manchester United text messages on their phones,' said one Labour Party source. 'We want slogans that could be used to interest young voters in the election, who may otherwise be less likely to vote.'

So will Big Brother be 'texting' you? The party is already collecting mobile numbers from supporters but insists its message system will only use numbers volunteered by people who know what they will be getting, rather than bombarding the unsuspecting public with propaganda.

Labour plans include allowing people to download trendy graphics onto their mobile screens. It has also launched a competition for young members to design slogans suitable for texting.

Networks say texting is most popular among the under-30s - and is overwhelmingly used by teenagers flirting with each other. But advertisers have also started to use it to send electronic 'junk mail'.

A million text messages are now sent every hour, and there have even been cases of 'textual harassment' involving stalkers who leave endless messages.

Text messaging was introduced in January 1999, but was never expected to take off: the mobile companies assumed typing letters into the keypad was so laborious nobody would bother.

webTitle: Mr Brown, Mr Balls and the elusive Mrs Mortgage

fields.headline: Mr Brown, Mr Balls and the elusive Mrs Mortgage
fields.standfirst: Women will be the Treasury team's prime target on Wednesday, report  Kamal Ahmed  and Gaby Hinsliff: Iron Chancellor or social democrat?
fields.trailText: Women will be the Treasury team's prime target on Wednesday, report  Kamal Ahmed  and Gaby Hinsliff: Iron Chancellor or social democrat?
fields.body:
To the mandarins of the Treasury it seemed a bizarre request. Could all notes to the Chancellor of the Exchequer please include home telephone numbers. The Chancellor likes to read papers between 6am and 7.30am, his office explained, before coming into the department. He needs to be able to get to any official while they're digesting their morning toast.

Over the past two weeks, Brown and his tight entourage of staff have been in what officials describe as 'Budget blitz' mode. From 6am Brown is on the telephone. With his two special advisers, Ed Balls and Ed Miliband, he has been worrying away, grinding the figures, totting up the advantages and disadvantages of a tweak here, a tweak there.

How will the latest details on increasing maternity pay work? How will widening the 10p tax band be made to look like a tax cut for everybody? How much will a family on average earnings of £25,000 be better off if all the tax and benefit changes kick in on 5 April? About £370, Gordon, came the reply.

It is a punishing schedule. At 7.30am his car arrives for the short journey from the Westminster home he shares with wife Sarah Macaulay to the Treasury. There he continues his machinations, banging out his thoughts on a laptop in large block capitals, all the more easy to read for a man with poor eyesight.

Sometimes his secretary brings in a projector. Brown's laptop thoughts are beamed onto a screen so that Balls and Miliband can see what he is writing, his Budget speech the centre of attention. No one else is in the room, a smaller, more private study off the original cavernous office Brown first occupied.

They bash phrases backwards and forwards - what will tickle the party, what will tickle the nation? - the loyalty of his two trusted lieutenants unquestioned. Not for Brown the process established by his predecessors. It is not officials who draft the Budget speech but the Chancellor himself.

Balls is the chief economic adviser to the Treasury. He is the channel through which every minute passes, and he has succeeded in outmanoeuvring the civil servants to ensure that his master's will is done. Brown and Balls hate endless memos. They keep their thoughts in their heads and in Brown's computer. It's safer that way. Not for nothing is Balls nicknamed the deputy chancellor.

The other Ed is the brother of David Miliband, head of the Downing Street policy unit. But even the family link is not enough to allow No 10 a peek at Brown's detailed thinking. The Chancellor ensures that the Prime Minister is kept up with the broad themes, but the details are under wraps until the last minute. Other members of the Cabinet are not told about their specific areas of spending until a few days before the big day.

The Cabinet as a whole will have to wait until Wednesday morning to hear about the Budget speech. They received a note last month from Downing Street saying Blair had moved the weekly Cabinet meeting forward to next Wednesday morning so that Brown could tell them what was going on. Five hours later Brown will get up in the House of Commons, pile up a set of books so that he can rest his speech high enough for him to see it and tell the nation what he is up to.

The Chancellor is not a man for formal meetings. Recent relations between the Chancellor's and Prime Minister's teams have improved, but the tension remains. Brown sees the Treasury as the natural headquarters of economic and social policy. Blair wants to concentrate power in No 10, the Policy Unit and the Cabinet Secretariat. The Treasury - tight-knit, secretive, ferociously intelligent - is winning the battle.

Thanks to a series of judiciously timed leaks, it is now becoming clear where Brown's priorities lie. Women, the voters Labour fears are most disillusioned with Tony Blair the politician and New Labour the Government, are to be wooed like never before.

Maternity pay will be boosted, rules on how many tax benefits new parents can claim will be relaxed, benefits for families with children will be increased. And the new Labour worry, Mrs Mortgage, will be told that interest rates and mortgage repayments are at their lowest for years. Everything, from a reduction in stamp duty for new homes in deprived areas to boosts for single parents, will be given a family-friendly edge.

It has all been planned with meticulous care. In 1998 Brown started plotting the route to the next election, fixed already in his mind as May 2001. Each year the Budget has had slightly more to give away, culminating in the Treasury's 'red-letter day', 5 April 2001.

On that day, in a month's time, a series of tax and benefit changes will kick in. Pensions will increase, rules on how much money the elderly can save before they have to pay for their own care will be relaxed, child benefit will increase, road tax will be cut for millions of cars, tax credits aimed at those earning under £40,000 will be launched.

Poorer families will be up to £2,600 a year better off. Tax cuts through the increase in the 10p income tax band will mean everyone has a little more in their pocket. An election will be called. Blair will win. Brown will be the man behind it. Perfect.

The procession of high-heels clicking across the varnished floorboards upstairs at No 11 Downing Street shortly after the last two Budgets were the first sign. Over the white wine and canapés, Brown struggled manfully to make small talk with magazine editors anxious to know where he bought his suits.

Sarah Macaulay circled among guests ranging from female MPs and journalists to prominent women such as Germaine Greer and even Cherie Booth.

But as with everything Brown does, there was a carefully calculated point to it all - to show that the Chancellor sympathised with women.

It underlined a message the Budgets had already made clear with promises of massive increases in childcare places, tax breaks for working women to pay for those childcare places, even the scrapping of VAT on sanitary products last year, a matter so embarrassing to the Chancellor that he failed to mention it in his speech and left it to a junior Minister to brief journalists afterwards.

Labour campaign strategists have identified Mrs Mortgage as the woman they have to woo. Middle England, middle income, hard-working, she will be the target of the election campaign. She was picked after research revealed that it was women who were least impressed with the Government's multi-billion pound economic arguments and felt that Labour had failed to be as modernising at it had claimed it would be.

The Chancellor has taken this on board, despite his predominantly male core of advisers. Helping him to win Mrs Mortgage's trust are Harriet Harman, an old Brown ally and former Minister, Maeve Sherlock, the former head of the National Council of One Parent Families, and Treasury ministers Dawn Primarolo and Melanie Johnson.

Primarolo and Johnson have linked up with the two Women's Ministers, Tessa Jowell and Margaret Jay. It was Primarolo, once a struggling single mother herself, who fought for the children's tax credit to be drawn by mothers as well as fathers, following fears that in some households it would never be spent on the children.

But there have been some hiccups for Brown. This week's announcement on maternity pay follows intense haggling between his officials and the women's lobby: the Chancellor favoured targeting help on poor new mothers, arguing that wealthy women earning large salaries did not need the state to top up their bank balances when they gave birth. But he has relented and will announce on Wednesday that the state will provide maternity pay for all, with a likely top-up for those most in need through extra tax credits.

Brown is acutely aware that Labour's election hopes will be heavily dependent on his performance in the House of Commons on Wednesday. Party officials know that if the public are not convinced, then the chances of another huge majority could suffer, even though some opinion polls are already predicting such an outcome on 3 May, which is still the favoured date for a poll.

He needs to be able to get to any official while they're digesting their morning toast. Over the past two weeks, Brown and his tight entourage of staff have been in what officials describe as 'Budget blitz' mode. From 6am Brown is on the telephone. fields.headline: Despairing Tories want Hague out
fields.standfirst: Poll shows party activists are convinced that the election is already lost, and a third want Michael Portillo to become leader, reports  Kamal Ahmed
fields.trailText: The Conservatives' most ardent supporters have given up on the general election and believe William Hague should resign if the party is ever going to beat Labour.
fields.body:
The Conservatives' most ardent supporters have given up on the general election and believe William Hague should resign if the party is ever going to beat Labour.

An Observer poll of hundreds of Tory activists and firm party supporters - one of the most comprehensive undertaken by a newspaper - reveals the depth of the malaise afflicting Hague's party despite public claims he is preparing for government.

The findings come at a particularly embarrassing time for the Tories. This weekend the party leadership was trying to drum up enthusiasm among its rank and file at the Conservative annual spring conference in Harrogate.

The poll reveals that even among the Tories' strongest backers, the party activists, more than three-quarters think that the party will lose the next election with over a third believing that Hague should resign immediately or 'early in the next Parliament'. Among more general supporters, the figure believing the party will lose rises to a remarkable 86 per cent and nearly half think Hague should step down now or after the election.

With the election thought to be only a matter of weeks away, that means that many party members think Hague should quit as leader before the summer. More than a third of Tory supporters think Michael Portillo should lead the party, with 18 per cent backing Ann Widdecombe.

Most worrying for the Conservative high command is the obvious disillusionment among its frontline workers, the people who have to persuade voters on the doorstep during the campaign, organise rallies and ensure that turnout is as high as possible. The results will delight Labour strategists, who for the first time have hard evidence the Tories have given up the battle.

One senior Conservative backbencher admitted that the party was in disarray and that Hague would be approached by the 1922 Committee, the powerful group of Tory backbenchers known as 'the men in suits', and asked to step down within a year of the election defeat.

He said that at a recent meeting of the forward planning committee of the party, which includes all the main leadership players, only two members of Hague's front-bench team insisted that they could still win.

'It is a very bleak time,' the backbencher and former Minister said. 'The major problem is that we don't have a Plan B. When William loses, as he will, there is not an obvious candidate to succeed him. Portillo will split the party, Widdecombe will not go down well with the country. We don't have a talented figure coming up on the rails. We're in a real stick.'

The Observer commissioned YouGov Opinion Research, the political research and information company, to compile the survey details from its extensive database of party activists and supporters. It asked more than 700 people, two-thirds describing themselves as 'party activists', a set of questions to test the party's mood.

The answers provide clear evidence on why Hague abandoned talk of 'compassionate Conservatism'. The Observer revealed last week that the Tory leader considered resigning in December 1999 after a glut of negative headlines and bad poll results. He admitted that attempts to reposition the party towards the centre had failed and told friends that he was in danger of losing his core vote.

Asked whether the party should shift to the left - the centre ground where most political experts believe elections are won and lost - only 8 per cent of Tory activists surveyed agreed. More than a third thought the party should shift more to the right with over half saying that Hague's present tone should be maintained.

The vast majority of Tory activists, 77 per cent, believe Tony Blair will win the general election, with many saying the Labour majority will be a comfortable one. A third said that the majority would be between 50 and 100 seats.

On Hague's performance, one in five Tory activists said they thought it was poor or very poor compared with just one in 20 Labour activists asked the same question about Blair.

Among Conservative supporters, rather than activists, 42 per cent rated Hague as poor or very poor. Surprisingly, 34 per cent of Tory supporters say that they think Blair is doing a good job, compared with just 12 per cent of Labour voters who thought Hague was doing a good job.

The results of the survey also reveal that Hague will have to look at the structure of the Conservatives if he is to keep party workers on side. Asked if they thought there needed to be a 'fundamental change' in the way the party operated, half of Conservative activists said that there was a need for radical reform.

YouGov Opinion Research interviewed nearly 2,000 party supporters from all the main political parties, including 734 Tory activists and supporters.

fields.headline: Is Labour aiming at you?
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Who are the voters the Labour must woo?
fields.body:
In the run-up to the general election, the Labour Party has sent all its candidates 'letter templates' which must be used when writing to target voters. Each is addressed to a different type of voter identified by the apparatchiks at Millbank as vital to winning the election. They are:

MRS MORTGAGE

A modified form of the famous Worcester woman, Mrs Mortgage has been identified by Labour as the Middle England voter they must woo. Married, with a three-bedroom house in the Midlands, she worries about interest rate rises and what they will do to her weekly household budget. She abandoned the Tories after interest rates hit 15 per cent, decided on Labour but is now not so sure.

Is impressed by: economic stability, tax cuts, low interest rates

Is unimpressed by: boom and bust, plans to ban hunting, Islington chattering classes

MR SQUEEZE

The voter who actually prefers the Liberal Democrats but will be willing to vote Labour to keep the Tories out. Could be the saviour in tens of marginal Labour-held seats where the Lib Dems are in third place. Needs to be told about the disaster that the Tories were and convinced that a vote for the Lib Dems is a wasted vote.

Is impressed by: public spending, radical constitutional change, positive announcements, Gordon Brown

Is unimpressed by: tax cuts, talk of bogus asylum seekers, negative attacks, Jack Straw

MRS WEAK

Labour's Holy Grail, the voter who switched to Labour at the last election but does not hold her convictions deeply. A close relative of Mrs Mortgage, she would like to vote Labour again but is worried that they have failed on crime and that public services aren't getting any better. Needs to be convinced that the statement 'all politicians are the same' is untrue.

Is impressed by: toughness, private enterprise, Jack Straw

Is unimpressed by: unions, any form of 'tax credit', helping single mothers

fields.headline: Blair stokes fear of eco-apocalypse
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is to paint an apocalyptic vision of a world being ravaged by global warming in a speech aimed at facing down critics who say that he does not take green issues seriously.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is to paint an apocalyptic vision of a world being ravaged by global warming in a speech aimed at facing down critics who say that he does not take green issues seriously.

In a move which will be seen as a sop to the green lobby, he will say that unless firm action is taken, the world can expect to face more natural disasters such as the flooding in Mozambique and the landslides in the Alps last autumn.

He will also say that diseases once confined to tropical countries could be on the way to Europe as the earth warms up. Michael Meacher, Blair's trusted environment minister, is so concerned that he has told Blair that he believes malaria could soon break out in Britain.

Blair agreed to speak at a conference organised by the World Wildlife Fund for Nature after the Government's green credentials were tarnished at last year's earth summit debacle at the Hague.

The meeting last November to set new green targets collapsed in chaos when John Prescott, the deputy prime minister with overall responsibility for the environment, stormed out saying that there could be no deal on reducing atmospheric pollution.

He then became embroiled in a diplomatic row with the French Green Party minister, Dominique Voynet, who accused Prescott of being too macho.

It will be the second time Blair has spoken on green issues in six months, in sharp contrast to the first three years of the Government when he turned down all requests to speak specifically on the issue.

Meacher, who has been shown the speech, will raise the problems of the environment in an interview today.

Speaking to BBC1's On the Record programme, he will cover much of the ground expected to be developed by Blair on Tuesday.

Meacher will make his bleakest assessment of the world situation, saying that malaria could come to major cities in Britain, just as it appeared in New York last summer.

'Rising water levels, the risks to our shore line, particularly in east England. These are the facts, that if the temperature does rise we could see many areas of the country, of the world, including this country, suffering an increase in malaria infestation. It is very, very serious.'

Meacher will say that the environment will be one of the 'landmark issues' for Labour's second term, a claim that will raise eyebrows among green lobbyists.

'Whether we like it or not we have fundamentally to change the way in which we run our economy, run our society.

'That's absolutely necessary otherwise we're going to suffer on an intensified scale, the kind of severe flooding which has actually been worse abroad and we may see worse in this country if we don't take note.'

webTitle: Comment: Don't make a mess of it, Mr Mayor

fields.headline: Don't make a mess of it, Mr Mayor
fields.standfirst:
Having bested the Chancellor, Ken Livingstone must now act positively to ensure the overhaul of London's Underground goes ahead

Transport in the UK
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Having bested the Chancellor, Ken Livingstone must now act positively to ensure the overhaul of London's Underground goes ahead.
fields.body:
Wow! Imagine the sensation if the Government took a special golden share in Railtrack, entitling it to direct its operations, ensured that a quarter of its board were non-executive directors with a statutory obligation to protect the public interest and offered to guarantee a high level of subsidy for at least seven-and-a-half years to ensure a freeze in rail fares, along with a mobilisation of new investment. It would be the U-turn of the decade and I, for one, would be delighted. It would represent the smartest way of reasserting the objectives of public ownership and cheap travel Britain has yet devised - and the left of centre would be purring with delight.

Well, it's happened or, at least, something very similar. Gordon Brown, criticised from all sides as the man obstinately blocking a sensible compromise on the London Underground, on Thursday offered Ken Livingstone the deal of his life. The scale of the concession is beyond anything mainstream opinion could have imagined when Livingstone was elected mayor nine months ago.

It is not just important for the proposed public-private partnership (PPP) for London's Tube - it sets a precedent for constructing public-private partnerships and the private finance initiative across the country, the importance of which is hard to overstate. If this redesigned PPP becomes the template for further partnerships, as it should, Britain would at last have devised a means of genuinely deploying private capital to deliver public objectives. Livingstone and his Transport Commissioner for London, Robert Kiley, have pulled off a coup.

That is not how they see it, though, and they are pressing for more. Transport for London does recognise that the Government's proposals are 'not purely cosmetic' and 'undoubtedly represent a real attempt on the Government side to find a compromise', an ungenerous way of describing the biggest climbdown the Government has made in four years of office. Ken Livingstone emphasises the safety dimension - 'Londoners will die if the PPP is forced through' - and Bob Kiley, a passionate believer in command and control management of Underground systems, stresses the need for an unified management structure.

The Government may have given him overriding votes, vetoes, assurances of money and de facto board control of the three private infrastructure companies (infracos) charged with modernising and maintaining the Tube for 30 years, but the basic fragmented structure of the PPP remains in place. Unless that is unwound, he cannot begin to negotiate a deal, he explained in a letter to the Government last Friday.

But Kiley's response already signals an important change of emphasis. His bottom line, rather than ownership and the right to issue bonds, is safety and unified management control; the Government's is that there is transfer of risk to private infrastructure companies which will undertake the modernisation of the Tube. Meanwhile, there is a threatened strike by the RMT. If a compromise deal is not done soon, London could dissolve into transport chaos.

So far, the Government has lost the PR battle hands down, but as the scale of what it has offered becomes more widely known, the line that it is intransigent and inflexible will not hold. The response of the infrastructure companies alone (see our report in today's Business section) will give the lie to that story, with one infraco chief executive fuming that when he saw the Government's proposals he thought they must be a spoof. This is no spoof. It is for real.

The first concession is that the Government is prepared to reconstitute the infracos as public-interest, stakeholder companies that must make their strategic and budgetary judgments within a framework set by Bob Kiley and London Underground Limited. Here I acknowledge my interest; this is one of the recommendations the Industrial Society and I made in our report to the mayor and London Assembly as a condition of the PPP going ahead. A quarter of the directors of each infraco board will be non-executive directors charged with protecting the public interest as defined by LUL.

Moreover, LUL will be able to sack the chief executive and veto the appointment of a replacement it does not like; it will veto budgets, acquisitions and business plans and its powers will be underwritten by a powerful 'golden' share with special voting rights. As anybody who knows how boards work, this confers real power on Bob Kiley, opening the way for him to appoint his own people, not just as key board members to the infracos but even as chief executive.

The second concession is to give LUL the power to direct the day-to-day management of the infracos. 'It would have explicit approval rights over maintenance plans and over the prioritisation and implementation of major programmes of work, power to direct the infracos in the execution of their work, power to approve and sack key managers and unrestricted "change order" rights,' says the Treasury. On top, every contract would be 'open book' to ensure there would be no sweetheart deals between the infracos and their shareholders. Small wonder the infracos think the proposal is a spoof. In effect, they would become subcontractors dancing to London Underground's tune.

And, lastly, there is money. Again my head spins. For the first time publicly, the Government agrees to provide 'a stable funding regime' that would provide 'explicit grant support' that would not be reviewed 'for each seven-and-half-year contract period'. This is a commitment that no public enterprise has ever won from the Treasury in modern times. Instead of the hand-to-mouth world of annual reviews and sometime cuts within an annual budget, the Treasury is promising to ring-fence what will have to be a substantial grant for each contract period. Gordon Brown's flexibility goes even further. The paper signals that the Government will relieve the infracos of having to pay for any future improvements in the safety regime, or, put another way, if the mayor wants more safety, the Treasury will pay for it.

It's been obvious for some time that the Government did not want a row with Livingstone over the Tube in the run-up to an election, and Livingstone's political judgment that he could pull off major concessions has been absolutely right. But apart from scrapping the PPP completely and starting again, a process that, to comply with EU rules on fair tendering, would take another two years, it's hard to see what more substantive the Government can offer. It's offered an open cheque book, de facto unified management control and effective strategic direction to London Underground while trying to transfer some genuine risk to the infracos. The open question is whether the infracos will accept the new deal. My guess is that if they are offered sufficient compensation they will.

Livingstone has the Government on the run. He has two options: do a deal around the new proposals or press on to try and crush the PPP. The latter means strikes, massive disruption and, after a general election, probable failure because a newly elected government will be in no mood to compromise.

Meanwhile, Prescott and Brown will claim they offered him what he wanted - effective control and cash - but he turned it down to grandstand. His best course would be to cut the deal that is now on offer, produced by his own rare political daring and skill . He has won. Now for magnanimity in victory.

webTitle: Comment: Scottish politics in a pickle

fields.headline: Politics in a pickle
fields.standfirst:
Despite the best laid plans of politicians, events can get in the way

Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: Despite the best laid plans of politicians, events can get in the way.
fields.body:
In Smollet's picaresque novel, The Adventures of Peregrine Pickle, the retired naval officer Hawser Trunnion, though living on dry land, insists on behaving as though he were still on the quarterdeck at sea.

He comes to mind this weekend after John Swinney's address to the SNP conference at Hampden Park. Swinney is no Trunnion: he is rational to a fault. Yet the good ship It's Scotland's Oil has had an extended outing since it was first launched way back in the Sixties.

But it is still afloat, if only just. Somewhat wearily Swinney sailed it once more round the bay. He also delivered his mantra, that Blair's Labour is the Conservative Party in new clothes. Otherwise he struggled to make waves in an unusually placid political ocean north of the border.

We are in that phoney period just before an election, foot-and-mouth permitting. But the preternatural calm may have a deeper cause. The voice of the spin doctor suddenly seems mute in the land. Team McLeish has decided to give the go-by to its false friends in the major Scottish newspapers, who like nothing better than to bite the hand that feeds them.

Many of the misfortunes that have beset the Scottish Executive have been of its own making, the result of spin gone awry. And so our First Minister seems determined to find another approach. The supply of titbits to the hacks has for the moment dried up.

Donald Dewar failed to appoint his full allocation of advisers but McLeish has now brought the department up to budget. The experienced political journalist Peter McMahon has replaced David Whitton as press secretary, and three advisers have been appointed to support him. Two come from journalism, one being my old friend Bill Heaney, the former editor of the Lennox Herald and winner of many Scottish press awards. The third is Andy Rowe, a migrant from Millbank who, the rumour mill disrespectfully says, has special responsibility for McLeish's haircut.

Bill Heaney has been given a specific task - to bypass the national papers and deliver the McLeish message that devolution is working for Scotland to local media. The first fruit of the new approach was an interview last month in the Aberdeen Evening Express in which the First Minister reassured its readers that the Executive was alert to regional issues, and explained how they could influence its decision-making process.

Regional newspapers can be less slanted than their metropolitan cousins. They must take care to satisfy a broad constituency. At its worst this produces bland journalism of the on-the-one-hand-and-on-the-other school; at its best it can encourage a vigorous pluralism.

But spin cannot be rusticated for long. It exercises a powerful grip on politicians. McLeish's men will soon enough be driven back to the major media, and to the tried, though not trusted, devices of the sound-bite and the leaked exclusive. Perversely, the Blair spin machine has tended to favour newspapers ideologically hostile to New Labour, presumably in the hope of disarming them. Thus, more sympathetic journalists who have had applications for interviews with senior Ministers pending for months are often mortified to find that right-wing rivals have been given first access.

Behind the dazzle of spin, of course, lies a less chimerical world. In many ways McLeish could hardly have taken office at a more favourable moment. Gordon Brown has opened the tap of public spending, and the Scottish Executive has at its disposal the biggest budget increase in 25 years, with annual increases in real terms of more than £1 billion in each of the next three years, with £1.4bn or 7 per cent in 2001 and £1.2bn or 5.5 per cent in 2002 and 2003.

David Bell, professor of economics at Stirling University, believes that harder times may lie ahead some time after the election. He says the Executive has been accumulating spending commitments at 'an alarming rate'. These include local government, teachers' pay, tuition fees, care of the elderly and NHS salaries.

He also argues that Scotland is receiving much smaller percentage increases than the major English departments. This, he says, is the result of the 'Barnett Squeeze', the formula designed to make per capita spending in England and the 'Celtic fringe' converge. When we spoke last week, he said he thought the Executive might find itself in a much tougher financial position in a few years' time, and would be forced to look for efficiency savings, for example by closing hospitals and schools.

But there is no unanimity on this issue. Indeed, Arthur Midwinter, professor of politics at Strathclyde University, goes so far as to say it is 'extremely silly'. The Barnett formula, he points out, applies to only 6 per cent of the grant and Scotland's historic advantage is being rolled forward. The Barnett Squeeze, he believes, is an invention of the SNP and convergence is simply not taking place. His analysis is that the new commitments undertaken by the Executive are perfectly sustainable.

As foot-and-mouth reminds us, events can overturn the best-laid plans. One of Denis Healey's favourite sayings, Midwinter recalled, was that economic forecasts were reliable in only one respect: they are always wrong.

webTitle: Winging it: Suddenly I'm James Bond joining the Lear jetset

fields.headline: Suddenly I'm James Bond joining the Lear jetset
fields.standfirst: Martin Buckley takes off into the social stratosphere to pick up a luxury plane and sample life in Hollywood
fields.trailText: Martin Buckley takes off into the social stratosphere to pick up a luxury plane and sample life in Hollywood
fields.body:
The world is getting disturbingly small. A fortnight ago, I was in Corsica. Next stop North Africa - then the call came from the charter company Gold Air International: 'We're buying a new Lear jet, and flying it from the factory to London. Would you like to come along?' I had to pinch myself: Lears are the personal transport of film stars and billionaires. I was being offered a chance to cross the Atlantic at close to the speed of sound in a privileged stratosphere, far above turbulence and tourist jumbos.

A few days later I arrived in Tucson, Arizona. While the Gold Air team stayed at the Sheraton, your correspondent found the cheaper Hotel Congress, an art nouveau pile which has sheltered the gangster John Dillinger and the cross-dressing FBI chief J. Edgar Hoover.

The next morning I was whisked, bleary-eyed, to the Lear factory by its director, Leon Rossow, the public face of a company providing transportation to the world's élites. The jets' Dorchester-like interiors bring out nouveau riche tendencies in some clients. 'We have millions of trim combinations,' Rossow told me, 'but some customers do like to provide their own fittings, which have included gold taps and zebra-skin upholstery. Some Brazilian clients have gone so far as to bring their own tree, from which the veneers are made.'

I track down Will Curtis, Gold Air's managing director, and find he's having problems collecting his plane: a Lear accountant somehow omitted to cash his $10,000,000 cheque, and it is a bank holiday. Curtis is stranded in Tucson, and furious. 'I may go to LA for a few days,' I say hesitantly, 'I have a sister and brother-in-law there.' 'Fine,' says Curtis. 'We'll pop over next week and pick you up.'

By nightfall I'm sitting in an LA mansion from Hollywood's pre-war heyday, all cool courtyards and exposed Hispanic beams - very Sunset Boulevard, very LA Confidential - with my relatives, Susan and Bill, and our hosts: the Czech film director Jiri Weiss and his wife, Katerina.

Weiss, now in his eighties, is a mittel-European intellectual as incongruous in Hollywood as Aldous Huxley must have been. A twinkle-eyed ex-communist, he spent the war in London, where he knew, among others, Bernard Shaw. 'I spent some time at Dartington,' Weiss told us, 'which was terribly progressive, and encouraged young people to swim in the nude. On one occasion, I was swimming with a girl. A man reading a newspaper kept edging his seat towards us until he was in danger of tumbling into the pool. "That horrible old fat man keeps leering at us," my companion told me. It was H.G. Wells.'

The aspiring film-maker lived in north London garrets and made a living as a waiter 'at the Savoy, 'which I hated. You British could be very racist. One day a repulsive female customer described a colleague of mine as a dago. He was enraged. In the kitchen he performed into her salad an act that delicacy forbids me from describing.'

I spent four days in LA before my brother-in-law Bill drove me to Santa Monica airport, where we watched the Lear land. Will Curtis gave me a thumbs-up from the captain's seat, as the Californian sun slid over the Union flag on the tail of the miniature, eight-seater airliner. 'This, said my brother-in-law, 'is like something out of a goddam James Bond movie!'

I would soon be crossing the US at 50,000 ft and nearly 600 mph. But even Lear jets need to refuel, and there were blizzards on the East Coast...

fields.headline: £5bn lifeline for Ken's Tube
fields.standfirst:
EU bank offers cash at private sector rate  Offer could break deadlock  New strikes loom

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The European Investment Bank is ready to lend up to £5 billion to help rescue a publicly controlled London Tube, it emerged this weekend.
fields.body:
The European Investment Bank is ready to lend up to £5 billion to help rescue a publicly controlled London Tube, it emerged this weekend.

The EIB money - to be repaid over 15 years - would go to an Underground network run by London Mayor Ken Livingstone and his transport supremo Bob Kiley at the same interest rate as offered to the private sector.

Such an intervention could help break the current deadlock between Livingstone and the Government, which is heading for the courts.

This weekend, Kiley formally rejected the Government's latest proposals for its controversial partial privatisation of the Tube. Livingstone said: 'Bob Kiley is talking to some of the best transport operators in the world. They won't come to London if they are unable to manage the system in a unified fashion.'

The Tube's biggest union, the RMT, is expected to vote for strike action on Friday. A senior RMT official said the union was ready to launch a one-day strike every week from 19 March until May 3, the expected election date.

Despite last week's major concessions from the Treasury guaranteeing the Underground long-term government funding and offering Kiley a veto over the management decisions and personnel of the private sector partners, the American transport expert insisted that the issues of safety, costs and a fragmented structure had not been resolved.

This paves the way for a court battle between Livingstone and the Government. Such action could drag on for three months, further delaying desperately needed modernisation.

But news that the EIB is equally ready to lend to either a private- or a public sector-run management could help drive the sides back to the negotiating table.

The bank, which is funded by the 15 member states of the European Union but has an independent management, is the world's leading financier of infrastructure projects. It supports road and rail projects to the tune of around £20 billion a year. It has already lent money to London Underground to buy rolling stock and power generators, and it funded the first phase of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link.

Susan Kramer, a board member of Livingstone's Transport for London authority, said: 'The (EIB) money is available and I see no reason why the funds are not on the table for Transport for London the same as they would be for the [private] bidders.'

While seething at the Government's concession on PPP, private bidders are unlikely to walk out of the process; they will prefer to wait and see whether the Government pulls the plug itself. This will gain them over £100m in compensation.


A deal gone down the Tube
Underground needs to mind the big gaps

webTitle: Lib Dems target UK's high earners

fields.headline: Lib Dems target UK's high earners
fields.standfirst: Neasa MacErlean  on proposals to increase our tax bill
fields.trailText: Neasa MacErlean on proposals to increase our tax bill.
fields.body:
People earning more than £22,000 a year would see their tax bills increase under proposals outlined last week by the Liberal Democrats. Although few people expect the Lib Dems to win the next general election, it is possible that their policies could have some practical impact if the Labour majority is reduced and the Lib Dems edge closer towards holding the balance of power.

Those who have most to gain from the plans are low earners, who would benefit from an increase in the threshold at which they pay tax. They would start paying tax on income above £5,905, rather than at the current level of £4,385. The Lib Dems would do this by replacing the current 10 per cent tax band with a zero-rate band on earnings between £4,385 and £5,905.

Those who have most to lose are people with incomes above £100,000 a year: they would pay tax at 50 per cent on income above that level. The Lib Dems have argued that taxpayers will not mind paying extra if they know that it will be well spent on improving health, education and other services. A key part of the Lib Dem pledges is a promise to increase the basic state pension by £5 a week for each pensioner under 75, £10 a week for 75- to 85-year olds and £15 a week for the over-85s.

The proposals are very similar to those the Lib Dems presented before the last election. But tax experts seem less than excited with these ideas.

'Ten out of 10 to the Lib Dems for transparency and honesty,' says Paul Falvey of accountant Grant Thornton. 'But I don't think the public have any appetite for tax increases.'

Although only 1 per cent of taxpayers have an income above £100,000, David Williams of accountant Smith & Williamson believes that the planned tax rises would put off far larger numbers of taxpayers. 'It's not what people have got that matters; it's what they aspire to,' he says. 'Someone earning under that level might think "I'm a prospective fat cat: this could affect me". So the plan could rebound.'

Another plank of the proposals is the Citizen's Tax Contract - 'a simple explanation of what people are paying in tax, any tax changes introduced, why, and what they are spent on'.

Maurice FitzPatrick of accountant Chantry Vellacott think such a move is 'long overdue' in a modern democracy: 'There is a feeling that people are getting increasingly remote from the whole tax process. So it could be very helpful if people could start connecting all the tax money they pay with things they might get back.'

But such a statement would need to be scrutinised by some independent body, Fitzpatrick suggests. Even the Inland Revenue is seen as having become increasingly politicised.

But civil servants may worry about the benefits of giving information on the way tax income is spent by the Exchequer, according to Williams.

'You could just imagine what might happen. People without children may ask why they should pay for education. People who call themselves pacifists may not want to pay for defence.'
