fields.headline: The great divider
fields.standfirst: Monty's first hedge helped him forget his troubles. Today, they sustain both him and his garden
fields.trailText: Monty's first hedge helped him forget his troubles. Today, they sustain both him and his garden.
fields.body:
I am always terribly aware of the date at the bottom of this page. Not least because it is not today. I try and throw myself forward the fortnight that divides the delivery and publication of these words, although at this time of year we oscillate wildly between winter and spring through a thousand shades of grey. Maybe I am not enough of a gardener to do 52 timeless horticultural essays, but it pleases me to try and be as pertinent as possible.

One of the ways I make sure I am tuning into the right kind of future is by checking back over my garden diaries. I have been keeping these for 13 years, always a desk diary, day to a page, and I try to write the weather, what looks at its best (or worst), what was sown or planted, what was eaten from the garden and what jobs were entrained. Lots of days run to no more than 'wet and grey: indoors all day'. But the picture does emerge over the weeks and months. The jobs you have done assume form and pattern when given a date. For instance, exactly a year ago I moved thalictrums, took melianthus and dahlias cuttings, thinned rocket and planted 150 'Turbo' onion sets. So much for the industry. But the important bit is: 'Primroses in great mounds in coppice and violets extraordinary - never seen anything like it. I hope they last as well over the next few years. Cowslips out - perhaps a dozen or more - weirdly early. Hyacinths in kitchen fabulous. Lonicera fragrantissima good. Lovely dawn - bright, clear, cold. Wonderful sunset.' You can tell that this was written that evening, still glowing from one of the first proper spring days in the garden.

The violets are not so good this year. Too much competition from grass, I think. Perhaps they will make a late burst for glory in the space between my fingers writing this and your eyes reading it. And so the same things happen year after year, but happen differently. Every violet or daffodil is the first one ever and every successive year enriches its freshness with experience.

These sparse diaries are slyly eloquent about one's life. So, 10 years ago there are just three notes, two seemingly unconnected to gardening but as clear a picture of my garden as a government enquiry. They are: 'Prepare statement of affairs for liquidation meeting'; 'Fax material to Rosie on trees' and 'Hedging pm'.

The liquidation meeting was that of our company and was part of the process of losing every material thing that we had. A fortnight earlier, we had sold our house and garden to put into the liquidator's pot and we had moved in, five of us plus two dogs, with my parents-in-law. I was gardenless, sort of. This qualification is because we had retained a field from the sale with the half-baked plan to build a house on it one day. In the event, the house never got past the dreaming stage, but I did dig a patch of it for an allotment that summer, driving the four miles to it after the children had gone to bed. It was lovely. The Rosie in question was Rosie Millard, now in front of camera and microphone as arts correspondent for the BBC, but then a fledgling director for Granada's This Morning . My only source of income at that stage was the sporadic appearance on that show, either filmed or live, and I was desperately trying to drum up enthusiasm for more work from me. In fact, this was to dry up altogether after a few more months and exactly a year later, on 3 March 1992, I have: 'Sign on at New St, Leominster'.

But the third entry for 3 March 1991, 'Hedging pm', is the good bit. To preserve my sanity - which is a glib phrase but in those circumstances, entirely accurate - I was laying a long hedge that bounded the field we had retained and the garden we had sold. With hindsight this was a kind of masochism, but it felt completely right and healing at the time. The hedge bounded a small wood and was completely invisible from anywhere other than our field. There was no one to observe me making a fool of myself. It was mainly hawthorn, with some field maple, elder and ash mixed in. I had never attempted to lay a hedge before and had had no instruction. I now know that it was extremely difficult, because it was very overgrown, more a line of small trees than a hedge, but with a chain saw, billhook and ropes, I slowly got it done. It was tricky and dangerous and enormous fun and because I had to concentrate completely in order to do it at all, it eased my mind. Across the field from this garden, a man has laid a similar hedge in half the time I took and with twice the degree of competence. It is a beautiful object.

I have not laid a hedge since but have earmarked one in this garden for my next foray into that field and hopefully it will be hedgecraft rather than hedging-as-therapy. The hedge in question is hawthorn and divides the coppice from the orchard. It was planted in the crudest possible manner, by lifting a line of turf and heeling the young plants in slits. The whole operation took two men about an hour. On one side it is 6ft tall and thriving, but on the other, where it skirts around some trees I planted eight years ago, it is stunted and thin. This is because the trees are taking all the moisture and goodness. The moral of the story is that if you want a hedge to grow away strongly, you must remove competition from all weeds. And here, two cherries, a field maple and an ash count as weeds. Anyway, I reckon that the hedge will be ready for laying in five years' time.

I have been preoccupied with hedges because we have been planting a whole load down the end of the garden. This area is very loosely orchard but except for a few months in summer, that looseness becomes a ragbag of compost heaps, orchard, chickens, tunnel, borders and play lawn. At best this bit of my garden has vitality, but on a grey, muddy afternoon it is plain ugly. The plan is to integrate them in such a way that the spaces flow together and work independently without losing any of their usefulness. So I have divided up the space, hedging off the lawn with hornbeam so it is still big enough to take a cricket net - without which no garden could possibly be complete - but is enclosed from all but the long central path. A hedge has do one of two things in a garden: either it acts as a frame, or it is a screen. In both cases, it defines space, and the space between plants is always the most important element in any garden.

We have also moved apple trees to clear space and concentrate the orchard in a smaller area. We have far too many apples for our needs, and the original planting was, I think, too grand for the space we have available. The upshot is that now we have a more intense space which will eventually need some pruning to contain it, but which still has 30-odd varieties of apple. More hawthorn hedges have been planted to screen off this redefined orchard and flank another path. I plan to extend the coppice where the orchard formally spilled over the main path and box it in with more hawthorn hedge. I particularly like this notion of boxing in areas so the contents spill out like a jack-in-the-box. The hedges need to be kept lower than the contents - not difficult in the case of a wooded area - but they act like a corset, accentuating the voluptuousness of the planting through restriction.

I think that most gardens underdo hedges. Even a very small garden can usually be improved by subdivision. Hedges do not have to be four-square. A cloud hedge looks great and hedges can just as easily snake and bend as march in a straight line. The important thing is to get the height right in relation to the space that the hedge bounds. As a rule, most hedges are too low. Just as a high ceiling tends to improve the proportions of a room, so high hedges make a garden seem bigger and more beautiful. And there is the added bonus that the higher and longer your hedges, the more bird life you will have in the garden.

Hedge your bets

 If you are planting a deciduous hedge, get on with it as soon as possible. An evergreen one is best planted in April.

 Do not cut corners in preparation. All time, effort or money put into preparing the ground will pay dividends in health and speed of growth.

 Mark out the location of the hedge with canes and string. Remember to allow 1m for its final width, if an enclosure hedge, and half of that if a containing one.

 If you are planting into grass, remove at least three spade-widths of turf along the line of the proposed hedge - 1m is ideal.

 Dig out the top soil one spit deep (a 'spit' is the depth of the spade). This will have to be broken up and used to put back around the roots.

 Fork or dig over the second spit so it is thoroughly loosened and add plenty of compost or manure.

 Buy bare-root plants from a specialist nursery if you can get them (they are much cheaper than plants in a container). Do not be tempted to buy large plants. This is a complete waste of money and only used by contractors to impress their clients. Small plants adapt and grow faster and will make a bigger hedge quicker. When planting, keep the roots covered and damp at all times. This is really important, because if the tiny feeding roots dry out, the plants will be much slower to get going. Before planting, give them a long soak in a bucket.

 Plant deep enough to cover the roots, but do not bury too much of the stem. Planting distances vary but in general a single row with adequate spacing will make a stronger hedge than one planted more thickly. A minimum of 18in is a good rule of thumb for beech, hornbeam and holly, and 12in for hawthorn and box. Yew should be at least 24in apart.

 I delay mulching for a week so the soil can settle a little and I give the hedge another big soak first, then mulch thickly. This is important, as it will stop weeds competing for moisture in the vital first years. Anything will do as long as it is water permeable and stops any light getting through, but obviously compost or manure will feed as well as smother.

 Staking each plant will stop wind rock and help the hedge to grow faster and straighter.

 There is some debate as to the merits and extent of cutting back a hedge after planting. Hawthorn definitely grows denser if cut back by 50 per cent immediately after planting. I have found hornbeam is best left to establish for a couple of years before cutting back by a third. Do not cut the leaders of evergreen hedges until they have reached their intended height but keep the sides cut well back.

 Keep an eye on the hedge for its first year and water if there is no rain for a week. As long as the drainage is good, drought is the biggest hindrance.

fields.headline: 'The last chance election for Britain'
fields.standfirst: Speech by the Rt Hon William Hague MP, leader of                                                   the Conservative party, to the spring forum in                                                   Harrogate, March 4 2001
fields.trailText: "As we gather here this weekend, we think of our fellow members and friends who had planned to be with us today in Harrogate, but who have had to remain at home or on their farms.
fields.body:
"As we gather here this weekend, we think of our fellow members and friends who had planned to be with us today in Harrogate, but who have had to remain at home or on their farms.

The thoughts and sympathy of the whole Conference are with all those whose livelihoods are at risk from the spread of the foot and mouth disease.

The pall of black smoke from the funeral pyres of slaughtered animals across our nation today tells the desperate story of a countryside in crisis.

I know from my own constituency that, for farmers already struggling in the depths of the worst agricultural depression for sixty years, this latest blow could not be more cruel or more bitter.

We support all the Government is doing to eradicate the disease and we welcome the financial support they have announced.

People have responded with calmness and restraint to this crisis. In postponing a protest in which they had invested months of preparation, the hundreds of thousands of people who were due to take part in the Countryside March for Liberty and Livelihood have shown great responsibility and courage.

I believe it would show the nation's solidarity with the countryside in this terrible hour if the Government were to suspend consideration of the Hunting Bill in Parliament at least until those who wish to protest against it are free to do so again. This morning we have also heard of a different kind of courage - the courage of one young man in a Burmese jail. James Mawdsley.

We heard about his unwavering belief in freedom. We heard of his passionate commitment to democracy and hatred of oppression. We heard of his defiance in the face of the extraordinary efforts made to silence him. And we heard of his pride that he is part of this Conservative family. By his actions James Mawdsley reminded us of all that is best about our Party.

We remember the enduring values that have run through two centuries of Tory history. The Tory values that stretch back to the days when Wilberforce freed the slaves, and Pitt led a war against tyranny, and Burke wrote his great tracts and Shaftsbury stood and watched the pauper's funeral and dedicated his life to the poor.

The values that animated the Conservative leaders of the Twentieth Century: the leadership of Winston Churchill, the resolve of Margaret Thatcher and the decency of John Major.

All of us are proud to be part of this Conservative family. And the values that have shaped our past must also guide our future. The determination to fight for freedom and democracy. The resolve to protect our national independence. The courage to speak the truth in an age of spin and political correctness. The self confidence to fight for our beliefs even when the odds are against us and to fight so hard against those odds that we win. The boldness to fight the next election on the most ambitious Conservative programme for a generation.

For we are going to go further than any government has ever gone before to hand back to individuals and families the ability to shape their own lives.

At his Party's Spring Conference, Tony Blair said that we were to blame for cynicism about politics. What a typically cynical attack from a man whose entire career has been built on one piece of cynicism after another.

When a Cabinet Minister who is sacked for telling lies is re-appointed, in the face of every constitutional convention, only for the same man to be sacked again from the same Cabinet for the same offence by the same Prime Minister - no wonder the public are cynical about politics.

When the Lord Chancellor violates the trust of his great office of state to solicit party donations from people whose careers he can control, and then says 'I'm not sorry, and I'd do it again' - no wonder the public think that power has gone to their heads.

When we have a Deputy Prime Minister who tells people not to drive cars but has two Jags himself, and where the Minister who tells people not to have two homes turns out to have nine himself - no wonder the public believe politicians are hypocrites.

And when the man who holds the highest office in politics will say anything and do anything to stay in power, when he thinks nothing of deceiving the public and Parliament, when he stuffs offices of the Crown with his cronies from Islington, breaking every promise on which he was elected, spinning yet another gimmick and yet another re-announcement in order to disguise his failure to deliver on anything at all - no wonder the public say they don't trust their Government.

This morning we read in the papers that, at the last election, the Labour Party hired American students to infiltrate our campaign.

Well, we have a confession to make. They weren't the only ones playing that game. We hired a bearded buffoon to infiltrate their campaign. But we never thought in our wildest dreams that he'd end up as Foreign Secretary.

None of the worthless promises and miserable failure of Labour's first term compares to what they have in store if we were to let them win again.

Just imagine four more years of Labour. Try to picture what our country would look like. Let me take you on a journey to a foreign land - to Britain after a second term of Tony Blair. The Royal Mint melting down pound coins as the euro notes start to circulate. Our currency gone forever.

The Chancellor returning from Brussels carrying instructions to raise taxes still further. Control over our own economy given away. The jail doors opening as thousands more serious criminals walk out early to offend again. Police morale at a new low. The price gauge on the petrol pump spinning ever faster as fuel taxes rise still further. Letters arriving on doorsteps cancelling yet another round of hospital operations under a Government that is all spin and no delivery.

That's Labour's Britain four years from now.

And if there are meant to be so many people enthusiastic for another four years of Labour, how come you never meet any of them?

Labour's Britain four years from now. Could anybody stomach it? The Dome still for sale. Peter Mandelson re-appointed to the Cabinet for a fourth time. The Liberals, on the edge of their seats, still convinced that a referendum on proportional representation is just around the corner.

We're not going to sit idly by and let this happen to our country.

That's why Michael Ancram has prepared us to fight the best organised, most vigorous, most spirited campaign we've ever fought in order to save Britain from this nightmare.

We are going to say to all the people who have been hit by Labour's stealth taxes: Can you afford another four years? To all the people who are still waiting for their operation: Can you really wait another four years? To all the people who are still waiting to see a policeman on their street: Can you really wait another four years? To all the parents who are waiting for better education: Can you really wait another four years?

So we're ready for the fight. We're ready because of the changes you have made to our Party. We're ready because of the victories that you have won in local and European elections.

But above all we're ready to speak for the people of Britain: for the mainstream majority who have no voice, for the hard-working people who feel they are ignored, for the men and women who despair that their country is being taken from them. We are not going to let them down.

We're ready and we can win.

As the next election draws near, people are beginning only now to focus on what the two parties stand for.

Well if there's one thing above all that sets me apart from Tony Blair, it's this: I'm not embarrassed to articulate the instincts of the British people.

The governing of this country has drifted far away from the decent, plain speaking common sense of its people. Its time to bring it back. It's time to bring Britain home.

We have a Government that has contempt for the views of the people it governs.

There is nothing that the British people can talk about, that this Labour Government doesn't deride.

Talk about Europe and they call you extreme. Talk about tax and they call you greedy. Talk about crime and they call you reactionary. Talk about asylum and they call you racist. Talk about your nation and they call you Little Englanders.

This Government thinks Britain would be alright if only we had a different people. I think Britain would be alright, if only we had a different Government. A Conservative Government that speaks with the voice of the British people. A Conservative Government never embarrassed or ashamed of the British people. A Conservative Government that trusts the people.

I trust the people. I trust the people on tax. People know that you can't spend more than you have. And they know that that holds true for governments as well for them. It seems like common sense to you and me. But not to Gordon Brown.

He's already running up huge bills on your behalf. He's promising to blow billions of pounds of your money. And what's spent today will have to be paid for tomorrow.

To the hard-working people who set a little bit aside each month, to provide for their children, or to fund their own retirement, I say: you should be rewarded not punished. You should be allowed to keep every penny of the interest on your savings. You've already paid tax on your money once; you shouldn't have to do it twice. We're going to make your savings tax free.

And to the pensioners who have paid their contributions throughout their lives, and who now want the dignity of independence, I say: you have already done your bit. You shouldn't have to go on paying. We're going to take a million pensioners out of the tax system altogether.

fields.standfirst: Anthea Turner has moved into the Big Brother house and comedians are queuing up to shout, 'Pants To Poverty'. But as Mariella Frostrup discovers, there's nothing funny about the work Comic Relief does in Britain
fields.trailText: Anthea Turner has moved into the Big Brother house and comedians are queuing up to shout, 'Pants To Poverty'. But as Mariella Frostrup discovers, there's nothing funny about the work Comic Relief does in Britain.
fields.body:
Red Nose Day is less than two weeks away and the country is gearing up for the eight-hour orgy of TV comedy and countrywide pranks that mark the return of one of the zanier dates in our biannual calendar. Racy Porsche drivers in the city are getting ready to 'Say Pants To Poverty' and Anthea Turner has briefly taken up residence in the Big Brother house.

We love a good charity. There's something about phoning in our credit-card donation or putting a pound in a collection box that makes us feel good about ourselves. Yet the appearance of increasing numbers of the recipients of the same generosity on British soil has ignited a blaze of indignation. No wonder Comic Relief tends to focus its appeals on heart-rending pictures from abroad. Yet since its inception in 1985, a third of all money raised has gone to charities in this country. These tend not to be as popular with givers. Battered wives, the homeless, children with Aids, drug addicts and that least-deserving of causes: the asylum seeker.

Britons today are a nation of enthusiastic pen pals who can't cope with the prospect of a face-to-face encounter. We'll do bizarre and humiliating things for Comic Relief, drop off excess clothing to Oxfam after an earthquake and protest against torture, dictatorships and war. Yet the sight of a victim of any of the world's injustices holding out a begging bowl outside our supermarkets throws us into paroxysms of outrage. The same Kosovan children we coo over on television are clambering off lorries outside Dover with only the clothes they're wearing. The same victims of the war in Sierra Leone or Saddam's regime wander the streets empty-pocketed as they await the decisions on sanctuary meted out by the Home Office. Apparently we are under siege from money-grabbing foreigners looking for a cushy life in the UK. Call me naive, but if someone is prepared to risk life and limb travelling across Europe in a refrigerated lorry for the sake of £36 in vouchers a week and a grotty room in a hostel, things can't be too good at home.

Yet among the cacophony of voices raised in political point-scoring, the rarest to be heard are those of the asylum seekers themselves. Which is why, on a beautiful late February day I find myself in the large common room which forms the Refugee Council's One Stop Service in Brixton, south London. There's a homely smell of cooking; people sit alone on plastic chairs or clustered in little groups. Some look up and smile shyly as I enter the room. It's not hard to recognise the outsider. Being fair-skinned and blonde makes me an incongruous racial type in any gathering of the world's oppressed and dispossessed. In a far corner, a bunch of toddlers play on a plastic frame - the solitary indication that this is the children's section of the room. To my right a group of silent African women sit together. A pretty woman in a plum-coloured hat beams as she talks on a mobile phone. Later I discover why she's so happy to be here. For now, she's the perfect example of what's unacceptable in an asylum seeker. As Nick Hardwick, chief executive of the Refugee Council puts it: 'The ideal refugee is shabby but not scruffy. They don't carry a mobile phone and they survive on nothing but fresh, British, democratic air.'

The Observer photographer's job is more difficult than mine. People are happy to talk - some are desperate to - but when it comes to posing on film, they politely decline. I presume it's because of their fear of repercussions for loved ones at home. For some that is the case, but for most it's the stigma and possibility of harassment here if they're identified as refugees. One of the escalating problems the Refugee Council is facing is the violence meted out to asylum seekers. Matters have not been helped by the policy of dispersing them around the country. In principle, the plan had much to recommend it. In reality, there are cities where it's easy to disappear into the local cultural melting pot, but there are many where a foreign face is exactly that. And not welcome.

After listening to the tales of what these people are escaping from, their treatment in this country becomes an even more acute embarrassment. Take Titi, the hat-wearing 30-year-old from West Africa. Her boyfriend became involved in one of the rebel groups in Sierra Leone. He left her, two months pregnant, promising to return in a week. A line of people is now forming to tell their stories. Alphonse Bartson was orphaned by the war in Rwanda. He came here at the age of 12. His is one of the happier stories. Having won his asylum application, he was educated in the UK and is now a project worker for the Refugee Council. Rose, a fellow Rwandan for whom he is translating today, is one of the saddest. A nervous woman, she stares constantly down at her twitching hands. Her husband and parents were murdered in front of her eyes and she fled the country with just one of her four children. The rest are scattered among friends and she can only hope they are still alive. Rose has just had her application turned down. Not because her case is questionable, but thanks to the 'non-compliance' regulations. If forms are not filled in on time or appointments not kept, applications are automatically refused. Timetables must be hard to keep when you are being moved around, don't speak English, don't have a telephone and often don't even have change for a bus.

Rose was in a hospital being treated for cancer when her Home Office appointment came up. Despite a doctor's letter informing the authorities she was bedridden in hospital - a letter they say they never received - her non-appearance was deemed reason to return her to Rwanda. Her cancer has meanwhile returned, but because of her appeal situation, Alphonse is finding it impossible to get her treatment. He tells me he fears she will die if she is not hospitalised. Tears well up in the corners of his eyes, and I am overcome with fury.

The last decade has seen bloody war and upheaval in many parts of the globe. As a result, the influx of refugees to the countries they deem 'safe' is at an all-time high. I read outraged reports in newspapers telling us that we have become a 'more popular destination than Germany for refugees seeking asylum'. Would we wish it any other way?

At the beginning of this new millennium, we are lucky enough to be a first-world country with a booming economy and a population of nearly 60m. At the Daily Mail 's worst estimate, there are 200,000 asylum seekers. It's hardly an invasion. Refugees make up 0.4 per cent of our population and frequently take on the menial jobs most of us prefer not to do. We have enjoyed sharing the glory with those whose children go on to achieve success in this country. Where would Britart be without Charles Saatchi, the fashion world without John Galliano, 80s pop music without the legacy of Freddie Mercury, literature without Salman Rushdie? Newcomer Zadie Smith won awards for her debut novel White Teeth last year - a timely celebration of the rich diversity of multicultural Britain.

Denise Lewis and Linford Christie may not be descended from a long line of Anglo Saxons, but we are proud of their successes. The other day, I met a Bosnian woman who came here as a refugee and has just earned a double first at Cambridge. Immigrants grab hold of the second chance they are given and make something of their lives. We should be proud our country has the wherewithal to offer them that opportunity and a reputation as an oasis of justice. For once, let's celebrate and live up to that image.

Comic Relief has every reason to be proud of the money it's donating to enable refugees to lead better and more rewarding lives in this country. Isn't it time we told them so?

webTitle: Jane Fonda has donated $12m to gender studies

fields.headline: Boys will be boys... but Jane is spending $12m to find out why
fields.standfirst: The Oscar-winning, fat-fighting, war-hating Ms Fonda has now donated a fortune to 'gender studies'
fields.trailText: Jane Fonda, former film star, anti-war militant and aerobics guru, has found a new outlet for her passions and her cash - breaking down the stereotypes that divide boys and girls.
fields.body:
Jane Fonda, former film star, anti-war militant and aerobics guru, has found a new outlet for her passions and her cash - breaking down the stereotypes that divide boys and girls. She has given $12.5 million (£8.5m) from her personal fortune for the establishment of a Centre for Gender and Education at Harvard University, which she hopes will help undo the damage she says is inflicted on young boys by America's schools.

The gift marks a departure for the one-time militant dubbed 'Hanoi Jane' after infuriating much of middle America by visiting the North Vietnamese capital while US troops were fighting on the other side in the Seventies.

Talking on Friday at the Harvard Faculty Club, the inner sanctum of America's establishment education system, Fonda told of her new passion for examining the different ways boys and girls learn in school. 'For too long it's been "boys will be boys" and "it's just a hormonal thing" for girls,' Fonda said. 'It's much more than that, and that's what we want to get at.'

The new centre will bring together researchers, psychologists and educationalists to help boys and girls fight the pressures of traditional sex roles. With most of the energy in gender studies currently focused on girls, Harvard will look initially at males, examining how boys are taught by the age of five to be 'manly and strong'.

Speaking to the New York Times, Fonda said: 'I don't think women suffer any more than men do. In some ways men suffer more. The damage done to boys as a result of these gender strictures is very profound.'

Four million US children, most of them boys, have been diagnosed with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder, and doctors write 11 million prescriptions for the drug Ritalin a year. In some schools as many as a third of all children are on Ritalin a result, and in some suburban areas of the US, including parts of New York, more than 20 per cent of white boys are taking Ritalin.

There is growing concern in the American academic community about the 'feminisation' of universities. In 1999, 8.5 million women enrolled in US colleges compared to 6.4m men, according to figures from the National Centre for Educational Statistics. In 2000, women made up 57 per cent of those entering college. The NCES expects this to rise to 61 per cent by 2009.

Announcing her gift, Fonda described how girls were 'bright-eyed and bushy tailed' at nine and self-censoring by 13, despite their academic successes. She looked around her at the audience and challenged Harvard to do something about this state of affairs. 'The old fuddy-duddies just stood up and raved about her,' said Jerome T. Murphy, dean of the educational faculty. 'She wowed a lot of people more than they expected.'

Asked whether her battle with the eating disorder bulimia had sparked her interest in gender issues, Fonda replied, 'It's in my DNA. The ways girls internalise and express the difficulty of growing up, they all happened to me.'

She said she had come to believe that traditional sex roles were key to understanding why boys are twice as likely to be on Ritalin and why girls stop speaking up in class as they grow older.

Some $2.5m of her donation will be used to endow a faculty chair to be named for Harvard psychologist Carol Gilligan.

Fonda has played almost as many roles in her personal life as she has in film. As the wife of French director Roger Vadim, and as the star of his film Barbarella, she was the ultimate Sixties sexpot. Then she was nominated for an Academy Award in 1969 for They Shoot Horses, Don't They? and won the Oscar two years later for Klute .

As a political activist and the wife of anti-Vietnam War protester Tom Hayden, she went to Hanoi to propagandise for the North Vietnamese; she even posed at the controls of a North Vietnamese anti-aircraft gun, for which she apologised during a Barbara Walters interview 16 years later.

Following in her father's impressive footsteps (and, luckily, not those of her mother, who cut her own throat when Jane was 12), she continued winning Academy nominations for Best Actress - a total of six - and she won her second Oscar for Coming Home .

In the Eighties, the longtime bulimic marketed the best-selling exercise video in history. Jane Fonda's Workout helped fund Hayden's political campaigns. She then went on to marry the founder of CNN, Ted Turner.

Fonda's generosity to Harvard continues the revived American craze for philanthropy in showbusiness. Giving endowments to colleges, causes and charities is a tradition dating back to weighty businessmen of the last century and has recently come to include rock stars such as Bruce Springsteen and Pearl Jam performing benefit concerts, and software billionaire Bill Gates becoming the nation's biggest philanthropic donor.

Apart from the time-honoured connection between Hollywood and the Clinton White House, some specific charities and lobbies have been established by movie stars: Bette Midler has poured a steady flow of money into her environmental trust which recently stepped in to buy up small islands of cultivated greenery in New York in order to rescue them from property developers.

And Paul Newman helps fill the political coffer which bankrolls the venerable Nation magazine which, alongside Mother Jones, constitutes a lonely, intelligent voice of the principled, if sometimes inflexible, hard left.

webTitle: ITN owners at odds over plans for flotation

fields.headline: ITN owners at odds over plans for flotation
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Shareholders in ITN are split over proposals to float the television news provider on the stock market this year. By Jamie Doward.
fields.body:
Shareholders in ITN are split over proposals to float the television news provider on the stock market this year.

News group Reuters is pushing for the company to finalise its listing plan by June, but two other share holders, Granada and Carlton, fear that is too early.

One source familiar with the project said: 'Granada privately believes market conditions make a float highly unlikely this year.'

Carlton is also known to have doubts. It wants to wait until the Government's attitude to cross-media ownership becomes clearer.

No shareholder can hold more than 20 per cent of ITN, but some are lobbying for this to be lifted or abolished.

Reuters favours a late summer flotation, despite a falling stock market and the fact that its ITV news contract, worth nearly £50 million a year, is being contested by a consortium spearheaded by BSkyB. This is ITN's largest revenue source by far; its loss would mean postponing flotation.

ITN, whose other share holders are United Business Media and the Daily Mail & General Trust, is pressing for ITV to decide on the contract as soon as possible.

ITN is also believed to be considering a number of alternative ways of raising money to fund plans for expansion. It is said to be exploring a number of joint projects with other broadcasters, and has not ruled out the possibility of seeking venture capitalist backing.

The need to secure extra funding is ITN's main priority. The company, which last year made pre-tax profits of around £10m, has invested heavily in its 24-hour News Channel.

Media analysts predict that this huge investment could shrink ITN's next set of full-year profits to as little as £3m.

fields.headline: Happy birthday, Rupert
fields.standfirst:
Rupert Murdoch is 70 next week. He's always been the enemy, says Peter Preston , but had he not existed we would have had to invent him

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch is 70 next week. He's always been the enemy, says Peter Preston , but had he not existed we would have had to invent him
fields.body:
Three score years and ten. It has become the late autumn of life, the season of mists and mellow fruitfulness when judges take their port and ex-ministers doze on the Lords' red benches. It is, in turn, a time that invites mellower verdicts on lives of toil. And Keith Rupert Murdoch is 70 this week.

I never thought to write this piece through his first 69 years. He was, in so many ways, the enemy: Rupert the Barbarian, laying waste established orders, debasing the currency of journalism, bending politicians to his right-wing agenda, marching ever on towards international domination. But there he sits now, in a New York apartment or Bel Air mansion, tended by a fierce young wife, and the balance has changed. We are nearer, far nearer, to the end of empire. We can see him whole.

He does not travel as much as he did. He is frailer, feeling the first pangs of mortality. His mind is much on the division of spoils among his family; the crown for Lachlan, the consolation prizes for James and Elisabeth. Meanwhile, the world he would rule has changed around him and his aura of infallibility has gone. He got the internet revolution wrong not once but twice; too late into the game, too slow to see that the tide had ebbed.

He must fight to survive against new foes he barely saw coming like AOL-Time Warner and Disney and Seagram. The predatory French of Vivendi snap at his heels. This jungle is suddenly full of big beasts.

That does not mean he has stopped. To the contrary, a deal to create a truly global satellite business - and a company worth $70 billion - hovers between glorious conclusion and ignominious collapse. He has staked out a unique position in the wars of digital supremacy, and he may well be right. But one other thing is also clear. These are the coming thirty-year wars, perhaps even 100-year wars. He will not be around to hail victory. He leaves that to future generations - and maybe, as he looks around at other media dynasties, he shivers a little. Whatever became of the Los Angeles Times Chandlers or Roy Thomson's newspaper legacy? Sold off because the heirs and successors weren't interested. The hereditary principle is only as good as heredity's next spin of the wheel. Does he feel lucky?

So, at 70, you can ask a different question. What would our world have been like without Rupert Murdoch? What if he had never been born or had carved out some modest Australian, beer-swilling career amid the debris of his own father's newspaper holdings?

He fights almost to the death rather than succumb. He gambles relentlessly on his own judgment. These are not minor virtues, and they belong to the world that surrounds us rather than the world we might wish to invent. Was there, in truth, any other option but the realpolitik of Wapping? If we're honest, we know the answer is no - and that there would be many fewer papers today without that stand. Was even the price war of the nineties as deplorable as those of us in its gale force path felt at the time? It had, in retrospect, one thing going for it that we all missed: newspapers had become too expensive, the automatic ratchet of annual price increases too cosy. He made us stop and think. And we are all still here.

The old mass market tabloids had lost touch with the masses. Football was another revolution waiting to begin, held back by the inertia of the clubs and (yes!) the BBC. And some of the grander arguments, too, are beginning to chase their own tails. Is the Sun too powerful for its own or anyone else's good? Yes, when you find prime ministers fawning after it: no, when Blair had to be endorsed last time - as he will be next time - because the electorate had made up its mind anyway and no cocky newspaper, clutching its mystique, can afford solemnly to advise its worshippers to do something they have no intention of doing. There's a thin line between swagger and cringe.

What remains of the Murdoch press (a distinctly non-global entity) isn't half as powerful as it likes to think, nor rigorously uniform in the lines it peddles. Matthew Parris, Simon Jenkins and Anatole Kaletsky sing from different Times hymn sheets: Jack Newfeld and Douglas Montero in the Post might transfer to the New York Times overnight. Sure, the British quartet don't like Europe (a following as well as a leading of readers, again) just as Rupert doesn't like Europe or its regulation of media entrepreneurs: but they don't like William Hague either. The Times has probably become his most implacable critic.

What looks wrong in a British context, moreover, can look right in an American one. New York is a Democrat city which the NY Times dominates with its own accepted, sometimes sonorous, wisdom. And we ought, in fairness, to wonder who else in similar circumstances would have proved so much bolder?

Satellite TV business is, of its nature, multinational business - and those knocking on China's door don't call the shots. One day China will be a real superpower of twenty-first century commerce; perhaps the new supreme power. But for the moment it is inching along that road, censoring its internet offerings, watching the programmes that are beamed from its skies. You can sit this one out if it gags in your throat, or you can bob and weave in the conviction that the process of opening up is on your side. A debate about ways and means, not between black and white.

Thus to the next, and maybe last, great adventure: Rupert's problematical and pending merger with DirecTV, the building of the world's first global satellite service covering Asia, Europe, North and South America. A dream of 10 years coming to final fruition. Untold riches as a glint in the eye. Yet here again the gamble is great and the odds on success little better than even. The fight is already a bloody one that reveals what you might call the real continuing curse of Murdoch. For a man worth $9 billion or so, he's always curiously short of ready money, and seems so again. He almost stumbled 10 years ago. He found heavy weather through 2000, and, for all the vaulting ambition of the moment, has a hiring freeze in place. The core businesses he leaves behind never seem to make quite enough to reduce the ocean of debt News Corp has grown accustomed to.

Is BSkyB a cash cow? No, the digital frenzy pushed it deep into a loss. Does the Star over Asia show a profit? Not yet, not yet. Will any merger with DirecTV generate enough investment to see off America's cable and broadband giants? Billions will be torn up in the attempt, win or lose (and the fact that he has Bill Gates, another misser of the internet bus, in his corner does not precisely reassure).

But here, even in triumph, is the way that empire ends in any case. The intricate, tax-defraying nature of News Corp has become too much of a personal tangle. Does anyone, apart from Rupert, really understand it? We're into an unbundling of flotations that started last year with Sky Global Networks, stalled, and will succeed now only if there is something to succeed with. The future, more and more, rests with separate, shared enterprises able to attract their own flows of investment rather than wallow in the general maw. What price, one day, even the old crown jewels of News International?

It is Rupert's own version of devolution, but it also fragments the empire and makes the job of the next generation more complex still. The days when he could demand the detail of everything he owned, barking down the telephone, have faded. Cultural imperialism is one thing, World Citizen Kanery rather another. Though he still gabs away rather too freely for the liking of his lieutenants - see his latest observation that Tony Blair is 'deluded' about Europe - the new Murdoch needs, of necessity, to be less seen and less heard. Perceptually, he can be defined as the problem and not the opportunity.

These are very deep waters. He has able lieutenants. He has usually been a good picker of managerial talent (as well as of editors). He has firm alliances with cable movers and shakers like John Malone. But transitions - as King Lear discovered - are the very devil; and voluntarily relinquishing old ways of control don't get easier in the eighth decade.

He is, make no mistake, a family man. He wants the warmth of his family, his children and their partners, around him. Sons-in-law get a job on the payroll. Nobody at News Corp doubts where power, once passed, will remain. The breakdown of his marriage to Anna and remarriage to Wendi Deng were not done easily or with a light heart. The owner of the News of the World is, perversely, a moral conservative: one contradiction among hundreds. But where there are families, there is also rich scope for feuding and fallings out. Step mothers the same age as the kids do not naturally fit; too much ambition piled upon a single, balding head carries its own crushing weight.

That is why, just for once, it is necessary to set Rupert Murdoch in the time capsule of his seventieth anniversary. Forget work in progress, because work is always in progress. Concentrate on what he has done.

It is a mixed ledger, to be sure. Those who want hanging cases have all the ammunition they could wish for. But it is also a story of brute resolve and drive, and courage at a crunch. Ask not where we have come with him, but where we would have been without him. Goodbye Robert Maxwell: you were utterly out-matched.

Goodbye, less obviously, Conrad Black: you are a (Canadian) seller of titles and a buyer no more; you are out of the race.

The difficulty, I think, is that if Rupert Murdoch had not existed, it would have been necessary to invent him. And the sins we visit on him - of cynicism, calculation, manipulation - are often no more than a reflection of our own weaknesses. When Tony Blair kow-tows, he tells us about New Labour, not Murdoch. When the rival press mounts its ritual attacks, the question is not what he has got away with, but what we let him get away with.

So happy birthday to the lion as winter nears. We can always resume normal service once the candles are off the cake and the last snows have melted.

1953: Takes the reins of News Ltd.

1964: Launches Australian - first national paper

webTitle: London blast rocks BBC TV Centre

fields.headline: London blast rocks BBC TV Centre
fields.standfirst: Explosion raises fears of renewed republican bombing campaign.
fields.trailText: Explosion raises fears of renewed republican bombing campaign.
fields.body:
Police blew up a car which had been abandoned outside the BBC TV Centre in Wood Lane, West London, early this morning.

Witnesses reported at least one massive explosion, which rocked houses up to a quarter of a mile away.

The BBC newsroom was evacuated after police were called to a suspect vehicle, believed to be a taxi, at 11.20pm. A controlled explosion was carried out at 12.30am. Nobody was hurt.

Anti-Terrorist Squad officers were on the scene, a Scotland Yard spokeswoman said.

A BBC spokesman said that the police had received a coded warning saying there was an explosive device outside the BBC in Wood Lane.

A witness who lives in Shepherd's Bush Green, around the corner from the BBC, said that the explosion had been so loud that it had woken him and had shaken his windows. He reported hearing a second explosion.

A second witness, Robert Fulton, who lives in Uxbridge Road, a quarter of a mile away, said: 'There was a loud explosion and my lamp fitting came off the wall. The sky lit up like fireworks and there were several loud bangs.'

Police in the area have been on high alert since a boobytrap bomb hidden in a torch exploded when it was picked up by a 14-year-old cadet at a Territorial Army base in nearby White City last month.

Stephen Menary, who was blinded in one eye by cancer as a baby, lost the other eye and a hand when he picked up the torch and it exploded, ripping a door to the 4th Battalion Parachute Regiment off its hinges.

Police and security forces have warned recently of an increased threat from Irish Republican dissidents who are unhappy with the peace process.

webTitle: Report links power lines to child cancer

fields.headline: Report links power lines to child cancer
fields.trailText: Living next to high voltage power cables may lead to an enhanced risk of cancer for children, according to new Government research to be made public next week.
fields.body:
Living next to high voltage power cables may lead to an enhanced risk of cancer for children, according to new Government research to be made public next week.

A team of experts commissioned by the National Radiological Protection Board (BNRPB) - the government's radiation watchdog - will also state that there may be a link to adult cancers.

The team has been led by Sir Richard Doll, the veteran epidemiologist who discovered that smoking caused lung cancer more than 30 years ago. He is expected to recommend further research.

There have been a number of studies of possible links between cancer in children and proximity to high voltage cables. This is the first official investigation to find a connection.

The researchers have said that they are not sure how it works, but it is possible that the power lines emit charged particles which react with oxygen and nitrogen in the air, making it easier for pollutants in the air to enter the body's cells. Professor Colin Blakemore, a member of Doll's team, said the risk was 'slightly elevated.'

The Electricity Association, which represents many of Britain's power generators and distributors, said they were taking the new findings seriously though there was no concrete evidence that power lines caused cancer.

As long ago as 1979, American studies showed high levels of leukemia in children living close to overhead power lines. The new research may prompt thousands of compensation claims against the government.

Doll refused to comment. No one from the BNRPB was available last night.

webTitle: Double jeopardy rule to end in murder cases

fields.headline: Double jeopardy rule to end in murder cases
fields.standfirst: Restrospective change could lead to new Stephen Lawrence prosecutions.
fields.trailText: Restrospective change could lead to new Stephen Lawrence prosecutions.
fields.body:
The government is to allow suspected murderers who have been found not guilty to face a second trial if there is compelling evidence that justice has not been served.

The move will end the historic ban against anybody being tried twice for the same crime, so-called 'double jeopardy', and would allow new proceedings against dozens of alleged killers. The review was prompted by the Macpherson report into the flawed investigation of the murder of Stephen Lawrence.

A report to be published this week by the Law Commission, a committee of experts which advises the Government on legal changes, is to recommend that the Court of Appeal be given the power to set aside an acquittal, but only in murder cases. The change should be retrospective, the Commission are expected to say.

The review was commissioned by Jack Straw, the Home Secretary. A Home Office source indicated last night that he would like to bring foward legislation after the election.

It is very rare for a recommendation by the Law Commission to be rejected and any new laws are likely to have an easy passage through parliament. They will be welcomed by police who say that new technology can lead to powerful new evidence being discovered after a trial.

But there is likely to be opposition from human rights groups. Roger Bingham, of Liberty said: 'The prosecution already have greater resources. This creates a risk of sending more innocent people to prison.'

Roger Bingham, of Liberty said: 'The prosecution already have greater resources. This creates a risk of sending more innocent people to prison.'

fields.headline: Deity tricks department
fields.standfirst: As two new movies about US Presidents head for Britain,  Peter Preston asks why America turns its leaders into gods while ours remain mortal
fields.trailText: As two new movies about US Presidents head for Britain, Peter Preston asks why America turns its leaders into gods while ours remain mortal
fields.body:
Here we go again, Mr President. One Commander-in-Chief fighting the sex war, another almost fighting the Third World War. Political thrillers have seldom had it so good - and it is instructive, as the Baftas and Blair cuddle ever closer to America, to wonder why. After all, even the National Lottery would not put up money to make a British movie about Downing Street. We may be interested in London lowlife and ballet boys, but domestic politicians are the untouchables of box-office indifference.

That in no way troubles a Hollywood which assumes (with plenty of evidence) that our fascination level with their dirty dealings at the top remains high. Two more big budget essays in White House power-broking arrive this month. One - Rod Lurie's The Contender - is a vicious struggle for power. The other - Roger Donaldson's Thirteen Days - is the story of John Kennedy's struggle to hang on to it through the Cuban missile crisis. Both invite our attention; indeed, almost command it. Whatever happened to the Falklands (with Maggie Smith) - or the filleting of Mandy (with Vinnie Jones as Alastair Campbell)?

It is a case, on examination, of a genre which has lived over decades and a defunct non-genre that died with Trollope. Britain has rarely, if ever, thought politics worth putting on screen. Churchill may occasionally be impersonated in war epics, but otherwise Prime Ministers are unsung.

Transient bores. America has never believed that for a second. It sees its leaders as heroes or villains. It expects greatness (or, at least, great entertainment). It wants to watch President Harrison Ford pitted against the forces of evil in Air Force One, just as it wanted to watch President Fredric March do his stuff four decades ago through Seven Days in May. It likes good Presidents played by Henry Fonda (The Best Man) and malignant Presidents played by Gene Hackman (Absolute Power). It is a nation obsessed by its own history which scents dollars in the recreation.

Over time, of course, the genre has developed its own standard themes and sub-divisions. By those lights, The Contender is bog-standard fare. Senator Laine Hanson (Joan Allen) is plucked from the back shelf when President Jackson Evans (Jeff Bridges) decides he wants a woman one heartbeat from the Oval Office. Joan is intelligent and thoughtful and ought to have voted for Ralph Nader last year; her confirmation hearings' adversary, Senator Shelly Runyon (Gary Oldman) is a warped, conniving creep - and, naturally, a Republican. The light and the darkness lock predictable horns. Manslaughter and mayhem follow.

What makes The Contender a rip-roaring ride, though, is not the bones of a plot that writes itself but the scope politics has to refresh it. This, perhaps the last offering of the late-Clinton period, lets President Jeff gorge himself on junk sharkfish sandwiches and play cocky, cornball bruiser. 'A girl died and you let it happen...' he tells one cowering candidate. 'You're the future of the Democratic Party, and always will be.' Sex can be talked about crudely - 'The one thing the American people can't stomach is a Vice-President with a mouthful of cock' - and even shown between consenting adults. We first meet Senator Joan flat on her desk being pleasured by a man who turns out to be her husband.

Should she pay the price for the student orgies of long ago? 'If I were a man, nobody would care how many sexual partners I had in college - and if it's not relevant for man, it's not relevant for a woman.' Should she answer back, as Bill Clinton tried to do, or suffer in saintly silence? A contemporary gloss of headline issues and pundit dilemmas can be applied like a new coat of paint. This, in essence, is the Fonda of The Best Man or the Redford of The Candidate reworked for modern times and modern manners. Everybody involved read Primary Colors, everybody sniggered at Wag the Dog. Thirteen Days sits handily at the other end of the genre spectrum. This is not a teasing collation of historic parallels, but a stab at recreating history - from White House tapes and Robert Kennedy's book about the crisis that seemed, for almost a fortnight, to signal the end of our world. It purports, as did Oliver Stone's Nixon, to be a version of the truth, and it belongs to the quasi-documentary tradition which All the President's Men began.

Bruce Greenwood plays JFK in the same way that Anthony Hopkins played Nixon: that is not as Travolta-style parody Clinton, but as a distinct, created character who convinces because he has a life of his own. He does not look much like Kennedy, but he exists and dithers and finds resolve in a White House which has the sniff of reality to it. You feel, at the close, that you have been there with him, through 13 days of hell.

Does that have any resonance for a cinema audience which, in the broad, was not thought of, let alone born, in 1962? Who, sitting in the stalls in Swindon, cares about very dead Presidents and wars that did not happen in confrontations with a Moscow which has ceased to exist? The trick - the developing trick for Stone as well as Roger Donaldson - is to add a little universality, which means layers of complexity. Greenwood's fight is not merely with an unseen Khrushchev but against his own gung-ho chiefs of staff and administration cold warriors. Look what his dad did at Munich, says Dean Acheson, 'Let's hope appeasement doesn't run in the family.' Hear the ancestral voices of George Bush's Pentagon.

Yet - and Stone's Nixon shows it most starkly - the universality is about more than the manoeuvres of governance: it depends on borrowing the classical structures of tragedy. Hopkins's Nixon is not Hannibal in a Sixties suit, rather a genuinely tragic figure. They Larkined him up, his saintly mum and dad. He carries his dirt-poor upbringing like a cross, bitterly resenting Kennedy's silver spoon. 'All my life he's been sticking it to me: now he steals it [the election] from me.' Those who see hints of Macbeth (Act Five) in his final fall are dead right. Exeunt omnes to the sepulchral verdict of Paul Sorvino's Kissinger. 'Can you imagine what the man might have been had he ever been loved?'

These parallels are not accidental. I was in the Smithsonian in Washington a few weeks ago, wandering round a new exhibition on the presidency which features a whole room of posters and clips about its TV and movie incarnations (from Polly Bergen's Kisses for my President up). That was interesting enough, but the way it melded with the whole (very packed) exhibition was more interesting still.

These Presidents, from Lincoln to Jimmy Carter, were heroes presented as heroes. They were kings and gods, their mementoes - Warren Harding's silk pyjamas - stored in glass caskets as though they were Buddha's ashes. The films about them, accordingly, have a very simple question to answer: What were they like? What is it like to be near them?

You may look for your answers at the pages of the National Enquirer, or in a collected Shakespeare, or yet further back. Some of these films are, in a sense, the old biblical epics Hollywood used to make refettled for a more cynical age. 'Here's the darkness reaching out for the dark. Open that scab and you uncover a lot of pus,' says Nixon of his Judas, Howard Hunt. No wonder the Britpack has steered well clear. We treat our leaders with fawning deference - where's Harold Macmillan in the Profumo movie Scandal ? - but build no legends around them. Ted Heath does not retire this year to a marbled memorial library; Jim Callaghan is down on the farm thinking foot and mouth; Mrs T, unchronicled, is out there somewhere, sounding off as usual. They are not quasi-gods, but the merest of mortals, their memory buried with their power. Nobody can be bothered to wrestle after their complexity, because they are already arcane themselves. We have, in movies, to make do with old kings instead.

East End not West Wing? Is that a happy state for a happy state? Hardly. Among other things, it denies a nation with a real history any access to it and confers the order of the Automatic Pygmy on those who pass through No 10. It is all of a piece as Tony trots off to pay homage to George W. But at least every downside has a redeeming upside. At least somebody's making films about politics - and better than that, on this month's form, films to make you choke on your popcorn.

Thirteen Days is released on 16 March; The Contender on 20 April

fields.headline: Crowe's feat
fields.standfirst: Meg Ryan's husband is being held by South American terrorists. Who can help her? It's Russell to the rescue
fields.trailText: Philip French: Hackford does not rush a film that takes place over four months
fields.body:
In my review of Jocelyn Moorhouse's Proof, the film in which Russell Crowe first made a strong impression a decade ago, I noted that the chief quality of the character he played (a tough odd-job man who befriends a bitter, well-off blind orphan) was a 'guileless honesty'. Crowe, one of the most engaging stars in today's cinema, has been playing variations on this role ever since, most notably in LA Confidential, The Insider, Gladiator and now Taylor Hackford's Proof of Life, a semi-documentary thriller written by Tony Gilroy and inspired by an article in Vanity Fair magazine.

Crowe has the open face of James Stewart and Gary Cooper, and he moves with the ambling swagger of Warner Brothers tough guys like Bogart, Robinson, Cagney and Garfield. But in Proof of Life, for the first time outside his native Antipodes (he was born in New Zealand, raised in Australia) he uses his own accent. He's Terry Thorne, an ex-SAS man working in the K and R (kidnapping and ransom) business for a City of London insurance firm. The opening credit sequence, an economical little film in itself, shows him reporting to his suave, immaculately suited bosses on a successful operation that involved freeing a Frenchman from Chechen rebels while holding off double-crossing Russian soldiers. This episode establishes Thorne as a man of probity with the diplomatic gifts of Henry Kissinger and the military skills of a hi-tech Orde Wingate.

Meanwhile, down in the fictitious Latin American state of Tecala, the United States government is supporting a right-wing regime that is seeking to promote US oil interests and suppress a ragged band of ex-Marxist guerrillas who deal in cocaine and ransom money. Caught in the crossfire is an idealistic engineer, Peter Bowman (David Morse), who thinks he's building a dam to help the local population though in his heart he knows it's a gift to Tecala's corrupt politicians by an oil conglomerate to obtain rights to build a pipeline.

Bowman's marriage to Alice (Meg Ryan) is fraying after years of dispiriting work in the Third World, and at this difficult point he's kidnapped by the terrorists and taken into the mountains. The US embassy refuses help on bogus diplomatic grounds, the local police and army are not to be trusted, and Thorne is dispatched from London to take over the case and bring hope to Alice.

It turns out, however, that Bowman's company has just been taken over, that their hostage insurance has lapsed, and the new owners don't want to get involved in freeing him. So Thorne's services are withdrawn and he returns to Europe. In case we miss the point about the utter venality of this political-commercial nexus, Hackford has cast as Bowman's local American boss the most deviously dislikeable character actor since Murray Hamilton (the mayor in Jaws) retired. He's Anthony Heald, best-known as the vindictive shrink who torments Hannibal Lecter in The Silence of the Lambs and a man who oozes insincerity from every pore.

For 40 years, films about Americans in Latin America like State of Siege, Missing, Under Fire and Salvador, have shown up Washington and the local politicians in an equally bad light. Proof of Life is no exception. Fortunately Thorne has a change of heart. He bids farewell to his young son at a smart English boarding school (Gilroy and Hackford must have had some lingering memory of an identical scene in the 1978 film The Wild Geese when mercenary Richard Harris goes off on a similar mission) and returns to help Alice in Tecala. There's an explosive scene in which he, his American mercenary sidekick (David Caruso) and their team turn the tables on Alice's devious Latin assistants and restore her confidence. He then takes over the operation and a fascinating cat-and-mouse game on mobile phones and shortwave radio gets under way between the guerrillas' representative and Thorne - first to establish 'proof of life', then to bargain over the ransom money.

As this slow, delicate business proceeds, Bowman is being dragged from camp to camp, physical condition deteriorating, morale fluctuating, hopes encouraged by meeting a captive missionary (Gottfried John). He's also sustained by a photograph of Alice, and we fear that the inevitable intimacy springing up from her dependence on Thorne might turn into something more serious.

There are announcements from time to time of which day of captivity we're watching, and wisely Hackford does not rush a film that takes place over four months, relying on his actors and on the continuing suspense to hold our interest. But he does introduce a melodramatic coincidence that more work on the plot could have averted, and at the end he switches into a slap-up action mode of a conventional, though exciting kind, in the manner of pictures like Uncommon Valor about mercenaries freeing PoWs in South-East Asia.

These films of liberation come from the captivity stories of the American West as mediated by John Ford's influential The Searchers. In the past I've spoken, not entirely disparagingly, of Hackford being a curious mixture of hack and Ford, and in this expertly crafted film he pays tribute to Ford in having at least three characters paraphrase John Wayne's climactic line in The Searchers: 'Let's go home Debbie'.

fields.headline: Classicwatch
fields.trailText: Perhaps Evelyn Waugh's finest comic novel
fields.body:
Scoop
Evelyn Waugh
(Penguin Classics £7.99, pp222)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Evelyn Waugh's magnificent satire on Fleet Street was published in 1938, the year before Waugh was commissioned in the Royal Marines and went to serve in the Middle East and Yugoslavia.

Scoop, perhaps his finest comic novel, follows the misadventures of bewildered innocent William Boot, dispatched by an inopportune case of mistaken identity to cover the burgeoning civil war in the African Republic of Ishmaelia for 'The Daily Beast'.

While the book is a romping comedy of errors with some ingenious plotting and an increasingly complex tissue of absurd situations, it is Waugh's gift for the subtleties of language that gives Scoop its great comic tone. Minor characters are presented briskly and brilliantly, the foreign correspondents who decorate the hotel bar are almost Dickensian, and one of the book's most memorable characters has become immortalised in the vernacular: 'Up to a point, Lord Copper.'

Scoop is a book of its time and class, and sensitive readers may find cause to wince on occasion, but its humour is vivid and enduring.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Judy Budnitz creates a fantastic world, plus The Euro, Joan of Arc, Babylon and The Romantics
fields.body:
If I Told You Once
Judy Budnitz
Flamingo £6.99, pp294
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Part Angela Carter, part old-fashioned fairy tale, and part her own blend of tough female characters and straight-shooting prose, Judy Budnitz creates a fantastic world in her Orange-shortlisted If I Told You Once.

It's an immigrant's tale which moves from snowy Eastern Europe to sweltering New York tenements, but this time there's myth and folklore to go with it. Budnitz's Ilana, the matriarch and main narrator, tells us her story and allows us to peer into her 'eggshell full of misread visions'. In doing so, we catch a glimpse of a world in which the past and the present seem to magically collide, which Budnitz executes with enviable style and grace.

The Euro - Should Britain Join: Yes or No?
Anthony Browne
Icon Books £3.99, pp125

This is a very informative little book. Anthony Browne manages to find the line between 'dumbing down' the complicated matter of the euro, tackling its intricacies and the debates which surround it. He neatly addresses all aspects of the impending decision for Britain: how will accepting or denying the euro as the single currency for Europe affect the UK, economically, politically, financially and on a personal level?

He's done so by listing common questions (Does monetary union lead to political union? Will jobs be lost by staying out?) and giving straightforward 'yes' and 'no' answers to all of them. Impressively, Browne even manages to add a little humour to what might be considered a humourless topic, and his practical, calm manner of handling this complex issue makes this book helpful and easy to read.

Joan of Arc
Mary Gordon
Phoenix £6.99, pp168
Buy it at a discount at BOL

We all know the story of Joan of Arc - or do we? Mary Gordon attempts, in her biography of 'La Pucelle' (the Maid), to show us the contradictions within the character of St Joan - from her modest origins as the daughter of peasants to her visions and the voices which called to her, and from her recognition of Charles VII as the real King of France to Joan's need to wear men's clothing and keep her virginity intact.

Gordon also, however, affectionately overanalyses Joan and dwells often on the dualities of her role as warrior and woman. Though she presents an interesting dissection of Joan of Arc's portrayal in history, literature and cinema, her own portrayal relies too heavily on metaphors and on repeated exploration of Joan's psyche, rather then allowing the reader to draw personal and perhaps more fulfilling conclusions.

Babylon
Victor Pelevin
Faber £6.99, pp250
Buy it at a discount at BOL

If you cross Kurt Vonnegut with Jay McInerney, lace them with hallucinogenic mushrooms and cocaine, place them in post-Communist Russia and add a twist of Zen Buddhism and Egyptology, what might you get? That's Victor Pelevin's novel Babylon for you. There's no concise way to sum up the nature of the plot, nor the chaotic pace of the novel.

Babylen Tatarsky - named after a Yevtushenko poem and Lenin - is thrown into the advertising world of mafiosos in Moscow, and the ride he takes us on is a truly bizarre one. Pelevin's commendably creative style and sometimes frustratingly frenetic prose keep the narrative moving along, but often you begin to wonder, what exactly is the point? Or perhaps that's the Buddhist answer after all.

Virginia Woolf and Vanessa Bell: A Very Close Conspiracy
Jane Dunn
Virago £8.99, pp338
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In the preface to Jane Dunn's intriguing, fluid and well-sourced book, the author explains that this is not a 'joint biography' but 'the story of a relationship between sisters'. Dunn seamlessly narrates Virginia and Vanessa's closeness and competitiveness, their reliance on one another, and their need for individuality - from their childhoods, through work and love. She also focuses on the importance of the other members of the the Bloomsbury group, whose lives were all integrally tied to those of Woolf and Bell.

Moving beyond the idea of 'the simple equation that Vanessa had chosen life at the expense of her art and Virginia had chosen art at the expense of life', Dunn plunges deep beneath the surface to the complicated emotions and personalities of these two women, illuminating them with great clarity and understanding.

The Romantics
Pankaj Mishra
Picador £6.99, pp277
Buy it at a discount at BOL

This is a brilliantly vivid, lucid debut from Pankaj Mishra. Set primarily in modern-day Benares, and later in Dharamshala, it centres on Samar, a Brahmin intellectual unfamiliar with the ways of the world, and often captivated by those around him. It's a story of the collisions between things European and Indian: his friendship with English Miss West, his infatuation with glamorous French Catherine, his conversations with the mysterious Rajesh, another Brahmin at the university in Benares.

Mishra has a remarkable eye for detail, and nothing escapes his gaze: from the banalities of chopping vegetables and the sound of a woman towel-drying her hair, to the discussions of what the 'real' India is, and how one finds it. This is a novel not to be missed.
fields.bodyText: If I Told You Once Judy Budnitz Flamingo £6.99, pp294 Buy it at a discount at BOL Part Angela Carter, part old-fashioned fairy tale, and part her own blend of tough female characters and straight-shooting prose, Judy Budnitz creates a fantastic world in her Orange-shortlisted If I Told You Once. It's an immigrant's tale which moves from snowy Eastern Europe to sweltering New York tenements, but this time there's myth and folklore to go with it. Budnitz's Ilana, the matriarch and main narrator, tells us her story and allows us to peer into her 'eggshell full of misread visions'. In doing so, we catch a glimpse of a world in which the past and the present seem to magically collide, which Budnitz executes with enviable style and grace. The Euro - Should Britain Join: Yes or No? Anthony Browne Icon Books £3.99, pp125 This is a very informative little book. Anthony Browne manages to find the line between 'dumbing down' the complicated matter of the euro, tackling its intricacies and the debates which surround it. He neatly addresses all aspects of the impending decision for Britain: how will accepting or denying the euro as the single currency for Europe affect the UK, economically, politically, financially and on a personal level? He's done so by listing common questions (Does monetary union lead to political union? Will jobs be lost by staying out?) and giving straightforward 'yes' and 'no' answers to all of them. Impressively, Browne even manages to add a little humour to what might be considered a humourless topic, and his practical, calm manner of handling this complex issue makes this book helpful and easy to read. Mary Gordon attempts, in her biography of 'La Pucelle' (the Maid), to show us the contradictions within the character of St Joan - from her modest origins as the daughter of peasants to her visions and the voices which called to her, and from her recognition of Charles VII as the real King of France to Joan's need to wear men's clothing and keep her virginity intact. Gordon also, however, affectionately overanalyses Joan and dwells often on the dualities of her role as warrior and woman. Though she presents an interesting dissection of Joan of Arc's portrayal in history, literature and cinema, her own portrayal relies too heavily on metaphors and on repeated exploration of Joan's psyche, rather then allowing the reader to draw personal and perhaps more fulfilling conclusions. webTitle: The Truth at Last by Christine Keeler read by Honor Blackman

fields.headline: The Truth at Last by Christine Keeler read by Honor Blackman
fields.trailText: 'I don't want to die and let the lies become history,' begins Christine Keeler.
fields.body:
The Truth at Last
Christine Keeler
Read by Honor Blackman
Running time 3hrs
Macmillan £8.99

'I don't want to die and let the lies become history,' begins Christine Keeler. This is why she has finally decided to write her version of the events that led to what has become known as the 'Profumo affair'.

It's a sordid tale of a 'stupid young girl' caught up in the glamour of nightclubs and the attentions of older men. Keeler was just 17 when she met Stephen Ward, whom she claims used her for the purposes of spying. Ward killed himself shortly after Keeler's affair with John Profumo, the Secretary of State for War, became public knowledge. Ward's side of the story will never be heard.

It's difficult to believe every word of a woman who states: 'I've always denied being a prostitute and I still do', when she then freely admits sleeping with men for money. Her claims that Ward tried to kill her are tenuous, and her reasons for becoming involved with Lucky Gordon - a brutal drug-dealer - are ludicrous. But Profumo was arguably as guilty, denying the affair until cornered. The real shame is that Keeler has been tarnished for life, struggling financially while Profumo found a new life and career.

Honor Blackman has achieved one of the hardest jobs in audiobook narration - reading in the first person. She sounds astonishingly like Keeler: the same gravelly deep voice edged with a west London accent. Blackman does Keeler's account credit - even the incredible bits.
