The columns of many late twentieth-century newspapers are littered with the whitened bones of those who predicted The Death of the Book. Caxton's handy device has been around for five centuries. If it now starts to disappear from our lives, that's not going to happen overnight. robert.mccrum@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Observer review: Our Word is our Weapon

fields.headline: Why did Marcos keep his mask on?
fields.standfirst: The words of Subcomandante Marcos in Our Word is our Weapon read like an instruction manual for the next wave of anti-capitalist protest
fields.trailText: The words of Subcomandante Marcos in Our Word is our Weapon read like an instruction manual for the next wave of anti-capitalist protest
fields.body:
Our Word is our Weapon: Selected Writings of Subcomandante Insurgente Marcos
edited by Juana Ponce de León
Serpent's Tail £20, pp456
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The mountainous forests of Chiapas are Mexico's most beguiling and majestic landscape, but the region has long been bloodied by violence and authority-sanctioned crime. In those rolling hillsides, some 60,000 soldiers - almost a third of the Mexican army - have driven thousands of local people from their homes and into makeshift camps. Water is a luxury; tuberculosis, typhoid, cholera, measles, tetanus, pneumonia and malaria are wiping out whole communities.

In January 1994, Zapatista rebels in Chiapas declared war on the Mexican government, 'not to usurp power, but to exercise it'. After 12 days of fighting, during which the rebel groups overran San Cristobal de las Casas and a number of other neighbouring towns in Chiapas, the Zapatistas declared a ceasefire.

Their rebellion won worldwide support and the Mexican government was condemned by human rights groups. In the spring of 1994, still bullish from their victory, the Zapatistas invited the foreign and national press into the Lacandon jungle.

The Zapatistas' official spokesman, Subcomandante Marcos, who appeared before the audience wearing a black mask, was asked: 'Why hide your face? What are you afraid to show?' To a stunned audience, Marcos offered to remove his mask and he wasonly stopped by cries of 'No! No! No!' The incident can now be viewed as a pivotal moment in the construction of a twentieth-century radical.

The Zapatista rebellion of 1994, as Marcos articulates here in this wonderfully annotated collection of thoughts, can be explained almost solely by the unequal distribution of land. In 1990, 6,000 of Mexico's most prosperous dynasties owned nearly 3,000,000 hectares of the available terrain in Chiapas, almost half the land of the state. At the same time, nearly a million villagers scratched a living on the remaining land, only 41 per cent of which was officially regarded as suitable for farming. Subcomandante Marcos writes: 'This is what capitalism leaves us as payment for everything that it takes away.'

Since the uprising, Subcomandante Marcos has seen his reputation become a byword for the anti-globalisation movement. Our Word Is Our Weapon, like all Marcos communiqués published since 1994, adds to his almost mystical appeal. Over the years, his mask has allowed Subcomandante Marcos to assume an iconographic persona.

Unlike revolutionary parties before them - the Black Panther Party For Self-Defence and the Nation of Islam were marginalised both by their politics and their visual aesthetic - Subcomandante Marcos and the Zapatistas enjoy continuing appeal.

Speeches, letters and personal diary entries from the considerable Marcos archives have been published before - they are smuggled out of Chiapas by activists, students and journalists willing to preserve his words - but Our Word Is Our Weapon is the first authoritative omnibus to detail the evolution of a local rebel into a considerable international statesman. Included in this collection are eloquent and often emotionally demonstrative letters to the US government, Leonard Peltier and Mumia Abu-Jamal.

Set against other radical manifestos from the past - Huey P. Newton's Revolutionary Suicide, Elijah Muhammed's The Spirit of the Black Man and Bobby Seale's Seize the Time - Our Word Is Our Weapon exudes a political timelessness. And in this, the age of 'Anti-Corporate, Inc', the tempered words of Subcomandante Marcos read like an instruction manual for future rebellions.

webTitle: Observer review: Leon Battista Alberti by Anthony Grafton

fields.headline: Genesis of a genius
fields.standfirst: Leon Battista Alberti was more than a Renaissance man - he would have flourished in any age, as Anthony Grafton shows
fields.trailText: Leon Battista Alberti was more than a Renaissance man - he would have flourished in any age, as Anthony Grafton shows
fields.body:
Leon Battista Alberti: Master Builder of the Italina Renaissance
Anthony Grafton
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Anthony Grafton's wonderfully lively and readable biography of the fifteenth-century humanist intellectual, architect and adviser to princes, Leon Battista Alberti, stands in a long tradition of works of homage to a remarkable individual hailed a century and a half ago by scholars as the original Renaissance Man. For it was Leon Battista Alberti - not Leonardo da Vinci as we might expect - who first earned the title l'uomo universale from Jacob Burckhardt, the scholar who shaped our modern idea of the Italian Renaissance. In his epoch-making book The Civilisation of the Renaissance in Italy, Burckhardt conferred that title on Alberti as the ultimate accolade for civilised achievement at the dawn of the modern age.

'When the impulse to the highest individual development was combined with a powerful and varied nature, which had mastered all the elements of the culture of the age,' Burckhardt wrote in 1860, 'then arose the "all-sided man" - l'uomo universale - who belonged to Italy alone. Among these many-sided men, some, who may truly be called all-sided, tower above the rest.' The greatest of these, Burckhardt continued, was Alberti.

According to Burckhardt, Alberti was both genius and pin-up - he could ride the wildest horses and jump from a standing start to the height of the man standing next to him. He was a brilliant cryptographer, invented a kind of camera obscura, wrote plays and treatises in Italian and Latin, dashed off a manual on horses, and was, in his personal life, a charming person and a loyal friend.

Beyond the dazzling personal successes, there were the brilliant writings which outlasted him. Posterity remembers Alberti for his masterly treatises on painting, sculpture and architecture, as well as for his handbook for leading a decent and orderly private life in fifteenth-century Florence - his much reprinted On the Family.

Above all Alberti is celebrated for his magnificent buildings - closely modelled on the ruins of antiquity, and on classical writings such as Vitruvius's - for some of the most powerful families in Italy, the Malatesta despots in Rimini, the military Gonzagas in Mantua, and the Rucellai millionaires in Florence. Leonardo da Vinci's notebooks ran to thousands of pages of ambitious engineering and design projects, none of which were ever executed. Alberti, by contrast, left us the great cathedral of Sant'Andrea and church of San Sebastiano in Mantua, the facade of Santa Maria Novella in Florence and the incomplete Templo Malatestiano in Rimini.

At the end of his life Alberti himself believed that he had left sufficient monuments to gain him a lasting reputation for humaneness: 'Oh! How sweet is the glory that we gain through our efforts. What worthy efforts are ours, through which we may show to those who are not yet alive, that we lived with other values than those of our times, and we have left something of our mind and name besides a mere funeral stone.'

So a new book on Alberti is far more than simply another biography. An author who attempts a new appraisal of Alberti stakes his own claim to reframe an entire tradition in understanding our cultural origins in the European Renaissance. The dust jacket of Leon Battista Alberti describes Anthony Grafton as 'one of the greatest living Renaissance scholars', then surveys afresh the lifetime achievements of the greatest of the Renaissance Men.

What Grafton gives us is, indeed, a genuine reappraisal which will itself stand the test of time. In lucid and accessible prose he constructs a portrait of an original Renaissance mind, using his own rich knowledge of the education and currents of thought which shaped a fifteenth-century intellectual's development. Alberti is no longer an isolated genius, but robustly the product of his times - a man whose alert intelligence and quick wit made the most sustained use of the resources of antiquity and the ruins of Rome, to which the new movement later dubbed 'humanism' gave him access.

Grafton's Alberti reads voraciously, bedrocking his ideas in a fully absorbed understanding of classical languages and rhetoric. He consults widely with artists, engineers and scholars of his day - just as alert to the practical exigencies of daily life as to the idealised pictures painted by philosophers. He responds astutely to the requests of demanding patrons,and is quick to spot career opportunities.

Grafton's Alberti, in other words, is a man for our times, to replace Burckhardt's by now outmoded, idealised uomo universale. This towering figure retains the breathtaking range and diversity, but gains, additionally, a hands-on flair for the practical and technical detail, and a clear-headed understanding of the exigencies of power-politics.

The biographer of Alberti works with an established canon of documentary materials - the surviving records have been sifted and catalogued to the point that little new is likely to emerge. Not long ago, however, an autograph letter surfaced, written by Alberti in 1454 to his site manager for the Templo Malatestiano project, Matteo de' Pasti. It is a letter preoccupied with the technical problems raised by the need to provide the building with a roof of particularly broad span, testing the limits of contemporary engineering.

'Do not trust the existing piers to carry any weight,' he writes, 'and use a light-weight roof form like a wooden barrel vault, to reduce the danger of collapse.

'Don't worry,' he continues, 'if the new pier specified in his design does not line up with the old ones - the old ones are not load-bearing, it is only the new ones whose positions are critical to carry the weight of the facade.'

At the beginning of the letter Alberti states boldly that he prefers always to follow the example of the great builders of antiquity, rather than to take the advice of contemporaries. Here as elsewhere, however, we watch Alberti wrestling with both extremities of the problem of architectural innovation. There are the glorious examples to be emulated - the Roman Pantheon, or the Arch of Augustus - and then there are the engineering and structural challenges that confront any architect working at the cutting edge of contemporary competence.

Grafton's biography of Alberti gives us a portrait of an outstanding individual which finally brings these two sides of his achievement into triumphant coherence and harmony.

webTitle: Observer review: Achilles by Elizabeth Cook

fields.headline: Achilles and the good ode days
fields.standfirst: In Elizabeth Cook's short epic that's neither a poem nor a novel, Achilles, the lives of the Greek hero and Keats entwine to produce an instant classic
fields.trailText: In Elizabeth Cook's short epic that's neither a poem nor a novel, Achilles, the lives of the Greek hero and Keats entwine to produce an instant classic
fields.body:
Achilles
Elizabeth Cook
Methuen £12.99, pp102

This remarkable little book is not a novel although Methuen, foxed by trying to classify it, have it on their fiction list. Nor is it a play - yet when RSC actor Greg Hicks read from it at the Edinburgh Festival last summer, it won a Fringe First award. Elizabeth Cook writes poetry and was the editor of John Keats's works for Oxford University Press but Achilles is not a poem either. It is slender - 102 pages short - yet epic in its scope. Its roots are well-known (Greek mythology; romantic literature), but its branches are new. I have never read anything like it.

Cook retells Achilles's story, making the reader feel that it exists in a present tense. She is not interested in polite distance: she gets close to the gods, makes them seem real - a feat in itself. Her writing is charged: every moment matters, each word counts, as if time were running out. And this suits her purpose for the book is, in part, trying to beat mortality in a race to the finishing post.

There is a tacit contest between those who are immortal and have to survive their loved ones and those who are mortal who regret that they must die. And like a river flowing beneath the story is the implication that life is precious because it is not permanent. There is grief for the same reason: when Odysseus visits Achilles in the underworld and compliments him on appearing to be a king there, Achilles is outraged. He says: 'Don't you know that it's sweeter to be alive - in any shape or form - than lord of all these shadows?'

It is an unusual book for a woman to have written: Cook seems to see with a man's eyes. It is as if the writing itself were a heroic enterprise. She writes unflinchingly about death and her occasional imagery is always arresting. (She describes, for instance, a 'sumptuous' hatred spreading through a body 'like cream'.)

She writes about love unflinchingly, too. Love involves challenges of every kind: there is a particularly seductive chapter in which Achilles, gorgeously disguised as a girl in silks, is uncovered - in every sense - by his friend Deidamia when the two go swimming together.

Water and love converge again when Achilles's father, the mortal King Peleus, makes love to the sea goddess Thetis. This chapter is a terrifying, erotic tour de force, an elemental tussle in which water becomes fire, fire becomes flesh and love resembles war.

Love often resembles war in this book. Cook writes beautifully about ambivalence, about loving the thing you hate. Achilles looks at Hector before killing him as if at a lover, seen in the sun. Later, he is transfixed by Hector's shining corpse that looks eerily alive. And when Achilles rides on horseback with Penthiseleia, the queen of the Amazons, she is at once enemy and object of desire. Allied to this is the examination of fate and choice. Can we choose the people we love? We are asked to consider this: 'The way to make your fate is to choose it.'

There is an athletic imagination at work here, but it is in the final chapter that Cook takes her most dangerous leap - from Achilles to John Keats. At first, the idea that Keats, short and not obviously bellicose, should have felt any affinity with Achilles comes as a surprise. But Cook, with quotations to shield her story, shows how greatly Achilles affected Keats and through this connection ingeniously extends her meditation on mortality.

She describes Keats in an anatomy class looking at the brain. Her own knowledge is striking in itself and she writes as surely as a surgeon while at the same time allowing the fugitive spirit room: 'He remembers the os spehnoidis from Bell's engravings. It reminded him of a giant butterfly with ragged, opulent wings. He touches his temples to feel the furthest reach of the wings that span his head. Feels - Already with thee - his own capacity for flight.'

Keats takes a September walk on Hampstead Heath and finds a lock of hair hanging from a tree. The hair recalls the lock cut from Achilles's own head and the hair of the mourners, shed to adorn Achilles's dead body. Loss and gain are plaited together as ingeniously as hair within a Victorian mourning brooch. The chapter is autumnal yet celebratory too - of life passed on through the centuries.

At the Cottesloe last Tuesday, Colin Mace read from Achilles to a rapt audience. He found a dynamic humour in the work while preserving its urgency and precision. He was like a magnificent war reporter - bringing us news from another world.

webTitle: Observer review: Death in Holy Orders by PD James

fields.headline: Adam Dalgliesh does it again
fields.standfirst: PD James is back on form with the latest in the Adam Dalgliesh series, Death in Holy Orders
fields.trailText: PD James is back on form with the latest in the Adam Dalgliesh series, Death in Holy Orders
fields.body:
Death in Holy Orders
PD James
Faber and Faber £17.99, pp387

With Death in Holy Orders, PD James has returned to the crime novel seemingly rejuvenated by her recent journey into memoir. Following one or two rather uninspired fictional works, Adam Dalgliesh's latest outing marks a comprehensive return to form and possesses the confident interplay of classical discipline, contemporary morality and strong evocation of place that had hitherto distinguished James's novels in an increasingly overpopulated genre.

Writing for the most part within the conventions of the detective story, she has again proved its constraints to be a liberating force for the creative imagination, drawing on accepted generic elements - the central mysterious death, the closed circle of suspects - to produce a thoughtful, beautifully-written book which is far more complex than the sum of its parts.

Set in the claustrophobic atmosphere of an isolated Anglican theological college, Death in Holy Orders takes Dalgliesh back to his boyhood retreat to re-examine the accidental death verdict on a young student whose body has been discovered on the beach, smothered by a fall of sand.

Treating it as little more than a political exercise to satisfy a powerful parent, Dalgliesh, who has a convenient tendency to holiday at sites of suspicious death, looks forward to a nostalgic few days but is faced instead with an institution on the brink of extinction, its faith brought into question by the changing priorities of the modern church. As more deaths follow, including the brutal murder of the archdeacon, James builds an intense picture of the fear, rage and desperation experienced by a community under threat.

Her primary concern is invariably to expose the levelling quality of murder, the way in which it temporarily removes the supports of law and religion and faces people with the truth about themselves. But it is more than the murderous mind that interests her; ironically, the strength of this new book lies not so much in the revelation of the killer's motive as in the reasoning behind less extreme acts of kindness, love and hate. Even Dalgliesh, ever the most detached of men, is not immune: in his return to the place of his childhood and the awakening in him of compassion and sexuality, James has written an elegy to the complexities of human behaviour.

Whether it is the Thames or the East Anglian landscape, James has always been entranced by her setting and never more so than when describing the Suffolk coast. Here, the skies, the sea, the light are not so much a backdrop as a powerful testament to the enduring hold of the past, against which more transient human dramas are played out.

Moreover, in St Anselm's - isolated and exposed to the elements - she has created a perfect fusion of theme and setting: the physical erosion of its bricks and mortar are matched, blow for blow, by the more symbolic demise of an old style of faith and the emergence of a twenty-first century creed that has no place for mystery or for art, no desire for heaven and no fear of hell.

James has by no means traded in the whodunit for a discussion on the future of the Church of England (Death in Holy Orders is as consummately plotted as any of her books), but she has added another dimension to the genre, one that refuses to indulge in the comforting illusion that death is a mystery which can be solved or that law and justice are inevitably the same thing.

Writing for the most part within the conventions of the detective story, she has again proved its constraints to be a liberating force for the creative imagination, drawing on accepted generic elements - the central mysterious death, the closed circle of suspects - to produce a thoughtful, beautifully-written book which is far more complex than the sum of its parts. Set in the claustrophobic atmosphere of an isolated Anglican theological college, Death in Holy Orders takes Dalgliesh back to his boyhood retreat to re-examine the accidental death verdict on a young student whose body has been discovered on the beach, smothered by a fall of sand. Treating it as little more than a political exercise to satisfy a powerful parent, Dalgliesh, who has a convenient tendency to holiday at sites of suspicious death, looks forward to a nostalgic few days but is faced instead with an institution on the brink of extinction, its faith brought into question by the changing priorities of the modern church. As more deaths follow, including the brutal murder of the archdeacon, James builds an intense picture of the fear, rage and desperation experienced by a community under threat. Her primary concern is invariably to expose the levelling quality of murder, the way in which it temporarily removes the supports of law and religion and faces people with the truth about themselves. But it is more than the murderous mind that interests her; ironically, the strength of this new book lies not so much in the revelation of the killer's motive as in the reasoning behind less extreme acts of kindness, love and hate. Even Dalgliesh, ever the most detached of men, is not immune: in his return to the place of his childhood and the awakening in him of compassion and sexuality, James has written an elegy to the complexities of human behaviour. Whether it is the Thames or the East Anglian landscape, James has always been entranced by her setting and never more so than when describing the Suffolk coast. Here, the skies, the sea, the light are not so much a backdrop as a powerful testament to the enduring hold of the past, against which more transient human dramas are played out. Moreover, in St Anselm's - isolated and exposed to the elements - she has created a perfect fusion of theme and setting: the physical erosion of its bricks and mortar are matched, blow for blow, by the more symbolic demise of an old style of faith and the emergence of a twenty-first century creed that has no place for mystery or for art, no desire for heaven and no fear of hell. James has by no means traded in the whodunit for a discussion on the future of the Church of England (Death in Holy Orders is as consummately plotted as any of her books), but she has added another dimension to the genre, one that refuses to indulge in the comforting illusion that death is a mystery which can be solved or that law and justice are inevitably the same thing.

webTitle: Observer review: Fabulous Time by Christina Koning

fields.headline: She's gone to seed, he's gone to pot
fields.standfirst: Sandy gets more than he bargained for from a slice of chocolate cake in Christina Koning's Fabulous Time
fields.trailText: Sandy gets more than he bargained for from a slice of chocolate cake in Christina Koning's Fabulous Time
fields.body:
Fabulous Time
Christina Koning
Viking £12.99, pp288
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Fabulous Time is a showcase for Christina Koning's literary dexterity, but it's not necessarily the sort of novel that will go down well with fans of her last novel, Undiscovered Country, a dreamily menacing account of expat life in Venezuela in the 1950s. Where that was atmospheric and gradual, this is fast and flippant, full of grotesques, caricatures and ghosts. Readers who closed Undiscovered Country with a sigh may find the follow-up easier to leave. Smart, cruel and brittle, it's a country-house farce, full of shabby furniture and shabbier behaviour.

At the opening of Fabulous Time, we seem to be in Molly Keane territory. It's the end of the Sixties and Sandy, an ageing antique dealer on his uppers, is on his way to see his widowed aunt, Constance, who lives alone and shambolically in Sussex, breakfasting on tap water and stale bread from the goats' scrap bucket. Next to Sandy in the Morris Minor is his heart's desire, Ray, a sulky 22-year-old forger who will settle for nothing less than a sugar daddy. Though Connie seems barely to register their arrival, it throws her niece, Iseult, a plain, grim innocent in her fifties who still nurses a crush on Sandy, into a terrible tiz.

Bad food served in cracked tureens, elderly spaniels that make horrid smells, mildew and dust, fish paste and the Monkees - Koning is good at all of this. She is also good at lifting the lid on her misfits' interior lives. Sandy, besotted with vicious little Ray; Ray, scenting that Connie plans to leave her nephew a fortune; Connie, drifting off into her scandalous past in Shanghai; Iseult, desperate to impress her cousin with an invitation to tea, then being caught in flowery dress, grey socks and brogues, weeping over a tray of burnt scones.

All of the characters, even Ray, who never develops beyond a stereotype, are, to some degree, prisoners of their past. Realising that she has scuppered a moment of intimacy with Sandy, Iseult thinks: 'But that was the way life went. One never knew until the moment was past how important the moment had been.' The moments that stay with you in this novel are the ones in the lively middle section, when Molly Keane gives way to a rather enjoyable Midsummer Night's Dream romp. Connie's houseparty, out for a picnic, collides with a Stones-like rock group (lots of kohl, velvet and feather boas) shooting an album cover on the coast, and the world turns upside down, transformed by marijuana rather than magic.

Having put away a large slab of the rock group's 'chocolate' cake, Sandy heads off for a walk. 'Beneath his feet, the chalky stones sparkle like diamonds, shooting out iridescent fragments which adhere to everything around - the grass, the rocks, even Sandy's shoes, which now glitter as bright as Dorothy's ruby slippers.'

After this, when things return to abnormal normal again, it's a little disappointing, but Koning is a merciless observer and the best bits of this novel are very good indeed.

fields.headline: The Diamond geezer
fields.standfirst: The writer John Diamond died on Friday after a long battle with cancer. His journalism and broadcasting touched the lives of millions. Here,  Victoria Coren, his friend and collaborator, remembers the man who was 'loved beyond description'
fields.trailText: The writer John Diamond died on Friday after a long battle with cancer. His journalism and broadcasting touched the lives of millions. Here, Victoria Coren, his friend and collaborator, remembers the man who was 'loved beyond description'
fields.body:
Of all the ironies surrounding John Diamond's throat cancer (the broadcaster who lost his voice; the brilliant cook's husband who couldn't eat), perhaps the greatest was that, although usually the only person in the room with a terminal illness, he always seemed the most alive.

You always saw him first in a crowd, his blaze of blond hair and dandy suits picking him out like a lighthouse in fog; a cluster of people roaring with laughter as John scribbled jokes and observations on a pocket pad faster and more engagingly than anyone else could speak. He laughed a lot, for a dying man: he laughed a lot for any man. He moved in a crackle of energy and wit. If you or I could take only liquids, through a syringe into a stomach tube, we would huddle self-pityingly at home. For John, the only question was how to get champagne down the tube without losing the fizz?

At one party, he was approached by a matre d' who took the syringe, gently decanted champagne into the body of the instrument, waited for the head to settle, topped it up, re-inserted the plunger, handed it back, clicked his heels and bobbed his head. With a grin, John scribbled across his notebook: 'Now that's what I call a matre d' !'

You came to forget, as his lightning fingers flashed across the page, that there was anything unusual in a man writing his side of the conversation on paper. Frustrating though he found it, not being able to chip in out loud like everyone else, he was tickled by the idea of written chat, half the dialogue recorded always for posterity. Hungover after a party, he would flick back through the notebook and mutter: 'Did I really say that to him ?' or, more thoughtfully: 'Why on earth do I have here, "My parents bought him an alabaster hunchback in 1968"?'

It was risky though, because John loved gossip, was sought by every social circle going, and always knew the latest scandals; tabloid editors would kill to get their hands on those notebooks.

This wasn't a public front; he was equally merry at home. Due in large part to the inspiring temperament and determination of his wonderful wife, Nigella Lawson, John's house was always full of people: laughing, chatting, frequently drunk, relishing the opulent meals which her magic hands could rustle up last-minute when she'd been expecting three people and 20 had turned up.

I haven't been in many homes of the terminally ill, but it must be rare to find one so glowingly warm and happy, buzzing with fun and games, with children skipping about in fancy dress, grown-ups betting on Scrabble. Every day felt like Christmas Day; it was somewhere you always wanted to be. The title of Nigella's book, How to Be a Domestic Goddess, was an ironic one, but, John said: 'It isn't ironic to me.'

He never lost interest in other people, however trivial our traumas seemed compared to his. Even as he lay in a lead-lined room last autumn, blasted for a solid week with radiation so strong that no visitor was allowed to stay longer than 15 minutes, he wanted to spend those 15 minutes hearing about your problems. He managed to blend an incredible amount of kindness and love for his friends with a staggering forthrightness towards those he didn't like. With months to live, John wasn't going to waste any time; if he thought someone was a bad man, he'd tell them straight. And 'bad man' is not the phrase he'd use. People who had mistreated his friends, or voiced an inexcusable opinion, would look down at that notebook and blanch. Social cowards among us looked on, and wished we dared do the same.

But John had no interest in becoming an oracle, or claiming some profound world vision as he walked through that valley. When he started writing about his cancer in the Times, the subject matter was ghastly but the style still the same old John - sparkling, witty, mischievous, unsaintly, just as he was in real life. He didn't embrace religion in his illness, only superstition ('I describe myself as a Jewish agnostic,' he said. 'I would say "atheist" but what would God think?') and he didn't scuttle to the spurious comfort of new-age 'alternative' remedies either.

In fact, this became a fervent cause of his - to defend the traditional, qualified medics he admired at the Royal Marsden, and wave the banner against quacks, cranks and magic potions sprinkled at midnight. He was assailed by angry post from people 'enclosing the oil of the Kovali tree, and books called Why Your Doctor Hates You And Wants You To Die . This was only grist to the mill, of course. He once stumbled across another John Diamond, who writes books recommending alternative treatments for cancer. John said: 'It's a bit like Ann Widdecombe discovering she shares her name with a kissogram girl in Widnes.'

Neither was there time to be precious. John shrugged off the accusations of those who considered his cancer confessionals inappropriate; he ignored the petty newspaper attacks written by meretricious, small-minded hacks who, instead of being inspired by John's powerful, brilliant journalism, continued to voice any half-baked opinion for a fee. Was this because he knew their bitchy witterings were in tomorrow's cat-litter tray, while his astonishing journalistic achievement would be remembered for ever? No, actually, it wasn't.

It is true that he received thousands of letters from cancer patients and their families, paying tribute to the comfort and joy they took from his writing. It is true that nobody had ever written with such frank wit, style, grace and insight on an illness which touches us all in one way or another. It is true that his words helped dismantle the taboos around cancer; persuaded people not to fear open discussion; persuaded doctors not to be mealy-mouthed and dainty with patients. But you wouldn't hear that from John, who said, modestly, that he wrote about cancer because it made life easier for him , that he was amazed and grateful for the outlet. 'The only reason I write about it,' he once said, 'is because I can.'

So his ability to dismiss the naysayers was nothing to do with smugness, merited though that would have been. He just had bigger things to think about. When Robert Katz and I adapted his work for the stage, John watched his life unfold in front of him and said only: 'Yep. I like it. But that guitar... it should really be a banjo.'

We were in the middle of readapting the play for the BBC, and John was going to be in it. His was, of course, a non-speaking role. John was excited; he used to teach drama before he became a journalist, loved performance of any kind, and always wanted to act. He said he wanted us to go ahead with the project if he died, so I suppose we will, but it won't be half as good without John. Then again, nothing will be.

They were strangely carefree, cancerous days. Confident that he'd provided sufficiently for his adored family, John merrily gambled the rest on blackjack, took his beautiful wife and children on a succession of holidays, and celebrated his frightening weight loss with a wardrobe of fresh designer suits in his new size. He got a tattoo and bleached his hair. When the illness was first confirmed, he bought himself another Harley-Davidson. Blushing as he confessed to Nigella, he observed: 'What was she going to say? That I'd kill myself on it?' When the cancer returned for the last time, he upgraded to a Roller.

I introduced him to a casino, a fairly low-rent basement joint, certainly not one of those top-drawer Mayfair places, but John wasn't fussy. My God, those other gamblers (gloomy addicts in trouble and cheap tweed) would stare when Diamond came in, usually with two or three glamorous blonde friends and a TV star or two, to chuckle over a game of casino stud. Nigella was indulgent about John's daffy hobby, happily leaving him to it; but occasionally she too came along, looking just like Claudia Cardinale in black velvet trousers. John gazed proudly across as she placed her bets, and for a moment you'd swear you were in a beautiful black-and-white 1950s film, not a smoke-filled, garishly-carpeted West London basement full of slot-machines.

But terminal illness, like his favourite vodka and water, doesn't alter the sufferer's character, only exaggerates his essence. In cancer veritas, John was never going to be a cautious man. Life was about indulgence, not denial, and he was damned if his (or his family's) fun was going to be compromised by that stupid illness.

And it wasn't. He derived an intense happiness just from watching his children splash in a paddling pool, or trying a new school uniform, or just from looking at Nigella across a room. He told me once that, after 10 years together, he still felt a secret thrill that he was allowed to go home with her.

And cancer or not, his presence was always a delight, his tangible air of recklessness and mischief made everything sparkle. I used to feel a physical surge of pleasure, when I walked into a party and saw that midnight-blue, crushed-velvet Katherine Hamnett suit and blond crop shining under the light; that always meant it was going to be a great evening. Everyone felt the same: he was loved beyond description.

Of course he was angry sometimes, and scared, and unhappy. When he learned, in January 1999, that the cancer was going to prove terminal, he wrote: 'I thought I'd be terrified when I got this news, but what I feel most of all is sad.' He was sad for himself and sad, above all, for the darling family with whom he was so desperate to remain.

But with the help of Nigella, Cosima and Bruno, he had a quite incredible capacity for finding joy along the way. When you looked at him, you didn't see sadness - you saw colour and light, dazzle and spirit, charm and laughter. He just shone . When John walked into a room it was like Pleasantville; the monochrome would give way to a ripple of blues and greens, pinks and golds. Without him, it's just grey.

Now I keep thinking of that bit from Tennyson:

He is not here; but far away
The noise of life begins again,
And ghastly through the drizzling rain
On the bald street breaks the blank day.

And John would say: 'The piece is fine, Toria. Just don't put that bloody maudlin quote on the end.'

Victoria Coren's play, A Lump In My Throat, based on the writings of John Diamond, was produced last year in London and Edinburgh

fields.headline: 'John's illness was unusually cruel'
fields.standfirst: Salman Rushdie recalls a loyal friend and the funniest of men
fields.trailText: Salman Rushdie recalls a loyal friend and the funniest of men
fields.body:
John Diamond taught me how to use a computer, hooked me on Apple Macs and served for many years as my computer maven - 'Dr Modem' - to whom I would turn every time my ignorance or stupidity prevented me from solving some glitch that had developed in my machine.

If a writer were to say of someone: 'He taught me how to hold a pen', that person's importance in the writer's life would immediately become apparent. That's what John did for me. He told me how to hold this pen.

He was also, as I'm sure many others will say, a loyal pal and one of the funniest men I knew. His and Nigella's wedding cake was a Ruth Rogers masterpiece that had apparently been designed by Richard Rogers. (It looked a bit like the Starship Enterprise.) John said: 'If this is a Rogers cake, shouldn't all the ingredients be on the outside?'

So much about John's illness was unusually cruel. For a man with such a quick tongue to all but lose the power of speech was one of the greatest cruelties of all.

He was a man who loved many things - John Rocha suits, expensive motor cars, and the wine and food that he was denied for so long. But he never fell in love with anything the way he fell for Nigella. And John's love - absolute, unconditional, passionate - was the rock on which Nigella built her family.

They will have to do without it now, but they know it was there. And we know.

And will remember.

He was a man who loved many things - John Rocha suits, expensive motor cars, and the wine and food that he was denied for so long. But he never fell in love with anything the way he fell for Nigella. And John's love - absolute, unconditional, passionate - was the rock on which Nigella built her family. They will have to do without it now, but they know it was there. And we know. And will remember.

webTitle: Observer review: The Geometry of Love by Margaret Visser

fields.headline: The virtue of being virgo intacta
fields.standfirst: Margaret Visser explores the little church of St Agnes just outside Rome in The Geometry of Love, but gets lost in mists of piety
fields.trailText: Margaret Visser explores the little church of St Agnes just outside Rome in The Geometry of Love, but gets lost in mists of piety
fields.body:
The Geometry of Love
Margaret Visser
Viking £18.99, pp323
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Chopping onions and wondering why they stung her eyes, Margaret Visser inadvertently began to uncover the 'anthropology of everyday life'. Books like Much Depends on Dinner examine the cultural history of meals and foodstuffs, but in this new study she explores a building - the church of St Agnes, outside the walls of Rome. In an epigraph, Socrates marvels that writers exalt 'everyday commodities' such as salt, but dodge the big subjects, none bigger than holy love. Although circling around a little church just off the tourist trail, The Geometry of Love reaches to the heavens, looking for the kingdom of God as reflected in a small building dedicated to a 12-year-old girl.

On St Agnes's Eve, maidens prayed to glimpse their future husbands. Agnes is the maiden's patroness because she refused to marry a Roman prefect's son and was bundled into a brothel, where she was killed, her throat possibly pierced by a sword. Her tomb attracted pilgrims and a church was built above it during the seventh century.

Visser is attracted by Christianity as a religion of paradoxes, and a church is paradox built in brick, a structure fixed in space that enacts a journey through time, a symbolic voyage into eternal light. Much of this church sits below ground and the descent into its pink and grey interior begins Visser's voyage through the nave towards the altar and its cup clustering the mystery of Eucharist, towards Agnes's tomb.

It is a pilgrim's progress heavily freighted with meaning. Symbolism clusters at every step, a densely researched mosaic detailing the language of bells, of fruits, indeed of mosaics themselves, as linguistics meet architecture and wide-ranging iconography. Catholicism gives the enterprise solemnity and commitment, but the zest of Visser's earlier writing is subsumed in awe. Scepticism continually stubs its toe on piety. We learn that early Christians looted columns for their churches from pagan monuments, but this endearing odd-jobbery is piously tidied into a symbol of Christianity's embrace of diversity.

So tight is the weave of this divine pattern that you grab for relief at quirks and happenstance - the seventeenth-century popes carried off by colds caught at Sant'Agnese, or the drinking club of Dutch artists who scratched graffiti into the adjoining church. Their misbehaviour might explain Visser's sniffiness towards visitors who treat churches as galleries with high-class atmospherics. She decrees: 'Religious art is religious before it is art' and earnestly defends Catholic kitsch ofbleeding hearts and relics.

Her polite refusal to prioritise between the information she unearths makes this book unexpectedly wearisome. Only in the closing pages, when the glimpses of Agnes coalesce into argument, does she take issue with the Church and its veneration of the virgin martyr, its insistence that she died intacta, as if assault in the brothel would have polluted her sainthood. I won't wander through a church in the same way again, but with a stronger sense of faithless exclusion. Visser leaves no gap in the mosaic for detached curiosity.

webTitle: Maria Scott: Equitable's deal is a blow to with-profits

fields.headline: Equitable's deal is a blow to with-profits
fields.trailText: 'Is there no end to the bad news for Equitable Life investors? They are now being forced to accept a lower-grade form of bonus.'
fields.body:
Is there no end to the bad news for Equitable Life investors? They are now being forced to accept a lower-grade form of bonus.

Even if this results in improved long-term returns, as Equitable hopes, investors have every reason to feel sore. Around every corner a new problem looms. The latest turn is a shock not just to them but to anyone with money in a with-profits fund. Equitable is refusing to pay bonuses this year in the guaranteed form considered to be the backbone of a with-profits pension or savings scheme. This undermines the ethos of with-profits investments.

It would be interesting to see what the Office of Fair Trading would make of a contract that imbues directors with such discretion. The OFT is already considering whether the fine print Equitable is using to impose a 10 per cent penalty on withdrawals breaches the unfair contract legislation. The OFT's decision on this could affect with-profits contracts throughout the investment industry.

The Equitable crisis has also helped provoke an investigation by the Financial Services Authority into with- profit investments. This is focusing on firms' discretion over the running of the funds and the impenetrable way returns are paid and publicised.

Investors should not be panicked into pulling out. The complex charges and withdrawal penalties could leave them out of pocket.

But the latest twist at Equitable underlines the importance of the FSA's inquiry and should prompt anyone considering a new investment to look at alternatives.

Accountant PricewaterhouseCoopers sums it all up in a new assessment of with- profits. Equitable's crisis is not the end of with-profits, but it is the beginning of the end.

Means-testing is one of the hallmarks of the social security system as reshaped under Chancellor Gordon Brown, particularly for pensioners, and he is expected to return to this theme in Wednesday's Budget. He still has time, though, to consider a report from the Institute of Actuaries pointing out that it is impossible for lower earners to work out whether it is worthwhile to save at all if this only disqualifies them from means-tested state help.

Much better to provide a decent basic state pension.

webTitle: Microsoft's detour from cyberspace to wonder land

fields.headline: Microsoft's detour from cyberspace to wonder land
fields.standfirst:
More net news
Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: On the Richter scale it measured 8.5 in Seattle. No, not last Thursday's earthquake. The really seismic event occurred on Tuesday in the US Court of Appeal, currently home to the saga that Microsoft ridiculously calls the Department of Justice vs innovation and others describe as nothing less than the battle for the future of the internet.
fields.body:
On the Richter scale it measured 8.5 in Seattle. No, not last Thursday's earthquake. The really seismic event occurred on Tuesday in the US Court of Appeal, currently home to the saga that Microsoft ridiculously calls the Department of Justice vs innovation and others describe as nothing less than the battle for the future of the internet.

But it now looks as though Microsoft may have landed itself a Get Out Of Jail card, despite having been found guilty of using its monopoly powers to violate anti-trust articles. It is a remarkable turnaround. Only last June, District Court judge Thomas Penfield Jackson issued a final ruling, calling for the company to be split into two parts: one focused on building its operating system, the other on applications and the internet. Consumer groups were delighted.

But after two days of appeal hearings, you can see the tide turning in Microsoft's favour. Harry Edwards, chief judge at the US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, criticised Jackson's attacks on Bill Gates, saying judges had no right to 'go run off our mouths'.

Until now, Gates has been the arch villain in the biggest anti-trust trial of all time. His earlier court appearances drew so much flak that he was forced to relinquish his role at Microsoft. In addition, Microsoft last week appointed Rick Belluzzo as president. A former group vice-president, Belluzzo is seen as the man to open up a more consultative dialogue with the government.

So now it is Jackson who finds himself on the receiving end. Almost overnight, he has become the man who, in the incipient days of Dubya's laissez faire Republican administration, finds himself out in the cold, castigated for trying to break up the world's most successful company.

The problem for Jackson and the DoJ is that times have changed since the case against Microsoft was launched back in May 1998. Other big beasts, such as AOL Time Warner, are stalking. Suddenly, Microsoft doesn't look so scary, especially given that its market capitalisation has crashed from $600 billion to barely half that now.

Factor in a profits warning, analysts' downgrades and gloomy predictions from Intel and Dell, and you could argue, as Microsoft is trying to, that the context is entirely different to that of 12 months ago.

It is a confusing turn of events but, then, as Alan Greenspan once put it: 'The world of anti-trust is reminiscent of Alice's Wonderland: everything seemingly is, yet apparently isn't simultaneously.' Last week the Wonderland judiciary had a rethink.

webTitle: Morton faces the chop as critics round on 'failure to deliver'

fields.headline: Morton faces the chop as critics round on 'failure to deliver'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: transport in Britain
More about transport
fields.trailText: Rail chief Sir Alastair Morton's days at the Strategic Rail Authority (SRA) could be numbered following 'huge disappointment' on the part of the industry and the Government, writes Joanna Walters.
fields.body:
Rail chief Sir Alastair Morton's days at the Strategic Rail Authority (SRA) could be numbered following 'huge disappointment' on the part of the industry and the Government, writes Joanna Walters.

Morton and chief executive Mike Grant may not survive long after a general election. Support for the two has waned in the face of continuing delays in the delivery of a 'big vision' for rail, hold-ups in the refranchising of passenger services and a lack of firm direction .

Morton was appointed chairman by Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott early in 1999 with a brief to shake up passenger service standards, distribute public funding under new legislation and devise plans to expand the network. He is also helping the industry recover from the Hatfield crash.

He tried to reshape the industry, but is understood to believe the Government has been too slow with legislation and funding. Critics are frustrated at his refusal to dictate the shape of the industry. They also blame Grant for a 'lack of ideas'.

Senior sources close to the industry and Whitehall said that Transport Minister Lord Macdonald, rail regulator Tom Winsor, the train operators and Railtrack had all concluded that Morton 'has not delivered'.

A spokesman for the SRA said that talk about Morton and Grant leaving was 'speculation'.

fields.headline: The genesis of genius
fields.trailText: 'I've had to pop in a few times to explain that physical and verbal abuse is not as orthodox an optional part of being a chess grandmaster as wearing odd socks and wandering into the path of oncoming traffic in a fog of cerebral narcosis.'
fields.body:
Heaven knows I can be as doubting as the next Thomas when it comes to broadening the children's cranial horizons with daily doses of Cosi Fan Tutte and multivitamin supplements disguised as Liquorice Allsorts, but, hey, you have to start believing in something when you see the little chaps huddled over a chessboard discussing the kinetic properties of knights and bishops when Live and Kicking is still blaring away on a TV screen within walking distance.

'Pawns can't go sideways, you duhh,' the eldest is saying, to the accompaniment of someone else yowling. Well, yes, admittedly I've had to pop in a few times to explain that physical and verbal abuse is not as orthodox an optional part of being a grandmaster of the game as wearing odd socks and wandering into the path of oncoming traffic in a fog of cerebral narcosis, but on the whole I am impressed by their progress towards embracing the life of the mind. My wife too is delighted enough to point out, without being asked, that boys get their intelligence from their mothers, owing to women having a more sensible number of X chromosomes, which are apparently the natural habitat of the bits of DNA that decide whether you will be a rocket scientist when you grow up or one of those people who ring you when you're in the bath to ask if you'd like to buy a PVC double-glazed Edwardian-style conservatory.

'That's why men choose mates who are more intelligent than themselves,' explains my wife, who has a psychology degree from a reputable university and yet is mysteriously unable to open any item of processed food fitted with a ring-pull. She is no doubt about to tell me that she married me for my physique, and that ring-pulls were invented by someone who got his brains from his father, when the little one joins in the debate by suddenly going pale and throwing up over the sofa. We both immediately leap into action, my wife showing that a superior intellect need be no bar to kicking a bowl of Frosties across the room while I anticipate the next tidal wave of sick by wondering aloud whether this might be a good time to nip up to the village for a paper. No, apparently it would not.

But the little fellow is obviously going down with something horrible, so after a decent interval of helping to leave vomit footprints all over the house, I volunteer to take the three other geniuses out to Stevenage for no good reason other than that our Hertfordshire Guide to Places of Unlikely Interest happens to be opened at the letter 'S'. But as it turns out Stevenage has a perfectly charming little museum with an interactive exhibition of how light behaves when children are allowed to switch things on and off for hours on end without being asked whether they have any idea how much electricity costs. We wind our way round the local history galleries, which reveal through judicious use of audiovisual archives the amazing story of how a sleepy country hamlet was magically transformed into a progressive New Town with abundant parking and leisure facilities simply by ignoring the wishes of the backward population and adding concrete.

I find the children laughing their heads off at a crackly recording of a woman talking about the early days of cinema when, it seems, the weekly film would be followed by someone doing a turd while holding a pig.

'Listen, Dad!' I listen, and then explain gently that the person in question is not doing a turd but a turn, which of course while still amusing is not quite as historically interesting. At last we file out, pausing to admire the country's only publicly held collection of sandpaper before eating our picnic in the doorway.

Just time to pop into the market for a copy of the Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? quiz book and we are soon continuing our pursuit of knowledge by pondering questions about whether trilbys are worn on the feet or if Sandringham has ever been the official residence of Bobby Davro. Hard to believe that this time last week they were making chimpanzee noises. Which, logically speaking, must come from their mother's side too.

webTitle: A deal gone down the Tube

fields.headline: A deal gone down the Tube
fields.standfirst:
Joanna Walters and Nick Mathiason on how the privatisation of the Underground came off the rails - and the political stakes of failing to reach a deal with Red Ken and his not so quiet American

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: 'The Government has done the impossible,' said an exasperated leader of one of the private consortiums bidding to run London's Underground this weekend. 'They've pissed everyone off.'
fields.body:
'The Government has done the impossible,' said an exasperated leader of one of the private consortiums bidding to run London's Underground this weekend. 'They've pissed everyone off.'

The bidder, representing some of the most powerful construction companies in the world, was fuming at the latest Government proposals to rescue the clapped-out Tube. 'When we saw it we thought it was a spoof. They haven't involved us in the process. It's unworkable. It's unbankable.'

Early in February, Bob Kiley, Mayor Ken Livingstone's transport chief for London, had supposedly been given a free run at remodelling the Government's controversial mechanism for modernising the Tube. That was until last Sunday, when he delivered a damning critique of the public-private partnership and suggested a simple alternative, a coherent management structure with a single point of responsibility.

Last Wednesday the Government sought to break the deadlock by unveiling its first serious modification to its treasured public private partnership - to univeral condemnation. A leaked briefing note from the Mayor's office said that 'the Government side has not understood the key issues at stake'.

Essentially the Government's 17 modifications stretch PPP to the limit. They allow Kiley to remove or veto the appointment of any chief executive of a private construction company contracted to run one of three bundles of Tube lines. They give Transport for London, the body that oversees all London's transport, which Kiley heads, the right to timetable improvements and remove key private sector managers if they are thought not up to the job.

The consortiums were in uproar. 'It impinges on our rights of ownership,' said one.

Many observers believe that Kiley and Livingstone should be beside themselves with joy at the major concessions they have won. But as the Mayor's briefing note says: 'It is not that the government proposals do not go far enough, but that they go down the wrong road'. What Kiley and Livingstone want is unified management control.

Kiley defines this as 'operations, maintenance and invesment priorities established by London Underground, and not three separate Infracos' (private sector consortiums responsible for track, signalling and tunnels). It is the pair's frustration at lack of progress on this point that has forced them to the brink of legal action against the Government. A preliminary hearing is expected within three weeks and a judicial review would last about 90 days, further delaying the PPP process.

Meanwhile, the Tube's biggest union, the RMT, is expected this Friday to confirm that it will be holding a series of one-day strikes, crippling the South-east's transport network up until May.

It had all seemed so simple a month ago. Then, in a ground-breaking agreement, Prescott appeared to give Kiley, considered to be one of the world's leading urban transport experts, the green light to resolve the impasse surrounding the Government's plans for the semi-privatisation of the woeful Tube system.

But on 12 February, a meeting between Kiley and top Treasury mandarin Shriti Vadera pulled the carpet from under Kiley. Under no circumstances would she sanction public control of the Tube. Any solution would have to be under the framework of the PPP. Just who would be responsible for safety, maintenance and timetabling massive upgrades was unclear.

'The only people rubbing their hands at this would be lawyers, accountants and management consultants,' said a senior Transport for London source. 'And they've never run a Tube system in their lives.'

Kiley this weekend formally rejected the Government's proposals. And Livingstone raised the ante. 'Bob Kiley is talking to some of the best transport operators in the world,' he said. 'They will not come to London if they are unable to manage the system in a unified fashion.'

Of course, there are ownership principles at stake here, plus billions of pounds and the welfare of 3 million passengers a day.

But the future of the Tube has always been something of a political football, and the issue is more deeply mired in politics now than it has ever been. The pantomime being played out here has a plot featuring a Faustian pact, a furious but seemingly impotent king, a joker and a mischievous hero.

The pact is between Brown and Prescott. Often opponents, many observers are intrigued to see these two heavyweight bruisers so publicly united in their determination to force a PPP solution for the Tube.

Brown has already built up his reputation as the Iron Chancellor and although the Government has conceded it will have to go on subsiding the Tube, to relinquish financial control to the public sector would be the last straw. And handing it over to Red Ken to boot...

So Brown, unsurprisingly, has dug his heels in. Whatever is negotiated over the next few weeks, Brown's bottom line is that the finished product will have the private sector in majority ownership of the infraco consortiums and the deal will be called a PPP.

What is more mysterious, however, is why Prescott is so passionate about PPP. The same applies to the Tube and for air traffic control where, in the face of widespread opposition, Prescott has stuck to the line that only a PPP will do.

Everyone agrees that Prescott has had to come a long way from his political grass roots to survive at the nucleus of New Labour. But even so it could reasonably be expected that his heart and soul would still be loyal to public sector ownership and control of public services. But he has a bargain to keep. After the last election he did a deal with Brown. Prescott would support the Treasury through thick and thin on the principle of PPP for the Tube, NATS and whatever if Brown would grant him two things.

First, that the leading publicly owned regional airports could be given the financial freedom to borrow money for expansion on the capital markets, rather than being hamstrung by the public sector borrowing requirement.

Second, that when Prescott brought in transport reforms allowing local authorities to charge motorists for driving into congested town centres or to tax them for parking at the workplace, the revenues would be fed exclusively back into transport improvements - so-called 'hypothecation'.

Brown agreed, handing Prescott two major policy triumphs early on in his role as Secretary of State for the Environment, Transport and the Regions. It is only now becoming clear the price he had to pay.

That is not the whole story, however. Prescott believes that as a true-new Labourite, he is in part the architect of PPP, the infamous Third Way. He has taken the Conservatives' private finance initiative and given it a more publicly accountable edge. For the Tube this means a pledge that after 30 years of being leased to the private sector, the network will be returned to public ownership. Throughout, the operation of the Tube will remain in the public sector, with the rights workers currently enjoy protected.

Both Prescott and, particularly, Brown are furious that Livingstone and Kiley have won over the media against the PPP, including the London Evening Standard and the Financial Times, by playing the aces of fair play, value for money and acerbic wit.

Livingstone is the hero, of course, so who's the joker? That'll be William Hague, who spun round spectacularly last week and announced that the Conservatives were dropping their policy of a sell-off of the Tube in favour of backing a Kiley-led solution. Did you ever?

That just leaves impotent King Tony. The Prime Minister's gut instinct is to secure a private sector future for the Tube. But he knows the 'people' have backed Ken and, with an election looming, has tried everything from calling his lieutenants in and banging their heads together to sending them off to charm Livingstone with orders to 'do a deal and keep Ken sane'. To no avail.

A judicial review is the last thing Blair needs and what should have been a minor irritation is threatening to become a major inconvenience.

If London shuns the talents of some of the best transport engineers and managers in the world, the public will hit the Government where it hurts. In the ballots.


£5bn lifeline for Ken's tube
Underground needs to mind the big gaps
fields.bodyText: 'The Government has done the impossible,' said an exasperated leader of one of the private consortiums bidding to run London's Underground this weekend. 'They've pissed everyone off.' The bidder, representing some of the most powerful construction companies in the world, was fuming at the latest Government proposals to rescue the clapped-out Tube. 'When we saw it we thought it was a spoof. They haven't involved us in the process. It's unworkable. It's unbankable.' Early in February, Bob Kiley, Mayor Ken Livingstone's transport chief for London, had supposedly been given a free run at remodelling the Government's controversial mechanism for modernising the Tube. That was until last Sunday, when he delivered a damning critique of the public-private partnership and suggested a simple alternative, a coherent management structure with a single point of responsibility. Last Wednesday the Government sought to break the deadlock by unveiling its first serious modification to its treasured public private partnership - to univeral condemnation. A leaked briefing note from the Mayor's office said that 'the Government side has not understood the key issues at stake'. Essentially the Government's 17 modifications stretch PPP to the limit. They allow Kiley to remove or veto the appointment of any chief executive of a private construction company contracted to run one of three bundles of Tube lines. They give Transport for London, the body that oversees all London's transport, which Kiley heads, the right to timetable improvements and remove key private sector managers if they are thought not up to the job. The consortiums were in uproar. 'It impinges on our rights of ownership,' said one. Many observers believe that Kiley and Livingstone should be beside themselves with joy at the major concessions they have won. But as the Mayor's briefing note says: 'It is not that the government proposals do not go far enough, but that they go down the wrong road'. What Kiley and Livingstone want is unified management control. Kiley defines this as 'operations, maintenance and invesment priorities established by London Underground, and not three separate Infracos' (private sector consortiums responsible for track, signalling and tunnels). It is the pair's frustration at lack of progress on this point that has forced them to the brink of legal action against the Government. A preliminary hearing is expected within three weeks and a judicial review would last about 90 days, further delaying the PPP process. Then, in a ground-breaking agreement, Prescott appeared to give Kiley, considered to be one of the world's leading urban transport experts, the green light to resolve the impasse surrounding the Government's plans for the semi-privatisation of the woeful Tube system. But on 12 February, a meeting between Kiley and top Treasury mandarin Shriti Vadera pulled the carpet from under Kiley. Under no circumstances would she sanction public control of the Tube. Any solution would have to be under the framework of the PPP. Just who would be responsible for safety, maintenance and timetabling massive upgrades was unclear. 'The only people rubbing their hands at this would be lawyers, accountants and management consultants,' said a senior Transport for London source. 'And they've never run a Tube system in their lives.' Kiley this weekend formally rejected the Government's proposals. And Livingstone raised the ante. 'Bob Kiley is talking to some of the best transport operators in the world,' he said. 'They will not come to London if they are unable to manage the system in a unified fashion.' Of course, there are ownership principles at stake here, plus billions of pounds and the welfare of 3 million passengers a day. Brown has already built up his reputation as the Iron Chancellor and although the Government has conceded it will have to go on subsiding the Tube, to relinquish financial control to the public sector would be the last straw. webTitle: Underground needs to mind the big gaps

fields.headline: Underground needs to mind the big gaps
fields.standfirst:
In the fourth of our series, we ask if PPP could ever keep the Tube's head above water

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: It was former Treasury mandarin Sir Steve Robson who invented the Government's controversial public private partnership for the Tube.
fields.body:
It was former Treasury mandarin Sir Steve Robson who invented the Government's controversial public private partnership for the Tube.

Robson, whose previous claim to fame was devising the now discredited British Rail privatisation, thought the best way to run an underground was to split the management between operators and infrastructure.

Tracks, signalling and stations were split, under Robson's plan, into three separate parcels, to be run by the private sector for 30 years while a public body was responsible for running the trains.

Private sector consortiums would take the commercial risk and invest the necessary cash, thought to be £7 billion, to refurbish the creaking network.

The consortiums would then charge London Underground for running trains over their tracks and infrastructure. They would also pocket a Treasury subsidy of up to £6bn over 30 years.

The idea was to transfer risk on the cost of modernisation from the public to the private sector and lever some cash into a system in desperate need of overhaul.

But PPP has been slated by the Industrial Society, an independent think tank, and by the Government's own spending watchdog, the National Audit Office.

What galls London Mayor Ken Livingstone and Bob Kiley, head of Transport for London (TfL), formerly London Transport, is that PPP is a very expensive refurbishment tool: the consortiums' lending rating is BBB, against TfL's AA. They believe its split management structure increases the risk of a repetition of the Hatfield rail disaster and will lead to constant contractual disputes between the various consortiums.

What's more, performance targets for PPP bidders are actually 5 per cent below current service levels. Were PPP to go ahead under its present form, the consortiums can hardly fail to make lucrative bonuses and would have little incentive to improve the Tube's increasingly poor levels of punctuality, frequency and reliability.

At no point during the process has London Underground completed an inventory of the clapped-out assets that it will pass on to the bidders; this gives rise to fears of huge cost overruns.

Kiley fears that should the companies responsible for maintaining the Underground infrastructure find problems with the tracks and signalling, they will inflate the price of contracts. One potentially calamitous threat to the safety of the Underground is the ongoing rise in the capital's water table. This threatens eventually to flood tunnels and weaken embankments, causing millions of pounds of damage.

Under PPP contracts, it is not clear whether the private sector would bear any of the risk to track, tunnels and signals, even though on paper this is their sphere of responsibility. Finally, a system of 30-year contracts gives Transport for London, to whom the Underground will be transferred, no flexibility should there be unexpected changes to London's transport requirements.

In a report by the Industrial Society last September, it was revealed that private consortiums could expect to reap a handsome 15.3 per cent return through the PPP.Ultimately, the reason Londoners voted for Livingstone to be their Mayor was that they wanted a publicly owned Underground system with a unified management structure that had the power and resources to undertake a thorough modernisation programme.

This weekend it seems only lengthy and costly court action will determine whether they get their wish.

A deal gone down the Tube

fields.headline: Family fortunes
fields.standfirst:
Oliver Morgan on how different groups have fared under four years of Labour

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Oliver Morgan on how different groups have fared under four years of Labour.
fields.body:
When Chancellors make Budget announcements, drinkers, smokers and drivers generally make the front pages. The effect of technical adjustments to taxes and benefits tend to merit mention in the small print of learned journals, if at all.

Gordon Brown is accused of being a Chancellor at a loose end after putting macroeconomics on autopilot, and of filling his time by tinkering with details which only serve to make people more and more confused by the tax system.

But the impact on some families of the Chancellor's measures has been marked - even if it has not been noticed by those higher up the income scale.

To shed light on the effects of his changes on the families, The Observer commissioned Holly Sutherland, senior research officer at Cambridge University's department of applied economics, to run a series of test cases through the computer model used by her microsimulation unit. The results appear below.

Four hypothetical examples were chosen, reflecting people with different incomes, marital status, numbers of children and whether they owned their homes.

In each case, Sutherland fed in a range of incomes, with no family member working, or with one in work.

The poorer family

Family one is at the bottom of the income scale. In case A there is no one in paid work, putting it in the bottom tenth of the population in terms of income. With two children, aged nine and 12, increases in Income Support and Child Benefit produce a rise in weekly income of £20.80, or 10.2 per cent. With no one going out to work, there is no benefit from the Working Families' Tax Credit.

In case B the same family has one member working full-time on the minimum wage, putting the family in the second tenth of the income scale.

A higher initial income of £233.43 has increased by £23.57, or 10 per cent. Reductions in national insurance and increases in child benefit are part of the rise. WFTC also comes into play, but this is offset by reductions in housing benefit and council tax benefit.

The lone parent

The abolition of lone-parent benefits was considered a misjudgment by the Chancellor. But outright abolition affects only those who have become lone parents since the measure was introduced. In Family Two, the parent was single then so the entitlement has been reduced, not ended.

In case A the parent is not in work, and the family falls into the third tenth of the wealth scale. Income increased by £12.10 from £138.30, or 8.7 per cent. In case B, the family is halfway up the scale because of single status with the parent working 38 hours on minimum wage. Income rises £19.92, or 9.9 per cent, from £201.04. This is thanks to WFTC, offset by a housing benefit cut. Lower NI and income tax help.

The childless homeowners

Family three, an owner-occupier household, has no children. It has therefore suffered in two ways: the end of mortgage interest tax relief and the end of Married Couple's Allowance (MCA), to be replaced by the Children's Tax Credit, available only to parents.

In case A, with no one in paid work, there is no change to income: raised benefits have been aimed at those with children. Case B, where one of the couple works, is in the lowest tenth of incomes, below the family with no one in work. Case A has its mortgage interest payments covered by income support, but this disappears when work is found, as in case B. This is the 'unemployment trap', which obstructs Brown's efforts to encourage people into work, and an argument for a higher minimum wage.

Case B sees income fall £5.72 a week, or 4 per cent, from £141.08. Lost mortgage tax relief and MCA is offset by cuts in income tax rates. In case C, half-way up the income scale, £4.68 (1.7 per cent) is lost from £275.23 a week, due again to lost mortgage relief and MCA, but the fall is broken by lower income tax.

The family with children

Family four has most children, and stands to gain most from the measures targeted at the young. However, the effects depend on income.

In case A, with one full-time employee on the minimum wage, the increase is £9.10, or 3.2 per cent on income of £284.01. The extra is from a small WFTC increase offset by a council tax benefit reduction, an increase in child benefit and an NI cut, offset by lost mortgage tax relief.

Case B, with one employee on £18,000 a year, sees the largest increase for this family type: £31.99 (9.8 per cent) on £325.83 of income. This comes from the effects of the WFTC, increases in child benefit and a fall in NI payments.

In case C, the net effect of a small NI increase, a tax reduction and a child benefit increase delivers £4.94 more income, or 1 per cent of the £461.27 a week it earned.

For case D, the richest family in the exercise, factors like those in case C deliver a 0.7 per cent rise on a weekly income of £820.35.

fields.headline: UFO's
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Since the dawn of man, it seems we have been looking to the skies to prove that we are not alone...
fields.body:
Since the dawn of man, it seems we have been looking to the skies to prove that we are not alone, or so prehistoric cave spacecraft-like carvings such as those in Hunan province of China suggest to many of those at the tenth Annual International UFO Congress Convention and Film which opens today in Laughlin, Nevada.

They are obviously spaceships, they say, though many of the rest of us may agree with the expert who told Winston Churchill nearly 50 years ago that all the evidence points to our universal solitude.

1. In 1322 a 'pillar of fire' was seen over the sky in Uxbridge

2. In 1948 the US Air Force opened a file called Project Blue Book. When it ended in 1969 it had reports of 12,618 UFO sightings

3. In 1997 the CIA admitted it encouraged reports of flying saucers in the 1950s to obscure trials of top-secret U-2 and Blackbird spyplanes

4. More than half of all Americans believe UFOs have landed on Earth

5. Since the early 1990s, Bonnybridge, near Falkirk, has been Britain's UFO capital, with some 2,000 of its 5,500 people claiming a sighting

6. In 1974 a couple in Avery, Essex, told of being held in a craft with 4ft tall creatures in coat-like gowns

7. In 2000, a man placed a £10 bet with William Hill that a UFO would land at the Millennium Dome. The odds were 50,000 - 1

8. Celebrity UFO spotters: Olivia Newton-John, Charlie Sheen

9. Join: The National UFO Research Association 01924-444049

10. Watch: Independence Day, Men in Black, Alien, X-Files

Compiled by Dorota Nosowicz
