webTitle: Heather Connon: Tumbling shares are still not cheap

fields.headline: Tumbling shares are still not cheap
fields.trailText: 'Many private investors had rushed into technology funds, but even the best-performing has lost money and the worst - Framlington Net Net - is down almost two-thirds.'
fields.body:
Private investors put 20 per cent less into equities Isas in January compared with a year ago, and who can blame them? Many had rushed into technology funds, but even the best-performing has lost money and the worst - Framlington Net Net - is down almost two-thirds.

Those who avoided technology have not fared that well either. The FTSE 100 index is 2.5 per cent lower than this time last year and has fallen around 400 points in the past month alone. Companies are falling over themselves to issue profit warnings - more than 40 so far this year, against 77 in the whole of 2000. And the US is teetering on recession. The surprise is that private investors are risking the market at all.

Most analysts are still bullish, but few can even remember what a bear market feels like. This time round, however, there are signs that professional investors are nervous, mainly because of the US.

The news from software, telecoms and computer hardware companies is unremittingly gloomy. Stocks are too high, demand has collapsed, debts - particularly in the case of telecoms - are crippling. The worst may be yet to come: many technology companies appear to have paid each other in kind, or through soft loans. Some may need to raise new money from shareholders to break out of these webs.

Technology shares may have collapsed, but they are still not cheap.Steve Russell, equity strategist with HSBC, calculates that their share prices are assuming earnings will grow by 10 per cent a year for the next decade. Even without the threat of a US recession, that is optimistic. One US researcher has calculated that, if share prices were to return to their historic valuation multiples, the Nasdaq could more than halve. In other sectors, too, share prices are assuming the US downturn will be short and shallow. That is certainly not guaranteed - US consumer giant Procter & Gamble said the economic crisis in Turkey would slow growth.

Professional investors are seeking out safe havens - utilities, drug companies and food retailers - whose profits are not much affected by downturns. Private investors should follow suit: Boots, Next, Severn Trent and Compass still look attractive.

Better still, wait until it is clear what is happening in the US, or invest via a regular savings scheme.

Stocks are too high, demand has collapsed, debts - particularly in the case of telecoms - are crippling. The worst may be yet to come: many technology companies appear to have paid each other in kind, or through soft loans. Some may need to raise new money from shareholders to break out of these webs. Technology shares may have collapsed, but they are still not cheap.Steve Russell, equity strategist with HSBC, calculates that their share prices are assuming earnings will grow by 10 per cent a year for the next decade. Even without the threat of a US recession, that is optimistic. One US researcher has calculated that, if share prices were to return to their historic valuation multiples, the Nasdaq could more than halve. In other sectors, too, share prices are assuming the US downturn will be short and shallow. That is certainly not guaranteed - US consumer giant Procter & Gamble said the economic crisis in Turkey would slow growth. Professional investors are seeking out safe havens - utilities, drug companies and food retailers - whose profits are not much affected by downturns. Private investors should follow suit: Boots, Next, Severn Trent and Compass still look attractive. Better still, wait until it is clear what is happening in the US, or invest via a regular savings scheme.

fields.headline: Gordon's tonic: the hot tips
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: The Chancellor has until Tuesday to decide between a raft of policy options. In a room deep inside the Treasury, mandarins have costed a menu of measures on a large blackboard. Here are hot tips for those that will make it into Wednesday's Budget speech:
fields.body:
The Chancellor has until Tuesday to decide between a raft of policy options. In a room deep inside the Treasury, mandarins have costed a menu of measures on a large blackboard. Here are hot tips for those that will make it into Wednesday's Budget speech:

Very Likely

 Children's Tax Credit at a higher rate than the originally-planned £10 a week

 Working Families Tax Credit Uprating for adults and children

 Pensioners Personal income tax allowances for the over-65s up by £240 more than inflation in 2003-4, as proposed in the Pre-Budget Report

 Research and development tax credits Consultation on extending the current scheme for small firms to larger companies. Needed to overcome problems in design and European Union regulations. Extra tax credit for development of drugs aimed at Third World

 The minimum wage Up by 10 per cent to more than £4 an hour

 Fuel Duty on low-sulphur petrol cut by 2p, and low-sulphur diesel by 3p

 Intellectual property Switch to taxing IP, such as brands and patents, on an accounts basis rather than the current system of capital allowances to make investing in it more worthwhile

 Urban regeneration Implementation of package of credits, relief and reduced rates of VAT on renovations, as promised in the Pre-Budget Report

 The countryside Expect tax relief and credits aimed at re-energising agricultural areas stricken by foot-and-mouth disease and diversifying their output

Likely

 Maternity benefit Higher statutory maternity pay and paid maternity leave

 Share options Increase in the value of share options on which tax credits are available from £30,000 to £100,000

 Climate change levy Tweaks to its operation following strong lobbying from business

 Cars A rise in the engine-size of cars qualifying for the lower rate of vehicle excise duty (the windscreen tax disc) from 1200cc to 1500cc

 Lorries Cut in lorry vehicle excise duty, and a new 'Britdisc' for foreign hauliers operating in the UK

 Tobacco duty May rise

Possible

 Income tax Widening of the 10p band to £1,800. Above-inflation increase in tax thresholds responsible for pushing too many people into high tax brackets

 Reform of the professions This includes an end to the ban on lawyers entering partnerships with other professionals such as accountants

 Private contractors Tax breaks to ameliorate the criticised IR35, which sees freelances taxed as staff

 Shares A cut in stamp duty on small share purchases

webTitle: Giving credit where tax credit's due

fields.headline: Giving credit where tax credit's due
fields.standfirst:
Faisal Islam on the policy tool of choice for 'doing good' without giving pain to the Treasury

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Faisal Islam on the policy tool of choice for 'doing good' without giving pain to the Treasury.
fields.body:
When Gordon Brown talks of 'targeted tax cuts', what he means is tax credits. And this week's Budget will be awash with them. Like many of Brown's policies, they form part of the American public policy lexicon. Al Gore's presidential campaign repeatedly referred to his plans for tax credits as targeted tax cuts.

Tax credits are on offer for children, childcare, pensioners, and working families, as well as communities that invest, businesses that research, and pharmaceuticals companies that develop cheap drugs for the third world.

It's the policy tool of choice for the Chancellor of the Exchequer.

Want to coax the big pharmaceuticals companies to produce that malaria drug? Trying to persuade the poor to become 'deserving' by seeking work? Tax credits will 'incentivise' the promotion of virtue and the avoidance of sloth.

Simultaneously, tax credits can target state support to approved groups, and promote socially desirable economic behaviour. And credits can even make the public finances look more creditable.

But who gains? By and large, you need to be paying tax to benefit. This suggests you are not among the very poorest of society. Within households, benefits that used to go to mothers now increasingly become a credit on the tax bill of the father. Similarly, only profitable companies pay tax, so how do the loss-making startups benefit?

And here is the twist. Not all tax credits are actually credits, says independent think tank, the Institute for Fiscal Studies. Some, such as the Working Families' Tax Credit, are rebadged as benefit handouts. For businesses the credits are subsidies by another name - and this invites the attention of the EU.

But there is a flipside. The corollary of tax breaks for target groups and desirable business behaviour is the need for identification and proof of qualification. For individuals this means more complex forms and a massive expansion of means testing.

The fiendish complexity of claiming the credits may be putting people off. Nearly 2 million eligible parents failed to claim the existing children's tax credit by last week's deadline, despite an expensive and memorably annoying ad campaign featuring SuperDad.

The proposed integrated child credit will extend such testing from 2.5 million to 6 million families in 2003, says the Institute for Fiscal Studies. For businesses the need for identification means more dreaded red tape as the Government seeks to ensure credits are given only where they are due. Last week's National Association of Citizen's Advice Bureaux report on the Working Families Tax Credit showed that some people were losing jobs because small employers couldn't bear the regulatory burden.

This poses a conundrum for businesses leaders wanting to take advantage of, for example, the Research and Development tax credit.

As a tool for redistribution, tax credits are already having an effect. But their role as the primary means to address market failure - in inner cities, in medicines for the Third World, and in promoting technology investment - is unproven.

Take the credit announced by Gordon Brown last week to encourage pharmaceuticals companies to invest more in drugs for developing countries. There are problems of companies relabelling inappropriate drugs, claiming the credit for labs used for existing drugs, and whether the credit should apply for the total volume of research done, or the extra encouraged by the existence of the credit.

Ed Mayo is executive director of the New Economics Foundation, a think tank which helped formulate the Community Investment Tax Credit now being considered by the Treasury.

'Tax credits are an astute approach that effectively provide an interest rate subsidy for investing in inner cities,' he says. 'The real advantage is that they avoid the bureaucracy and centralisation of public spending - they don't pre-specify what the money is for.'

The childcare credit can be seen in a similar way. In the past, governments may have created state run nurseries; now they subsidise demand and leave the supply to the private sector.

But the real growth area is the use of tax credits to promote social and environmental responsibility, says Mayo. Tax credits for environmentally useful business activity are the carrot approach to incentives rather than the 'stick' of measures such as the climate change levy. In the Netherlands, tax credits are on offer for certain green projects. In the US there is, among others, the Historic Preservation and the Low-income Housing tax credits. Many are offered and voted for within regions or states. Bill Clinton even named a tax credit for further education after his home town.

Presentationally they are a godsend. A £1bn tax credit for urban regeneration will cost the Exchequer just 5 per cent of that - £50m. It doesn't even count as public spending. They offer unbeatable political value for money. They allow governments to state baldly the good things they wish to promote, without addressing the pithy issue of paying much for them.

But will they work? Perhaps there should be a tax credit for that.

webTitle: Don't scare the horses in the City

fields.headline: Don't scare the horses in the City
fields.standfirst:
Companies need incentives if they are going to invest in the future, says Digby Jones

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Companies need incentives if they are going to invest in the future, says Digby Jones.
fields.body:
As the Chancellor puts the finishing touches to his pre-election Budget, my bottom line message must be that the continued success of business - and the millions of jobs involved - depends on nothing being declared on Wednesday that might upset the macroeconomic stability the UK has come to accept as the norm.

We live in the real world, and expect the key Budget proposals to focus on measures designed to deliver most votes come polling day, but I would urge the Government not to turn its back on the long-term needs of the UK.

Stability has played a major part in the continuing success of many of our companies, but that on its own is not enough. Too many businesses still lack the confidence necessary to commit to vital long-term investment; too many decisions in the research and development arena are being postponed; some are simply abandoned.

The US slowdown will heighten anxiety and cause further delays to major investment decisions. The resulting low levels of investment will have a detrimental affect on our overall productivity.

The Government should act decisively now and introduce a creative package of incentives that would give business renewed confidence to invest for the future.

Specifically, we would like to see the extension of tax credits to cover the research and development work of large firms. A firm commitment to this measure, coupled with full consultation on its implementation (with an eye on keeping red tape to a minimum) would create new jobs and make the UK more attractive as an R&D centre into the bargain.

Further increases in capital allowances for small and medium enterprises would also be very welcome. By easing cashflow pressures, it could help stimulate a change of culture in this potential growth area towards capital projects. We have to get the investment momentum moving again if UK productivity and competitiveness are to be among the best in the world five years from now.

We also need to see business expansion encouraged by a reduction in stamp duty on commercial property and other business assets, recognising that it should be separated from stamp duty on residential property.

Last year the Chancellor unexpectedly introduced major changes to Double Taxation Relief. Business had not been consulted on the measures proposed, which had serious practical implications for companies with business overseas. Following intensive CBI lobbying, significant modifications were introduced and further changes are expected.

The new regime must enhance our international competitiveness without saddling our businesses with unnecessarily complex compliance mechanisms. Also, the measures come into effect at the end of this month, and companies are increasingly concerned about the absence of detailed regulations, which they need if they are to comply effectively with the new regime.

The iniquitous climate change levy continues to be a real issue. Its ill-thought-through implementation threatens the competitiveness of many companies in a globally mobile world where jobs are always at risk. The CBI continues to press the Government to widen the criteria for discounts. The clock is ticking and the choice of 1 April for implementation seems sadly appropriate. Something must be done, and quickly.

Not even the farmers - right now fighting for their very survival - have escaped the scourge of the climate change levy. Those that are eligible for a discount do not yet know whether their energy-efficiency agreement will be signed with government; many others, even if they had the time to devote to negotiating a discount, are not eligible.

This energy tax is a blunt instrument to bring about a change in behaviour that could have been achieved by other means in a less bureaucratic, more cost-effective way.

And lastly, a plan for the medium term. Surely, it must be possible to simplify our tax system. Is it really necessary to have 22 different grades of company-car taxation or 10 different rates of capital gains tax? Regulation is a systemic problem in the UK and next Wednesday the Chancellor has a chance to start consultation on finding a systemic solution to tax bureaucracy.

Being radical is always more difficult than tinkering around the edges and adding new layers, but on a bad day you can hear the current system creaking under the weight of its own complexity.

Such a bold intervention would certainly go some way to winning the business vote.

Digby Jones is director-general of the Confederation of British Industry.

webTitle: Now, will the real Gordon  Brown please stand up?

fields.headline: Now, will the real Gordon  Brown please stand up?
fields.standfirst:
Iron Chancellor or social democrat, asks Oliver Morgan

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Iron Chancellor or social democrat, asks Oliver Morgan.
fields.body:
The applause as Gordon Brown made his entry to the Treasury in May 1997 may have reflected the hope in a demoralised department that things could only get better.

But to the world outside, he presented a conundrum. Brown had spent months in the City arguing that Labour could be trusted with the economy. But he had also signalled some redistribution - such as welfare-to-work schemes funded by a £5 billion windfall tax on utilities.

Nearly four years on, with an election looming, the answer to the question 'Gordon Brown - Iron Chancellor or social democrat?' is a little clearer. Peter Robinson of the Institute for Public Policy Research says: 'All Labour chancellors have to balance the need to appear competent on the economy with their desire for social principles - adequate funding for public services, better benefits for pensioners and families. In that sense he is typical.'

But Brown's tenure is unusual in that while other Labour Chancellors had the same instincts, few had the macroeconomic background against which to perform this delicate balancing act. Brown has. For eight years the economy has grown, and unemployment has fallen.

Apart from enhanced credibility, the key consequence is room for manoeuvre, evidenced by consistent Budget surpluses - this year's is estimated at a bigger-than-expected £15.9 billion. The Institute for Fiscal Studies estimates that Brown has £3bn-£4bn to play with in his pre-election Budget.

This happy state of affairs is due firstly to increased tax receipts - by 2000-1 they are estimated to be £24bn higher than the Conservatives predicted in their last Budget - garnered partly through growth and partly through tax increases early in the Parliament.

But the other side of the equation was the use of tax receipts to pay off debt while sticking to Conservative spending plans for two years. In that time, spending was lower than under the Tory plans.

It was this spending regime, combined with independent interest rate decisions, that gave Brown credibility. But keeping public spending low meant users of public services - typically the less well off - were disadvantaged.

Robinson says Brown's balancing act was largely successful: 'He can - though he would never say this publicly - claim to be a strongly social democratic Chancellor.' But Robinson adds that Brown's social democratic reputation may have been tarnished by the following political misjudgments:

 Abolishing the £6.45-a-week lone-parent benefit

 Introducing means-testing on some disability benefits

 Increasing the state pension by only 75p a week (which culminated in a showdown with pensioners before it was substantially increased last autumn).

Brown's reforms strongly favour low-income groups. A large proportion of the resources now finding their way into these households are the fruits of growth, but Carl Emmerson of the IFS points out: 'The tax burden on higher-income families has increased.'

Brown stripped these families of perks such as tax relief on mortgages, on dividend income and on private health insurance, as well as introducing measures such as insurance premium tax and, until the last Budget, an increased fuel duty escalator.

Meanwhile, business - assiduously courted with share option tax relief, research and development credits and reduced corporation tax - faced net bills thanks to the abolition of dividend tax credits and the bringing forward of corporation tax payments. The IFS calculates the cost to business of these measures at £3bn-£4bn. A package of fairness- at-work measures, including a minimum wage, also altered the balance in favour of lower-income Labour supporters. Despite this, Brown maintained his reputation for economic soundness .

The distributional effects of Brown's work target most strongly those in poverty, particularly children. His flagship measure has been the Working Family Tax Credit, which replaced, and is more generous than, Family Credit, giving adults £2.50 more a week, and young children £12.65.

Brown has also increased Child Benefit by 29 per cent for first children, and by 5 per cent for subsequent ones. Alongside this, Income Support for youngest children was increased by 72 per cent over previous inflation-indexed Conservative upgrades. And finally, a Children's Tax Credit, giving a discount of £8.50 a week, again targets less well-off families over wealthier ones, but not the very poorest.

Academics Holly Sutherland and David Piachaud calculate that Brown's measures have led to an increase in household incomes for the lowest three income deciles of 12.3 per cent, 13.9 per cent and 10.8 per cent respectively, while the top three gained 1.4 per cent, 1 per cent and 0.3 per cent. They find that the number of children in poverty has fallen by 35.5 per cent. The average shortfall of income beneath the poverty line for poor children has also fallen by 31.7 per cent.

Sutherland says: 'These measures have achieved a lot in terms of reducing child poverty, but to abolish it within a generation, which is the Government's aim, they need to do more.'

Following the 75p pension debacle, Brown used the means-tested Minimum Income Guarantee to deliver a substantial increase in income to the poorest pensioners. However, as Brown admits, there is still much that needs sorting out.

But there are two groups less affected by his largesse - non-working low- income families and those without children. The IFS indicates that, as part of a possible £1.2bn package for children, Brown could increase child allowances in income support and the children element of the WFTC to tackle the first of these issues - or concentrate resources on those without children.

But most believe the real Brown will not emerge until after the election. Some of his ambitions have been well flagged. One is an Integrated Child Credit, bundling the children's elements of current benefits and credits. The IFS says this could channel further resources to the least well-off, because income support payments would be increased.

Another is the Pension Credit, which, along with above-inflation increases in the basic pension and MIG, would increase the incomes of pensioners by some £4bn. A third is the employment tax credit, which would extend the WFTC to families without children.

Much of Brown's welfare-to-work and New Deal agenda has been built on a strong labour market, and he is keen to be remembered as the man who restored full employment. Robinson believes he needs to introduce a target of 80 per cent of the working age population in work. The figure is currently less than 75 per cent. On top of this, he believes correcting the UK's regional imbalance is vital.

Unemployment and output rates vary widely between the depressed North East and the prosperous South East. One option would be to increase the £120m regional selective assistance budget, channelled into businesses in struggling areas. Another would be Brown's Social Investment agenda, under which he announced £1bn in tax breaks to create investment in poorest communities.

Then there are longer-term issues, such as improving education and skills. Or he could introduce an exchange rate policy to ease the plight of manufacturing companies. Whether he needs to pursue the latter may be decided by public opinion on the euro, and a referendum.

fields.bodyText: The applause as Gordon Brown made his entry to the Treasury in May 1997 may have reflected the hope in a demoralised department that things could only get better. But to the world outside, he presented a conundrum. Brown had spent months in the City arguing that Labour could be trusted with the economy. But he had also signalled some redistribution - such as welfare-to-work schemes funded by a £5 billion windfall tax on utilities. Nearly four years on, with an election looming, the answer to the question 'Gordon Brown - Iron Chancellor or social democrat?' is a little clearer. Peter Robinson of the Institute for Public Policy Research says: 'All Labour chancellors have to balance the need to appear competent on the economy with their desire for social principles - adequate funding for public services, better benefits for pensioners and families. In that sense he is typical.' But Brown's tenure is unusual in that while other Labour Chancellors had the same instincts, few had the macroeconomic background against which to perform this delicate balancing act. Brown has. For eight years the economy has grown, and unemployment has fallen. Apart from enhanced credibility, the key consequence is room for manoeuvre, evidenced by consistent Budget surpluses - this year's is estimated at a bigger-than-expected £15.9 billion. The Institute for Fiscal Studies estimates that Brown has £3bn-£4bn to play with in his pre-election Budget. This happy state of affairs is due firstly to increased tax receipts - by 2000-1 they are estimated to be £24bn higher than the Conservatives predicted in their last Budget - garnered partly through growth and partly through tax increases early in the Parliament. But the other side of the equation was the use of tax receipts to pay off debt while sticking to Conservative spending plans for two years. In that time, spending was lower than under the Tory plans. It was this spending regime, combined with independent interest rate decisions, that gave Brown credibility. But keeping public spending low meant users of public services - typically the less well off - were disadvantaged. Robinson says Brown's balancing act was largely successful: 'He can - though he would never say this publicly - claim to be a strongly social democratic Chancellor.' But Robinson adds that Brown's social democratic reputation may have been tarnished by the following political misjudgments:  Abolishing the £6.45-a-week lone-parent benefit  Introducing means-testing on some disability benefits  Increasing the state pension by only 75p a week (which culminated in a showdown with pensioners before it was substantially increased last autumn). A large proportion of the resources now finding their way into these households are the fruits of growth, but Carl Emmerson of the IFS points out: 'The tax burden on higher-income families has increased.' Brown stripped these families of perks such as tax relief on mortgages, on dividend income and on private health insurance, as well as introducing measures such as insurance premium tax and, until the last Budget, an increased fuel duty escalator. Meanwhile, business - assiduously courted with share option tax relief, research and development credits and reduced corporation tax - faced net bills thanks to the abolition of dividend tax credits and the bringing forward of corporation tax payments. The IFS calculates the cost to business of these measures at £3bn-£4bn. A package of fairness- at-work measures, including a minimum wage, also altered the balance in favour of lower-income Labour supporters. Despite this, Brown maintained his reputation for economic soundness . The distributional effects of Brown's work target most strongly those in poverty, particularly children. His flagship measure has been the Working Family Tax Credit, which replaced, and is more generous than, Family Credit, giving adults £2.50 more a week, and young children £12.65. Brown has also increased Child Benefit by 29 per cent for first children, and by 5 per cent for subsequent ones. They find that the number of children in poverty has fallen by 35.5 per cent. The average shortfall of income beneath the poverty line for poor children has also fallen by 31.7 per cent. Sutherland says: 'These measures have achieved a lot in terms of reducing child poverty, but to abolish it within a generation, which is the Government's aim, they need to do more.' webTitle: Will Bush humanise the war on drugs?

fields.headline: A truce, not a crackdown
fields.standfirst:
With the success of Hollywood's Traffic, even President Bush recognises the US must show a more human touch in its fight against a narcotics epidemic. Ed Vulliamy reports from Miami: Bush, a former heavy drinker and rumoured drug taker, says that addiction is 'an illness'

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: With the success of Hollywood's Traffic, even President Bush recognises the US must show a more human touch in its fight against a narcotics epidemic.  Ed Vulliamy reports from Miami...
fields.body:
Johnny H, who has the right contacts in Overtown, takes you as far as a bungalow off 26th Avenue, the farthest it can be deemed safe to go - and even then he advises jumping the red lights. Money up front, of course: $100 for four 'hits' of crack, $10 for the runner and $10 for himself. The runner is Everton, in whose drive we park. He gets out to complete the final phase across 36th, to an undisclosed address, and returns 20 minutes later with the gear.

That affords time for a chat with Everton's girl, Katie - white, serially tattooed, horribly thin with punctured arms. She came from Athens, Georgia, and has been 'working' Miami's Overtown for three years, living with Everton and financing her habit at a discount.

Apparently sharing their home is Calvin, aged about 50, who has been 'blowin' rocks' for five years now and is alive but a tad jittery. 'Have to watch this stuff,' he counsels. 'You come off it fast and gotta eat. When the money's gone, and maybe on a weekend.'

Once loaded up, Johnny navigates a way back to Decadence-sur-Mer - the hinterland of clubs hidden behind the glitz of Ocean Drive. There, he and hundreds like him will connect with thousands of customers pouring into this crossroads between the Americas - under the watchful but ultimately defeated eye of the authorities. Now, however, the orthodoxy of 30 years that has seen America lead the world in the 'war on drugs' is itself under scrutiny. The iron heel of 'zero tolerance' drew America into distant wars, criminalised two generations of black youth and incarcerated hundreds of thousands of people. A combination of the 'war on drugs' and turf wars between dealers dominates crime in America.

No one would have thought the election of a Republican President could bring with it the signs of a sea change. But, as the movie Traffic heads for Oscar glory, so the advent of George W Bush, a former heavy drinker and rumoured drug user, also heralds a more cunning approach and a remarkable rebellion within his own party. This is partly because the iron heel has not worked, partly because it is too expensive and partly because treatment of drug users and addicts is a better - as well as cheaper - cure than imprisonment.

Addiction to drugs in America is down on the all-time high of 20 years ago, but the drop is in marijuana and soft drugs, while the number using heroin is higher than ever - more than three million recorded, and cocaine still above two million recorded. The new heroin capitals are New Jersey, California and Deep-South Georgia. Of America's two million prisoners, between 60 and 70 per cent test positive for substance abuse (including alcohol) when arrested, and the proportion of offences that are drug-related offences varies from state to state between 18 and 27 per cent.

The cost of drug addiction, smoking and alcohol abuse to American society has been estimated by the Centre on Addiction and Substance Abuse at $300 billion a year, while the amounts spent on treatment and prevention are a small percentage of federal and state drug-related budgets. The federal drug-control budget is $18.4bn, of which half goes on domestic law enforcement and only $3.6bn on treatment.

The morning after the Overtown drug deal, in the federal building downtown, even an official with the Drug Enforcement Administration, a veteran Mafia-buster, admits the flood of cocaine and its derivatives from Colombia and other nations has increased 'beyond realistic control'. There is, he says, 'only a degree where the dope business can be policed... down there where those mothers grow the stuff and on the streets around here. The lid can't be held on this thing. It needs a cut in demand so that the supply side eases up on its own accord'.

On the same day, up in Washington, the State of the Union address was preceded by an even more pressing appointment for President Bush - his third summit meeting with a head of state in 10 days, and the most important: with President Andrés Pastrana of Colombia.

Top of their agenda was Plan Colombia, the largest aid single package - some $2 million a day - ever dispatched by the US, authorised by the Clinton administration last year to a nation which thereby claimed its place as the third biggest recipient of US generosity after Israel and Egypt. The package has so many complicated strings attached that it has been assailed from left and right: the Left sees it as aid to a weak government that mutates into covert backing to right-wing death squads, and last Monday even Bush's State Department lambasted Pastrana's government for its record on human rights. A parsimonious Capitol Hill sees the package as throwing good money after bad.

But the most cogent argument has come from Colombia's neighbours, frayed at the frontiers by raging drug wars. They say the world's biggest consumer of drugs should attack the problem at home in different and more effective ways than the cumbersome iron heel that may have brought about a relatively peaceful period in America's drug history, but has failed to put an end to the narcotics epidemic. This was the message Bush and his aides brought from his meeting with Pastrana: that there is an imminent sea change in US tactics in the war on drugs - a shift towards a more considered strategy.

Of all the appointments to Bush's cabinet, one is striking by its omission to date: there is still no replacement for Bill Clinton's 'drug tsar', Bill McCaffrey. White House officials told The Observer last week that Bush has a choice in mind: Colonel James McDonah. The colonel's brief, however, will be what aides like to call 'demand-side reduction' rather than war in Colombia. This is propelled in part by the latest thinking on how best to confront the drug problem, and in part because the cost of incarcerating addicts is higher than that of treating them.

The irony is that the iron heel, zero-tolerance policy was that of Bill Clinton, who claims never to have inhaled but was the hallmark of the sax-playing, baby-booming, draft-dodging Sixties generation. And the smoke signals of a turn away from such a policy are being sent from a White House inhabited by the heir to the Bush dynasty and former governor of the execution state of Texas. Yet he is also a man who admits his own alcoholism and never denied reports that a hefty proportion of the allowances he was paid as a spoiled student allegedly went up his nose.

As the New York Times reminded its readership this week, the President understands addiction better than most of the learned preachers on the subject. He said on CNN that he regarded alcohol and drug addiction as 'an illness', adding: 'We haven't done a very good job thus far of curing people of that illness.' Bush may be a conservative, but this is the new, not the old, language. The New York Times added that this is the America which will probably cheer Traffic to numerous Oscars later this month, and which demands a more creative approach to its most urgent social problem.

Some of those around Bush don't show signs of a departure from the status quo - new Attorney-General John Ash-croft even opposes needle exchanges, common in Europe - but elsewhere within Bush's own Republican Party there is an appetite for change. This began with the governor of New Mexico, Gary Johnson, emerging from the debate over candidate Bush's cocaine use to say he too had snorted in his time and, moreover, believed both his state and America should consider alternative means to prison in dealing with the drug problem. He urged decriminalisation of possession of drugs, and possibly even legalisation, which could lead to sale for profit. Most surprisingly, the governor's popularity was undented by the confession. His plan, announced last month, to present a Bill packaging his recommendations to the Capitol in Albuquerque stands little chance of success, but he has enacted and funded a 'harm-reduction' programme using Narcan, an easy-to-inject alternative to heroin.

A more remarkable sea-change has came from one of the most senior Republican figures, New York state's governor, George Pataki - Bush's henchman in the state and on his short list for vice-president. Pataki has laid before the New York legislature his plan to rip up the Rockefeller Code - draconian laws passed by Governor Nelson Rockefeller in 1973.

Rockefeller passed his laws to order mandatory jail sentences of between 15 years and life for the more serious drug offences and lesser prison terms for non-violent drug-related crimes. Pataki's Bill, which stands a good chance of success, proposes to cut the 15 years to eight-and-a-half years and recommends treatment rather than prison for a host of non-violent drug-related offences.

The Bill would not only affect future cases but convicts currently serving time for non-violent offences, making some 500 out of 600 of those in for more than 15 years eligible for release. Pataki says his plan 'builds on the experience and reflects an understanding of the experiences we have had since the Rockefeller laws were enacted'.

That experience has seen the Democratic state of California pass a prototype for Pataki's law in the form of Proposition 36 - a referendum vote offering treatment options rather than jail for non-violent offenders. It has also seen the judicial system pay greater heed to scientific, social and fiscal research. The rise of 'drug-courts', allowing judges to impose substance-abuse treatment in place of jail sentences, has accompanied medical research into controlling the 'hedonic regions' of the brain.

The Centre on Addiction and Substance Abuse published a report last week saying that states spend an average of 13 per cent of their total budgets 'shovelling up' the 'wreckage' of substance abuse - more than they appropriate for higher education and 100 times what they spend on prevention and treatment. In another study the Rand Corporation calculated that every dollar spent on drug treatment saved $7 in services.

Bush has put drug treatment high on the list of priorities for what he calls 'faith-based initiatives' - the infrastructure of voluntary and church services which he envisages as agents of social reform. But the languages of commerce and charity often make for a bad mix. Back in Miami, some of the victims of the Overtown drug trade also suffered a different fate at the apparently model Sea Winds drug rehabilitation centre. The authorities recently found the centre was operating without a Florida state detoxification license, and was breaking medication law. Affidavits were filed by some of its partners against another, one Mohammed Ibrahim, alleging that medication law was broken, and Ibrahim has himself pleaded guilty to a criminal charge of 'grand theft'.

So in Miami, while the Bush administration debates whether to use the term 'Drug War' or 'Drug Cancer', the courts continue to try those who deal the drugs, and at least one of those who claims to treat the wreckage they leave in their wake.

fields.headline: When prudence turns dangerous
fields.standfirst:
Gordon Brown is the too-lucky Chancellor. The result is underspending and failure to reverse national decay

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is the too-lucky Chancellor. The result is underspending and failure to reverse national decay.
fields.body:
It was Napoleon who wished for lucky generals, and every Prime Minister worth his salt should wish for lucky Chancellors. Tony Blair chose well. He has a lucky Chancellor - and Wednesday's Budget, with another judicious mix of spending increases and tax cuts, will cap Gordon Brown's four years of charmed fiscal stewardship. It's been a remarkable chancellorship and has transformed Labour's reputation for economic management. But luck sooner or later runs out - and even virtue has its costs.

His luck has been the wider economic context. There has been no world recession; the fallout of the Asian financial crisis was contained - indeed, the world carried on growing, and inflation everywhere has been depressed. Against this benign background Brown's tax receipts have flowed and the British economy carried on performing well.

But if that luck fell to him, he has gone on to make his own. Brown has played his economic management just as he planned in the long dark nights of opposition. The establishment of an independent Bank of England proved a masterstroke; its interest rate policy has been nearly faultless. Other Labour governments have spent in the first two years of a Parliament and endured the next three regretting it; Brown has made his spending increases and tax cuts so they kick in for the next election rather than reward the vote at the last one. He raised taxes by some £17 billion in the first two years of his term, and spent less in the first three years than even Margaret Thatcher in her pomp. The result is a stunning fiscal position that Brown has continually underestimated.

Carl Emmerson, of the Institute for Fiscal Studies, calculates that Brown has beaten his own Budget forecasts for the public surplus or deficit in the following year by approaching an average 1 per cent of GDP - a bias any post-war Chancellor would envy. It's not that getting the forecast wrong is unusual; it is underestimating it for four consecutive years that is so untypical. The joke about prudence is wearing thin. Brown is so prudent that the financial markets do not believe his forecasts; they factor in a Brown underprediction.

The most extraordinary year was in the spring of 1999 when he forecast he would borrow just £3bn in the following financial year. In the event there was a cash surplus of over £16bn, a swing of some £19bn to the good that is close to a post-war record. The combination of low inflation and consistent repayment of National Debt - the best guess is that there will be another £16bn surplus in the current financial year alongside the £22bn of debt repayment financed by the mobile phone spectrum auction - has driven the interest rate on long-term British government debt to an astonishing 4.9 per cent, the lowest in the G7 except Japan and Germany. Britain is becoming the new Switzerland, with the lowest debt and inflation, and the largest budget surplus, in Europe.

Yet still the IMF and the European Commission are not satisfied - in part because they worry that Brown's spending plans over the next three years will fritter away this strength, and in part because the IMF worries that the economy will buckle under the combined weight of private and public spending and reignite inflation - a warning it repeated last week. In particular, it worries that the build-up of capital investment will mean the Government may have to borrow to finance capital spending, a position that Brown explicitly permits in his definition of sound fiscal policy (the golden rule) but which offends the new conservative hawks in the US, who argue for permanent balanced budgets as part of their jihad against the state.

The IMF is wrong. Its hyperconservatism takes no account of the powerful disinflationary forces worldwide alongside an emerging surfeit of global productive capacity; the chances of an open economy such as Britain's suffering from a surge in inflation in this context is negligible. The greater risk, given Britain's chronically stretched public services, and a pension structure dependent on high real interest rates, is not spending the cash.

For, while part of Brown's success lies in the strength of the economy and his own crafted strategy, the rest is explained by the Treasury's inability to make sure that the great spending departments actually invest the cash they have been allocated. Brown will avoid mentioning the subject in his Budget speech, confident that the Conservatives are doctrinally unable to attack him, but the Government is presiding over a fiscal scandal. It is so inefficient that it has been unable to invest the money allocated to it, so that public investment has sunk to new lows. This is not what Brown intended, but the feebleness of the Opposition has prevented the collapse of public investment from becoming a hot political issue. Gordon is lucky in every sense.

But perhaps too lucky. Because the Government has not decisively reversed the decay in the public infrastructure, and has underspent what it planned, absurdly it is finding itself criticised by the IMF and EU Commission for potentially loosening a fiscal stance that is much tighter than it ever wanted. The baseline against which the Government is being judged is just too good. Moreover, we would all have begun to see a tangible improvement in the public infrastructure, while the adverse consequences of demand being higher than it was in actuality would have been trivial.

Nor is that all. There is much self-congratulation about how much better Britain has organised its pension system than its principal European competitors. We don't have a generous state pension scheme, as they have, and better still the majority of pensioners, present and future, have saved privately for their old age through their own or company pension schemes. As a result Britain has no impending fiscal crisis about how it is to pay for an ageing population living off generous state pensions.

But there is no such thing as a free lunch. For 20 years private pensions have proved an excellent investment, with annual returns on equity investment averaging 15 per cent alongside high real interest rates; as a result pensioners have been able to buy rich annuities with their highly performing savings. But now the British national debt is falling to some 30 per cent of GDP, carrying long-term interest rates and annuities to new lows. The assumptions on which private pension plans are based are being shredded.

Any pension scheme - private or occupational - that defines a final pension in terms of some relationship to the contributor's final salary is in crisis. Employers who offer these defined benefit schemes are facing breathtaking increases in their contribution rates and thus payroll costs in order to keep their pension funds solvent in this new universe of low annuity rates. Even if they launch a new pension scheme with less generous benefits they face maintaining the solvency of the old fund. Paradoxically, paying off the national debt and fiscal conservatism is proving a payroll tax - via lower annuity rates - on many employers as they raise their contribution rates to their pension fund. Fiscal virtue has unexpected costs; running budget surpluses as large as Brown's is becoming an economic distortion in its own right.

To his credit Brown is fighting the conservatism of the IMF and EU, but even following his own rules will only allow him to 'give away' some £3bn to £4bn. This will be hailed by the City as prudent and by his own supporters, as long as it is crafted to direct money at Labour's core constituency, as a political masterstroke. The other reality - national debt too low and government spending departments chronically unable to raise investment - will be forgotten. But this is a lucky Chancellor.

fields.bodyText: It was Napoleon who wished for lucky generals, and every Prime Minister worth his salt should wish for lucky Chancellors. Tony Blair chose well. He has a lucky Chancellor - and Wednesday's Budget, with another judicious mix of spending increases and tax cuts, will cap Gordon Brown's four years of charmed fiscal stewardship. There has been no world recession; the fallout of the Asian financial crisis was contained - indeed, the world carried on growing, and inflation everywhere has been depressed. fields.headline: Avenging angel
fields.standfirst:
Barely five feet tall, this Swiss lawyer has beaten La Cosa Nostra, Russia's Mafia and Switzerland's financial empire. Now she's gunning for the killers and rapists of Yugoslavia and Rwanda

Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Barely five feet tall, this Swiss lawyer has beaten La Cosa Nostra, Russia's Mafia and Switzerland's financial empire. Now she's gunning for the killers and rapists of Yugoslavia and Rwanda.
fields.body:
Some people are usefully described by their enemies, who have cause to fear and despise them. The Serbian tyrant Slobodan Milosevic and his hate-machine media call Carla del Ponte 'the new Gestapo'. The Cosa Nostra mobsters of Sicily who tried to blow up del Ponte in 1988 like to brand her ' La Puttana ' - 'the whore' - and one of the many banking executives into whose affairs she snooped as Attorney General of Switzerland defines her as 'an unguided missile'.

Dominique Poncet, a fellow Swiss lawyer, worried that del Ponte's campaign against banking secrecy might drive foreign custom away from these gnomes of Zurich, described her colleague as 'not good for Switzerland'. But a friend, the assassinated anti-Mafia hero judge Giovanni Falcone, called his colleague 'the personification of stubbornness' and del Ponte in turn describes herself as simply: 'a chain smoker' and 'a prosecutor'.

Carla del Ponte is currently chief prosecutor for two historic institutions that have become metaphors for our era - whether they stand or fall: the international tribunals on war crimes established at The Hague - trying those accused of crimes committed in former Yugoslavia - and at Arusha, trying defendants from the Rwandan genocide.

The tribunal established during the maelstrom of the Bosnian war in 1994 was at first dismissed as an unarmed hunter unlikely to bag any big game. It took nearly two years to hear the first case and the defendant in the first genocide trial (in which, declaring an interest, I testified for the prosecution) died in custody of a massive heart attack. The diabolical triad of prize indictees - Milosevic, Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic - remain at liberty.

But some epic events have occurred at The Hague of late, which bear the unmistakable hallmark of Carla del Ponte. Suddenly, the court has become a judicial bowling alley, defendants going down like skittles. The conviction was secured last week of its most senior defendant, the Bosnian Croat political commander Dario Kordic, for directing a series of horrific massacres of Muslims along the Lasva valley, and his aide-de-camp.

But far more significant, last month came a piece of history in our lifetime. Three Bosnian Serbs from Foca were convicted in the first ever war crimes trial dealing exclusively with sexual offences - charges that seared the imagination of even the most hardened of lawyers or war reporters; the systematic mass rape and torture of captive women and young girls.

Here was not only justice being done, but justice being played in a new, female key; painted in new, female colours that depicted rape as a tool of war and crime against humanity. If The Hague was conceived as proceeding in the traditions of Nuremberg, this was a crime of which the male world of those trials had not even attempted to convict the Nazis, for all the copious evidence available.

The Foca verdict came on the slipstream of two civil suits against an absentee Radovan Kadadzic filed through New York by women who had been raped at the Omarska concentration camp, in which the juries asked the judge for permission to award up to 10 times the maximum damages allowed.

Systematic rape was also a component part in the conviction for genocide of Jean-Paul Akayesu, a Hutu leader in the Rwanda genocide, at the Arusha court last year. But the central and sole conviction for mass rape in Foca ended once and for all grotesque doubts that some had sought to cast over the veracity of the accounts of women raped in Bosnia, which first surfaced in 1992. Others seemed to find it hard to deal with. The then UN envoy David Owen, when pressed in Sarajevo to draft a response, said: 'It's very difficult to talk to the Serbs about this kind of thing.'

The investigation was made by a tenacious American female attorney, Nancy Patterson, and the verdict delivered by a female judge, Florence Mumba of Zambia. But it is impossible for the world not to associate the conviction with del Ponte and the success of the prosecution's case with the feminisation of The Hague tribunal.

Carla del Ponte is third in a line of formidable women at The Hague - the others were the judge in the first case who became its president, Gabrielle Kirk MacDonald, a black civil rights judge from Texas; and judge Louise Arbour of Canada, whom del Ponte replaced in September 1999.

Del Ponte was the first career prosecutor to step into the prosecutor's shoes. And what a prosecutor she was: a woman who, as she puts it herself, 'never served anyone or anything but the law', and a woman with enemies; a veteran of the war through the courts against the Cosa Nostra, the Russian Mafia, Swiss bank secrecy, Colombian drug cartels and more. She was the only figure in Swiss pubic life with a 24-hour personal armed guard.

The first things you notice about Carla del Ponte are her height and the cigarettes. She is a powerhouse a little over five feet tall and lights one cigarette from the other. Oh to have been a fly on the wall when she came though Washington last year to confront her main critic in the US, Jesse Helms of the Foreign Affairs Committee and heavy-hitter for the tobacco lobby.

Del Ponte was born in Lugano in 1947, and began practising law in her hometown. Somewhere along the way, she married and divorced a man about whom she will say nothing, and gave birth to a son about whom she says little.

She was soon appointed public prosecutor and carved the tracks of her career when seconded to the 'Pizza Connection' Mafia investigation, crossing a perilous line by decoding numerical Swiss accounts held by the Cosa Nostra. Inevitably, she paid a visit to Sicily to meet the man with whom she worked hand-in-glove, the celebrated judge Falcone, and was with him in his house one summer's day in 1988 when the carabinieri found 100lb of Semtex packed into the foundations - just in time.

Falcone was blown up in his car after three years further work which would deliver a series of shattering blows to the Cosa Nostra, but del Ponte lived on - in her way. Her former press spokesman at The Hague, Paul Risley, recalls the day he told her about the killing of the Serbian mass-murderer, Arkan, for whom del Ponte had issued an indictment. She asked where he had been shot. 'In the head,' replied Risley, reporting later that she had nodded, saying: 'They shoot you in the head because they assume you're wearing a bullet-proof vest.' 'It was then I realised,' said Risley, 'this is a woman for whom the threat of assassination is part of the job.'

Del Ponte was always a step ahead of the game as she assailed Switzerland's role as financial haven for the world's dirty dealers. From the Cosa Nostra, she progressed to the Russian Mafia which, she warned early, was driving a wedge into the economies of the West and laundering its cash through Switzerland. She was the first to name President Boris Yeltsin as an accomplice of the crime syndicates. She froze millions of dollars belonging to former Pakistani president Benazir Bhutto and triggered another firestorm by seizing $118 million from the accounts of Raul Salinas, brother of Mexican president Carlos Salinas de Gortari. Raul was later imprisoned for laundering drug money.

Her tenacity - sometimes successful in court, sometimes not - invoked the exasperated wrath of the Swiss banking establishment. And when she took on The Hague and Arusha she said: 'I plan to continue to work in this way. It makes many enemies, but that doesn't matter. That's what we're here for.'

Yet even some of her hawkish supporters were appalled when del Ponte opened investigations into the possibility of Nato war crimes having being committed during the bombing of Kosovo. And they were much relieved when she dropped those investigations. Then Yugoslav Foreign Minister Petar Jojic sent del Ponte the following friendly missive: 'You are running the dungeon which, like the worst whore, you have sold to the Americans and to which you bring innocent Serbs by force, kidnapping and murder.' Minister Jojic further suggested that 'sooner or later, your own actions will face investigation, and you will spend the last part of your rotten life behind bars'.

So far, this has failed to occur. Instead, del Ponte has walked a high wire at The Hague between the Anglophone (generally hawkish and committed to precedent law) and Francophone (less so and in the Napoleonic legal tradition) factions that have always built an invisible Berlin Wall through the tribunal's work.

By introducing a subliminal language of gender and being a legal hawk whose fourth language is English, she has managed to unite the cumbersome body which - after a lean and idealistic start - has been as prone to bureaucratic lurching and the cult of the free luncheon as any other wing of the United Nations.

Under her direction, the tribunal is on a roll, its critics ridiculed. Del Ponte's deputy, Graham Blewitt, said on Friday that he expected to see Milosevic in the dock by the end of the year. And as if the importance of the Foca verdict were not enough, its global as well as legal impact was immediate. Only a matter of days later, investigators with the fledgling tribunal set up in East Timor announced they had found a 'pattern' of organised rape involving high-ranking officers.

The dynamo behind all this, del Ponte, is the last person to call herself a heroine, or even brave. 'You don't have a feeling of courage,' she once said. 'It's a job like any other. You do it.'

Carla Del Ponte

webTitle: Comment: Irish smugglers are not heroes

fields.headline: They are not heroes
fields.standfirst:
No scapegoats in the foot-and-mouth epidemic... just villains

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: No scapegoats in the foot-and-mouth epidemic... just villains.
fields.body:
Blaming Brid Rogers and her officials at the Department of Agriculture for the arrival of foot-and-mouth disease in Ireland is to miss the point about the crisis creeping over our countryside. The most likely reason why Fortress Ireland was breached and the virus spread from Britain has been the insidious practice of livestock smuggling. The principal lesson therefore for Ireland to emerge from this catastrophe is that if you tolerate a culture of lawlessness to the point of awarding it some sneaking-regard mystique, then society as a whole will ultimately pay a very heavy price.

The farmer on whose land the infected sheep were first diagnosed may have been an unwitting and innocent party to this irresponsible flouting of import restrictions. Nevertheless, it is no accident that the smuggling of this infected flock from England had its terminus in South Armagh, a region where blind eyes are consistently turned and illegality is looked upon as a virtue. It is an area where the smuggler is portrayed as the cute hoor hero, pulling strokes on the taxman, the VATman and the policeman. Hopefully, one of the positive upshots of foot-and-mouth's arrival on these shores is the end of this false image of smuggler as modern-day Robin Hood.

It is worth remembering this is the place that gave us Angel Dust, green diesel and many assortments of smuggling enterprises involving alcohol, tobacco, fake perfume, CDs and videos. Republicans in the region have been quick to launch verbal attacks on Rogers' department, alleging official inertia in preventing the disease spreading into the North and across the border. They would be better examining the organic links between smuggling and paramilitarism in South Armagh. For the symbiosis between smuggler and subversive has been corroding the rule of law and civic society in the border region for more than three decades.

South Armagh is Sicily without the sun - a place where political violence and criminality coalesce. Perhaps local republican representatives should ask themselves why Department of Agriculture officials, unarmed civilians rather than the police, cannot move quickly and efficiently in South Armagh. Even tax collectors and TV licence inspectors have been threatened and beaten up there for daring to enforce laws that everyone else abides by.

The foot-and-mouth outbreak in Britain may indeed, as environmentalists like George Monbiot contend, be due to the transformation of farming into an agro-industrial Leviathan and the mass trafficking of cattle and livestock from one end of the UK to another. But it has spread first to Northern Ireland and then to the Republic only because greedy individuals engaged for generations in smuggling knew they would get away with it.

The anger of the people of Ireland, including the law-abiding farmers and agricultural producers of South Armagh, should be directed towards that enduring cult of the cute hoor and the quick buck. For the nod and the wink given to the smuggler avoiding the VAT and stroking the tax while vacuuming up every subsidy going from the EU is an indulgence Ireland can no longer afford.

But in the South Armagh/Louth border region, livestock smuggling is a site specific art-form revered in folklore and song, as an act of rebellion against authority, any authority, but has now developed into a back channel for a virus that threatens the economy of the entire island.

Solidarity, meanwhile, to Neil Lennon, the Lurgan-born Celtic player who was the target of moronic, bigoted abuse and booing at Windsor Park last Wednesday night. A masochistic friend who braved the freezing temperatures to watch Norway turn over a mediocre Northern Ireland side estimated that perhaps up to a quarter of the stadium were involved in the loyalist sectarian chanting. Who then can blame young promising Catholic players for signing up to the Republic rather than Northern Ireland if all they can expect from their own supporters is boos, jeers and even death threats?

There are two solutions - one short-term, the other long - to the cancer of sectarianism in Ulster sport. As a tumor has to be excised from the body, so those making a player's international career a misery just because of his religion must be expelled from the national stadium.. And in the long run, perhaps it is time to transplant the home of the national team from Windsor to a new, more neutral venue free from sectarian association and menace.

webTitle: Comment: We are too sentimental about our animals

fields.headline: A cow is just a cow
fields.standfirst:
We get too sentimental about our animals, whether they are foot-and-mouth infected cattle or wild marmosets, says Cristina Odone

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: We get too sentimental about our animals, whether they are foot-and-mouth infected cattle or wild marmosets, says  Cristina Odone.
fields.body:
Animals exist for us. Farmers understand this, which is why whenever they are pushed in front of a mike for a quote on their most recent plight, they describe the spread of foot and mouth as a farming crisis, a tragedy that is blighting human communities. Animals don't get a look in. They are an economic, not an emotional, investment, and now that their value as foodstuff has been destroyed - who among us wants to eat a desiccated chop from an emaciated animal? - the farmers know what to do: slaughter the infected animals and wait for compensation. They see no intrinsic value in the four-legged critters. Even though foot and mouth is not a life threatening disease (just a cattle form of flu), the farmers are matter of fact about killing off their animals when they don't weigh enough to bring in a healthy profit.

They see no reason to spare them - even if the government allowed them to - once they've become useless; they're just a meal ticket. Indeed, this unsentimental view of sheep and cows explains why we have an outbreak of disease in the first place. When you see livestock as your livelihood you don't give a toss about their quality of life. If you did, you wouldn't opt for the kind of intensive farming that packs animals in cramped quarters or asphyxiating battery sheds, stuffs them with unnatural feeds, inject them with hormones. The farmer views these conditions not as cruel but as cost-effective.

Yet the vast majority of Britons, the 90 per cent plus who live outside the farming community, describe the fate of farm animals in Holocaust terms. The talk is of funeral pyres and barbaric slaughter and a Schindler's List of the few marked for survival.

It is the usual hyperbole the British go in for when they talk of four-legged, fanged or furred beings. Ever since it became primarily an industrialised, rather than agricultural, country, Britain has lost all perspective on animals. In France and Italy, where agriculture still employs a sizable proportion of the population, and plays a significant role in the economy, a farmer is a pivotal figure and a sheep is just a sheep. But in a Britain where the farmer and his animals are a rare sighting, many believe the farmer is in reality a BBC producer with a second home in Shropshire, a hobby farmer who waxes lyrical about his organic turnips and the glossy pigs that feed on them. His animals are not a means of livelihood, but essential figures in the bucolic landscape that is the urbanite's interpretation of rural England.

This attitude has turned the beasts of burden that from Biblical times were there for our service and our stomach into creatures indistinguishable from ourselves. Urban dwellers whose encounters with the animal kingdom are limited to a squirrel in the park or a fat pigeon in the square, are equally ignorant of the farm animal's habits and the wild animal's haunts. And so they invest these mysterious little beings with a Walt Disney sentimentality that depicts them as soft cuddly and unfailingly benevolent. There is no room in this fantasia of fauna for the fox that - shock horror - eats the rabbit or the mink that kills the water vole. To them nature is not Blake's vision of red in tooth and claw, but pretty in pink, a nursery mural rather than a feral landscape.

This silly anthropomorphism turns dangerous when it turns the fox into the Anne Frank of the countryside - hiding from the uniformed fascist hunters; and the lamb transported across the channel in a cattle truck into a victim of ethnic cleansing. Gross distortions like these belittle human dignity and suffering, and defile the memory of victims of war, violence and disasters. The smoke and smell of the burning carcasses of diseased cattle may be very similar to the funeral pyres that immolate the remains of the Gujarat earthquake victims - but there is no moral equivalence. To think that there is betrays bankrupt ethics that regard man as no better than sheep.

When Britain was a God-fearing country, this would have been blasphemy. We were taught that God made all creatures - but only man in his image. In the divine order, man with soul ranked well above animal without. Now we've ditched God, we've lost this hierarchy; every living being is value free. The farmer's plight is no worse than his calf's, his rights no greater.

Once you accept this blurring of the species, you follow a ridiculous, if not downright wicked, logic. One animal sentimentalist of my acquaintance toured India for three weeks and the only charitable donation he made during the entire trip was to a donkey sanctuary. The dumb, grey beasties looked so vulnerable, he tearfully explained to me, in the middle of a market place teeming with starving beggars, legless lepers and sunken eyed children.

I remember, too, going with some friends to see Gorillas in the Mist in London. In one scene, a gorilla's paw is cut off so that the evil hunter may sell it on as an ashtray. One of the women started bawling in the darkened room, her sobs hysterical and piercing as she indulged in a bleeding-heart exhibitionism that no brutal footage about Bosnia or Rwanda had ever triggered.

But to erase the distinction between man and beast can prove more damaging than this show of insensitivity; it can place lives at risk. Inflate the value of animal life, and you won't sacrifice a dog for a child. This kind of wrong-headed prioritising is already causing damage. Scientists involved in animal experimentation know that their lab work on mice, beagle or marmoset may save millions of lives - or at least alleviate their suffering. Yet they must work in bunker-style conditions and live in fear of attacks from animal rights activists like the one that left Brian Cass of Huntingdon Life Sciences semiconscious.

I claim an interest in animal experimentation. My half-brother, Lorenzo, suffers from a rare neurological disorder called adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD). His only hope lies in a series of experiments being conducted in hidden locations throughout Britain and the US. If someone you love is fighting for his life and owes his survival to animal experiments, you have no doubt that research scientists must continue their work unmolested by terrorists who, as others have pointed out, have in all likelihood, at some point, benefited from a drug at one time tested on animals.

To witness Lorenzo's fate and then confront a placard-waving mob outside the laboratory where men and women are working to find the key to his condition, is to gag with bitterness. Yes, I feel uneasy about the ordeals that lab animals suffer - being shaved for x-rays, having a catheter introduced into their throat, being force-fed. But if these procedures lead to a cure for even one child, I have no doubt that this suffering is necessary. There is nothing like watching someone you love suffer, to convince you of the difference between a child's torment and a puppy's or a calf's.

There is a hierarchy of beings, and we humans stand at the top. Our first allegiance must be to one another; this calls for a challenge to the universe we have devised, wherein a farmer's ruin is of no greater consequence than an animal's killing; and a child's health of no greater value than a marmoset's.

 Cristina Odone is deputy editor of the New Statesman

webTitle: Law to break supermarkets' grip on farmers

fields.headline: Law to break supermarkets' grip on farmers
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Special report: countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: A crackdown on the way Britain's biggest supermarkets use their power to manipulate the food industry is to be unveiled by the Government.
fields.body:
A crackdown on the way Britain's biggest supermarkets use their power to manipulate the food industry is to be unveiled by the Government.

A legally enforceable code of conduct being drawn up by the Department of Trade and Industry and the Office of Fair Trading will demand that supermarkets have a fairer relationship with farmers, who complain they are bullied into providing food at very cheap prices by the large chains.

The need for cheap food has been cited as one of the reasons for the foot and mouth disease epidemic, which had yesterday spread to the Continent, prompting fears of a Europe-wide crisis.

Supermarkets - including Asda, Safeway, Tesco and Sainsbury's - will face heavy fines if they fail to stick to the new rules.

Last week, the Prime Minister Tony Blair admitted supermarkets had farmers 'in an armlock'.

The move comes as the agriculture crisis continues to grip the nation. The Government revealed yesterday that seven more cases of foot-and-mouth had been found - from Cornwall to Dumfries and Galloway - bringing the total number of cases to 51.

The chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, said 45,000 cattle had now been slaughtered. Scudamore admitted that there were at least three more highly suspect cases. He could not say how long the crisis was likely to last.

The Government announced a new set of measures yesterday:

 Vets from Italy, Canada, America, Australia and New Zealand will fly to Britain this week to help overstretched British colleagues.

 £156 million of European Union payments to compensate farmers hit by the strong pound will be brought forward.

 Critics of the Government's food policy will be invited to a specially organised food summit to discuss radical changes.

 The Government's position on vaccinating sheep and cattle against foot and mouth will be reviewed, although it said it was unlikely it would change the 'no vaccination' position as it would harm exports.

Nick Brown, the Agriculture Minister, said he hoped that some domestic meat supplies would be able to start moving by tomorrow as supermarkets said stocks were running low.

The crisis means some supermarkets are preparing to ration supplies. All the major chains expect shelves to empty of British-produced fresh meat by Tuesday or Wednesday. A spokesman for Somerfield said certain red meats would run out in the next 24 hours.

The Government said that strictly controlled licences would be awarded to farms outside the foot and mouth exclusion zones. Haulage firms would then be allowed to take cattle to abattoirs, with the animals being slaughtered before entering the food chain.

Brown said it was time for a more fundamental look at the food industry. As well as the new code for supermarkets, the Government has said it would review 'just-in-time' supply chains which involve the movement of vast quantities of food very quickly around the country.

It will also look at the role of smaller, more locally based abattoirs, which would mean livestock being transported shorter distances.

The job of the dealers, who move animals to different markets across the country in a chase for the best price, will also be investigated. All three factors are thought to have played a part in the rapid spread of the disease.

The supermarket code of conduct, which will affect the five biggest supermarket chains, will demand that any disputes between farmers and supermarkets are settled by an ombudsman.

It will also say that food diversity is an important part of the food chain and that supermarkets should be aware of their role in maintaining healthy competition and diversity.

The National Farmers' Union welcomed the new code. 'Anything that is good for the food supply chain is ultimately good for the consumer,' said Ian Gardiner, NFU deputy director general.

fields.headline: Disease suspected on Continent
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: France and Belgium reported their first suspected cases of foot and mouth disease yesterday, stoking fears that the contagion that broke out in Britain might have spread to continental Europe. The border was closed to livestock traffic.
fields.body:
France and Belgium reported their first suspected cases of foot and mouth disease yesterday, stoking fears that the contagion that broke out in Britain might have spread to continental Europe. The border was closed to livestock traffic.

'If we do nothing, it will spread across our country fast. My specialists are convinced,' French Health Minister Bernard Kouchner said. 'If it doesn't reach France, we can consider it a real miracle.'

It is feared several sheep among a flock of 80 at a farm in Roche-la-Moliere, in the Loire region, have the disease.

A public veterinary official said initial tests proved negative, but results from additional ones were not due until tomorrow.

The Belgian Farm Ministry was investigating a suspected case at a pig farm at Diksmuide, near the French border in western Flanders.

An official said initial laboratory tests had been negative. But Agriculture Minister Jaak Gabriels ordered a nationwide ban on the transport of live farm animals.
