fields.headline: Fear grows in plague village
fields.standfirst:
Fatalism rules in a farm community as a way of life seems to be dying. Paul Harris reports from Devon

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Fatalism rules in a farm community as a way of life seems to be dying.  Paul Harris reports from Devon.
fields.body:
Highampton is a modern-day plague village. It lies at the centre of a viral hot zone, surrounded by farms infected with foot and mouth disease.

Life here has come to a complete halt. Dozens of families in the farms around the hamlet have practically barricaded themselves into their homes. Some have not left their farms in almost a week.

The village has been transformed from a sleepy backwater in the rolling hills of mid-Devon to a surreal place reminiscent of the Black Death or the aftermath of a nuclear accident. Signs on gates, often painted in big red letters, warn visitors to keep out. Straw soaked in disinfectant has been laid across farm roads, and buckets of it stand at gates for the few allowed in to soak their boots.

The village primary school has shut for fear of spreading the virus further - either between farms or infecting children from neighbouring villages. Church services, too, have halted. The church warden, who had the only keys to the vestry, lives on a farm and cannot leave it or be visited. Traffic on the lanes around Highampton has dwindled to a trickle as local markets have closed, and trips to the shops are being kept to an absolute minimum.

In the village itself, the white-coated figures of officials from the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food wander from house to house, telling the occupants the latest news and giving them advice. After anyone, from a doctor to a vet, leaves an infected farm he or she has to burn overalls and change clothes. So great is the fear of the virus that even their pens and papers are left behind to be destroyed. The people of Highampton are scared and bewildered. Foot and mouth does not kill but they know it could destroy their livelihoods and their way of life.

Ross Baker, 35, farms land just inside the five-mile exclusion zone set up round Highampton's Burdon Farm, where the outbreak began in Devon and spread to infect at least seven other farms. Baker says that, after BSE, things were just beginning to improve. 'I grew up here and I would like my son to follow me. I want to go on farming, but I will have to see if my overdraft can take it. This really is a disaster,' he said.

It is hard to overestimate the impact of the crisis. Morris Thomas, 61, runs an old people's home deep in the exclusion zone. He has a special pass that allows him out, but he cannot set foot on a farm for fear of passing on the virus. He is worried about the mental state of his brother, George, whose farm may be infected, but he cannot go inside the property to see him. 'I went to talk to him because he is under a lot of strain and he came down to the gate and we spoke over the fence. We didn't want to get too close for fear of passing it around,' he said.

A grim fatalism has settled on the countryside as the culling of thousands of animals in the area has begun. In an industry battered and bruised by food scares, foot and mouth is seen as the final straw for some farmers. 'This is a calamity; it is of horrendous magnitude. People are extremely frightened and there is an anticipation of doom,' said Asad Aldoori, the village doctor. It took until Wednesday for Aldoori to secure a permit to visit two farmers who needed counselling. Now that he has been on an infected farm, Aldoori cannot visit any other farm for at least five days. 'But I had to go,' he said, 'they just needed someone to talk to, and perhaps something to help them sleep.'

Local churches are also involved. But again the full extent of the disaster prevents visits to many of the farmers feeling the strain, as herds and flocks built up over generations disappear in the smoke of a bonfire.

Alan Andrew, a lay worker with the Methodist Church, is manning his farm's phone all day to answer calls from his depressed neighbours. Neither he, nor anyone in their family, has left their farm since Sunday, but he is ready to talk. 'It is my faith that keeps me going. But I am here for everyone, no matter whether they are church people or not. I just tell them to stay at home and hang on in there. I am a farmer too and they like to hear it from someone who understands them.'

Ian Harris's tragic story is becoming all too typical. He built up his business over almost 20 years, from a single flock of sheep to two farms in the Highampton area.

Now all his sheep have been shot. His cows will most likely follow. Almost a lifetime's work has been destroyed. 'I feel sick,' Harris said.

He first noticed the disease on Wednesday, when several of his sheep could not walk properly or feed and kept on licking their lips. Harris, 48, had never seen the virus's effects before, but he knew straight away that he had fallen victim to it. A quick visit by Ministry officials soon confirmed his fears. Now he faces an uncertain future. When the crisis finally rolls to a halt, people like Harris will be barred from keeping any animals on their land for a further six months. That means no income and he must search for any part-time work going.

'My farm will be a dead farm. I will need to get some work, but my farm has been infected, I might be seen as some kind of hazard.'

For Harris, who appears stoical, the reality of the situation has not yet sunk in but he knows that when he wakes up this week with two empty farms and compensation pay-outs months away, it will hit him hard.

'At the moment I have things to do still but when I don't, that will be difficult.'

Despite the determination of people such as Harris, some are worried that the crisis could impel Highampton farmers to leave the land. Previous crises have left many in the red and financial rewards seem a lot greater off the farm than on it. It would be the end of a way of life. Rural Devon is still a tight-knit community where surnames in a village often go back centuries and some farms have been in the same family for 100 years.

Despite the disaster, there is little real anger. Farmers mutter about cheap foreign imports bringing in the disease and the closure of local abattoirs allowing it to spread so quickly. But Highampton is still too numb with shock to voice any real rage.

Instead an eerie silence seems to dominate the landscape. 'In the fields it is just so quiet - even the birds are hardly making any noise. I can't explain it. It is like everything knows something is wrong,' Harris said.

fields.headline: Is Labour aiming at you?
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Who are the voters the Labour must woo?
fields.body:
In the run-up to the general election, the Labour Party has sent all its candidates 'letter templates' which must be used when writing to target voters. Each is addressed to a different type of voter identified by the apparatchiks at Millbank as vital to winning the election. They are:

MRS MORTGAGE

A modified form of the famous Worcester woman, Mrs Mortgage has been identified by Labour as the Middle England voter they must woo. Married, with a three-bedroom house in the Midlands, she worries about interest rate rises and what they will do to her weekly household budget. She abandoned the Tories after interest rates hit 15 per cent, decided on Labour but is now not so sure.

Is impressed by: economic stability, tax cuts, low interest rates

Is unimpressed by: boom and bust, plans to ban hunting, Islington chattering classes

MR SQUEEZE

The voter who actually prefers the Liberal Democrats but will be willing to vote Labour to keep the Tories out. Could be the saviour in tens of marginal Labour-held seats where the Lib Dems are in third place. Needs to be told about the disaster that the Tories were and convinced that a vote for the Lib Dems is a wasted vote.

Is impressed by: public spending, radical constitutional change, positive announcements, Gordon Brown

Is unimpressed by: tax cuts, talk of bogus asylum seekers, negative attacks, Jack Straw

MRS WEAK

Labour's Holy Grail, the voter who switched to Labour at the last election but does not hold her convictions deeply. A close relative of Mrs Mortgage, she would like to vote Labour again but is worried that they have failed on crime and that public services aren't getting any better. Needs to be convinced that the statement 'all politicians are the same' is untrue.

Is impressed by: toughness, private enterprise, Jack Straw

Is unimpressed by: unions, any form of 'tax credit', helping single mothers

fields.headline: Mr Brown, Mr Balls and the elusive Mrs Mortgage
fields.standfirst:
Women will be the Treasury team's prime target on Wednesday, report Kamal Ahmed and Gaby Hinsliff: Iron Chancellor or social democrat?

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Women will be the Treasury team's prime target on Wednesday, report  Kamal Ahmed  and Gaby Hinsliff: Iron Chancellor or social democrat?
fields.body:
To the mandarins of the Treasury it seemed a bizarre request. Could all notes to the Chancellor of the Exchequer please include home telephone numbers. The Chancellor likes to read papers between 6am and 7.30am, his office explained, before coming into the department. He needs to be able to get to any official while they're digesting their morning toast.

Over the past two weeks, Brown and his tight entourage of staff have been in what officials describe as 'Budget blitz' mode. From 6am Brown is on the telephone. With his two special advisers, Ed Balls and Ed Miliband, he has been worrying away, grinding the figures, totting up the advantages and disadvantages of a tweak here, a tweak there.

How will the latest details on increasing maternity pay work? How will widening the 10p tax band be made to look like a tax cut for everybody? How much will a family on average earnings of £25,000 be better off if all the tax and benefit changes kick in on 5 April? About £370, Gordon, came the reply.

It is a punishing schedule. At 7.30am his car arrives for the short journey from the Westminster home he shares with wife Sarah Macaulay to the Treasury. There he continues his machinations, banging out his thoughts on a laptop in large block capitals, all the more easy to read for a man with poor eyesight.

Sometimes his secretary brings in a projector. Brown's laptop thoughts are beamed onto a screen so that Balls and Miliband can see what he is writing, his Budget speech the centre of attention. No one else is in the room, a smaller, more private study off the original cavernous office Brown first occupied.

They bash phrases backwards and forwards - what will tickle the party, what will tickle the nation? - the loyalty of his two trusted lieutenants unquestioned. Not for Brown the process established by his predecessors. It is not officials who draft the Budget speech but the Chancellor himself.

Balls is the chief economic adviser to the Treasury. He is the channel through which every minute passes, and he has succeeded in outmanoeuvring the civil servants to ensure that his master's will is done. Brown and Balls hate endless memos. They keep their thoughts in their heads and in Brown's computer. It's safer that way. Not for nothing is Balls nicknamed the deputy chancellor.

The other Ed is the brother of David Miliband, head of the Downing Street policy unit. But even the family link is not enough to allow No 10 a peek at Brown's detailed thinking. The Chancellor ensures that the Prime Minister is kept up with the broad themes, but the details are under wraps until the last minute. Other members of the Cabinet are not told about their specific areas of spending until a few days before the big day.

The Cabinet as a whole will have to wait until Wednesday morning to hear about the Budget speech. They received a note last month from Downing Street saying Blair had moved the weekly Cabinet meeting forward to next Wednesday morning so that Brown could tell them what was going on. Five hours later Brown will get up in the House of Commons, pile up a set of books so that he can rest his speech high enough for him to see it and tell the nation what he is up to.

The Chancellor is not a man for formal meetings. Recent relations between the Chancellor's and Prime Minister's teams have improved, but the tension remains. Brown sees the Treasury as the natural headquarters of economic and social policy. Blair wants to concentrate power in No 10, the Policy Unit and the Cabinet Secretariat. The Treasury - tight-knit, secretive, ferociously intelligent - is winning the battle.

Thanks to a series of judiciously timed leaks, it is now becoming clear where Brown's priorities lie. Women, the voters Labour fears are most disillusioned with Tony Blair the politician and New Labour the Government, are to be wooed like never before.

Maternity pay will be boosted, rules on how many tax benefits new parents can claim will be relaxed, benefits for families with children will be increased. And the new Labour worry, Mrs Mortgage, will be told that interest rates and mortgage repayments are at their lowest for years. Everything, from a reduction in stamp duty for new homes in deprived areas to boosts for single parents, will be given a family-friendly edge.

It has all been planned with meticulous care. In 1998 Brown started plotting the route to the next election, fixed already in his mind as May 2001. Each year the Budget has had slightly more to give away, culminating in the Treasury's 'red-letter day', 5 April 2001.

On that day, in a month's time, a series of tax and benefit changes will kick in. Pensions will increase, rules on how much money the elderly can save before they have to pay for their own care will be relaxed, child benefit will increase, road tax will be cut for millions of cars, tax credits aimed at those earning under £40,000 will be launched.

Poorer families will be up to £2,600 a year better off. Tax cuts through the increase in the 10p income tax band will mean everyone has a little more in their pocket. An election will be called. Blair will win. Brown will be the man behind it. Perfect.

The procession of high-heels clicking across the varnished floorboards upstairs at No 11 Downing Street shortly after the last two Budgets were the first sign. Over the white wine and canapés, Brown struggled manfully to make small talk with magazine editors anxious to know where he bought his suits.

Sarah Macaulay circled among guests ranging from female MPs and journalists to prominent women such as Germaine Greer and even Cherie Booth.

But as with everything Brown does, there was a carefully calculated point to it all - to show that the Chancellor sympathised with women.

It underlined a message the Budgets had already made clear with promises of massive increases in childcare places, tax breaks for working women to pay for those childcare places, even the scrapping of VAT on sanitary products last year, a matter so embarrassing to the Chancellor that he failed to mention it in his speech and left it to a junior Minister to brief journalists afterwards.

Labour campaign strategists have identified Mrs Mortgage as the woman they have to woo. Middle England, middle income, hard-working, she will be the target of the election campaign. She was picked after research revealed that it was women who were least impressed with the Government's multi-billion pound economic arguments and felt that Labour had failed to be as modernising at it had claimed it would be.

The Chancellor has taken this on board, despite his predominantly male core of advisers. Helping him to win Mrs Mortgage's trust are Harriet Harman, an old Brown ally and former Minister, Maeve Sherlock, the former head of the National Council of One Parent Families, and Treasury ministers Dawn Primarolo and Melanie Johnson.

Primarolo and Johnson have linked up with the two Women's Ministers, Tessa Jowell and Margaret Jay. It was Primarolo, once a struggling single mother herself, who fought for the children's tax credit to be drawn by mothers as well as fathers, following fears that in some households it would never be spent on the children.

But there have been some hiccups for Brown. This week's announcement on maternity pay follows intense haggling between his officials and the women's lobby: the Chancellor favoured targeting help on poor new mothers, arguing that wealthy women earning large salaries did not need the state to top up their bank balances when they gave birth. But he has relented and will announce on Wednesday that the state will provide maternity pay for all, with a likely top-up for those most in need through extra tax credits.

Brown is acutely aware that Labour's election hopes will be heavily dependent on his performance in the House of Commons on Wednesday. Party officials know that if the public are not convinced, then the chances of another huge majority could suffer, even though some opinion polls are already predicting such an outcome on 3 May, which is still the favoured date for a poll.

The Chancellor has taken this on board, despite his predominantly male core of advisers. Helping him to win Mrs Mortgage's trust are Harriet Harman, an old Brown ally and former Minister, Maeve Sherlock, the former head of the National Council of One Parent Families, and Treasury ministers Dawn Primarolo and Melanie Johnson. Primarolo and Johnson have linked up with the two Women's Ministers, Tessa Jowell and Margaret Jay. It was Primarolo, once a struggling single mother herself, who fought for the children's tax credit to be drawn by mothers as well as fathers, following fears that in some households it would never be spent on the children. But there have been some hiccups for Brown. This week's announcement on maternity pay follows intense haggling between his officials and the women's lobby: the Chancellor favoured targeting help on poor new mothers, arguing that wealthy women earning large salaries did not need the state to top up their bank balances when they gave birth. But he has relented and will announce on Wednesday that the state will provide maternity pay for all, with a likely top-up for those most in need through extra tax credits. Brown is acutely aware that Labour's election hopes will be heavily dependent on his performance in the House of Commons on Wednesday. Party officials know that if the public are not convinced, then the chances of another huge majority could suffer, even though some opinion polls are already predicting such an outcome on 3 May, which is still the favoured date for a poll. webTitle: Around the country - foot and mouth latest

fields.headline: Around the country - foot and mouth latest
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: • The number of outbreaks rose to 48 yesterday, with new cases confirmed in Cornwall, Scotland, Durham, Cumbria, Lancashire and Oxfordshire.
fields.body:
 The number of outbreaks rose to 48 yesterday, with new cases confirmed in Cornwall, Scotland, Durham, Cumbria, Lancashire and Oxfordshire.

 Foot and mouth panic spread to mainland Europe, with Belgium getting the first suspected case of foot and mouth disease in pigs imported from Britain. Belgium banned all animals exports, outlawed the transport of farm animals around the country and cancelled all horse races.

 Preliminary results from the first suspected case in Ireland proved negative but it still announced a complete halt to slaughtering and banned the movement of animals. Border crossings with Northern Ireland were closed, mass at Catholic churches was cancelled and rural schools were threatened with closure. France banned imports of livestock from Ireland.

 The Government announced it was bringing forward payments of £156 million from the European Union to compensate farmers for foot and mouth disease.

 Panic-buying spread in the UK, as Tesco supermarket reported sales of beef were up by 45 per cent, lamb by 65 per cent, pork by 35 per cent, chicken by 35 per cent and bacon by 41 per cent. Somerfield reported sales of pasta and rice were up by 87 per cent on the previous week. Frozen fish sales were up by 40 per cent.

 Approximately 45,000 animals have now been slaughtered as a result of the disease, including 6,300 animals which may have come into contact with infected animals.

 The Government announced an investigation into the implications of increased world travel, globalisation of trade and modern farming methods on issues of disease control.

 Officials started preparing special licences to allow healthy animals to start being moved from disease-free areas to abattoirs on Tuesday.

 Walkers abused a local council official putting up signs asking people to keep off footpaths in Basildon, Essex, because of foot and mouth. Police were called and the walkers were reminded local authorities had the power to prosecute.

 Police took away the firearms of a distraught farmer 'heartbroken' by the loss of livestock from foot and mouth disease. Cattle and sheep farmer George Thomas called the emergency services asking for police and TV cameras to attend his farm.

webTitle: Johnny 'Mad Dog' Adair has become 'Johnny B Good.'

fields.headline: Adair is working like a mad dog to win prison favours
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Johnny 'Mad Dog' Adair has become 'Johnny B Good.'
fields.body:
Johnny 'Mad Dog' Adair has become 'Johnny B Good.'

One of the most dangerous terrorists in Ireland, Adair has covered up his bulging muscles and loyalist tattoos with the uniform of a prison orderly.

Adair, a leader in the Ulster Defence Association, has become a model prisoner, taking up a post washing windows, brushing floors and fetching hot water for fellow inmates at Maghaberry jail outside Belfast.

Loyalism's most infamous prisoner has signed up to Maghaberry's progressive regime, which encourages inmates to take up prison work and education.

Relatives of republican prisoners held in the jail said Adair has been on his best behaviour in a bid to win privileges from the prison authorities.

The UDA commander is held in the same complex which houses Continuity IRA prisoners such as Tommy Crossan. But so far Adair has avoided any confrontations with dissident republicans and other Catholic inmates.

Republicans have refused to take part in any prison work and have demanded to be segregated from other inmates. Crossan, fellow CIRA prisoners and Real IRA inmates are engaged in a campaign for political status at Maghaberry. Adair was taken to Maghaberry by British Army helicopter after being arrested near his home in Belfast's Lower Shankill area last August. Peter Mandelson, the previous Northern Ireland Secretary, ordered Adair's re-arrest over his alleged involvement in the feud between the UDA and the rival Ulster Volunteer Force in the Greater Shankill last summer.

He had been freed the year before from the UDA wing of the Maze prison under the Good Friday Agreement's early release scheme for terrorist inmates. Adair had been serving a 15-year sentence for directing acts of terrorism.

A spokesman for the Northern Ireland Prison Service said the progressive regime at Maghaberry was open to all 246 sentenced inmates. Under the scheme - which ranges from basic, standard and enhanced forms of co-operation - a prisoner can be assessed in terms of conduct, personal hygiene, participation in prison work and education, and attitude to staff and other prisoners.

Prisoners such as Adair who join the scheme can gain privileges such as extra family visits and more credits for the tuck shop.

Unlike the Maze, Maghaberry is a fully integrated prison where loyalists and republicans live cheek-by-jowl. There have been clashes between republicans and loyalists in recent months.

Pastor Clifford Peeples, a convicted loyalist pipe bomber, was responsible for an attack on Tommy Crossan last year.

Adair is fighting through the courts to have his re-arrest overturned. Late last year the Northern Ireland sentence review board recommended that Adair be freed from Maghaberry. But Mandelson overruled their decision and insisted Adair remain in prison.

fields.headline: Alarm as Dublin trains 'KGB'
fields.standfirst:
Moscow rights groups attack lessons for security agents in bomb techniques

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Moscow rights groups attack lessons for security agents in bomb techniques.
fields.byline: Amelia Gentleman  Moscow and Henry McDonald
fields.body:
Human rights groups have expressed concern about the Irish government's decision to reveal IRA bomb-making techniques to Russian security agents.

The Glasnost Foundation, Moscow's Helsinki Watch and the Memorial group, claim that training the KGB's successor agency to defuse bombs manufactured by terror groups such as the IRA could be highly dangerous.

The three human rights groups say suspicion hangs over the Russian FSB's role in a series of bombings in Moscow three years ago, which the authorities claimed were the work of Chechen terrorists.

Twelve FSB officers are nearing the end of a six-week training course with the Irish Defence Forces' Ordnance Corps. The Russians are in Ireland at the invitation of Taoiseach Bertie Ahern to learn from the Irish army's experience in dealing with 'improvised' IRA and loyalist bombs.

The Irish Defence Forces and the British Army are world experts in dealing with sophisticated 'improvised' bombs after 30 years of terrorism in Northern Ireland.

But Sergei Grigoriants, the president of the Glasnost Foundation in Moscow, expressed doubt about the wisdom of the training project.

'This kind of project can be useful only if there is a guarantee that the newly acquired expertise will be used solely for peaceful purposes,' he said. 'But we have no such guarantee. If used wrongly by the FSB, this kind of knowledge could be very dangerous.'

Lyudmila Alexeyeva, the head of Moscow's Helsinki Watch group, said she shared those concerns.

'Given the reputation of the FSB, I do have doubts about how sensible this kind of training exercise is,' she said.

Several independent investigations have queried the role of the FSB in the spate of terrorist bombings across the Russian capital in 1999. This followed the discovery of a large quantity of explosives under an apartment block in Ryazan shortly after the Moscow bombings. Sugar sacks, apparently containing the explosive hexagen, were found by residents and the police were alerted. Residents were evacuated and spent the night out on the streets. The police later traced the car, which had deposited the sacks to the FSB. An FSB spokesman declared later that the sacks had been put there as a training exercise.

The Moscow bombings were seen as a precursor to the re-invasion of Chechnya by Russian forces and the subsequent levelling of Grozny.

Both Alexeyeva and Grigoriants stressed there was still no firm evidence to connect either the FSB or Chechen terrorists to the Moscow attacks. But they said serious questions remained unanswered about the role the FSB played.

A spokeswoman for Memorial, the human rights organisation that has been monitoring the conduct of the Chechen war and the FSB's role in the conflict, added: 'We fear there are people within the FSB who could abuse this kind of knowledge. This kind of training is vital, but great care needs to be exercised in selecting the individuals who participate.'

A spokesman for the Department of Defence in Dublin said he could not comment on the allegations made about the FSB and the 1999 Moscow bombings. He confirmed that the invitation to train six FSB officers at the Curragh camp in Co Kildare and Dublin's Clancy Barracks - the home of the Defence Forces' bomb disposal teams - was made by Ahern during a trip to Russia three years ago. Ahern offered Irish technical assistance when he met Vladimir Putin, the Russian President, during a ceremony launching co-operation in combating drug trafficking and fighting crime.

The explosives training course began in, February and ends this month with Irish officers concentrating on the make-up of IRA and loyalist bombs.

The Defence Forces point out that while they and the British Army have shared their knowledge with other armies, so the IRA has learnt from fraternal terrorist groups such as ETA and Middle Eastern organisations.

webTitle: More cash and time off for mothers

fields.headline: More cash and time off for mothers
fields.standfirst:
Maternity pay boosted as Budget targets women voters

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Maternity pay boosted as Budget targets women voters.
fields.body:
New mothers are to be given a significant boost in maternity pay and the right to take six months off work as the Government directs the last Budget before the general election towards wooing women voters.

As a war on tax erupted between the two main parties yesterday, Government sources revealed that a central part of Chancellor Gordon Brown's £4 billion giveaway, to be announced on Wednesday, will be an expected increase in the flat rate of maternity pay from £60 a week to £100 a week. The present 18 weeks maternity leave will be extended to 26 weeks.

The Chancellor is using the Budget to respond to concerns that women voters are turning away from the Government, which they believe has not been as radical as expected and has failed to modernise Britain's struggling public services.

The new maternity package will be bolstered by allowing mothers to claim the new working families tax credit - cash back through the pay packet - from the birth of the baby onwards, effectively targeting most help on those who are least well-off.

Previously it could take up to six months before women could get the extra money.

'We hope this is going to be a very, very good package for women,' said one senior source. 'Our absolute determination has been that the greatest help should be for the poorest women. The aim is that women can have long enough to get to know their new babies, which up until now has been the prerogative of the better-off.'

However, the Chancellor is understood to have rejected demands from unions and other campaigners for a major extension of earnings-related maternity pay.

At the moment women get 90 per cent of their usual earnings paid by the state for the first six weeks, then go on to a much lower flat rate for the rest of their time off.

The maternity pay will be one of a package of measures aimed at making the Budget as 'family friendly' as possible, a move which the Prime Minister has told colleagues is vital to winning the election.

Brown will also announce a large extension of the 10p tax band which will be trumpeted as a 'tax cut for all'. Although he is thought to have rejected an across the board 1p cut in income tax as appearing too profligate, he will say that from April families on average earnings of £25,000 will be £370 a year better off. He will also claim that poorer families on £12,500 a year will be £2,600 a year better off and will have the lowest direct tax burden since 1972.

Yesterday, Michael Portillo, the Shadow Chancellor, upped the war on tax by pledging that he would match any tax cuts announced in the Budget.

Speaking at the Conservatives spring conference in Harrogate, Portillo said the promise came on top of £8 billion of cuts the Tories have already said they can achieve.

He also said that indirect taxes, so-called 'stealth taxes', meant that everyone was now paying the equivalent of 10p extra on the basic rate of income tax.

Labour dismissed the claims, saying that Portillo had a black hole in his spending plans which could only be filled by increasing national borrowing and pushing up interest rates.

The Treasury had initially balked at increasing maternity leave, concerned that it would mainly benefit wealthier high-flyers who are keenest to return to work.

But it has been persuaded by arguments that having a child is the single biggest strain on family incomes - and that if women are allowed to take long enough off to bond with their babies and return only when they are ready, they are less likely to drop out of the labour market. The children's tax credit, which will be given to parents earning up to £40,000, is also likely to be introduced at a higher than expected rate of £10 a week from April.

fields.headline: Best Foot goes ever forward
fields.standfirst:
'Tony Blair? I've known better, but I'm happy to have good relations. Labour will be in power for the next 10 or 15 years': Now 87, and having endured a year of personal tragedy, the former Labour leader remains robustly optimistic and full of energy

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: 'Tony Blair? I've known better, but I'm happy to have good relations. Labour will be in power for the next 10 or 15 years':  Now 87, and having endured a year of personal tragedy, the former Labour leader remains robustly optimistic and full of energy.
fields.body:
'It wasn't a donkey jacket.' His one good eye twinkles. He can laugh about it now. Almost.

It was a dark green coat, 'a perfectly good jacket', which sat over his Sunday-best black suit, bought from Herbie Frogg in Jermyn Street, and was worn to keep himself warm at the Cenotaph that day in 1982. He's still got it, and offers to fetch it from his Hampstead hallway, but he's been leaping up and down all morning chasing coffee and cakes, and every jerky movement is accompanied by a quiet groan, only half-stifled.

He was tempted back then, he has said, as Left and Right alike heaped scorn on him for his unstatesmanlike choice of clothing, to seek solace in one of his favourite quotes from Thoreau: 'Beware of all enterprises which require new clothes.' But, as he points out himself: 'Thoreau never had to face the Sun...'

One of the most contemptible pieces of myth-making from the Eighties was that Michael Foot, then leader of the Labour Party, insulted our soldiers' memory by dressing scruffily at the Cenotaph. Contemptible partly because, like so many big lies about that period, it has thrived through malicious repetition; ask a 25-year-old about Foot and it won't be long before the 'donkey-jacket' is mentioned; but mostly contemptible because of the savage irony within. The man falsely remembered for not paying 'suitable' tribute is the same man who has dedicated much of his long life to paying the biggest tribute possible to the dead of two world wars - by trying to make sure there isn't a third.

But time, and history, have not been kind to Foot. A life-long international socialist - and 'still proud to call myself that, you bet!' - the history books remember him mainly for being at the helm of the Labour Party during the most destructive of its many flirtations with self-immolation, and presiding over its most shaming electoral defeat ever, in 1983. And, at 87, he has lost most of those to whom he was closest. His great hero, Aneurin Bevan, went many years ago. 'I still miss him, yes. He died at the peak of his powers, and died partly in the middle of a quarrel with us, and that was... difficult.'

His beloved wife Jill Craigie died last year, shortly after a traumatic period in which she revealed that in 1951 she was raped by her husband's friend Arthur Koestler. The last of his three distinguished brothers, Baron (John) Foot, died a couple of years ago; recently he almost lost his nephew, journalist Paul Foot, to a heart attack. And his beloved Labour Party is changed beyond all recognition.

I wouldn't have been surprised to find him gazing listlessly into the empty grate of his fire, wallowing, justifiably, in harsh memories and soft tears. Instead, he has the twitchy energy of a teenager. He bristles with good news, unstoppably so. Uninterruptably so - for despite his obvious frailty, his mind is still flensing-sharp, and he still does that trick of wrong-footing the emphasis... 'that would be the first point but insuperably more important is that' (pause for breath)... so the breaks come when you least expect them and you can't interrupt.

He bristles evangelically about the renaissance of Tribune, organ of the old Labour Left, which will honour him later this week with a gala dinner where the grand and gutsy of what's left of the Left - John Mortimer, Tony Benn, even Robin Cook - will pay tribute to Michael's contribution to the movement and to the paper. He joined in 1937 ('my first job on Fleet Street, five quid a week') and saw through its principled battles with governments of both hues - on Franco's Spain, on the H-bomb, the Balkans; all fights Michael is now intensely proud of having fought and, to a greater extent, won.

And he's bristling with good news about the election. 'The Labour Party saved the country in some of the most troubling times of the century - 1940, 1945 and the period afterwards - and I believe that's what's going to happen now. We'll spend the next 10 or 15 years in government. It's very exciting.'

So it is still the Labour Party, his Labour Party? 'You bet. I know many were disappointed by sticking to Tory spending plans. And I think that was a mistake, and the old socialist arguments are coming back, about how do you fund services without raising money. But I understand Gordon Brown had to take some hard decisions, alarmed that we would have similar experiences to 1974.'

Hang on, hang on. Finally I manage to interrupt. I have just come across Norman Mailer's account of watching Foot in the 1983 election, when the American arch-conservative admitted being moved by the passion of these words of Foot's: 'We are not here in this world to find elegant solutions, pregnant with initiative, or to serve the ways and modes of profitable progress. No, we are here to provide for all those who are weaker and hungrier, more battered and crippled than ourselves. fields.headline: Mandelson 'cleared' of scandal
fields.standfirst: Inquiry finds no evidence on four key charges over Hinduja brother's passport, says source
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson will be cleared of the four main charges against him by the Government inquiry into the Hinduja passport scandal which is to be published this week.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson will be cleared of the four main charges against him by the Government inquiry into the Hinduja passport scandal which is to be published this week.

Sources have told The Observer that Sir Anthony Hammond has failed to find any evidence that Mandelson sought to influence the passport application of the billionaire businessman Srichand Hinduja.

It will also say that there is no documentary evidence that the Home Office Minister Mike O'Brien received a call direct from the former Northern Ireland minister, the element that was key to Mandelson's resignation at the end of January.

Tony Blair, who has yet to see the report, is expected to agree to its publication at the end of this week. The Prime Minister has admitted that the affair has been an embarrassment and a diversion from the work the Government is doing.

Although the Hammond inquiry will say that Mandelson gave confusing answers when asked about the Hinduja affair, it will also make clear that it is impossible to come to any firm conclusion on the issue as there is no 'direct corroborating evidence' about the telephone call.

Blair ordered Hammond to launch an inquiry after Mandelson resigned as Northern Ireland secretary when he was accused of giving misleading answers about the affair.

He was asked about a telephone call between his office and O'Brien's office by The Observer in January. At first he said that he hadn't made the call personally but then was accused of changing his story when the Home Secretary, Jack Straw, said that he reminded Mandelson of the call a few days before. Mandelson said that he was tried and sacked by a 'kangaroo court' and has vowed to clear his name.

The report by the former Home Office civil servant will not criticise O'Brien, saying that both accounts of the contact between the two men were honestly held. The other minister being investigated by the inquiry, Keith Vaz, the Foreign Office Minister with responsibility for Europe, is also likely to be cleared of any wrong-doing. Vaz has told colleagues that he regrets 'topping and tailing' two letters sent by two of the Hinduja brothers to the Home Office about passport applications as a backbench MP.

But he told the inquiry that he had not broken any rules and was merely acting as a conduit between the Government and the two men, as he would for many leading members of the Asian community.

Government sources have said that the report cannot be seen to directly criticise any serving Ministers as the Prime Minister cannot afford any more resignations this close to an election.

Hammond has been struggling to complete his report which has become bogged down in conflicting evidence from the main parties involved. It is thought that the Home Office Ministers were recalled before Hammond two weeks ago to give fresh evidence after he said he couldn't square the accounts that were being given to him.

Yesterday it was revealed that O'Brien sent an email to passport staff about SP Hinduja's application in 1998, reminding them that the passport laws had been relaxed so that people like Hinduja could be treated more leniently.

Mandelson lost a battle to have appendices to the report published.

webTitle: Mugabe bullies his way to international approval

fields.headline: Mugabe bullies his way to international approval
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe's ruler was close to defeat last year. Now tactics of terror and violence appear to have won, reports Andrew Meldrum in Harare

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's ruler was close to defeat last year. Now tactics of terror and violence appear to have won, reports  Andrew Meldrum in Harare.
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe will arrive in Brussels and Paris this week a satisfied man. Even as he is received into the heart of Europe, at home his government is succeeding in his strategy of eradicating significant opposition in all quarters.

Just a few months ago Mugabe was widely written off. Now he is entrenching his rule and neutralising any independent forces. On Friday his government finessed the exit of the Chief Justice, Anthony Gubbay. It is also continuing its attacks on the local and foreign press, white farmers and the main opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC).

Known MDC supporters in Harare's townships are harassed and beaten by a motley collection of army, police, war veterans and young thugs.

The icing on the cake for Mugabe is being welcomed in Paris this week by French President Jacques Chirac and in Brussels by Belgium and the European Union. On the agenda in his talks will be the war in the Democratic Republic of Congo, in which Zimbabwe is a key player, rather than internal affairs. Calls being made in Britain for Mugabe to be arrested and charged for gross human rights abuses will be ignored.

Mugabe has triumphed in getting Chief Justice Gubbay to go on leave immediately and to take early retirement from 1 July. His removal clears away one of the most substantial obstacles to the government's policies, particularly its 'fast track' land seizures.

Soft-spoken and even timid, Gubbay, 68, led the Supreme Court bench to make carefully reasoned, logical judgments which rejected Mugabe's land policy as violent, lawless and unlikely to improve the lives of those being resettled.

The Supreme Court decisions, delivered in December and January, acknowledged the need to redistribute land to poor blacks to redress the historical injustice of the seizure of their land by white colonialists from 1890 to 1970. But it insisted the reforms must follow the law. This infuriated the Mugabe government which responded by calling the judges 'relics of Rhodesia' and racists.

Mugabe's war veterans invaded the Supreme Court and chased the five justices away. The judges received death threats and were vilified in speeches by Mugabe and others.

One of the most notorious of Mugabe's war veterans, Joseph Chinotimba, went to Gubbay's offices on Friday morning. Chinotimba has been identified at the centre of several violent incidents and has been charged with shooting his neighbour because she supports the MDC. After his visit to the Supreme Court chambers, Chinotimba announced that if Gubbay did not vacate his office, his war veterans would declare war upon him.

Gubbay agreed to leave his office, but he wrested guarantees from the government that it would respect the independence of the courts and would not take unlawful steps to remove any other judges. 'Gubbay sacrificed himself so the other judges could stay,' said one legal expert.

'Everyone knows that the only way to deal with a bully is to stand up to him,' said lawyer and MDC member of parliament Tendai Biti. 'This has empowered the other judges to stand firm.'

Other lawyers, however, are more sceptical of the guarantees, saying that if the government does not honour Supreme Court judgments, why should it honour agreements with Gubbay? They say once the government installs Godfrey Chidyausiku as Chief Justice, it will pursue its stated plan to clear the Supreme Court and the High Court of independent judges.

The government, through the increasingly powerful Information Minister Jonathan Moyo, has already announced its intention to rid the Supreme Court of the four remaining justices and to clear out four judges from the high court.

'The government expresses its lack of confidence in judges on the Supreme Court and the High Court,' said Moyo last week. 'We find those judges to be partial to white farming interests. We cannot have judges colluding with forces opposed to Zimbabwe. We must have judges who are part and parcel of our experience of the liberation struggle and who side with the majority of our people, especially the landless.'

Moyo has also spearheaded the government's attacks on the independent press, both local and foreign. The expulsion last month of two foreign journalists gained a great deal of attention, but it is the Zimbabwean journalists who write for privately-owned newspapers critical of the Mugabe government who are most at risk. They are persevering under enormous pressure to expose human rights abuses and corruption.

fields.headline: Despairing Tories want Hague out
fields.standfirst:
Poll shows party activists are convinced that the election is already lost, and a third want Michael Portillo to become leader, reports Kamal Ahmed

Special report: election countdown
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Conservatives' most ardent supporters have given up on the general election and believe William Hague should resign if the party is ever going to beat Labour.
fields.body:
The Conservatives' most ardent supporters have given up on the general election and believe William Hague should resign if the party is ever going to beat Labour.

An Observer poll of hundreds of Tory activists and firm party supporters - one of the most comprehensive undertaken by a newspaper - reveals the depth of the malaise afflicting Hague's party despite public claims he is preparing for government.

The findings come at a particularly embarrassing time for the Tories. This weekend the party leadership was trying to drum up enthusiasm among its rank and file at the Conservative annual spring conference in Harrogate.

The poll reveals that even among the Tories' strongest backers, the party activists, more than three-quarters think that the party will lose the next election with over a third believing that Hague should resign immediately or 'early in the next Parliament'. Among more general supporters, the figure believing the party will lose rises to a remarkable 86 per cent and nearly half think Hague should step down now or after the election.

With the election thought to be only a matter of weeks away, that means that many party members think Hague should quit as leader before the summer. More than a third of Tory supporters think Michael Portillo should lead the party, with 18 per cent backing Ann Widdecombe.

Most worrying for the Conservative high command is the obvious disillusionment among its frontline workers, the people who have to persuade voters on the doorstep during the campaign, organise rallies and ensure that turnout is as high as possible. The results will delight Labour strategists, who for the first time have hard evidence the Tories have given up the battle.

One senior Conservative backbencher admitted that the party was in disarray and that Hague would be approached by the 1922 Committee, the powerful group of Tory backbenchers known as 'the men in suits', and asked to step down within a year of the election defeat.

He said that at a recent meeting of the forward planning committee of the party, which includes all the main leadership players, only two members of Hague's front-bench team insisted that they could still win.

'It is a very bleak time,' the backbencher and former Minister said. 'The major problem is that we don't have a Plan B. When William loses, as he will, there is not an obvious candidate to succeed him. Portillo will split the party, Widdecombe will not go down well with the country. We don't have a talented figure coming up on the rails. We're in a real stick.'

The Observer commissioned YouGov Opinion Research, the political research and information company, to compile the survey details from its extensive database of party activists and supporters. It asked more than 700 people, two-thirds describing themselves as 'party activists', a set of questions to test the party's mood.

The answers provide clear evidence on why Hague abandoned talk of 'compassionate Conservatism'. The Observer revealed last week that the Tory leader considered resigning in December 1999 after a glut of negative headlines and bad poll results. He admitted that attempts to reposition the party towards the centre had failed and told friends that he was in danger of losing his core vote.

Asked whether the party should shift to the left - the centre ground where most political experts believe elections are won and lost - only 8 per cent of Tory activists surveyed agreed. More than a third thought the party should shift more to the right with over half saying that Hague's present tone should be maintained.

The vast majority of Tory activists, 77 per cent, believe Tony Blair will win the general election, with many saying the Labour majority will be a comfortable one. A third said that the majority would be between 50 and 100 seats.

On Hague's performance, one in five Tory activists said they thought it was poor or very poor compared with just one in 20 Labour activists asked the same question about Blair.

Among Conservative supporters, rather than activists, 42 per cent rated Hague as poor or very poor. Surprisingly, 34 per cent of Tory supporters say that they think Blair is doing a good job, compared with just 12 per cent of Labour voters who thought Hague was doing a good job.

The results of the survey also reveal that Hague will have to look at the structure of the Conservatives if he is to keep party workers on side. Asked if they thought there needed to be a 'fundamental change' in the way the party operated, half of Conservative activists said that there was a need for radical reform.

YouGov Opinion Research interviewed nearly 2,000 party supporters from all the main political parties, including 734 Tory activists and supporters.

Asked if they thought there needed to be a 'fundamental change' in the way the party operated, half of Conservative activists said that there was a need for radical reform. YouGov Opinion Research interviewed nearly 2,000 party supporters from all the main political parties, including 734 Tory activists and supporters.

webTitle: Hague: 'Britain will be a foreign land'

fields.headline: Hague: 'Britain will be a foreign land'
fields.standfirst:
Tory leader plays nationalist card in appeal to swing voters

Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: William Hague will today accuse Labour of turning Britain into a 'foreign land' where its own people feel unwelcome.
fields.body:
William Hague will today accuse Labour of turning Britain into a 'foreign land' where its own people feel unwelcome.

In a determined attempt to play the nationalist card, the Tory leader will argue that he is proud to champion the man in the street's gut instincts.

He will tell delegates at the Conservatives' conference in Harrogate to imagine what the country would be like if Labour wins a second term, adding: 'Let me take you on a journey to a foreign land - to Britain after a second term of Tony Blair. The Royal Mint melting down pound coins as the euro notes start to circulate.

'Our currency and our ability to set our own interest rates gone forever. The Chancellor returning from Brussels carrying instructions to raise taxes still further.'

Aides said his speech, focusing on Europe, tax, immigration and law and disorder, will be aimed at disgruntled swing voters who feel unwanted and disapproved of in a liberal Blairite Britain.

Hague is threatening an aggressive and hard-fought election campaign. 'It will be a bumpy ride,' said one. He is conveying the message of Britain becoming a country where its people feel uncomfortable, where its people feel alienated - a great example is political correctness.

'People feel nervous and ill at ease in their own country because the way that they express themselves, their instinctive attitudes and beliefs, the way they communicate with each other, are suddenly circumscribed by unfamiliar rules.'

The Tories insisted there were no racist undertones to the speech, and that Hague was not drawing an explicit parallel between the influx of immigrants and the sense that ordinary Britons were no longer welcome in their own country.

Hague has already been accused of a dangerous flirtation with populism over immigration or law and order issues. However, he will say tomorrow that the Tories are in line with what the majority of people want, including a system that rewards 'people who are trying to do the right thing' such as pensioners and married couples with children.

Aides say they are targeting not hardline core voters but the 10 million voters their private polling identifies as not yet having made up their minds on how to vote.

Meanwhile, Michael Portillo fired the first shot in the Budget battle in a speech that twice harked back to his time serving under Margaret Thatcher, a deliberate pitch to right-wing activists. He accused the Chancellor of 'stealth' tax rises which would undo any headline-grabbing tax cuts announced next week.

The Shadow Chancellor came under attack from the Government and the unions over his commitment to lower the inflation target to 2 per cent. Ken Jackson, leader of the AEEU union, warned that lower inflation targets would mean higher interest rates.

'The Tories tried monetarism in the 1980s and it cost us a third of manufacturing,' Jackson said. 'Portillo wants to do it all over again and that would cost us 250,000 manufacturing jobs.'

webTitle: Foot and mouth; who's to blame?

fields.headline: Who's to blame?
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: UK farmers
fields.body:
UK farmers

Yes The squalid conditions in which the pigs are kept act as breeding grounds for the disease, and the transport of animals across the country spreads it far and wide.

No Sheep and cows also get the disease. It is the Government's fault that so many abattoirs have closed down and animals have to be transported so far for slaughter

Supermarkets

Yes They have farmers over a barrel, and have driven down profits and standards of farming. They are responsible for promoting the industrialisation of agriculture which has led to the current outbreak.

No The Government is responsible for agricultural policy in the UK, not supermarkets, which simply respond to the demand from customers.

Animal activists

Yes They brought the disease to this country in a deliberate act of sabotage against livestock farmers.

No They would have had to knowingly buy an infected animal or infected meat and smuggle it into this country, which would be extremely difficult.

Foreign farmers

Yes The disease clearly came from somewhere, and there have been outbreaks in many other countries.

No There is no evidence that foreign farmers are particularly to blame. There are strict import controls on infected meat - which obviously failed - and the disease could have entered the country in something as simple as a cured meat sandwich.

The government

Yes The Government has driven the policy of cheap food that has lead to the industrialisation of agriculture which created the conditions for the disease to spread.

No The Government implements strict controls on hygiene and animal husbandry that has ensured that Britain hasn't had a significant outbreak of foot and mouth for over 30 years.

webTitle: Top IRA diehards threaten to defect

fields.headline: Top IRA diehards threaten to defect
fields.standfirst:
The Provisionals' most hardened killers 'say they'll go over to the Real IRA' if a single gun is surrendered

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Provisionals' most hardened killers 'say they'll go over to the Real IRA' if a single gun is surrendered.
fields.body:
Senior commanders of the Provisional IRA have told the Irish government that some of their most experienced members will defect to the dissident Real IRA if the Provisionals are forced to hand over any of their weapons.

Deep divisions with the Provos' notorious South Armagh 'brigade' have heightened fears that the province is on the brink of a renewed campaign of violence. Its members have been responsible for some of the worst atrocities during the Troubles and bitterly oppose any decommissioning.

The warning was given at secret talks within the past fortnight between senior Provisionals and Irish government representatives. Official sources in Dublin said radical steps towards permanent sealing of arms dumps holding guns, ammunition and explosives would lead to the defection of senior members in the 'bandit country' of South Armagh.

These terrorists are among the most capable and ruthless in the world. They planned and carried out so-called 'spectaculars', including the 1992 City of London bomb attacks that caused £800 million worth of damage. They also planned the London attack at Canary Wharf in 1996, which killed two people.

The Real IRA, which killed 28 people in the 1998 Omagh bombing, is desperate to take advantage of any possible split. The recruitment of new members from the IRA in South Armagh would be a major coup for the group, and would deal a huge blow to the Sinn Fein political leaders, Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness.

The failure of the IRA to make a fresh gesture on decommissioning has kept the Northern Ireland peace process in limbo. The Ulster Unionist Party has warned it will step up political sanctions against Sinn Fein, unless there is movement on the arms issue.

One senior Irish government source at the centre of secret contacts between the republican leadership and Dublin said: 'They told us that they could not sell decommissioning, or there would be a major split.

'They kept saying, "We cannot sell it". There would be no breakthrough.'

With the IRA refusing to put its illegal stores of rifles, rocket launchers, surface-to-air missiles, heavy machine guns, flame-throwers and Semtex explosive beyond use, there is little chance of the power-sharing Executive in Belfast surviving beyond the general election.

David Trimble, the Northern Ireland First Minister, is under increasing pressure to withdraw his Ulster Unionist Party from its coalition with Sinn Fein. His critics say he should not sit in government with a party whose military wing holds on to illegal weapons.

Resistance to any concessions on IRA arms is strongest in South Armagh, the most dangerous posting for British soldiers over the last 30 years. Underlining the worries of the republican leadership, Brian Keenan, one of the most respected IRA leaders and believed by some to be its chief of staff, was sent there last weekend.

Keenan, who directed the IRA's bombing campaign on mainland Britain during the Seventies, spoke at a commemoration for two IRA men who blew themselves up while transporting a bomb in 1988. One of them was Brendan Burns, who triggered the bombs that killed 18 British paratroopers in the Warren point massacre in 1979. Keenan told 800 local republicans: 'Those who say the way is over - I don't know what they're talking about. The revolution can never be over until we have our country, until we have British imperialism where it belongs, in the dustbin of history.'

Unionists including Trimble seized upon the remarks as proof that the IRA was ready and willing to return to war. But observers believe the comments were designed merely to placate the hardline gathering. A former IRA member who read the entire text of Keenan's speech told The Observer that Keenan's bellicose statement was intended to keep the Provisional movement together in South Armagh.

'The speech was more for internal than external consumption,' the ex-member said. 'Most of it emphasised republican unity and the need for cohesion while Sinn Fein is involved in negotiations. The speech should be viewed not primarily as a threat to the British but [as] an appeal to keep unity.'

He spoke as more evidence emerged of Real IRA support in the area. Recent bomb attacks along the Belfast to Dublin rail line have taken place outside Newry station, close to two republican housing estates. Local republicans say that until recently all attacks on the line occurred on the South Armagh side of the border town.

Recent explosions on the Newry side, however, prove the Real IRA has formed at least one, and perhaps two, new units in the town, they add.

A British Army spokesman expressed concern about the growing dissident republican threat in the border zone. There was a pattern to their attacks - 'a spate of bombings and shootings followed by a lull. A pause in attacks is always followed by a fresh wave of attacks and we are expecting a new onslaught very soon,' he said.

Last year the Real IRA, which broke from the Provisionals in 1997 because the Provos were willing to allow Sinn Fein to sign up to non-violence, carried out a bombing or shooting once every dozen days. These included bombs on London railway lines and a daring rocket attack on the headquarters of MI6 by the Thames.

Security forces fear that 2001 will see an intensification of that campaign.

fields.headline: Poll danger to peace process
fields.standfirst:
IRA stalls on demands to decommission in order to keep its ranks united

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: IRA stalls on demands to decommission in order to keep its ranks united.
fields.body:
For Taoiseach Bertie Ahern the news from the republican movement was bleak. All last week the secret and not-so secret contacts between Irish officials and IRA leaders contained the same depressing message - no moves possible on IRA disarmament.

The IRA would make no radical gesture to seal the bunkers containing tons of rifles, rocket-launchers, surface-to-air missiles, heavy machine-guns, flame-throwers, ammunition and Semtex explosive. The Irish peace process would remain in a dangerous deadlock.

'They [republican leaders] told us they could not sell decommissioning, or if they did there would be a major split. They kept saying "we cannot sell it". There would be no breakthrough,' one senior Irish government official at the centre of the contacts told The Observer.

With the IRA refusing to put its huge arsenal beyond use, the chances of Northern Ireland's power-sharing government, which includes the IRA's political allies, Sinn Fein, surviving beyond the general election look slimmer than ever. The Ulster Unionist Party says it cannot remain in government with Sinn Fein until the IRA decommissions its weaponry.

If Ahern and his officials wanted to find the principal reason why the IRA would not and could not move on guns, they might have travelled 60 miles north into South Armagh, the region known as 'bandit country'.

South Armagh - one of the most dangerous postings for British soldiers over the last 30 years - is the crucible of a struggle for the heart and soul of Irish republicanism. In one corner are those IRA members still loyal to the leadership of Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness, the Sinn Fein MPs whose peace strategy delivered the ceasefire. In the other corner is a growing band of republican dissidents who believe that strategy to have been a sell-out of their ideology, a retreat from their simplistic but emotionally effective demand for a British withdrawal and a united Ireland.

Resistance to any move on decommissioning arms, such as sealing IRA bunkers with concrete, is strongest here. Local IRA units have even threatened to break away from the organisation if the leadership compromises its arms dumps.

On the cusp of South Armagh, along the main Belfast to Dublin railway link, lies the physical evidence of the growing dissident threat. Two explosions have left large craters alongside the rail line close to two housing estates at the western edge of Newry. Train journeys between the two capitals remained disrupted over the weekend. Until recently most bomb attacks on the railway took place closer to the border with the Irish Republic, carried out by members of the Real IRA living along the frontier between South Armagh and North Louth.

Local republicans say the shift in attacks on the line proves that the Real IRA has also established fresh terror units in Newry, normally a stronghold for Sinn Fein.

Last year the Real IRA launched scores of terror attacks on British Army bases and police stations from the region. A British Army spokesman said there was real concern that there had been a lull in RIRA activity. 'A pause is always followed by a fresh wave of attacks, and we are expecting a new onslaught very soon,' he said.

In 2000 the RIRA carried out a gun or bomb attack every 12 days, including the firing of a Russian-made rocket at MI6 headquarters in London last September.

Several miles west of Newry is the village of Camlough, the home of Raymond McCreesh, an IRA prisoner who died on hunger strike in 1981. Every year republicans march to a memorial erected in honour of McCreesh on the left-hand side of the road between Camlough and Newry. This year, however, dissident republicans plan to hold a separate march to the memorial, another small but symbolic sign that the republican family in the area is drifting further apart.

Into this fractious and fiercely independent republican region last Sunday stepped Brian Keenan, a Belfast-born IRA veteran with a long pedigree of involvement in republican armed struggle.

Keenan, who directed the IRA bombing campaigns in Britain during the 1970s, was in Creggan, near Crossmaglen, to speak at a commemoration in honour of two IRA men who blew themselves up while transporting a bomb in 1988. One of the duo was Brendan Burns, who triggered the bombs that killed 18 British paratroopers at Warren Point in August 1979. On the same day the man who taught Burns how to make bombs, Thomas McMahon, blew up Lord Mountbatten and his fishing party in Sligo.

South Armagh is after all the region where the IRA has launched most of its so-called 'spectaculars' in the Troubles.

Surrounded by 800 republican supporters, some of them members of the Provisional IRA's elite South Armagh Brigade, Keenan issued a bellicose warning.

'Those who say the war is over, I don't know what they're talking about. The revolution can never be over until we have our country, until we have British imperialism where it belongs - in the dustbin of history,' he told his audience.

Unionists, including First Minister David Trimble, have seized upon Keenan's remarks as proof the IRA was not only unwilling to decommission but ready and able to return to violence. Trimble demanded an explanation from Sinn Fein.

But former IRA members who read Keenan's speech suspected the reason for his sabre-rattling was to keep the movement together in South Armagh and halt defections to the Real IRA, the group responsible for the Omagh atrocity in August 1998.

'The speech was more for internal than external consumption,' one former IRA volunteer told The Observer , 'Most of Keenan's speech emphasised republican unity and the need for cohesion while Sinn Fein is involved in negotiations. The speech should be viewed not primarily as a threat to the British but rather an appeal to keep unity.'

Keenan is highly respected in South Armagh for his role in directing bombings and assassinations in Britain as well as helping to organise arms shipments and contacts with foreign governments, including Libya and Syria.

One of the IRA's local commanders still loyal to the leadership is Thomas 'Slab' Murphy, a South Armagh farmer whose property straddles the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic.

Murphy is not only an in-famous IRA leader but also a successful businessman whom the authorities on both sides of the border suspect made his fortune smuggling livestock and fuel back and forth across the frontier.

Smuggling cattle, diesel, cigarettes, alcohol, fake CDs and perfume has helped fund the Provos' war effort, while amassing a fortune for those in charge of the operations.

Smuggling is even celebrated in song as one local ballad written around 1940 boasts:

Now when first the border started and 'twas seen that smuggling paid
King George he ordered out his men to try and stop the trade
'But don't,' says he, 'pass Silverbridge, you might not come back again
For there's not a cop would ever stop the boys of Crossmaglen

On Friday, reporters and camera crews attempting to get close to Murphy's and other farms belonging to leading republicans were warded off by groups of men wearing leather jackets and sunglasses. Many of them threatened to break cameras if the crews advanced further.

The media had descended on 'bandit country' to cover the presence of foot and mouth disease on a farm at Meigh, close to the Irish border. Moderate nationalist politicians, such as the SDLP's John Fee, blamed local republicans for smuggling the infected sheep from England to South Armagh, thus endangering the entire economy of Ireland.

South Armagh's smugglers, said Fee, are now posing as much of a threat to both parts of Ireland as the Provisionals' South Armagh Brigade did. Fee, who was beaten up by the IRA for speaking out in 1994, has put himself at considerable risk.

The presence of foot and mouth in the most dangerous part of Northern Ireland also poses a paradox for the Province's politicians.

David Trimble, besieged by critics in his own party who want him to leave the power-sharing government with Sinn Fein, would dearly love the general election to be postponed. Trimble needs more time to persuade Sinn Fein that it must get the IRA to shift on arms, otherwise he will be deposed as Unionist leader and replaced by hardliners like Ian Paisley.

If an election were called tomorrow, Trimble's Ulster Unionists would suffer heavy electoral losses at the hands of Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party. Trimble, like Adams and McGuinness, is caught between the demands for internal unity and making concessions to traditional enemies.

Yet if the foot and mouth crisis spreads, it could have a positive spin-off for the Irish peace process - the postponement of an election which many agree is hampering any chance of compromise between unionists and nationalists.

One of the duo was Brendan Burns, who triggered the bombs that killed 18 British paratroopers at Warren Point in August 1979. On the same day the man who taught Burns how to make bombs, Thomas McMahon, blew up Lord Mountbatten and his fishing party in Sligo. South Armagh is after all the region where the IRA has launched most of its so-called 'spectaculars' in the Troubles. Surrounded by 800 republican supporters, some of them members of the Provisional IRA's elite South Armagh Brigade, Keenan issued a bellicose warning. 'Those who say the war is over, I don't know what they're talking about. The revolution can never be over until we have our country, until we have British imperialism where it belongs - in the dustbin of history,' he told his audience. Unionists, including First Minister David Trimble, have seized upon Keenan's remarks as proof the IRA was not only unwilling to decommission but ready and able to return to violence. Trimble demanded an explanation from Sinn Fein. But former IRA members who read Keenan's speech suspected the reason for his sabre-rattling was to keep the movement together in South Armagh and halt defections to the Real IRA, the group responsible for the Omagh atrocity in August 1998. 'The speech was more for internal than external consumption,' one former IRA volunteer told The Observer , 'Most of Keenan's speech emphasised republican unity and the need for cohesion while Sinn Fein is involved in negotiations. The speech should be viewed not primarily as a threat to the British but rather an appeal to keep unity.' Keenan is highly respected in South Armagh for his role in directing bombings and assassinations in Britain as well as helping to organise arms shipments and contacts with foreign governments, including Libya and Syria. One of the IRA's local commanders still loyal to the leadership is Thomas 'Slab' Murphy, a South Armagh farmer whose property straddles the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic. Murphy is not only an in-famous IRA leader but also a successful businessman whom the authorities on both sides of the border suspect made his fortune smuggling livestock and fuel back and forth across the frontier. Smuggling cattle, diesel, cigarettes, alcohol, fake CDs and perfume has helped fund the Provos' war effort, while amassing a fortune for those in charge of the operations. Smuggling is even celebrated in song as one local ballad written around 1940 boasts: Now when first the border started and 'twas seen that smuggling paid King George he ordered out his men to try and stop the trade 'But don't,' says he, 'pass Silverbridge, you might not come back again For there's not a cop would ever stop the boys of Crossmaglen On Friday, reporters and camera crews attempting to get close to Murphy's and other farms belonging to leading republicans were warded off by groups of men wearing leather jackets and sunglasses. Many of them threatened to break cameras if the crews advanced further. The media had descended on 'bandit country' to cover the presence of foot and mouth disease on a farm at Meigh, close to the Irish border. Moderate nationalist politicians, such as the SDLP's John Fee, blamed local republicans for smuggling the infected sheep from England to South Armagh, thus endangering the entire economy of Ireland. South Armagh's smugglers, said Fee, are now posing as much of a threat to both parts of Ireland as the Provisionals' South Armagh Brigade did. Fee, who was beaten up by the IRA for speaking out in 1994, has put himself at considerable risk. The presence of foot and mouth in the most dangerous part of Northern Ireland also poses a paradox for the Province's politicians. David Trimble, besieged by critics in his own party who want him to leave the power-sharing government with Sinn Fein, would dearly love the general election to be postponed. Trimble needs more time to persuade Sinn Fein that it must get the IRA to shift on arms, otherwise he will be deposed as Unionist leader and replaced by hardliners like Ian Paisley. If an election were called tomorrow, Trimble's Ulster Unionists would suffer heavy electoral losses at the hands of Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party. Trimble, like Adams and McGuinness, is caught between the demands for internal unity and making concessions to traditional enemies. Yet if the foot and mouth crisis spreads, it could have a positive spin-off for the Irish peace process - the postponement of an election which many agree is hampering any chance of compromise between unionists and nationalists.

webTitle: SNP dissidents lose out in row over tax

fields.headline: SNP dissidents lose out in row over tax
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: A plan to give the Scottish Parliament full control over all taxes raised north of the border yesterday sparked a bitter debate among Scottish National Party candidates at the forthcoming general election.
fields.body:
A plan to give the Scottish Parliament full control over all taxes raised north of the border yesterday sparked a bitter debate among Scottish National Party candidates at the forthcoming general election.

At the party's spring conference in Glasgow, candidates called for the plan to be shelved. They dismissed it as vague and said it would legitimise Labour's devolved Assembly and dilute plans for full independence.

The dispute came in a debate on finance. Andrew Wilson, the Shadow Finance Minister, argued that Scotland would send to the London Treasury £8 billion more in tax revenues over the next two years than it would get back in government spending.

Calling for 'full fiscal powers' for the Edinburgh Parliament, he said: 'We have right on our side. The Scottish Parliament for which we waited so long has fewer powers than any other parliament on earth, bar none. We don't even have the power to borrow that local authorities have.' He argued Scotland was in a strong financial position, with a surplus of tax revenues equivalent to £1,500 per head.

But Heather Williams, prospective candidate for Edinburgh South, complained that the resolution did not define full fiscal autonomy, or say what tax revenues should be included.

She said some voters would wonder what was the difference between full fiscal autonomy and the goal of independence. 'If the unionists want to offer us fiscal autonomy, we take it, obviously,' she said. 'But as a party of national sovereignty we should not be campaigning for it on its own,' she said.

Alex Dingwall, candidate for Glasgow Maryhill, said: 'We are going down there to argue the case for independence and I don't want sideshows or diversions on other issues.' But Angus McNeill, candidate for Inverness East, Nairn and Lochaber, told activists that Scotland was hampered by a one-size-fits-all economic policy set by London. 'If we can get half a loaf before the loaf, we take it. Ideally, we get the loaf,' he said.

Andrew Wilson, replying to the dissidents, said: 'It's part of the case for independence - not instead of it.' The call to shelve the resolution was lost and delegates approved the plan.

At the end of the two-day conference, SNP leader John Swinney told delegates that with the Tories effectively out of the race for seats north of the border, the nationalists could now take the fight to Labour in its heartlands.

'The SNP's message that we stand for Scotland will be the most powerful and compelling message in the campaign,' he said.
