fields.headline: Ireland put under plague siege
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Ireland's vital multi-billion pound farming industry breathed a collective sigh of relief last night after initial tests on a suspected foot and mouth outbreak in Co Louth proved negative.
fields.byline: Henry McDonald, Kamal Ahmed and Sarah Ryle
fields.body:
Ireland's vital multi-billion pound farming industry breathed a collective sigh of relief last night after initial tests on a suspected foot and mouth outbreak in Co Louth proved negative.

But this weekend the Irish Republic still resembled an enclosed medieval city fighting to keep out the plague, with border crossing points closed, the movement of people and animals in the countryside banned, masses at Catholic churches cancelled and even rural schools threatened with closure.

Meanwhile it emerged that there is to be a crackdown on the way Britain's biggest supermarkets use their power to manipulate the food industry. This follows Tony Blair's comment that they had an 'armlock' on farmers.

A legally enforceable code of conduct being drawn up by the Department of Trade and Industry and the Office of Fair Trading will demand that supermarkets have a fairer relationship with farmers, who complain they are bullied into providing food at very cheap prices by the large chains.

Despite the good news from Co Louth, Ireland is not lowering its guard. It will take another 24 hours for veterinary scientists analysing tissue samples taken from animals at the farm close to the Northern Ireland border fully to verify a negative result.

However, the Irish Agriculture Minister Joe Walsh said he was cautiously optimistic that the state would escape an outbreak of the disease. which would threaten an industry worth IR£11 billion. One economic forecaster, Jim Power of Friends First Asset Management, estimated that the crisis could knock 1.5 per cent off the Republic's national growth rate.

There was however a further boost for Ireland's struggle to protect vital agriculture export markets when the United States Department of Agriculture lifted its threat to ban Irish imports into North America. France, though, has banned imports of live stock from Ireland .

Ireland only consumes 15 per cent of its agricultural produce; the remaining 85 per cent is exported to 100 countries around the world.

A spokesman for the Department of Agriculture in Dublin said the results of preliminary tests on a suspected foot and mouth outbreak have proved negative. The animals were on a farm in the exclusion zone, close to another farm in Northern Ireland where there had been a confirmed outbreak of the disease.

The RUC is currently investigating allegations that the infected animals were brought to Ireland from England by South Armagh-based smugglers.

In a desperate bid to seal the border, the Irish government called for more police officers to patrol on the northern side of the border. Michael Smith, the Republic's Defence Minister, appealed to the RUC to deploy officers on the South Armagh end of the frontier. But the RUC is thin on the ground in the region because of the ever-present threat of attack from dissident republican paramilitaries. Even heavily armed British troops only travel through the area via helicopter avoiding roads that might be booby-trapped or mined.

Smith has already dispatched 4,000 Irish troops to the border in a move to shut down one of the most porous frontiers in the world, which is littered with hundreds of unapproved roads and crossing points.

Many sectors of Irish economic and social life have simply shut down as the Republic closes the drawbridge in a bid to keep foot and mouth out.

For the first time since the anti-Catholic penal laws of the seventeenth century, Catholic masses have been called off across the country. Thirteen churches in the Louth-South Armagh border zone have been asked not to celebrate Sunday mass.

In a letter to priests, the leader of Ireland's four million Catholics, Archbishop Sean Brady said that where it was considered necessary to cancel services, parishioners were excused from Sunday mass and should not travel to neighbouring parishes.

The Licensed Vintners Association, which represents Ireland's publicans, has told members to provide disinfectant for rural pubs. In Co Longford a district court judge urged local nightclubs to close for a week.

Air travel between Ireland and Britain has also effectively shut down with Aer Lingus and British Airways cancelling many flights.

Although Irish trainers and horses will not be travelling to this week's Cheltenham festival there was some good news for punters. Irish bookmakers will refund all bets on Cheltenham races. A spokesman said the gesture could cost the industry hundreds of thousands of pounds.

Sporting fixtures have been heavily affected with no soccer, Gaelic games, horse racing, hockey and even Ireland's Six Nations rugby clash with Wales called off.

St Patrick's Day parades north and south have also been cancelled including a four-day festival in Dublin.

Meanwhile Northern Ireland's Agriculture Minister Brid Rogers announced yesterday that further tests on farms in the Province showed there were no further suspected cases of foot and mouth.

She said that other than one confirmed case there are no other cases, which would have forced her officials to send samples to be tested. About 1,000 pigs have already been slaughtered as a precautionary measure on a South Armagh farm.

Like the Republic, rural life in Northern Ireland has ground to a halt as a result of restrictions on the movements or animals and people. All sporting fixtures including soccer matches in Belfast city, which is unaffected by the disease, were called off yesterday.

But the Province's deputy first minister Seamus Mallon criticised the Belfast Giants - the North's new ice hockey side - for going ahead this weekend with home games against Nottingham and Cardiff.

Hundreds of Welsh ice hockey fans have come to Belfast even though the rugby international was cancelled to prevent Irish supporters from travelling to Cardiff.

'I say to the Giants it is not in the interests of the people of Northern Ireland,' Mallon said.

In Britain supermarkets - including Asda, Safeway, Tesco and Sainsbury's - will face heavy fines if they fail to stick to the new rules.

The Government revealed yesterday that seven more cases of foot and mouth had been found - from Cornwall to Dumfries and Galloway - bringing the total number of cases to 51.

The chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, said 45,000 cattle had now been slaughtered. Scudamore admitted that there were at least three more highly suspect cases . He could not say how long the crisis would last.

fields.headline: Going to court
fields.standfirst: Three more food emporia
fields.trailText: Three more food emporia.
fields.body:
The Orient Food Court Trafford Centre, Manchester (0161 749 1717). Bow-shaped, like an ocean liner, with wooden decks and teak recliners, The Orient makes a glitzy centrepiece for the Trafford Centre and houses a plethora of fast-food outlets with 1,600 seats between them. These range from McDonald's (natch) to Shere Khan (Indian) and even Vie 2 Go (vegetarian), but your best bet is probably Bar M, which serves Mediterranean snacks. Tuesdays (4.30-7pm) are the highlight of the week, when a showband plays for the tea dances held on the central stage. Old-timers come by the coachload to practise their steps and demonstrate just what stamina is to weary shoppers caught with their shoes off.

Swansea Market Oxford Street, Swansea (01792 654 296). Ask the Welsh which is their favourite food court and you may get some very odd looks. They think it's a mad idea (and who can blame them?). But they do recommend a visit to the principality's biggest covered market in Swansea, where the principle is much the same. Visitors wander from stall to stall, sampling local delights, such as laver bread and cockles. You can't sit down, but at 70p/qtr, who's complaining?

Harrods Food Halls Knightsbridge, London SW1 (020 7730 1234). Even if you hate Harrods out of habit, you have to admit that the food halls, with their vaulted ceilings and Victorian tiling, their towering displays of chocolates and caviare and smoked salmon and foie gras are, well, impressive. So it's hardly surprising that so many people succumb to a sense of gastronomic decadence and sit sipping champagne (flute, £8.50), mid-shopping trip, at the many on-site food bars. The sushi bar is one of the most popular. It has kimono-clad waitresses and serious sushi chefs, but you have to take a numbered ticket before you can order, which leaves hopeful pescivores to mill about in front of a counter where things have been made to stand oddly to attention in aspic. Nothing here is cheap, but at the Bar Fromage opposite you can get one cheese with salad and a glass of house wine for £9.75. Or there's the pizzeria, complete with roaring, wood-fired oven, a tapas bar in the wine section, a sea grill, rotisserie and oyster bar in the fish hall and an espresso bar above the root-veg display. No matter where you look, there are little cut-out policemen with flashing red bicycle lights, warning the light-fingered of CCTV in the store.

webTitle: Phil Hogan on the Porsche Boxster

fields.headline: Blonde ambition
fields.standfirst: The Porsche Boxster might be perfect in every way, but Phil Hogan didn't manage to impress a single woman
fields.trailText: The Porsche Boxster might be perfect in every way, but Phil Hogan didn't manage to impress a single woman.
fields.body:
Price from £31,450

MPG 28.5

Engine size 2,687cc

Max speed 155mph

0-62mph 6.6 seconds

Driven wheels 2

The new Porsche Boxster is a joy to look at. For a good half-hour after Bob the Porsche delivery man has dropped it off at our house at the crack of breakfast, I keep coming back out to gawp at it, imagining I'm one of the neighbours wondering who that fantastic car belongs to. I am not a person who has ever dreamed of owning a Porsche or, for that matter, any other car that attracts such extremes of envy, pity, contempt and Schadenfreude, but now that I've got one I know when Bob comes back for it next week I'll have to shoot him and bury him under the patio rather than hand it over. I love it. Look at those silvery curves! Look at those big wheels! I open the door and sniff the inside. I seem to have the vegetarian option - fake leather - but it does look the business.

Actually getting inside the Boxster is a trickier job unless you have been a limbo dancer in a previous life. It's go-kart low. You wouldn't be advised to get in one wearing a kilt. And it is a bit restricted in terms of movement (think luxury coffin), and has shockingly bad vision at the back. But the seats are comfy and the instrument panel has, refreshingly, not been inspired by aeroplanes. Everything is heated and fingertip-adjustable, with electronic this, that and the other. The blower can demist the windows and whip your hair up into a bun at the same time. And if you could measure the virility of a car by the power of its windscreen washers, this one is Tom Jones right down to the lungs.

What now? Well, I feel duty bound to inspect the engine. I lift the bonnet, which conceals a generous luggage compartment. Mmm. I look in the boot. Hang on, it's not here either_ I try the front again just in case it's a very small, see-through engine. Nothing. Eventually I discover from the blurb that the engine is cunningly hidden beneath the back parcel shelf. I almost give it a round of applause. Who says the Germans have no sense of humour?

Naturally the first thing I want to do with my new Porsche is put a sticker in the rear window saying 'My other car is a Fiat with balding tyres' but if I do that there won't be enough window left to look out of and it would be a shame to reverse into next door's kitchen. So the first thing I plan to do instead is cruise around town to see if the car works properly - by which I mean see how many impressionable young women at the bus stop mistake me for a daytime TV presenter or Premiership footballer. Of course, received wisdom has it that they are more likely to mistake me for someone with a midlife crisis whose parents have died in suspicious circumstances, leaving me a small but useful bungalow to sell.

People like to poke fun at the maturer man who enjoys nothing more than to tool it down the M4 in a sleek convertible with a blonde at his side and the wind blowing through his hair transplant. But who do they expect to see driving expensive sports cars? I mean, even at £30,000-plus for the basic model, they're hardly targeted it at your average spotty junior estate agent, unless he plans to live in it, too. No, according to my research, the majority of Porsches are driven by financially stable chaps who have reached the point where they are old enough to have sex with women half their age without breaking the law. So off I go. There are plenty of traffic lights to idle at with the window down and the music turned up; I try cruising slowly past the ladies hairdressers; I try getting out to pretend to see what time the post office opens; I sit outside Blockbuster tapping the steering wheel impatiently, as though I am waiting for Jennifer Lopez to come out. There's not much interest. So I take it down the motorway to check out its handling.

I'm never quite sure what 'handling' is, but the car seems to know exactly what to do, and I am soon having fun watching my fellow motorists scarper for cover as I roar up behind them out of nowhere. Eventually I turn off and snake back through little villages, watching out in vain for sidelong glances from shepherdesses and milkmaids admiring my low drag coefficient.

I pull into a layby and press the button that lets the top down. This is as smooth as I'm ever going to get. I look around. I entertain the fleeting idea of strolling back down the road to look in an antique shop window and then casually vaulting back into the car without opening the door, but I am now being closely scrutinised by a horse in a field. I drive on, alfresco, trying to ignore the striking effect that not having a roof has on ambient temperatures. I arrive home with icicles in my hair, not having picked up a single blonde. Luckily, I am already married to one (well, a reddish blonde), who has been wondering where I've got to.

No matter. I'm just as happy to potter round the locality. Few people realise that the Boxster also doubles as the perfect weekend leisure vehicle for the family man. Imagine. It's Saturday morning, and you're sneaking out for a paper and a packet of Rolos when your wife reminds you that the children need ferrying to their kung fu/ canoeing/bassoon lessons. Well obviously you'd love to help but, sorry - only two seats. Bye!

On the other hand it can be used to earn valuable credibility points with your innumerable offspring, whom you can take in turn on quality-time joyrides ('Don't touch the ejector-seat button, son! Arf, arf!'). On the Monday I run the eldest to school, and in the process offer an educational demonstration of G-forces courtesy of the car's breathtaking 0 to whooooooooahhhh! in 6.7 seconds. We glide to a halt opposite the school gates to be immediately surrounded by a crowd of drooling year sevens.

'Wow, look at that,' says one.

My sentiments exactly. Just look at it.

For a good half-hour after Bob the Porsche delivery man has dropped it off at our house at the crack of breakfast, I keep coming back out to gawp at it, imagining I'm one of the neighbours wondering who that fantastic car belongs to. I am not a person who has ever dreamed of owning a Porsche or, for that matter, any other car that attracts such extremes of envy, pity, contempt and Schadenfreude, but now that I've got one I know when Bob comes back for it next week I'll have to shoot him and bury him under the patio rather than hand it over. I love it. Look at those silvery curves! Look at those big wheels! I open the door and sniff the inside. I seem to have the vegetarian option - fake leather - but it does look the business. Actually getting inside the Boxster is a trickier job unless you have been a limbo dancer in a previous life. It's go-kart low. You wouldn't be advised to get in one wearing a kilt. And it is a bit restricted in terms of movement (think luxury coffin), and has shockingly bad vision at the back. But the seats are comfy and the instrument panel has, refreshingly, not been inspired by aeroplanes. Everything is heated and fingertip-adjustable, with electronic this, that and the other. The blower can demist the windows and whip your hair up into a bun at the same time. And if you could measure the virility of a car by the power of its windscreen washers, this one is Tom Jones right down to the lungs. What now? Well, I feel duty bound to inspect the engine. I lift the bonnet, which conceals a generous luggage compartment. Mmm. I look in the boot. Hang on, it's not here either_ I try the front again just in case it's a very small, see-through engine. Nothing. Eventually I discover from the blurb that the engine is cunningly hidden beneath the back parcel shelf. I almost give it a round of applause. Who says the Germans have no sense of humour? Naturally the first thing I want to do with my new Porsche is put a sticker in the rear window saying 'My other car is a Fiat with balding tyres' but if I do that there won't be enough window left to look out of and it would be a shame to reverse into next door's kitchen. So the first thing I plan to do instead is cruise around town to see if the car works properly - by which I mean see how many impressionable young women at the bus stop mistake me for a daytime TV presenter or Premiership footballer. Of course, received wisdom has it that they are more likely to mistake me for someone with a midlife crisis whose parents have died in suspicious circumstances, leaving me a small but useful bungalow to sell. People like to poke fun at the maturer man who enjoys nothing more than to tool it down the M4 in a sleek convertible with a blonde at his side and the wind blowing through his hair transplant. But who do they expect to see driving expensive sports cars? I mean, even at £30,000-plus for the basic model, they're hardly targeted it at your average spotty junior estate agent, unless he plans to live in it, too. fields.headline: Top crops
fields.standfirst: You don't have to go far for exotic food that's ready to eat
fields.trailText: You don't have to go far for exotic food that's ready to eat.
fields.body:
Not all the fruit and vegetables on sale at Wembley Exotics (133-135 Ealing Road, Wembley, Middlesex; 020 8900 2607) are exotic. Some appear so because they are simply out of kilter with our seasons - you can buy fresh peas in the pod, for example - while others are relatively unusual. We are used to seeing chickpeas dried or in a tin, but here they come fresh, green and lightly peppery tasting, two to a pod: 'an annual treat not to be missed', says Madhur Jaffrey.

Most of the vegetables come from faraway locations including Kenya, Uganda, Nigeria, South Africa, Bangladesh, Pakistan, India, North and South America and the Far East. Among them, try knobbly skinned, cucumber-shaped karela (stuff it with minced meat); green-skinned dudhi (grate the white flesh, boil, sieve and add to yogurt, together with salt, pepper and chillies); and crisp-textured tindori, which looks like a cross between a cherry and a rugby ball (dice it into a vegetable curry).

Spring is the best time for fresh goat's milk cheeses, which are just starting to arrive in March. David Lockwood at Neal's Yard Dairy (17 Shorts Gardens, London WC2; 020 7240 5700, and 6 Park Street, London SE1; 020 7645 3550) recommends three in particular at this time of year, two of them from Ireland. St Tola, made in Co Clare, is an organic log, while Mine Gabhar, from near Blackwater in Co Wexford, is a wrinkly 2in-high cylinder. Tymsboro, made by Mary Holbrook at Slate Farm near Bath, is a pyramid-shaped, ash-covered cheese. All three are young, soft and matured for between two and four weeks. Among cow's milk cheeses, Burland Green is an all-year-rounder that shines particularly well just now. Made near Nantwich in Cheshire by the Allwoods, it is an organic soft-ripening cheese in the style of Brie and Camembert.

Even Mediterranean countries experience an agricultural slow-down at this time of year. In Spain, it is a time to enjoy the produce of two harvests that go well together: pork and beans. Tormesina beans are harvested by hand in October; rich and creamy, they are sold by Brindisa (Thursday to Saturday on Borough Market, London SE1 and via its mail-order company Pata Negra, 020 7736 1959; info@patanegra.net). Judion (large butter beans) are £10.70 for a 1kg box. Arrocina (small haricot) are £6.80, and Planchada (long white haricot) are £6.40. Pigs are traditionally slaughtered in autumn, and while hams may take a couple of years to mature (Iberico hams from the Iberian black pig are rated tops, £38.30 per kg), other pork products are in their prime now. Chorizo sausages come in two basic forms: cured for slicing or semi-cured for grilling and eating hot. A pack of six Catalan chorizos (mild or spicy) costs £3.50. Delivery is £4.95.

 Jim Ainsworth is editor of The Good Food Guide.

fields.headline: All in the mind
fields.standfirst: You may be convinced you're at death's door, but to GPs hypochondriacs are just a headache. Sophie Radice reports on health anxiety
fields.trailText: You may be convinced you're at death's door, but to GPs hypochondriacs are just a headache. Sophie Radice reports on health anxiety.
fields.body:
Having children has meant an awful lot of nervous flicking through the Family Health Tome. Mine always falls open at the 'M' pages (measles, meningitis and mumps) but I usually end up daring myself to have a random and prurient peek at the grisly photographs and descriptions of symptoms in the pages preceeding or beyond. Once I have diagnosed my child, I feel I am at leisure to find something deeply unpleasant with symptoms closely resembling the feelings and discomforts I have been suffering in silence while selflessly tending to my family's health needs.

I think that most of us suffer from a degree of anxiety about our health, and we certainly recognise it in those we live with. My cold is my husband's flu and my father's every sore throat 'streptococcal', while my son gives me a list of serious ailments each day which he self-diagnoses with a pessimism which would rival the hypochondriac in Molière's Le Malade Imaginaire .

For the majority of us, however, these feelings of anxiety about our bodies malfunctioning are replaced by another preoccupation soon enough. It is amazing, for instance, how quickly my son perks up when I inform him that his 'broken wrist' will prohibit him from playing PlayStation that day. And even when we take our health concerns as far as a trip to the doctor, most of us are reassured by their diagnosis or opinion and quickly move on to worrying about money or schools or our marriage instead. For some people, though, this isn't the case - these feelings of preoccupation with a disease or indeed any number of illnesses don't pass but grow and start to dominate the way they think about themselves, their body and their future. The persistence of this anxiety about health is what separates the 'worried well' from the hypochondriac.

Sheila Roderiquez, 52, is often told that her feeling that she has ovarian cancer is 'only' her imagination. She has had three private investigative operations, countless tests and visited more than 20 doctors in England, France and Spain. Nothing has been found to be medically wrong with her, yet that does not reassure or stop her trying to find 'better' medical advice.

The fear, anticipation and certainty of having an illness has taken over, costing her time and money and affecting the quality of her life. Her husband, Freddo, feels that this experience is marring their life almost as much as a physical illness 'because increasingly she lives like an invalid. I think I have probably gone along with it all too much, but every time she saw a new doctor I thought she might believe what they had to say. Certainly my son now feels that I should help her to get over her fears.'

Professor Paul Salkovskis is the clinical director of the Centre for Anxiety Disorders at the Maudsley hospital and treats cases of 'persistent health anxiety' (a term which has less negative connotations then hypochondria) with cognitive-behavioural therapy. 'People get anxious about what is important to them, and of course health is very important to most people. Those with severe health anxiety seem to interpret their bodily variations differently from other people, though. This may not just come from physical sensation but also from something heard on the radio, read in a magazine or seen on television. For those with severe health anxiety, the information will trigger feelings of hyper-awareness of the body which are very real and need to be taken very seriously.'

Professor Salkovskis does not test his patients for the illness they think they have because the nature of health anxiety means that this almost certainly will not offer reassurance. Instead, they go through a series of behavioural experiments in which they will find out for themselves that they may be interpreting their symptoms of anxiety as a physical illness. 'For instance, someone may think there is something wrong with the glands in their neck, that their size is indicative of a serious disease, and repeatedly touch them to check. We would suggest that they may actually be causing the glands to become inflamed and/or enlarged because of this constant touching. Each case is different, though, so the cognitive therapy is, of course, personalised.'

Melissa Woycechowksy, 32, is able to be objective about her hypochondria because she has, to a large extent, recovered from her health anxiety through psychiatry and courses of Prozac. She has set up a health-anxiety website, http://healthanxiety.com/, which offers support to other sufferers - an irony because there was a time when the internet fed and fuelled her health concerns - and she has featured in a number of articles about 'cyberchondria', which occurs when an individual surfs the net in a frenzy of health anxiety. 'I started spending more and more time on the net in an attempt to find out what kind of disease I had,' says Woycechowksy. 'I was having a lot of physical anxiety symptoms, couldn't sleep, and was sure I had a neurological disorder.' At her most extreme, she was absolutely terrified. 'I'd just sit in bed with my laptop computer, crying.'

It seems that those who are severely concerned about their health have no common cause for their obsession. According to Professor Salkovskis, 'There are only guesses and theories. For instance, you may be preoccupied with the illness that someone you loved died of. Others seem to feel that they somehow deserve to have a serious illness, or it may be that they got more attention as a child when they were ill. Equally, it may be a reaction to stress or a feeling that it's more acceptable to be physically ill than mentally ill. Oddly enough, those who have been seriously ill, who you might expect to suffer from severe health anxiety, rarely seem to, and parents who have suffered from health anxiety don't seem to pass it on to their children.'

For the average GP, who is trained to spot and treat those with genuine physical illness, dealing with someone suffering from hypochondrosis (or, in GP speak, 'the thick file' patient) is very difficult. Helen Cartwright, a GP who works in a busy London practice, certainly finds herself wondering what to do when she looks at the computer and realises that the person in front of her has seen dozens of doctors about the same thing. 'You want them to go and get help, but as they believe so strongly that there is something wrong (often with their heart or stomach, in my experience), it is very difficult to convince someone to do that. Also - and I think that this is very important - just because they are suffering from hypochondrosis does not mean that there is definitely not something physically wrong with them.'

And that really seems to be the crux of the matter - hypochondriacs want a certainty that they are 100 per cent well. But the truth is that there is no doctor on earth that can ever be completely, without a shadow of a doubt, certain about the health of a patient. For most patients, that slight uncertainty is something they live with and accept as part of life, but for the hypochondriac, this uncertainty is unacceptable and becomes a daily torment - a torment that can eventually only be relieved by specialist psychiatric help. As Helen Cartwright says: 'It is very hard to understand when someone is not relieved by a negative diagnosis and reacts instead with disappointment and disbelief. Ordinary GPs are simply not equipped to deal with this very particular psychological complaint and need the support of the friends and family of the person suffering from health anxiety to make them stop "doctor shopping" and to take the giant step of seeing someone who is trained to deal with this complex mental-health problem.'

Health anxiety symptoms

1 Worrying endlessly about your health.
2 Being acutely aware of your body and its variations.
3 Feeling that people are not taking your illnesses seriously enough.
4 Worrying about getting every disease that comes to your attention.
5 Finding it hard to believe the doctor when he/she tells you that there is nothing for you to worry about.
6 Losing sleep over the fear that you have a serious illness.
7 Being endlessly bothered by symptoms of illness.
8 Constantly seeking second opinions from doctors.

For help and advice

Go to http://healthanxiety.com or call the No Panic helpline on 01952 590 545.

 Jane Clarke will be back next week.

fields.headline: Well being
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: spring-cleaning your liver for extra energy, and the perils of too much travel
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: spring-cleaning your liver for extra energy, and the perils of too much travel.
fields.body:
With the daffs in the garden trumpeting in the arrival of spring, it's time to examine the Taoist take on this joyous seasonal transfer. Go 'Brrrr!' and shake off the kidney-crunching cold of winter. Take your fists and use them to massage some warmth into your lower back, then relax while I talk you through the Taoist springtime schema. You have five vital organs: heart, lungs, spleen (including pancreas), kidneys and liver.

During each of the five seasons (summer is split into early and late), a different organ is energetically predominant. Right now we're coming into liver time. It's no accident that your 'liver' is spelt the way it is. It's what gives you the oomph to slough off your inner wallflower, grab your adventure by the ears and live it to the full.

Each of the vital organs is assigned different responsibilities in connection with your self-development. While your kidneys give you will power, your heart the power to love, your spleen the power to intellectualise and your lungs the power to create, your liver gives you the power to grow and take on new challenges. In this capacity (of self-renewal and, by extension, species renewal), it also gives you the drive to come out of hibernation, both literally and metaphorically, and interact with the external world - socialise, in other words. This is true all year round, but is more pronounced in spring, when nature invites you to partake one way or another in the mating game (and renewal of the species).

However, being the season's predominant organ doesn't come without its drawbacks, vulnerability to climate being one. Spring is traditionally known as the windy season, when the winds of change blow through your system and stir the sap in your sacrum that it might rise through your spinal column to your brain and stimulate you to go out and make a difference to the scheme of things. Which is fine if your energy circuits are clear of blockages. But if - as it is in most cases in this polluted, stressful madhouse of a world we've created - your meridians are somewhat clogged with energetic debris caused by toxic build-up in the system, when the wind blows through it will activate those toxins and place strain on your liver.

This is why it is often recommended to engage in detox activities at this time of year, one of the most effective being a four-day apple and spring-water fast, with honey as an optional add-on to the apples. If you opt for this route, lead into the fast gradually by cutting out alcohol, coffee, stimulants, meats and carbohydrates a couple of days prior, and do likewise in reverse on the way out, gradually reintroducing all the tasty stuff, rather than launching into a cheeseburger and chips for breakfast on the fifth day. (It has been known!)

You can eat as many apples as you like, including the core, which is perfectly safe if eaten with the rest of the apple. You can choose any brand you like, but Granny Smiths tend to pack the most punch energetically. Be sure to drink ample water. You may experience headaches on the second day as the toxins start surfacing, so it's a good idea to arrange a soothing aromatic massage in the evening. As you may feel rather weak for the first two days, it might be best to begin on the weekend. By day three, your energy will have increased significantly, enabling you to bound into work annoyingly bright-eyed and bushy-tailed, ready to put your sallow-faced colleagues to shame.

Whether you plumb for this simple detox suggestion or something more elaborate such as the infamous 10-day brown-rice fast, or skip the whole idea altogether, it will be highly beneficial to invest in an acupuncture or shiatsu session for purposes of seasonal adjustment. More importantly, it is crucial you take up some form of daily, preferably morning, exercise regime.

This is because the liver also governs your tendons and ligaments and therefore the flexibility of your joints and muscles. By upping the exercise ante, not only are you taking advantage of the liver's extra seasonal energy, thus maximising on muscle-toning possibilities, you are also helping to circulate the energy in your meridians and thus clear out the debris. Obviously the efficacy of this depends on both the kind of exercise you do and the way you do it. Huffing, puffing and straining at the weights in a sweaty gym will give you a temporary endorphin high but will not make your energy surge as much as, say, huffing, puffing and releasing your way through a sweaty power-yoga session, and definitely not as much as losing yourself in a concentrated chi-kung or t'ai-chi mess-about.

But then again, if you relax and move from your centre, allowing your breath to flow uninterruptedly, smoothly and evenly, with your mind fully engaged in internal body awareness as you would in t'ai-chi, for example, any exercise will be of benefit, from cartwheeling to tossing the caber.

If you can warm yourself into it slowly so as not to damage your muscles or joints, it is far more beneficial to do 30 to 60 minutes of exercise, preferably outside or near an open window, in the mornings, when the air is less polluted and the 'yang' daylight energy is most available, than in the evenings when the air is filthy from the day's traffic and your system is clogged by stress.

And contrary to popular belief, it is correct, according to Oriental wisdom, to exercise in a structured way every day, not just three, four or five days a week, as Western exercise specialists often recommend. Exercise is really part of your daily hygiene and to skip a day, except when ill, exhausted or otherwise prevented, is a bit like going out without brushing your teeth: it won't kill you, but it's unpleasant.

Finally, spend a few moments at the end of each day making the Taoist healing sound for the liver. Try it now. Take a deep breath and exhale making the sound, 'SSSHHHHHHHH!', imagining it as a jet of water steam cleaning your liver (under the ribs on your right) from within. Did I hear you say, 'Shush!'? OK, I get the hint. Happy springtime.

Your questions

Dear Barefoot, I have a high-pressure job requiring long hours at the office, a lot of travel and so a lot of time away from home. I suffer a lot from mild stomach upsets and general feelings of anxiety. I know the job is not right for me and am making the lifestyle changes to correct this. These changes, however, do not happen overnight. I find that when I am not 100 per cent happy, I tend to put on weight despite no change in my eating or exercise habits. When everything is in balance, the weight drops off. Due to work pressures, I am not able to follow a strict routine and often have to eat airplane or hotel food, though I try to stick to the healthiest options. Can you give me any advice?
Julie via email

In Oriental medicine, the spleen is considered responsible for governing food intake and assimilation and weight regulation. Metaphysically speaking, the spleen is associated with the 'earth' element. Earth equates to home and being settled therein. Being seldom at home, constantly on the run and often in the air dislodges your internal earth or ground, causing your spleen to lose control of weight regulation and leaving you emotionally ungrounded (literally removed from the earth).

The spleen is also believed to control your intellectual faculties, so when unbalanced is likely to lead you to find a false sense of stability from throwing yourself headlong into intellectually orientated pursuits such as high-level career workaholism. When the spleen is in balance, you naturally feel satisfied or happy, which is why the condition only appears when you're unhappy or anxious. Take astragalus, the all-purpose spleen builder, visit an acupuncturist, and above all learn meditation to find the 'off-button' before it finds you.

fields.headline: When scoring doesn't count
fields.standfirst: Playing away
fields.trailText: Playing away.
fields.body:
I have been a vegetarian - oh, all right then, a non red-meat eater, if you must nitpick - for close on 20 years. However, on a recent visit to the prime pork-producing areas of Spain, I gorged myself on sausages and Iberian ham and loin.

This was my less glamorous, but more calorific, version of the DCOL rule - Doesn't Count On Location. We profess ourselves stunned every time another venerable Hollywood union (for 'venerable' read about three years plus) goes belly up, but it should be no surprise that they crash and burn with Groundhog Day monotony. For, every working day, the world's most beautiful people are paid vast sums to pretend to be other people having unparalleled sex with equally beautiful people pretending to be other people. They're emphatically not themselves (if they'd ever established a vague identity of their own in the first place). So, when the choicest metaphorical cuts of pork loin are offered up to them, in the most auspicious of circumstances, of course they're going to nibble. And in the midst of the mind-numbing tedium of a film set, it would be a saint who wouldn't wolf it down. But to then play the 'doesn't count' card is rather stretching the point. Yes, the provision for vegetarians in Extremadura left a little to be desired, but I could have got by; instead, I scoffed Percy Pig and his adorable friends. And they tasted good.

Hollywood's dizzying relationship la ronde, the endless on-set flings - from Tom Cruise's alleged (and completely untrue, if his libel lawyers are reading this) dalliances with Penelope Cruz on Vanilla Sky to Meg Ryan and Russell Crowe's fling during the shooting of Proof of Life - are really just a ponced-up version of that most mundane of dalliances, the holiday romance. When we step out of the regimen of our own lives, we delight in assuming a different identity - the kind of person who performs karaoke versions of Burt Bacharach standards, and on occasion, has vigorous sex with virtual strangers - sometimes outdoors: the kind of person we'd ordinarily run to the hills to avoid. This is the DCOL rule at its purest.

Yet complications ensue if one life starts to bleed into another. A friend of mine met a man while travelling, and, on the briefest of acquaintance, convinced herself that this was The Real Thing, inviting him back home to live with her. He abandoned his job, his family, his friends and his life; but on seeing him arrive at the airport, she realised she'd made a terrible mistake - he was wearing terrible clothes, and his hair was just awful. In short, he was irredeemably Australian. He was sent packing on the next return flight, the victim of a rare case of DCOL in reverse: Counted On Location, Sure As Hell Didn't Count At Home.

There are many variations on DCOL doublethink. Next time you're at an airport WH Smith, check out the businessmen, wedding bands gleaming, stocking up on porn mags and ready to put the poses into practice at their safely anonymous destinations. They have a patron saint in Bill Clinton, the man who claimed that taking drugs without inhaling didn't count as taking drugs, and that non-ejaculatory oral sex didn't really count as sex.

But double standards don't have to assume impeachment dimensions. Take Dieter's Denial, the conviction that calories don't count if they're ingested from food eaten standing up or even from a whole bar of chocolate - as long as it's consumed over the course of a day. In this case, the location where it doesn't count is the most perilous, but also the most common: our own brains. DCOL, running the gamut from a breezy 'when in Rome' attitude to a wanton Last-Days-of-the-Empire blowout, is just a delicious branch of kidology.

It could also be a deeply necessary safety valve. Hypocrisy and humbug are built into our DNA. But in a society which we like to think of as unprecedentedly liberal but which actually involves more rigid compartmentalisation of roles than ever before, the times when we indulge our secret desires are those times when we feel most free. One could argue that the 'secret self' is just another compartment. Generally, however, DCOL is just the latest label for a form of temporary self-abnegation that's kept the world ticking over since the Fall of Man (one location where it emphatically did count), and thus too important to be left to actors - why cry for Tom & Nicole & Russell & Meg when their thespy neuroses will be fed by the next location-inspired intrigue, just as brittle as its prequels and sequels in its countlessness?

As for me, I'm back on the vegetarian straight and narrow. But I'm going to Marrakech next month, where I hear they do amazing things with lamb.
