fields.bodyText: On Friday, I'm going to a party and I must say I'm excited. Haven't a clue what to wear, though. Mostly because the dress code is 12 years ago, and, while willing to enter into the spirit of things, I'm not sure I really want to revisit such sartorial trauma. I remember what was de rigueur in 1989, and, folks, it wasn't pretty. Will it be the washed-out dungarees with the purple Kicker boots? The hooded top with the tracksuit bottoms? Jordans? Shell-tops? British Knights? Should I accessorise with an African skull cap/a crystal on a string/a poncho? One thing I'm sure of: I won't be showing my legs. In 1989, men were boys and girls could well have been. Everything you wore was two sizes too big. You couldn't tell who or what was under there. Even your hair was too long, hanging somewhere between shoulder and knee in just-stepped-out-of-the-chip-pan condition. Flip-flap-flop. When you walked along the street, you looked like a wandering laundry bag. And when you walked into a north-west wind, you had to grab onto bus stops to keep from taking off. The reason for my 'I Heart 1989' clothing crisis is because I'm appearing as an extra in a club scene for the Hacienda film, 24-Hour Party People, that Michael Winterbottom is making in Manchester, with Steve Coogan as Tony Wilson, Sean Harris as Ian Curtis, John Simm as Bernard Sumner. There's been quite a bit of hoo-hah about it, mostly because it's set in the recent past, so many of the protagonists are alive and arguing about what really happened. The film will cover the Manchester scene from Joy Division to Madchester, and it's the Madchester era that I'm revisiting. Which, essentially, means house music and sweating in pastel casualwear. The real Hacienda has long been closed, so we'll be raving-I'm-raving in a film studio. As an official OAP, you'll find me in the Grab-A-Granny arena. I'm interested in going, because I like a party and because I wonder how they'll recreate the atmosphere of that time (other than by providing ecstasy on the door. Wrapped in a smiley bandana.) In 1989 and into 1990, there was an air of revolution, of wild possibility. The government was running scared, bewildered at the idea of its nation's youth spontaneously gathering in huge numbers to... well, to take drugs and to run on the spot and call it dancing. Eventually, it was deemed necessary to pass a law curbing 'repetitive beats'. Nothing new about that: many overexcitable youth fads have resulted in legislation or, at least, arrests. The difference with the one in the early 90s is that it just wouldn't go away. Twelve years later, we're still reaping the legacy. House music is background music, chart music, the sound of the shopping mall and restaurant. Breweries and bars have reinvented themselves, taking over banks, shops and old police stations, refurbishing interiors to recreate the chill-out area in a club. No one goes to pubs any more. Mostly because there are hardly any left (rip up that swirly carpet! paint that wood lilac! swap that dowdy jukebox for two shiny Technics!). But also because, given the choice, most young people would rather go somewhere noisier, dressier, more packed, with better music, on a Friday night. A nightclub, but with brighter lighting. Even the drinks have changed. All those Bacardi Breezers, Vodka Sources - sugar and meths in a bottle - they're fist-sized, which means you can take them on to a dancefloor. Well, have you ever tripped the light fantastic while balancing a pint of Special? And they're strong, alcopops: they get you smashed, quickly. Once you know a good night out can be swallowed in pill form, you get impatient with sipping. But the main thing that's been recognised is the power of young women. Clubs and bars now know that they'd better get the girls in. And now they know how. Girls love dancing, and they love to be included. Happy house music did both. Many pop-music revolutions exclude women, explicitly or implicitly: they're too trainspottery and dismal, requiring a glum attitude, a degree in guitars or shouting, and absolutely no bump in your hustle. But the ones that last - soul, disco, house, r&b, garage - they always include the ladies. Because a club without women is a tragic affair: just young men trying to out-do each other in hard looks and cig-smoking. I hope they include that in 24-Hour Party People. First reports aren't too hopeful, though. Just long lists of men imitating older men: Ralf Little as Peter Hook, Shaun Ryder as his own dad. From Joy Division through to the Stone Roses and Happy Mondays: boys, all boys. Thank God for New Order's Gillian. Even though she doesn't say much.  Barbara Ellen will be back in two weeks.

fields.headline: Crowe's feat
fields.standfirst: Meg Ryan's husband is being held by South American terrorists. Who can help her? It's Russell to the rescue
fields.trailText: Meg Ryan's husband is being held by South American terrorists. Who can help her? It's Russell to the rescue
fields.body:
Proof of Life (135 mins, 15) Directed by Taylor Hackford; starring Russell Crowe, Meg Ryan, David Morse, David Caruso

In my review of Jocelyn Moorhouse's Proof, the film in which Russell Crowe first made a strong impression a decade ago, I noted that the chief quality of the character he played (a tough odd-job man who befriends a bitter, well-off blind orphan) was a 'guileless honesty'. Crowe, one of the most engaging stars in today's cinema, has been playing variations on this role ever since, most notably in LA Confidential, The Insider, Gladiator and now Taylor Hackford's Proof of Life, a semi-documentary thriller written by Tony Gilroy and inspired by an article in Vanity Fair magazine.

Crowe has the open face of James Stewart and Gary Cooper, and he moves with the ambling swagger of Warner Brothers tough guys like Bogart, Robinson, Cagney and Garfield. But in Proof of Life, for the first time outside his native Antipodes (he was born in New Zealand, raised in Australia) he uses his own accent. He's Terry Thorne, an ex-SAS man working in the K and R (kidnapping and ransom) business for a City of London insurance firm. The opening credit sequence, an economical little film in itself, shows him reporting to his suave, immaculately suited bosses on a successful operation that involved freeing a Frenchman from Chechen rebels while holding off double-crossing Russian soldiers. This episode establishes Thorne as a man of probity with the diplomatic gifts of Henry Kissinger and the military skills of a hi-tech Orde Wingate.

Meanwhile, down in the fictitious Latin American state of Tecala, the United States government is supporting a right-wing regime that is seeking to promote US oil interests and suppress a ragged band of ex-Marxist guerrillas who deal in cocaine and ransom money. Caught in the crossfire is an idealistic engineer, Peter Bowman (David Morse), who thinks he's building a dam to help the local population though in his heart he knows it's a gift to Tecala's corrupt politicians by an oil conglomerate to obtain rights to build a pipeline.

Bowman's marriage to Alice (Meg Ryan) is fraying after years of dispiriting work in the Third World, and at this difficult point he's kidnapped by the terrorists and taken into the mountains. The US embassy refuses help on bogus diplomatic grounds, the local police and army are not to be trusted, and Thorne is dispatched from London to take over the case and bring hope to Alice.

It turns out, however, that Bowman's company has just been taken over, that their hostage insurance has lapsed, and the new owners don't want to get involved in freeing him. So Thorne's services are withdrawn and he returns to Europe. In case we miss the point about the utter venality of this political-commercial nexus, Hackford has cast as Bowman's local American boss the most deviously dislikeable character actor since Murray Hamilton (the mayor in Jaws) retired. He's Anthony Heald, best-known as the vindictive shrink who torments Hannibal Lecter in The Silence of the Lambs and a man who oozes insincerity from every pore.

For 40 years, films about Americans in Latin America like State of Siege, Missing, Under Fire and Salvador, have shown up Washington and the local politicians in an equally bad light. Proof of Life is no exception. Fortunately Thorne has a change of heart. He bids farewell to his young son at a smart English boarding school (Gilroy and Hackford must have had some lingering memory of an identical scene in the 1978 film The Wild Geese when mercenary Richard Harris goes off on a similar mission) and returns to help Alice in Tecala. There's an explosive scene in which he, his American mercenary sidekick (David Caruso) and their team turn the tables on Alice's devious Latin assistants and restore her confidence. He then takes over the operation and a fascinating cat-and-mouse game on mobile phones and shortwave radio gets under way between the guerrillas' representative and Thorne - first to establish 'proof of life', then to bargain over the ransom money.

As this slow, delicate business proceeds, Bowman is being dragged from camp to camp, physical condition deteriorating, morale fluctuating, hopes encouraged by meeting a captive missionary (Gottfried John). He's also sustained by a photograph of Alice, and we fear that the inevitable intimacy springing up from her dependence on Thorne might turn into something more serious.

There are announcements from time to time of which day of captivity we're watching, and wisely Hackford does not rush a film that takes place over four months, relying on his actors and on the continuing suspense to hold our interest. But he does introduce a melodramatic coincidence that more work on the plot could have averted, and at the end he switches into a slap-up action mode of a conventional, though exciting kind, in the manner of pictures like Uncommon Valor about mercenaries freeing PoWs in South-East Asia.

These films of liberation come from the captivity stories of the American West as mediated by John Ford's influential The Searchers. In the past I've spoken, not entirely disparagingly, of Hackford being a curious mixture of hack and Ford, and in this expertly crafted film he pays tribute to Ford in having at least three characters paraphrase John Wayne's climactic line in The Searchers: 'Let's go home Debbie'.

webTitle: First The Word, now the pictures

fields.headline: First The Word, now the pictures
fields.standfirst: Amanda de Cadenet, the wildchild who made her name dancing on nightclub tables and hosting yoof TV now grows celery and understands the spirituality of animals. Oh, and she's also a photographer
fields.trailText: Amanda de Cadenet, the wildchild who made her name dancing on nightclub tables and hosting yoof TV now grows celery and understands the spirituality of animals. Oh, and she's also a photographer
fields.body:
'I've been around such a long time, you'd think I must be 50 by now,' sighs Amanda de Cadenet. For someone who is 27, she certainly has packed it in. Since becoming Famous For Being Famous at 14, she has been in constant search of a niche to accommodate her peculiar brand of celebrity, a celebrity that has become more commonplace since the advent of docusoaps, reality TV and Heat magazine. Amanda was arguably the first WAIF (Why Am I Famous): young, posh, blonde, buxom and desperate for attention, she danced on nightclub tables in a rubber dress in 1987, much to the consternation of tabloid readers and the staff at her Wiltshire boarding school, who were under the impression she had been tucked up in her dormitory at the time.

After that, every step was a matter of public record: the three months in White City children's home after her parents called in the police; the relationship with the boy-band singer (when she was 15); the gig presenting Channel 4's notorious The Word (17); the Playboy shoot and marriage to a pop icon (19); motherhood and the grand exit to Hollywood and what was supposed to be a career in movies (20); a divorce (22) and a romance with Keanu Reeves. Nowadays, Amanda calls herself a photographer and has an exhibition coming up in LA. We should probably give thanks that she never experimented with pop - unlike her boyfriend of the past three years, Nick Kamen, who became very famous indeed after taking his jeans off for a 1986 commercial set in a launderette, and subsequently launched a successful assault on the charts. Amanda has known Nick (now a painter, 'quite abstract', firmly based in London) forever - since she was 14.

Do not make the mistake of assuming that Amanda is no longer famous. Why, news of her pregnancy was all over the Sun in January. Just one little problem there, as she points out with a philosophical shrug: she's not pregnant. No, she isn't having Nick's baby, she doesn't know where that came from, she's heard so many weird rumours about herself over the years. But she wouldn't mind having another child 'one day, one day, I don't know. I love him a lot.'

I ask if she always had her eye on Nick.

'Always, always,' says Amanda, guilelessly. 'There are only two men who I, like, big-time fancied.'

'Who's the other one?'

Amanda pulls a wry, isn't-it-obvious face: 'Keanu.' When asked how Nick and Keanu get on, she casts me a significant, omigod look, and gives the impression of longing to talk about them all afternoon - only not to a journalist. 'But Nick's the best-looking man I've ever seen, to me. There is never a time when he doesn't look good. Never! Ever-ever-ever. Which is great. Listen, I don't see him for months at a time. So when I'm with him, I stare at him. You know? I watch my boyfriend while he's asleep.'

On The Word, Amanda's voice was sloanily mid-Atlantic: the sort of voice that loiters at the junction of the King's Road and Rodeo Drive. Today, the languid consonants of the West Coast dominate, with a vocabulary to match. Her life, she says, is much easier now that she has found her 'format', by which she means eight hours' sleep, no dairy products, no wheat, no caffeine, a little yoga, an hour with a book every day. (Currently, she's reading Cherry by Mary Carr, an autobiographical account of a rebellious Texan adolescence.) Without blushing, she explains she has 'a real love of life', 'a thirst for life', and talks about 'my primary focus' and 'my emotional, psychological place at that time'. Statements conclude with a rhetorical 'you know?'

However, there are signs that the charms of Los Angeles are beginning to pall. Because she grew up in London and France, the daughter of a French motor-racing driver and a Manx model-turned-interior designer, she has 'a different kind of sensibility. Part of the life is very alien to me. Americans really love pop culture and I can only handle it for so long.' Amanda, a glorious product of the pop-culture factory line, has a habit of saying things like this without realising how comical they sound: her conversation is a curious mixture of woolliness and heartfelt sincerity. Listening to her, you're struck by how sophisticated she sounds, and at the same time how naive.

Were it not for her eight-year-old daughter Atlanta, she'd be back in the UK like a shot, but she and her ex-husband, Duran Duran's John Taylor (the one with the amazing chin), have joint custody, and he has remarried an American, 'so he's firmly stuck in Los Angeles'. But they're talking through the possibilities. 'I would love to come back for good, but it depends. It's just a question of working it out. I can't leave Atlanta in LA, I could never do that. I may end up staying there... I don't know.'

She and John originally stormed out of England in the early Nineties, after a photographer snapped her breastfeeding Atlanta on a Hyde Park bench. They ended up in Los Angeles because she was unknown there and 'as far as John was concerned, in America you've got Julia Roberts at the grocery shop, nobody cares - everyone's famous out there'. But things have changed a bit. 'I'm not anonymous in America any more, you know.' It must be a source of irritation that this is less attributable to her film career ('English prisoner' in Brokedown Palace , 'Receptionist' in Grace of My Heart ) than to a splashy social feud with ex-gal pal Courtney Love ('I, uh, don't really have anything to say about that'). Now that the National Enquirer is doorstepping her over the pregnancy story, London seems increasingly appealing, despite the fact that the British paparazzi bring out the bunting whenever she comes to town. Two hours after touching down at Heathrow, she was coming out of a Westbourne Grove health-food store with a girlfriend, clutching a soya barley cup, and there they all were, snapping away. 'Things are only as important as you make them out to be,' says Amanda, mellowly. 'That's really my experience. I've learnt that if you can't get rid of something, you have to find a way to live with it.'

At her suggestion, we've met in a smart, noisy little west London deli not far from Nick's home. She does not attract much attention until she tugs off her aviator shades, scarf and overcoat, releasing her tangle of lion-coloured hair (her brunette phase, captured in the recent self-portrait above, was shortlived) and those celebrated undulations. Nowadays, she favours jeans, a candy-pink V-neck and Converse sneakers, which she calls her 'Womble' look - light years away from those tight little black dresses and dagger heels she wore on telly - and despite the fact that she has been suffering from ME for the past year, there is a fetching milkmaid robustness to her appearance.

When the waiter comes over, Amanda, who has really lovely manners, gives him a dazzling smile and orders a hearty lunch: organic sausages and dairy-free mash with a decaf soya latte. She has come to London to talk about a possible exhibition of her photographs and to audition for a British film, but she will proceed with care. 'I will not sell anything ever again that I do not believe in. I'm not willing to do a job for pure financial gain. I've done that, and it wasn't worth it. I didn't even know that was what I was doing until a few years later when I realised, "Oh, the price was me".'

At the moment, she is putting together a collection of her work for the exhibition in LA. The subjects are 'flowers and women who are quite severely physically scarred. I always like imperfection. That's sort of human to me. That's why I photograph women's bodies: I'm not interested in some Sports Illustrated swimsuit model. It's the rolls of fat, saggy tits, whatever. That is beauty to me. That's what I look for. It's the truth. That's real.'

Her next project is 'women who marry men who have life sentences, or who are on death row. Don't you think that would be really good?' With a blithe lack of inhibition, Amanda declares: 'I tend to side with people who are considered the underdog. I have empathy.' She tells me about her latest project, photographing people with terminal illnesses for Marie-Claire magazine. The experience taught her that a) it's not worth worrying about tomorrow, and b) it helps if you have a faith.

Amanda has been interested in spiritual matters for the past six years. She says she believes in the earth force. 'You know, "the force is with you".' Her mother, Anna, who is deeply involved with Aids charities, Crisis and the Hurlingham Club, is Born Again. Amanda suspects her wildchild period, itself triggered by her parents' divorce, nudged her mother towards the Church. 'It sent her off in the right direction, I would say.'

Mother and daughter are now close. When Amanda was a child, Anna's passion for routine drove her crazy: now she and Atlanta have their own format, which involves having Chinese takeaway one night a week. Sometimes Monday, sometimes Thursday. Never the same night every week, because that would be too regular.

'When I was younger, routine was hell,' says Amanda earnestly. 'It felt like a trap. I hate the idea of people not being able to say what they want to say, be who they are. I don't think it's fair to crush the human spirit. When I was at school, I was told to wear knee socks. Well, now, what's that got to do with anything - with my future, with my career, with my exams, with my brain? But you got punished if you didn't wear knee socks. It's a power trip. Ephemeral shit. That I don't do well with, people asserting authority over others just for the hell of it. Like, injustice,' she continues, sounding very Californian. 'I have a major over-empathy with victims of injustice. Which is why if I watch the news I'm in tears all the time.' Oh dear.

There's lots to like about Amanda. She does have a sense of the absurd, though it is fairly well-hidden. After describing, at some length, the spiritual satisfaction she gets from growing beets and celery in her back garden, she adds quite mildly: 'Look, I live in LA, I can get a little metaphysical sometimes.' She is very engaging when talking about Atlanta, a football fanatic who rises at seven when Chelsea have a match so she can watch it live; and about their menagerie: 'cats and dogs and birds and fish and rabbits'. The chihuahua sounds like a bit of a star. 'I really hate dogs like that, but Zig is the cutest dog. People pay 300 bucks for cashmere sweaters for their dogs in LA, you know? Fuck that. We've made his out of socks. We cut the holes for his front legs and stitched his name on it - it's very ragga.'

Is Amanda's past always going to drown out her present, her future? She is doing her best not to let it. 'I'm not interested in sitting here and talking about choices I made when I was, like, 14 years old. I've done all that. Of course all those things make me the person I am today, but it is not where I live.'

Mostly, she tolerates my questions and addresses them with killer solemnity, but at one point she puts down her latte and says: 'I suddenly realised... I don't really do interviews so much any more. I find it quite exposing in a way. I have a friend who will not talk about anything to do with his personal life, nothing. If anyone talks about anything other than his work, he'll just sit there. He's a very hard interview.'

I say that he must be a bit of a superstar to get away with that.

'Yes, he is,' says Amanda, proudly.

Who?

'Oh, Keanu. He will just look at people. He will not answer the question.' It's a nice moment: Amanda, smitten with Keanu's mystique, effectively blowing her own.

But things have changed a bit. 'I'm not anonymous in America any more, you know.' It must be a source of irritation that this is less attributable to her film career ('English prisoner' in Brokedown Palace , 'Receptionist' in Grace of My Heart ) than to a splashy social feud with ex-gal pal Courtney Love ('I, uh, don't really have anything to say about that'). Now that the National Enquirer is doorstepping her over the pregnancy story, London seems increasingly appealing, despite the fact that the British paparazzi bring out the bunting whenever she comes to town. Two hours after touching down at Heathrow, she was coming out of a Westbourne Grove health-food store with a girlfriend, clutching a soya barley cup, and there they all were, snapping away. 'Things are only as important as you make them out to be,' says Amanda, mellowly. 'That's really my experience. I've learnt that if you can't get rid of something, you have to find a way to live with it.' At her suggestion, we've met in a smart, noisy little west London deli not far from Nick's home. She does not attract much attention until she tugs off her aviator shades, scarf and overcoat, releasing her tangle of lion-coloured hair (her brunette phase, captured in the recent self-portrait above, was shortlived) and those celebrated undulations. Nowadays, she favours jeans, a candy-pink V-neck and Converse sneakers, which she calls her 'Womble' look - light years away from those tight little black dresses and dagger heels she wore on telly - and despite the fact that she has been suffering from ME for the past year, there is a fetching milkmaid robustness to her appearance. When the waiter comes over, Amanda, who has really lovely manners, gives him a dazzling smile and orders a hearty lunch: organic sausages and dairy-free mash with a decaf soya latte. She has come to London to talk about a possible exhibition of her photographs and to audition for a British film, but she will proceed with care. 'I will not sell anything ever again that I do not believe in. I'm not willing to do a job for pure financial gain. I've done that, and it wasn't worth it. I didn't even know that was what I was doing until a few years later when I realised, "Oh, the price was me".' At the moment, she is putting together a collection of her work for the exhibition in LA. The subjects are 'flowers and women who are quite severely physically scarred. I always like imperfection. That's sort of human to me. That's why I photograph women's bodies: I'm not interested in some Sports Illustrated swimsuit model. It's the rolls of fat, saggy tits, whatever. That is beauty to me. That's what I look for. It's the truth. That's real.' Her next project is 'women who marry men who have life sentences, or who are on death row. Don't you think that would be really good?' With a blithe lack of inhibition, Amanda declares: 'I tend to side with people who are considered the underdog. I have empathy.' She tells me about her latest project, photographing people with terminal illnesses for Marie-Claire magazine. The experience taught her that a) it's not worth worrying about tomorrow, and b) it helps if you have a faith. Amanda has been interested in spiritual matters for the past six years. She says she believes in the earth force. 'You know, "the force is with you".' Her mother, Anna, who is deeply involved with Aids charities, Crisis and the Hurlingham Club, is Born Again. Amanda suspects her wildchild period, itself triggered by her parents' divorce, nudged her mother towards the Church. 'It sent her off in the right direction, I would say.' Mother and daughter are now close. When Amanda was a child, Anna's passion for routine drove her crazy: now she and Atlanta have their own format, which involves having Chinese takeaway one night a week. Sometimes Monday, sometimes Thursday. Never the same night every week, because that would be too regular. 'When I was younger, routine was hell,' says Amanda earnestly. 'It felt like a trap. I hate the idea of people not being able to say what they want to say, be who they are. I don't think it's fair to crush the human spirit. When I was at school, I was told to wear knee socks. Well, now, what's that got to do with anything - with my future, with my career, with my exams, with my brain? But you got punished if you didn't wear knee socks. It's a power trip. Ephemeral shit. That I don't do well with, people asserting authority over others just for the hell of it. Like, injustice,' she continues, sounding very Californian. 'I have a major over-empathy with victims of injustice. Which is why if I watch the news I'm in tears all the time.' Oh dear. There's lots to like about Amanda. She does have a sense of the absurd, though it is fairly well-hidden. After describing, at some length, the spiritual satisfaction she gets from growing beets and celery in her back garden, she adds quite mildly: 'Look, I live in LA, I can get a little metaphysical sometimes.' She is very engaging when talking about Atlanta, a football fanatic who rises at seven when Chelsea have a match so she can watch it live; and about their menagerie: 'cats and dogs and birds and fish and rabbits'. The chihuahua sounds like a bit of a star. 'I really hate dogs like that, but Zig is the cutest dog. People pay 300 bucks for cashmere sweaters for their dogs in LA, you know? Fuck that. We've made his out of socks. We cut the holes for his front legs and stitched his name on it - it's very ragga.' Is Amanda's past always going to drown out her present, her future? She is doing her best not to let it. 'I'm not interested in sitting here and talking about choices I made when I was, like, 14 years old. I've done all that. Of course all those things make me the person I am today, but it is not where I live.' Mostly, she tolerates my questions and addresses them with killer solemnity, but at one point she puts down her latte and says: 'I suddenly realised... I don't really do interviews so much any more. I find it quite exposing in a way. I have a friend who will not talk about anything to do with his personal life, nothing. If anyone talks about anything other than his work, he'll just sit there. He's a very hard interview.' I say that he must be a bit of a superstar to get away with that. 'Yes, he is,' says Amanda, proudly. Who? 'Oh, Keanu. He will just look at people. He will not answer the question.' It's a nice moment: Amanda, smitten with Keanu's mystique, effectively blowing her own.

fields.headline: Loafer's guide
fields.standfirst: The new sisterhood
fields.trailText: The new sisterhood.
fields.body:
The new sisterhood? Is that the latest batch of Blair's Babes? No - this has nothing to do with politics, it's more of a leisure thing. Take All About Eve, for example.

You mean the 1950 Bette Davis film? Hardly. It's a glitzy women-only club in central London. The only way men can get in is if they're hanging off the arm of a member - or if they get picked from the adjacent bar in an eenie-meanie-miny-mo kind of way - and even then only 10 blokes are allowed in at a time, so there's no chance of the oestrogen levels taking too much of a dip.

What's the big idea? Well, sometimes it seems it's just easier for the sisters to relax if there are no men around. The trend started with women-only financial advisers and women-only gyms - now there's a new market in the ultimate girls-only night out.

So what else is happening? The Playing Fields (a gaming café in London's West End) has been a real hit. It seems women find it easier to get into their gun-toting stride if there aren't any computer-friendly hunks/geeks around saying, 'Oh stop being such a hopeless girl' when they get things wrong.

Looks like there's money to be made in this sisterhood thing. Too right. Women have more cash these days and, as always, they want to spend it. They also like to do business in all-female environments: the latest perk for female execs is a networking session at the local women-only spa.

Female execs rule, OK! That's the way it appears to be going. The Swiss have even opened a women-only three-star hotel called Lady's First. Men can get as far as the reception, and that's their lot. At the end of a hard day, guests can knock back a couple of drinks in the bar without having to fend off unwanted advances, and they can potter happily between the bedrooms and the health and beauty centre in their dressing gowns and slippers, because all the staff are women. Now doesn't that sound relaxing?

webTitle: Money writes: Our cash fell into a Time warp

fields.headline: Our cash fell into a Time warp
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
Last October we bought a computer from a Time store in Leeds. We paid £1,489 by cheque and were told to expect delivery within 21 days. A month later, we received the monitor with an invoice for £181. At the end of November, Time said it had no record of the original purchase and the shop we had bought it from had closed down.

We faxed the receipt and bank statement proving that the money had been taken from our account and on 1 December sent back the monitor asking for a refund. On 15 January, we received £181.

We are still waiting for the remaining £1,307. Whenever we phone Time, we speak to a different person who will not refer us to a supervisor and we are told they have no record of our original purchase or request for a refund.
NT, Shipley

Time puts this down to an 'unfortunate administrative error' within its systems. It looks more like incompetence than a computer problem. But the company has now managed to sort out the muddle and has agreed to send you a 'full refund' of £1,489.

This overlooks the fact that it has already refunded you £181. The company makes no mention of an ex gratia payment for treating you badly, so I assume this is another oversight. I believe you are entitled to keep the £181 to compensate you for the difficulty of trying to buy one of Time's products.

Honesty was the worst policy

Water from a dripping tap in my guest room caused damage to my neighbour's lounge ceiling and furnishings. When I submitted my insurance claim to the Prudential, I admitted that my frail mother had been unable to turn off the tap and she had not informed me.

The Pru denied cover because my mother did not permanently reside with me. If I had been the person who caused the damage, the claim would have been honoured. My honesty has cost me £300.
RY, Bromham

The Pru says your house contents policy covers only people who live in your house. You could add her name to your policy if she stays with you for extended periods and, at first, the Pru said your claim would be valid if she had been staying with you for several weeks. But, on a second look at your claim, it decided she had to live with you permanently.

If she has contents insurance for her own home, she ought to be able to claim on that policy, but I can understand why you do not want to upset her by raising the subject again.

The pain in Spain

My mother, who died in 1991, had a bank account in Majorca with the Banco Bilbao. I requested that they close her account and send me the proceeds, some 85,000 pesetas (£320).

Nothing happened, so in 1999 I wrote to Banco Bilbao in London. They told me how to proceed but I have heard no more since last July. The sum involved is not the main issue but I do wish to stop receiving bank statements addressed to my late mother. They seem happy to take 2,000 pesetas from the account each year for administration but seem incapable of actually doing anything.
MT, Norwich

Closing overseas accounts costs money, unfortunately more than is worthwhile for an account of this size. When Spanish banks are told that an account holder has died, they have to freeze the account. Spanish law requires documentation translated into Spanish. You'd have to use a professional translator who makes a declaration of competence before a notary. The total bill can be around£900.

Banco Bilbao, now BBVA, says it is 'in a circular discussion' with the bank statements. It can accept instructions not to send statements only from the account holder. If the account holder dies, it cannot change the name on the account unless you go through legal formalities. Any readers with foreign bank accounts should consider changing the details before they die.

A place of equal safety

My wife and I own National Savings Pensioners Guaranteed Bonds, due to mature later this year. They pay 7 per cent gross monthly, which acts as a top-up to our pensions, but the new bonds pay only 4.9 per cent. Can you recommend another investment which approaches our original one and is equally safe?
LR, Tonbridge

No savings are quite as safe as National Savings, but bank and building society deposit accounts come close. Interest rates are falling and National Savings is particularly uncompetitive.

You get the best rates on cash Isas: between 6.75 and 7 per cent is good. Outside Isas, the best instant access accounts pay 6 to 6.5 per cent on £5,000; try Birmingham Midshires (0845 602 2828) and Saga (0800 056 5094). Scarborough building society (0845 458 4458) pays 6 per cent on £100. Notice accounts pay no better, apart from Safeway at 6.9 per cent on a minimum £10,000 at 60 days' notice. With internet access, Abbey National's eSaver pays 6.85 per cent, Nationwide 6.7 per cent and Smile's cash Isa 7.25 per cent.

Unlike Pensioners Bonds, these rates are not fixed. Neither do they pay monthly interest. You can make withdrawals each month from instant access accounts; some Isas organise monthly withdrawals. Birmingham Midshires has a new guaranteed income bond for over-fifties, paying monthly at 5.75 per cent guaranteed for five years.

Cancelled holidays

A year ago, Lisa Rimell of Bristol contacted Money Writes because Atlas Travel Insurance had rejected her travel claim. Her parents had booked a family holiday in Portugal for the previous June. Her mother arranged insurance for the other five members of the family through the travel agent but the parents were refused cover when they declared they were suffering from cancer. Their doctors confirmed that they were fit to travel at the time of booking.

Both parents' conditions worsened towards the end of April and Lisa's mother told the travel agents to cancel the holiday. They died at the end of June, within three days of each other.

The underwriter refused to refund the cost of cancelling the holiday, claiming the cause was a pre-existing medical condition which had not been disclosed. Lisa argued that the travel agent, acting as insurance agent, talked to her mother about the cancer and completed the application forms for the rest of the family.

The insurer also refused to pay on the grounds that the holiday was not cancelled in writing. Although she did not have a copy of the handwritten letter, Lisa was confident that her mother did write, and received written confirmation.

At the same time as writing to the Observer , Lisa took a case through the small claims track (what used to be called the small claims court).

In January, Lisa and her brother won their case. The judge agreed that the parents were obviously acting for the whole family in booking the holiday, and insurance. He thought it would be odd if, when Lisa's mother declared the illness, she did not do it on behalf of the whole party. He noted that when the underwriters learned of the parents' cancer, they did not notify the others that their cover would be restricted.

Lisa says: 'We were awarded £2,440 between us plus £50 expenses each and the court fee of £100. The court fee is the only financial cost involved in making a claim via the small claims track, but my brother and I had to spend a considerable amount of time responding to correspondence from both the court and the defendant's solicitors.'

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

fields.headline: Snap and crack - but no pop for first-time writer
fields.standfirst: Mark Powell tells Neasa McErlean about his wild times
fields.trailText: Mark Powell tells Neasa McErlean about his wild times.
fields.body:
Mark Powell - whose first novel, Snap, (Weidenfeld & Nicholson, £9.99) will be published this week - has spent most of his 33 years conforming. University was followed with officer training at Cranwell, the Royal Air Force's equivalent of Sandhurst. But he has also had his wild times - sleeping rough in New York's Central Park as part of a gang that spent its days 'stealing, fighting, drug-dealing and searching for sex'.

Snap - a story of violence and tenderness in the black gangs of East London - was sparked by his own upbringing in Loughton, Essex, and the East End. At 19, fascinated by hip-hop culture, he went to New York. He spent his first few months on the streets and in shelters. Most of his friends were crack addicts who got money by begging, drug-dealing and stealing (from businesses, rather than individuals). 'I was yearning to do something exciting,' he says. 'Other generations have had their wars; I wanted a real challenge. It wasn't happening for me in London. But New York was vibrant and funky.'

At the end of each day, his group of five would split the proceeds and he would usually have $5. Getting food was not a problem: 'I wangled a false social security number so I had a meal ticket to the hand-out places and churches.'

It was also an unwritten rule that when they got a social security check each month, the (all-male) group would blow most of it on a big night out: 'We'd go to Brooklyn and buy crack, loads of food and women.' The girls, whose London equivalents appear in Snap, weren't exactly prostitutes, but they were happy to have sex with anyone who bought food and gave them crack.

Having satisfied some of his wanderlust, Powell came back. Knowing he wanted to write, he thought he could combine it with the RAF, which would release him at 42 with a pension.

Although he enjoyed the training, he realised he could not write in the evenings, so decided to focus on writing. He joined Manchester University's novel-writing MA course, and the result was Snap . With a 'five-figure advance', he was able to concentrate on writing, although he works part-time as a teacher for 'excluded' pupils in Brent, north London.

His wife, Claire, has also helped him. 'She's the real breadwinner; she's really been my financial backbone.' He meets men who say they would not like to earn less than their partner but he says: 'I like to feel that I'm beyond the insecurities of having to prove myself. I don't have any problems with Claire being more successful financially and in her career than me. I take pride in her career.'

Now working on his second novel for Weidenfeld & Nicholson, Powell is not yet putting money into a pension or thinking about long-term savings. The big change was buying a house. While Claire takes care of the mortgage, he borrowed money from his father for the deposit, which he is now repaying. 'I have never been one to scrimp now to have money later.'

Money messes up some of the characters in Snap - the lowlife prostitute, for instance, who finds the money too good and will not come off the game despite 'the bruises over her body, the discharge, the awful pains in her abdomen'.

But even in his social life now, Powell sees people who are guided by money, not happiness. 'I don't feel I need to be out at 2am, swilling champagne. Many people have got the car and the house, and are not happy.'

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Both Pat Barker and Wendy Robertson base their novels on their shared north-eastern heritage. But when they meet for lunch, they talk about prison workshops and why the Prince of Wales was wearing rouge in 1934
fields.trailText: Both Pat Barker and Wendy Robertson base their novels on their shared north-eastern heritage. But when they meet for lunch, they talk about prison workshops and why the Prince of Wales was wearing rouge in 1934.
fields.body:
Wendy Robertson: My friend Anne met a woman named Pat Barker in hospital who she said really reminded her of me.

Anne is a musician and doesn't really know writers, so I told her that Pat's work is well known and very good.

Anne organised a lunch so that Pat and I could meet and we got on straight away. It was just like finding a sister. It was an unexpected and strange thing really. After lunch we sat in the sitting room and talked about the research we were doing; I was working on a book about the First World War and Pat was researching Regeneration. Anne was playing Chopin in the little dining room and it was lovely.

Since then we make a point of meeting for lunch as much as we can. In a busy life it's a great relaxation. You often have to hold back when you discuss serious subjects with friends, but with Pat you just go straight for it. Neither of us like the label 'Northern writers', but the truth in our novels comes from our heritage. I see people emerging from this background as quirky and interesting and she can tackle really strong characters and subjects in her writing. I think that Billy Prior in Pat's Regeneration is one of the great fictional creations of last century. He grows up in the north-east and becomes a commissioned officer in the First World War. My characters are similar - breaking stereotypes but being true to the north.

Pat's protective and very kind. She sees when I'm overdoing it with my writing workshops in prisons and tells me to focus on my work. I ran a competition to help new writers last year and she agreed to be a patron, so she was very supportive. We both have daughters who we talk about a lot. They are journalists, so we are writing mothers who have writing daughters.

We make time to have good long chats. Even though we're both interested in the darker side of the personality we seem to laugh a lot. The time goes by very quickly. We used to meet at one o'clock but the poor waiters were always waiting for us to finish, so we started to meet at 12.30, but we still manage to end up with the stragglers.

Pat Barker: Friendships between writers are essential because writing is an incredibly isolating thing to do. You can take so much for granted when you meet another writer, like those 3 o'clock in the morning doubts. It helps to spend time with someone who knows exactly what it's like.

Wendy and I never talk about work in progress in any detailed way. One of the things that makes her so valuable to me, and I think me to her, is that we don't get into the other person's work while it's being written. You've got to keep the steam inside the pressure kettle and I think Wendy understands that.

That's not to say we don't talk about our work at all. The last time I saw Wendy she had just finished her last book. She had literally printed it out that morning and arrived at our monthly lunch in this dazed and incredulous state. So I was very happy to buy her a nice bottle of wine to celebrate.

Wendy was talking about the Prince of Wales visiting the north-east in 1934 as material for one of her books, and I told her that my grandmother stood about 18in away from him and noticed that it looked as if he was wearing rouge. My grandmother was terribly disillusioned because he was hero-worshiped by the northern working classes.

Being working-class northern girls we can take a lot about each other for granted. We have a shared passion for people who have been forced to the margins of history and have essentially been silenced.

What I like about Wendy is her deep respect for other people. One of the reasons she is so good at her work in prisons is because she deals with the prisoners on equal terms. I'm sure she takes on too much though. I said to her, 'The trouble with you is that you enjoy writing so much that you think of it as an indulgence.' That involvement in the prisons is actually very good for her work though. I get torn to pieces when I try to do several things so I admire her for her ability to put so much of herself into so many different things.

webTitle: Swap your  Tessa for  a younger  model

fields.headline: Swap your  Tessa for  a younger  model
fields.standfirst: Tracey Boles explains how Toisas can replace maturing tax-free accounts
fields.trailText: Tracey Boles explains how Toisas can replace maturing tax-free accounts.
fields.body:
If your Tessa is coming up to maturity and you do not want to cash it in, start looking for a new home for your money. Otherwise it will sit in a holding account which is likely to pay a meagre rate of interest. If you don't act within six months, you could lose a valuable tax break.

The two main options available to you are a cash mini Isa or a Tessa-only Isa. Taking out a new Tessa is not an option any more: Tessas were closed to new investors in 1999 and replaced by Isas.

Tessa-only Isas, or Toisas, enable you to reinvest the capital - although not the interest earned - from your maturing Tessa in another tax shelter without losing any of your Isa entitlements. They come in three guises: variable-rate, fixed-rate or stock market-linked. Variable-rate Toisas, whose rates move roughly in line with general movements in interest rates, are by far the most common.

Toisas benefit from higher rates than on standard savings accounts. They pay up to 7 per cent on a variable-rate account and about 6 per cent on a fixed-rate deal. By contrast, the average instant-access account pays just 1.62 per cent before tax.

Toisas are also more flexible than the old Tessas. Tessas allowed you to save up to £9,000 over five years and earn tax-free interest as long as the capital was untouched. Because the Toisa operates under Isa rules rather than those governing the old Tessas, you don't have to leave the capital untouched for five years to keep the tax break - you can withdraw chunks whenever you need to. However, taking out money will also mean the loss of your tax-free allowance for that year. Watch out as well for restrictions imposed by individual institutions on access to your money. Terms vary widely, with notice periods of anywhere between 30 days and three years.

Money in Toisas does not count towards your normal Isa investment allowance for the year, so you can put up to £9,000 into a Toisa without it reducing your £7,000 Isa allowance. This is where it has the upper hand over the cash mini Isa option for Tessa holders.

But don't assume that your current Tessa provider will offer the best Toisa deal. Ideally, you should put your money in a bank or building society with a good track record. Best buys according to adviser David Aaron Partnership include Cheltenham & Gloucester's and Bradford & Bingley's variable-rate Toisas, which pay 6.75 and 6.25 per cent respectively. To transfer to a new provider, simply ask your old provider for a maturity certificate, which proves the money is tax exempt, and take it to your new one, which will arrange the changeover.

If you are willing to take more of a gamble you may prefer an equity-linked Toisa, where returns relate to the stock market. The potential for higher returns is greater, but so is the risk that your money will not grow. As Andrew Jones of David Aaron puts it: 'The risk is zero return.' Whatever happens, your capital is guaranteed and will not be eroded.

Rival financial adviser Chase de Vere favours equity Toisas above the others. Chase's Janine Starks says: 'Variable rates are fine if you want a completely safe investment but returns on them are not the same as they used to be thanks to the low interest rate environment. Links to the stock market provide potentially better rates of return. The top five performers in the past five years have been equity-linked Toisas returning an average of £16,000 on a £9,000 investment, compared with £12,500 for variable deals.'

HSBC has recently launched its Performance plus Tessa Isa, whose return is linked to the FTSE 100 index. If the index rises, your investment will increase by a proportionate amount. If it falls, you get back only your original investment. Bristol & West and Birmingham Midshires also offer equity-linked Toisas.

Fixed-rate deals make sense if interest rates fall over the period to which the fix applies. However, the rates are so low at present that the fixes do not represent good value, Chase says. Providers include Norwich & Peterborough, currently offering 6.25 per cent a year for five years, and Leeds & Holbeck.

Toisa rates are generally buoyant at the moment to attract maturing Tessa funds, but there is a danger they will come down if the base rate falls. Also beware of banks and building societies that hoist their rates in the first few weeks to attract new money, only to cut them once they have your savings safely in the bag.

People with maturing Tessas have six months to decide what to do with their money before it loses its tax-exempt status. It is better to decide as soon as possible, as once the Tessa has matured, many banks and building societies will transfer the funds into an instant access savings account unless instructed otherwise. Not only do these accounts usually pay derisory rates of interest, but it is taxed, too. So leaving money to languish can lose you money.

A full list of available Toisas can be obtained from Moneyfacts magazine on 01603 476 100.

Chase de Vere publishes a free guide to Tessas - available from 0845 609 2005.

webTitle: Waiting in for the gasman can make you boiling mad

fields.headline: Waiting in for the gasman can make you boiling mad
fields.standfirst: Nick Paton Walsh  was cold, and sick of Pavarotti, by the time his heating was fixed
fields.trailText: Nick Paton Walsh was cold, and sick of Pavarotti, by the time his heating was fixed.
fields.body:
It's everyone's mid-winter nightmare - radiators as icy as the temperature outside. It was 3pm on a freezing January afternoon when I first realised that the the boiler in my flat had broken down. I rang British Gas: our landlord has a contract with them under which they guarantee to send someone round within 24 hours. I told the operator that I could smell gas. 'I am forced to notify Transco,' he said. A Transco engineer would be around within two hours, I was told, and a British Gas repairman would be round some time between midday and 6pm the next day.

By 6pm the Transco engineer arrived. He detected no leak. I asked him what was wrong with the boiler. He said that before privatisation he could have checked for a leak and fixed the boiler all in one trip. But the new company would not grant him safety clearance to the higher level of boiler repair. He very kindly explained that, despite his 20 years' experience fixing boilers before privatisation, he was not allowed to help.

My flatmate and I spent a cold and unhygienic day huddled around an oil heater. I had the next week off, and so my 'holiday' would begin with a day at home waiting for the gasman. The next day, at around 4pm, the British Gas engineer, Keith, arrived. He took the cover off the boiler and said that too much water pressure had built up inside. He then let some of the water off into a bucket. The water was brown. 'Too much sludge and silt in the pipes,' he said. We would need the pipes cleaning and a new boiler - most probably. For the meantime, the boiler would work, he said. Sure enough, he put the cover back on and lit it up. We had hot water.

Two hours later, I went for a long-delayed shower - the neighbours had started to complain. The water was cold again. The boiler had turned itself off. I rang British Gas again. The first few times they said it was too busy and I should call later. I eventually found a spare line and held for about 15 minutes.

The operator told me that, under the service contract we had, the company could not be called out again to fix the boiler without charging. Apparently, our pipes needed cleaning, and any other attempts at fixing it would be mere timewasting. He said that Keith should have quoted me a price for cleaning the pipes and installing a new boiler. He offered to get Keith to have the quote sent to my landlord, who could then authorise the work. 'I really, really apologise,' he said. Next day I rang British Gas again. I had by now become accustomed to the sound of Puccini's 'Nessun Dorma' and Lloyd Webber's 'The Music of The Night' as I waited for answers to my calls.

After a 10-minute wait, I reached another operator, who said that last night's operator had misinformed me. Keith couldn't do it that way, and I'd need another engineer. But, if I wanted a new boiler and clean pipes, I'd best speak to sales. She'd try and put me through.

Pavarotti was pretty much exhausted when the operator said sales weren't answering the phone, so she'd have to get them to call me. They didn't. I called British Gas back.

This time I got somebody whom I can call obnoxious at best. She said that it wasn't her fault that I hadn't been called. I agreed and asked her not to be so antagonistic. She said I was being antagonistic, and then asked me to hold. Her team leader interrupted to tell me that I had to speak to sales. She tried to put me through. Sales were engaged, but they would call me, she said.

I rang British Gas back a few hours later. I then got an enormously helpful woman who said that sales didn't need to be involved. An engineer could do the quote. Did I want to stay in and wait for him the whole day or just the afternoon? I had been waiting all day when the gasmen arrived at nearly three o'clock. At this point, I must add that my landlord had been taking alternative action. He had asked a local boilerman to call. He took off the cover of the boiler, and then found an override switch on the back. One press of this button got the boiler working again. It has worked well ever since. He said the pipes might need a clean, but a new boiler was, in his opinion, probably unnecessary.

The boiler was working very well when British Gas arrived. Two men in their late twenties approached the boiler, pressed a few buttons, and then wrote out a quote that said clean pipes would cost £550. But one of them added that this procedure might not work. Only a new boiler could guarantee perfect performance. How much would that be, I asked? '£2100,' he said. I'd have to wait at least two weeks for the work to be done, he added.

British Gas failed to keep the last appointment to fix the boiler and it has yet to explain why. The boiler still works. But its brief collapse granted me a glimpse of British Gas's monumental incompetence in dealing with such a simple issue. We were messed about for four days, and, had a local boilerman not intervened, we would still be without heating.

I rang British Gas about this article. 'It is very unfortunate and we can only apologise,' said a contrite spokeswoman. 'That is not the service we expect customers to receive.' She added that my boiler was installed in 1972 and that I had been aware that it was ailing for a few months.

I asked if, had I been a pensioner or the parent of young children, I might have expected a shorter waiting time than two weeks. 'No,' was the answer. She also said that British Gas offered a quality service and if I found this state of affairs unacceptable I was welcome 'to go to another engineer'. So I have.

Can't stand the heat?

I'm not alone in my experience, writes Nick Paton Walsh. Energywatch, the energy consumer's complaints body, recorded 19,486 complaints against British Gas last year. 17,581 of these involved the customer having to complain twice to Energywatch. Npower Calortex was the only firm to come close, with 4531 complaints. British Gas attracts 45 per cent of all complaints against domestic gas suppliers. Complaints have been going down, but these figures mean that only ten per cent of complaints are settled first time around.

fields.headline: Regulator to investigate Isa guides
fields.standfirst: Investors are being misled by IFA reports on funds that are distributed in newspapers, writes  David Prosser
fields.trailText: Investors are being misled by IFA reports on funds that are distributed in newspapers, writes David Prosser.
fields.body:
The Financial Services Authority is coming under increasing pressure to investigate the growing number of guides to individual savings accounts published by financial advisers. The UK's chief financial regulator has received several objections to the guides, including a complaint from independent adviser Best Investments. It alleges that advisers are being paid by Isa fund providers to recommend their products to investors.

Best's allegation is that advisers will tip only funds whose providers pay for advertising and the insertion of their application forms in guides. Deputy managing director Jason Hollands says: 'There is a 100 per cent correlation between advertised funds and recommendations. Fund managers tell us that they know they will not get into these guides unless they advertise.'

The number of guides to Isas published by advisers has mushroomed over the past six months. The guides have high print runs, and are often distributed free with national newspapers. Most recommend a handful of funds, and include application forms.

The providers accept that they often have to pay to secure recommendations. Last year Virgin Direct told Money Observer it had turned down a request for £150,000 in advertising costs from one adviser, which had then failed to include Virgin in its list of tipped funds.

The current scandal follows a long-running Money Observer campaign. We first investigated Isa guides in 1999 but since then many more firms have launched their own publications. Most come from discount brokers, which offer reduced initial charges on tipped funds. Financial Discounts Direct, Chelsea Financial Services, HCF, Isa Choice, Willis Owen, Investors Direct and WiseUp have all published guides this year. In each case, the providers of all the funds recommended paid to advertise in the guides. None carries advertising from a provider whose fund is not tipped.

Jonathan Gains, managing director of WiseUp, whose guide has been distributed with the Sunday Times and Mail on Sunday , denies that his firm is doing anything wrong: 'The six funds recommended in our guide have all been through a rigorous research and selection process before being recommended.'

However, Hollands argues: 'This is undermining the concept of independent financial advice and squeezes out small companies who cannot afford to advertise but may have the best funds.' He also warns: 'Often, these guides are put together by advertising agents, so you have non-regulated people making investment recommendations.'

For advisers, the guides are lucrative. Advertising revenue pays for most, or all, of the costs of publishing the guides, and the advisers then earn commissions on every fund bought via the application forms. Indeed, several mainstream independent advisers have begun publishing guides.

The David Aaron Partnership, a Milton Keynes-based firm, has published Invest It . Though it carries more independent advice than the discount brokers' guides, it too carries adverts only from the 10 providers of the funds it tips. Hargreaves Lansdown, another well-known IFA, has published a similar guide.

Stephen Aaron, marketing director at the David Aaron Partnership, accepts that all the providers recommended in Invest It are large managers with big marketing budgets. But he says: 'We would never include a fund that wasn't up to our standards. We invite firms to participate but if they don't pay us, it wouldn't mean their fund wouldn't be recommended.'

Jackie Blythe, a spokesperson for the FSA, says the regulator will investigate all complaints it receives about the guides. 'The rules are that you can ask providers to pay for advertising but not for distribution or production costs,' she says.

However, one problem is that fund providers are wary of speaking out or complaining because they rely on brokers to distribute their products.

fields.bodyText: The Financial Services Authority is coming under increasing pressure to investigate the growing number of guides to individual savings accounts published by financial advisers. The UK's chief financial regulator has received several objections to the guides, including a complaint from independent adviser Best Investments. It alleges that advisers are being paid by Isa fund providers to recommend their products to investors. Best's allegation is that advisers will tip only funds whose providers pay for advertising and the insertion of their application forms in guides. Deputy managing director Jason Hollands says: 'There is a 100 per cent correlation between advertised funds and recommendations. Fund managers tell us that they know they will not get into these guides unless they advertise.' The number of guides to Isas published by advisers has mushroomed over the past six months. The guides have high print runs, and are often distributed free with national newspapers. Most recommend a handful of funds, and include application forms. The providers accept that they often have to pay to secure recommendations. Last year Virgin Direct told Money Observer it had turned down a request for £150,000 in advertising costs from one adviser, which had then failed to include Virgin in its list of tipped funds. The current scandal follows a long-running Money Observer campaign. We first investigated Isa guides in 1999 but since then many more firms have launched their own publications. Most come from discount brokers, which offer reduced initial charges on tipped funds. Financial Discounts Direct, Chelsea Financial Services, HCF, Isa Choice, Willis Owen, Investors Direct and WiseUp have all published guides this year. In each case, the providers of all the funds recommended paid to advertise in the guides. None carries advertising from a provider whose fund is not tipped. Jonathan Gains, managing director of WiseUp, whose guide has been distributed with the Sunday Times and Mail on Sunday , denies that his firm is doing anything wrong: 'The six funds recommended in our guide have all been through a rigorous research and selection process before being recommended.' However, Hollands argues: 'This is undermining the concept of independent financial advice and squeezes out small companies who cannot afford to advertise but may have the best funds.' He also warns: 'Often, these guides are put together by advertising agents, so you have non-regulated people making investment recommendations.' For advisers, the guides are lucrative. Advertising revenue pays for most, or all, of the costs of publishing the guides, and the advisers then earn commissions on every fund bought via the application forms. Indeed, several mainstream independent advisers have begun publishing guides. The David Aaron Partnership, a Milton Keynes-based firm, has published Invest It . Though it carries more independent advice than the discount brokers' guides, it too carries adverts only from the 10 providers of the funds it tips. Hargreaves Lansdown, another well-known IFA, has published a similar guide. Stephen Aaron, marketing director at the David Aaron Partnership, accepts that all the providers recommended in Invest It are large managers with big marketing budgets. But he says: 'We would never include a fund that wasn't up to our standards. We invite firms to participate but if they don't pay us, it wouldn't mean their fund wouldn't be recommended.' fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Cold callers | Your Budget | Green and seen
fields.body:
Cold callers
Call centres and automated telephone systems get the thumbs down from the public, according to a survey by market researchers Valoris. Call centre staff were found to be unhelpful while the telephone systems were deemed irritating. The survey into technology and its use as a means of communication also found that less than a fifth of those questioned had bought products on the web. Interactive TV also left them cold.

Your Budget
You can find out how much better or worse off you will be after the Budget by using the Budget estimator on Microsoft's personal finance website, MoneyCentral. Simply enter your details into the estimator from tomorrow. Once the Chancellor has made his speech, the tool will calculate how the changes will affect you. To access the Budget estimator, visit www.msn.co.uk and click on MoneyCentral.

Green and seen
You will soon be able to monitor the performance of companies that have passed a 'green' test through a new set of indices from the stock exchange named FTSE4Good. The indices, which should be up and running in June, are the first step towards setting a global standard for socially responsible investment. They will also generate significant funds for Unicef.

webTitle: I'll see you in court - in cyberspace

fields.headline: I'll see you in court - in cyberspace
fields.standfirst: Neasa MacErlean on a legal brave new world
fields.trailText: Neasa MacErlean on a legal brave new world.
fields.body:
The day is in sight when ordinary people will be able to begin legal proceedings through their computer.

Feel that you have waited too long to get that refund you have been promised? You could soon fill in the forms online and email them to the courts. Decided to sue that second-hand car salesman or that shoddy plumber? You could be able to collect your thoughts and sue them from the comfort of your sofa.

After staying firmly in the Victorian era, the courts system is now trying to propel itself into the twenty-first century. In the criminal courts, moves are afoot to copy the New York system of running 24-hour courts. Changes are also planned in the civil courts which will make it easier for people to use the Small Claims Track to try to solve smaller debt, neighbourhood, contract and other disputes.

The Lord Chancellor's Department (LCD) is now consulting on the use of tech nology to widen access to justice. It envisages case management systems whereby litigants will check the progress of a case and all its documen tation by consulting a secure website. Some private law firms offer this already - a development which is popular with clients, who get more control over their case.

A pilot study is due to start at the beginning of March in Telford in which a touch- screen kiosk in the library provides free advice, information and court forms - and is linked, at certain times of the day, by a video-conferencing link to the Telford Citizens' Advice Bureau, where an adviser will answer any questions.

If successful, this scheme could be spread throughout the country in the next few years. Part of the reason that the courts are considering such moves is that the number of courts is due to be cut.

In its paper, 'Modernising the Civil Courts', published in January, the LCD revealed that London's 16 county courts may be cut down to four. If there has been an outcry about village post offices and banks disappearing, there are also grounds for concern about the closure of local courts. Travelling cross-country to a court using public transport is an almost impossible task in some areas. Timetables often do not match court hours. This is one reason why the LCD wants to encourage more telephone hearings in Small Claims Courts.

Over 88,000 people launched claims through the Small Claims Court in 1999. Claims can be brought when the sum in dispute is £5,000 or less.

The court is meant to be a low-cost and speedy way of solving small disputes, with people representing themselves. At the moment, users can go to the LCD's website and download the appropriate forms to begin proceedings. They would then post or deliver them to their local county court. The LCD plans to produce a 'detailed implementation plan by early summer 2001' for its technological (and court closure) plans - including the move to allow people to email their Small Claims Court forms.

Deputy District Judge Graeme Smith, a partner in law firm Pannone, is enthusiastic about the idea of taking advantage of technology, but does not see many signs yet of a computer revolution.

'The use of technology in courts is extremely basic,' he says. 'If a judge is dealing with a matter, he will usually write the order by hand. It's astonishingly basic.'

But, assuming the proposals do come to pass, he thinks they could work well. He is not worried that suing your neighbours will become another weekend hobby for the middle classes if it is made too easy.

But he does wonder if the type of cases brought in Small Claims Courts might not widen, due to a completely separate influence: the Human Rights Act, which came into force last year. There is a box on the Small Claims Court application form which asks the applicant whether they wants to raise a human rights point. 'We'll see more cases dealing with human rights,' he says. 'One area ripe for it now is invasion of privacy.'

If Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas can argue their case for privacy, ordinary people may extend the principle to fight off their snooping neighbours.

Although Smith is not suggesting that people do this, he can see that one or two innovative litigants could set a ball rolling. The Small Claims Court could be the forum for this sort of dispute, with the applicant claiming a certain sum to retain their right to privacy (the cost of putting up a fence, perhaps). Could neighbours also rely on the Act's provision allowing people peaceful enjoyment of their possessions to fight against a noisy neighbour?

Back in the world of the here and now, the National Association of Citizens' Advice Bureaux (Nacab) is preparing its response to the LCD's 'Modernising the Civil Courts' paper. Spokeswoman and legal services specialist Alison Green sees many positive elements: 'We're quite keen to support anything that is likely to increase access.'

Having said that, she has many concerns: about court closures; about focusing too much on email communication, which could exclude people who cannot or do not want to operate that way; and about court fees for the Small Claims Court. Until last April, an applicant had to pay £107 in fees to pursue a £200 debt in the court. Now that fee has been reduced to £27. If you are claiming between £1,001 and £5,000 from your opponent, your total fees are £195. This means that your litigation can be very expensive at the lower end of the scale.

Using the Small Claims Court is also a complicated and more lengthy process than people expect. 'Even if you are very intelligent and articulate, it is still a scary process,' says Chris Cox of Telford CAB. 'Cases can take an awfully long time. It does put people off when we tell them their dispute could take six months to resolve.'

Outside the Small Claims Court, there are growing concerns about the way access to free legal services is being whittled back. Only benefit claimants and those on very low incomes are likely to qualify to get their legal fees paid by the Community Legal Service Fund, the scheme which has replaced Legal Aid.

The LCD now wants to introduce a new rule which would hit low-earning homeowners. People with more than £3,000 of equity in their homes would be expected to pay the excess towards legal fees if they were involved in a case which was partially funded by the Community Legal Service Fund. So if they had £7,000 of equity, they might have to pay £4,000 towards their legal costs. This sum would become payable at completion of the case.

If they did not want to sell their home to pay the bill, the person would have to accept that a charge would be put on their property and that they would be charged interest on the amount when they settled up. Nacab believes this will discourage people from taking cases.

fields.headline: Be happy - spend  money
fields.standfirst: Barbara Oaff  on the new habits of good-time Britain
fields.trailText: Barbara Oaff on the new habits of good-time Britain.
fields.body:
They say you can't buy happiness. But more and more people are trying to. Britons now spend more on having a good time than on keeping a roof over their heads, a government report reveals.

The average household is spending a record-breaking £62.50 a week on leisure, according to Family Spending , published by the Office for National Statistics. This compares with £57 a week on housing, £62.50 a week on food and £53 a week on that other essential, motoring.

A generation ago the sums looked rather different. Back then optional extras accounted for around 9 per cent of a British budget; they now account for 17 per cent.

This money is spent on anything from personal computers to special interest classes to summer holidays abroad - once a rare luxury now an item the average household spends £13.20 a week on.

This represents a real shift, says Martin Hayward of the Henley Centre, a London-based consumer consultancy. 'Twenty or 30 years ago our money went towards staying alive. Now it goes on having fun.'

Arguably this is due to an across-the-board increase in wages. In 2000 the gross household income was £475 per week. In 1970, it equated to less than £300. 'There's been a rapid increase in wealth and personal disposable income,' says Hayward. 'And a lot of us are still getting used to it.'

But not everyone has yet to get to grips with this problem. Family Spending divided the households who responded to its survey in to 10 income groups. The richest has £780 a week to dispose of. The poorest has £120. These two extremes used their leisure pounds in markedly different ways.

The highest group spent 10 times more on going to the theatre and the cinema than the lowest. The highest group spent 25 per cent of their food expenditure on dining out; the lowest group spent eight per cent. The highest group spent 42 per cent of their sports and entertainment expenditure on going to a game, the lowest spent 10 per cent. The latter were far more likely to spend what money they did have on a satellite dish so as to watch the match at home. As for that holiday abroad, the top 10 per cent of households could afford £34.50 a week, the bottom 10 per cent considerably less - £1.90.

Yet the big picture is not as bad as all that, says Melanie Swift, editor of trade publication Leisure and Hospital ity Business. 'Leisure has become an important part of our lifestyle. It is not so much a luxury as a necessary release given our working patterns and our pace of life. And this is true of everyone. Even in low-income families, people are spending money in ways that make them happy and keep them sane.'

But are we all spending too much on enjoying ourselves today, and not enough on saving for tomorrow? Findings suggests that no, we are not. In fact, Britons are spending more on finance and financial services than ever before. It is the fastest growing consumer sector, according to market researcher Mintel. It has risen 5.7 percentage points in 10 years. To put that in context, the next fastest growing consumer sector is travel, which has risen 0.5 percentage points over the same period.

So we are not scrimping on our life assurance in order to have an extra long weekend away - we are having both. This is a 'good sign', says Mintel analyst Shaheed Alam. 'We seem to be taking quite a balanced approach. We are making the most of the present. But we are also aware of the future.

'The test,' he points out, 'will come when and if there is a recession. Will people cut down on their holiday - or will they cut down on their pension?'

In answer to this question Hayward of The Henley Centre says we will see the emergence of 'hedged hedonism', where people are cautious in some areas of their spending and wild in others.

He also says there will be greater emphasis on value for money and value for time. People will not only want to purchase a good product, they will want to purchase a good experience.

'It will come to a point when people will find that they get less and less satisfaction out of simply acquiring yet another material possession. Getting a third television or a third car or a third wardrobe full of clothes or whatever will not be nearly as exciting as getting the first.

'People will want something more. They will want intangibles. Rather than just buying goods, people will want to buy a good time.'

What it costs to:

 Attend a premier league football game: £15-£150

 Go to a national opera performance: £3-£70

 See a West End show: £19 up

 See a new film: up to £7.50

 View an art exhibition: £0 - £7

Here's what it costs a family of four to:

 Eat out at an Indian restaurant: £30

 Get a takeaway. Fish and chips: £14

 Go to a theme park. Alton Towers: £80

 Visit a tourist attraction. The London Eye: £27

 Take a package summer holiday. Costa Brava: £800
