fields.headline: Insurer 'starving us out'
fields.standfirst: Angry investors attack firm for suspending bonuses
fields.trailText: Angry investors attack firm for suspending bonuses.
fields.body:
Investors with Equitable Life received another blow last week, when the insurer announced that it was suspending payment of guaranteed bonuses.

Equitable has given no commitment to reinstating the bonuses; it has hinted that this may depend on it reaching agreement with policyholders to control the cost of the guaranteed pensions that plunged it into crisis (see box).

Paul Braithwaite of the Equitable Members' Action Group accused the firm of trying to starve policyholders into submission. 'They have sold the members and policyholders down the river once again. Pensions are left without any guarantee of nourishment.'

Kean Seager, an independent adviser co-ordinating another policyholders' group, called the latest news 'very, very disappointing'.

Annual, or reversionary, bonuses are the basic building blocks of a with-profits investment. Once added to a policy, normally annually, they cannot be taken away.

Equitable says it cannot afford to pay them this year because it needs to set aside reserves to pay these guaranteed returns in future. This would mean tying up even more money in lower-risk investments, and limiting its ability to invest for growth.

The insurer has already warned that returns on its with-profits fund are likely to be cut as a result of its problems, and policyholders have also lost out on bonuses for seven months of last year.

Bonuses will be restored from August last year, but they are to be paid as terminal, or final, bonuses, which are not guaranteed. Equitable could retroactively withdraw the money.

Equitable spokesman Alistair Dunbar said: 'It is sensible this year to look at total allocation rate and pass it on as a final bonus. They [policyholders] will get more in the end because it won't constrain our investment freedom.'

An announcement is due shortly on the rate of the firm's bonus for 2000.

Seager, representing the Equitable Policyholders' Action Group, believes the decision not to pay a reversionary bonus reflected the 'rather parlous' state of the insurer's reserves.

These are 'very tight,' he said, despite money being injected into Equitable by the Halifax, in a deal hammered out after the insurer closed to new business in December (see box).

Seager and Braithwaite both point out that Halifax has paid so far for the assets of the business only. Further money is forthcoming but only on certain conditions - one of these being a deal to cap Equitable's liabilities for the guaranteed bonuses.

Braithwaite said: 'People breathed a huge sigh of relief that Halifax was going to solve the problem. That was a false sense of security. All that did was buy the assets. The problem is still there.'

The suspension of the guaranteed bonuses will further rattle investors who have not withdrawn money from Equitable. Those who take cash away from the with- profits fund face a 10 per cent exit penalty, imposed when the firm shut to new business last December.

Some people, mainly those with annuities, cannot move. Others, including those with the guaranteed policies that Equitable has been told it must pay out on, are being advised to wait for the outcome of negotiations over the guarantees' future.

Advisers are also telling people within 10 years of retirement to stay put because it will be hard for them to make up for the 10 per cent penalty if they go.

Amanda Davidson of independent adviser Holden Meehan said that, generally, she had been advising younger pension clients to move, and last week's news had reinforced her view.

Actuary Ronnie Sloan, who has devised a computer program to help people work out whether to move their money, said the latest news was not, on its own, a signal to pull out. But investors should be looking at the bonus rate declared by the insurer to compare it with those elsewhere.

Sloan is concerned, however, about the long-term outlook for Equitable's with- profits funds, and is not convinced that the Halifax money will strengthen the fund sufficiently to make it competitive. 'It stops the situation getting any worse. I can't believe it makes it positively better. I would regard it as damage limitation.'

Another independent actuary, Vince Whitefoord, who has written guides for Equitable investors, also feels younger investors should go: 'The 10 per cent it is a relatively small hit on your retirement prospects.'

Seager said: 'A lot of people ought to be thinking about starting a new pension elsewhere.'

Kevin Wesbroom, a partner at actuary Bacon & Woodrow accepted Equitable's view that not paying a guaranteed return could work to policyholders' advantage because it should improve the insurer's freedom to invest for growth.

Policyholders should probably sit tight to see if the insurer could secure agreement to cap its liabilities, but for some emotion might rule. 'Are you sick to your teeth of opening newspapers and seeing something new happening at Equitable?'

 The Office of Fair Trading has told Equitable it is unhappy about the way it imposed the penalty on policyholders wanting to leave.

It believes that such action could contravene the unfair contracts laws, but it is is unlikely to order refunds.

The story so far

Equitable Life closed to new business last December. It had been forced to put itself up for sale in the summer after a House of Lords' ruling said it must pay out on guaranteed pension policies it had sold years earlier. This group of policyholders - known as the guaranteed annuity rate policyholders (GARs) are owed an estimated £1.5 billion.

But the final bill could be higher and because of the uncertainty buyers were scared off.

Investors who wanted to withdraw were charged a penalty fee of 10 per cent, and the insurer warned that future returns to with-profit policyholders would be reduced as a result of its problems.

A deal has since been done with Halifax bank, but a quarter of the potential price of up to £1bn is conditional on reaching agreement to cap the money owed to the GAR investors and a further quarter on the Equitable sales force meeting certain targets.

A new chairman and chief executive are in place at Equitable and executives are planning a series of meetings with policyholders, starting on 12 March, aimed at persuading them to accept a settlement over the GAR policies.

Policyholders who want to attend Equitable's 'roadshow' meetings should write to Equitable's new chairman Vanni Treves, at: Policyholders' Meeting (MKT). The Equitable Life, FREEPOST, Aylesbury, Bucks, HP21 7BR.

fields.bodyText: Investors with Equitable Life received another blow last week, when the insurer announced that it was suspending payment of guaranteed bonuses. Equitable has given no commitment to reinstating the bonuses; it has hinted that this may depend on it reaching agreement with policyholders to control the cost of the guaranteed pensions that plunged it into crisis (see box). Paul Braithwaite of the Equitable Members' Action Group accused the firm of trying to starve policyholders into submission. 'They have sold the members and policyholders down the river once again. Pensions are left without any guarantee of nourishment.' Kean Seager, an independent adviser co-ordinating another policyholders' group, called the latest news 'very, very disappointing'. Annual, or reversionary, bonuses are the basic building blocks of a with-profits investment. Once added to a policy, normally annually, they cannot be taken away. Equitable says it cannot afford to pay them this year because it needs to set aside reserves to pay these guaranteed returns in future. This would mean tying up even more money in lower-risk investments, and limiting its ability to invest for growth. The insurer has already warned that returns on its with-profits fund are likely to be cut as a result of its problems, and policyholders have also lost out on bonuses for seven months of last year. Bonuses will be restored from August last year, but they are to be paid as terminal, or final, bonuses, which are not guaranteed. Equitable could retroactively withdraw the money. Equitable spokesman Alistair Dunbar said: 'It is sensible this year to look at total allocation rate and pass it on as a final bonus. They [policyholders] will get more in the end because it won't constrain our investment freedom.' An announcement is due shortly on the rate of the firm's bonus for 2000. Seager, representing the Equitable Policyholders' Action Group, believes the decision not to pay a reversionary bonus reflected the 'rather parlous' state of the insurer's reserves. These are 'very tight,' he said, despite money being injected into Equitable by the Halifax, in a deal hammered out after the insurer closed to new business in December (see box). Seager and Braithwaite both point out that Halifax has paid so far for the assets of the business only. Further money is forthcoming but only on certain conditions - one of these being a deal to cap Equitable's liabilities for the guaranteed bonuses. Braithwaite said: 'People breathed a huge sigh of relief that Halifax was going to solve the problem. That was a false sense of security. All that did was buy the assets. The problem is still there.' The suspension of the guaranteed bonuses will further rattle investors who have not withdrawn money from Equitable. Those who take cash away from the with- profits fund face a 10 per cent exit penalty, imposed when the firm shut to new business last December. Some people, mainly those with annuities, cannot move. Others, including those with the guaranteed policies that Equitable has been told it must pay out on, are being advised to wait for the outcome of negotiations over the guarantees' future. Advisers are also telling people within 10 years of retirement to stay put because it will be hard for them to make up for the 10 per cent penalty if they go. Amanda Davidson of independent adviser Holden Meehan said that, generally, she had been advising younger pension clients to move, and last week's news had reinforced her view. Actuary Ronnie Sloan, who has devised a computer program to help people work out whether to move their money, said the latest news was not, on its own, a signal to pull out. But investors should be looking at the bonus rate declared by the insurer to compare it with those elsewhere. fields.standfirst: Liverpool Victoria With-Profits Growth Bond
fields.trailText: Liverpool Victoria With-Profits Growth Bond.
fields.body:
Contact 0845 6020690 or your IFA.

Aim To produce steady growth by investing in the Liverpool Victoria with-profits fund.

Bells & whistles A previous bond investing in the same fund has been deemed top-performing bond by Money Marketing magazine in 1999 and 2000 for £10,000 invested over five years. An investment of £10,000 in August 1995 would have grown to £17,561 over the next five years, producing average annual growth of 11.92 per cent, compared with a building society account return of 3.21 per cent.

How it works The bond is a single premium investment. The allocation rate, which shows what percentage of your money is invested on your behalf, ranges from 102 per cent for investments of £10,000 to 103.25 for sums of £100,000 or more. Your IFA may surrender commission to increase the allocation rate. Up to 5 per cent of the amount invested can be withdrawn in each of the first five years without penalty. No limit thereafter. Not to be confused with a bond of the same name sold by Liverpool Victoria's direct salesforce.

Minimum £10,000.

Charges No initial charge . Monthly charge of 0.075 per cent of the bond value in first five years, nothing thereafter. Monthly investment management charge of 0.057 per cent taken before bonuses are added. Early withdrawal charge (from 9 per cent in first year reducing by 1.5 per cent each year) in first five years if the bond is fully cashed in or withdrawals in any policy year exceed 5 per cent of amount invested. After the fifth year you can withdraw any amount without penalty, although larger sums may be subject to tax, and/or a market value adjustor (a reduction in value imposed by the insurer) if the withdrawal is made after a stock market slump.

Tax Returns from the bond are taxed at basic rate. This cannot be reclaimed by non-taxpayers. Up to 5 per cent of amount invested can be withdrawn each year by basic-rate taxpayers without paying any further tax, although higher-rate taxpayers may have to pay additional tax after 20 years or when all the bond is withdrawn.

Risk Medium.

Should you invest? Patrick Connolly of Bath independent financial adviser Chartwell: 'It's just an ordinary with-profits bond with average charges.' He adds that while Liverpool Victoria's performance has been good in past years, few policies matured in that time .Martin Brown of Nottingham firm The With Profits Bond Shop disagrees: 'The financial strength is good, the charges are good, the five-year performance is tops, and it's an easy contract to understand.'

Points out of 10 Connolly - 4, Brown - 10.

webTitle: Life coaching: Financially fit for life

fields.headline: Financially fit for life
fields.standfirst: Sandra Deeble  on how a personal trainer can help you get rich
fields.trailText: Sandra Deeble on how a personal trainer can help you get rich.
fields.body:
Are you in denial about your pension, tax return and credit cards? Do 'don't go there' signs pop into your mind every time you consider sorting out your finances? Then you may benefit from a life coach.

Life coaches help you assess your life now and work out how to change it to the way you want to be in future - fitter, happier and possibly richer. Getting a life coach may seem as indulgent as having a personal trainer to drag you out of bed to go jogging every morning, yet life coaching, which originated in the US, is gaining popularity in the UK.

There are about 450 life coaches in this country, which means there are probably up to 20,000 people involved in life coaching, according to Aboodi Shaby, president of the International Coach Federation in the UK.

He coaches 14 clients, spending hours on the phone with them each week. He also keeps up with clients via emails in between calls, as well as maintaining a website and writing a book. 'I'm not a guru, I'm not a magician, but I am keeping people on track,' he says.

The coaching is rarely conducted face to face - so the next time you see a colleague sitting on a park bench at lunchtime, talking seriously into a mobile phone and nodding sagely, you could be witnessing a coaching session. Sometimes with as little as one half-hour telephone call each week, life coaches check in with their clients to support, encourage and galvanise people to continue with the commitments they have already made.

But if you need to change your attitudes towards money - curbing compulsive spending and keeping to a budget while you pay off your debts - possibly the last thing you want to do is shell out up to £200 each month just to chat to someone whom you may have never met about how you can't stop money trickling through your fingers.

And surely the best person to advise you on your finances is an independent financial adviser?

But while a financial adviser may wheel out the latest on the best Tessa-only Isa, he's unlikely to truffle out what really trips you up when grappling with your finances.

'People have one or two issues about money,' explains coach Niki Cassidy. These issues could be related to how our parents perceived money: was it hard or easy to come by in your family home?

The work ethic may have conditioned us to believe that you have to work really hard to earn money, and a lifetime of positive or negative money-related experiences can colour our view of our finances.

'Some people have some shame around money,' says Cassidy. 'And there do seem to be people who feel they don't have any control over it.'

One of her aims as a coach is to 'create lightness' around the subject. 'When I'm coaching, I'm standing in the middle of a river. A fish is coming down the river. I'm waiting for that fish and I will leap on it, explore it and rip that fish to shreds.'

Quite. In researching this piece, salmon, bikes and streams were all popular metaphors.

'It offers a soft-focus approach to money,' is how Cassidy regards life coaching and money. For the 'hard' bit, your life coach is likely to recommend a financial adviser.

And even if you're fully invested, have your retirement plans sorted out and have never been overdrawn, life coaching can help you to do even greater things with your money.

Indeed, as Shaby explains, while many people seek out a coach to help them to make big changes in their lives, at the same time there are thousands of others who get a coach after musing contentedly: 'Life's all right, but how could it be better?'

'Things felt bigger in my head than they were in life'

Jan (not her real name) is a university lecturer. She has been working with life coach Fiona Reed for 10 months.

'Life coaching still feels terribly indulgent to me - it's so American and indulgent that a large part of the British population will think it's simpering and over the top. And yet, at the same time, it works.'

Jan originally started working with Reed to help her to make better use of her time. 'Things felt bigger in my head than they were in real life,' she now realises.

'If you go on a time-management course, once you're away from it, everything you've learnt goes. It's the ongoing nature of life coaching which seems to help people. It's regular and in short, sharp bursts.'

Another area of her life which Jan wanted to sort out was her desk. 'You can't go to a therapist and say, "I can't get my desk sorted," ' she says. 'But Fiona is much more practical than a therapist.' Desk tidying and paper sorting finally led to looking at money. Jan had never really looked at her finances before.

'I knew I could bring down my mortgage and that I should be putting more into savings, but I thought I had to make the best decision, so I put it off.'

Fiona recommended a financial adviser and Jan's homework one week was to call him. 'The only reason I did it was because I couldn't bear to tell Fiona that I hadn't done it.' When Jan finally met the financial adviser, she thought: 'He's going to think that I am the saddest person in the world.' With Reed's encouragement, Jan worked with the financial adviser, with remarkable results, which included renting out her flat overnight and discovering that she was due a payment of £40,000 from a critical health policy.

'Once I got started, I was on a roll. It was as if the universe fell into help,' is how she describes it. Jan believes she would never have got her life sorted out without Reed. 'She helps me prioritise and it doesn't seem like such a big deal.'

Reed helped Jan discover that she constantly gave away her time by accepting invitations and helping people, but then felt exhausted when she didn't have enough time to herself. 'And Fiona was keen that I didn't do with my money what I usually did with my life.'

The £40,000 has now been invested for Jan's pension and retirement, and she has been able to invest in ethical funds - something she feels strongly about.

'Now I know where my money is going, whereas before it got me tied in knots. There's a feeling of joy that I don't have to worry about it.'

'It's money well spent'

Anthony Nally is a hospital manager and works in private health-care. He started working with his life coach, Jadzia Kopiel, three years ago, when he was 'earning good money but spending a lot', he had amassed huge credit-card debts, and had completely given up opening bank statements.

'The important thing around coaching and money was recognising that it was a symptom of other things not being right,' is how Nally sees it. 'My coach said I was using money as an excuse. It was a block. I couldn't confront this spending. It was a compulsive thing.'

Working with Kopiel, Nally was able to recognise the role money was playing in his life. 'I managed a multi-million pound business but I couldn't manage my own money. I felt flawed.'

By addressing his own beliefs around money, he was able to change his life. He left his job, paid off his debts, now has a long-term pension plan and is doing work he enjoys. 'Coaching gave me objective help, having someone who challenged me.'

Nally's coaching started with the 'Clean Sweep' questionnaire. 'Although money wasn't one of my worst scores, my job was,' he admits. 'But I depended on the job for the money. I was constantly saying: "I've got to stick at this job," and it was preventing me from planning ahead.'

He spends £200 a month on four hours of phone calls with unlimited emails. 'It's money well spent. Coaching is about life balance, as it looks at environment, well-being, relationships and financial responsibilities.'

So is it for you?

Life coaches often take on pro-bono clients, so it's fairly easy to give a coach a whirl before you take them on. Fees range from £30-£50 an hour and coaching is by phone with email contact in between calls. The International Coach Federation in the UK is the professional body for coaches.

Coach University
Mark Forster
Niki Cassidy
Fiona Reed
Aboodi Shaby
Carole Gaskell
Jadzia Kopiel

'Transform Your Life' by Carole Gaskell (Thorsons)
'Get Everything Done and Still Have Time to Play', by Mark Forster (Hodder & Stoughton)
'Be Your Own Life Coach', by Fiona Harrold (H&S)

Training

See www.coachu.com for information on how to be a coach. Reckon on investing up to £3,000 to qualify. Training takes up to three years.

webTitle: Wealthcheck: My poetic hopes after GP justice

fields.headline: My poetic hopes after GP justice
fields.standfirst: Widowed and retired, Joan wants to invest for a good life, she tells  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Widowed and retired, Joan wants to invest for a good life, she tells Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
Joan Carney

Age 66

Lives in Sunderland

Occupation Retired

Pension £12,600

Mortgage £5,000

Debts None

Investments Bank deposit account

Aims To find suitable investments for her capital so she can enjoy the rest of her retirement

After her husband Robert died, retired teacher Joan Carney fought a six-year legal battle to prove his GP's negligence for failing to spot that Robert had been suffering from heart disease.

The case was finally settled out of court last autumn, providing Joan with a £50,000 settlement. Feeling vindicated, she now wants to enjoy the rest of her life.

She has already used most of her settlement to pay off all but £5,000 of her mortgage, and to make an informal loan which is being repaid on a monthly basis. She has a modest amount of capital left, which she hopes will soon be increased by an estimated £33,000 in legal costs which the court awarded her last September. She would like to know the best way to invest this money.

Her immediate plan is to move to a smaller property. 'My current home has three bedrooms and I hate cleaning,' she admits. She has just put in an offer for a bungalow nearer to her daughter. If it is accepted, she will put her property on the market. This will free up some more capital.

After moving, she estimates she will have another £10,000 left over from the sale of her house to invest.

She also expects her living expenses to go down when she is in a smaller home. Not that she has any trouble coping on her pension, she says. When she retired from teaching on ill-health grounds 10 years ago - after 16 years in the profession - her pension was enhanced and she has also inherited another pension from her late husband.

At present all her spare cash is in a variety of Halifax accounts. Last summer she tried dabbling in some shares but did not stay in the stock market for long. 'I couldn't stand the way the price of the shares kept going up and down, so I sold them. I found it too unsettling.' She made a £700 profit, but could have made more had she waited.

As a diabetes sufferer, she is convinced that she has not got much longer to live. 'I may have four or five goodish years left,' she says. During this time, she would very much like to pursue her passion for poetry. She has written poetry herself and is considering taking a university course. Getting a small car is also on her wish list.

While not hard up, she does not like wasting money. As health is a major concern, she feels she is not getting good value from her private medical insurance policy. 'It costs £132 a month and I've only used it occasionally. I wonder if I would be better off cancelling the policy and saving the premiums in a separate account to pay for consultations or treatment when I need them.'

Adviser 1: Dan Kemp

The first thing to look at is Joan's attitude to investment risk. As she sold her shares because she was uncomfortable with stock market risk, we need to adopt a cautious strategy so she can sleep at night.

Such an approach would mix guaranteed and low-risk equity investments. It is important that some low- risk equity holdings are included as these are likely to achieve a better level of growth than cash holdings over the long term. It is necessary to take the longer term into account in case Joan is still studying poetry in her eighties.

On the other hand it is clearly important that she has enough capital available in the short term in guaranteed/cash holdings to make the purchases she wants and give her a level of financial freedom. We therefore recommend a 60/40 split between low-risk and guaranteed/cash investments. This will enable Joan to have a lump sum of around £20,000 available to buy a new car. We recommend that the cash is held in a high-interest deposit account.

We would then recommend that she invests £30,000 in long-term low- risk holdings such as low-risk Isa with-profits bonds. There are a number of companies, such as HSBC, offering low-risk equity-based Isas, where the initial capital investment is protected.

fields.headline: Have prescription - won't travel
fields.standfirst: Tracey Boles  on insurers who give all but the healthiest a hard time
fields.trailText: Tracey Boles on insurers who give all but the healthiest a hard time.
fields.body:
University lecturer Chris Bloom is diabetic but she works in a demanding environment, drives and is extremely active, controlling her condition with insulin. Yet when her annual travel insurance renewal with Europe Assistance came up this year it was refused.

Bloom, not her real name, is not alone in experiencing difficulties. The British Insurance Brokers' Association (Biba) has noticed an increase in complaints from people with pre-existing medical conditions, who find themselves unable to get travel cover. Either that or they are forced to accept policy excesses of between £5,000 and £10,000.

'This shouldn't be happening,' says the Association of British Insurers. It believes the practices contravene new legislation designed to protect the disabled from discrimination.

But a mystery shopping exercise by Holiday Which? , the consumer magazine, has found some insurers more helpful than others towards people with pre-existing conditions. It will be naming and shaming the worst offenders in the March issue.

'Some insurers operate a blanket ban on pre-existing conditions,' says assistant editor Roger Lakin. Boots, among others, will not automatically give cover to anyone who has been on a prescription medicine in the past 12 months, according to insurer TravelPlan Direct. If you take medicine for flu in the winter, you may not be able to find insurance the following summer.

Any problems with your heart or lungs will make it tricky to find insurance, as will a diagnosis of cancer. You are also likely to encounter problems should you plan to travel against your GP's advice.

Outside these cases there is a surprising lack of consensus as to what constitutes a pre-existing condition. Travel policies can be woolly in their definitions, using terms such as 'blood conditions' or 'psychiatric disorders'. You may also be refused cover if you have had 'medical treatment' in the two years preceding the trip or are awaiting an operation. Pregnancy can also cast you into the insurance wilderness.

Most insurers have a helpline where you can find out where you stand. The more open you are, the more likely you are to get turned away. But before you think about keeping quiet, check out the small print to see if your condition is among the exclusions. If it is and you fall ill when away, the insurance policy will not pay out.

Why the sudden difficulty in insuring pre-existing conditions? Biba puts it down to the entry into the market of companies selling insurance direct. 'Their off-the-shelf policies are not specialised - it is like going to Ikea,' says Biba spokeswoman Jennifer Weller. Other companies are said to be tightening up their policies due to an increase in complaints as more people travel. Biba recommends that those with pre-existing conditions go to a specialist provider.

Nearly two-thirds of people still buy travel insurance from a travel agent, but a travel agent is not an expert on such policies. He will get a fat commission cheque to boot. 'Travel agents are the last place you should go for you holiday insurance,' says Paul Charles of online broker screentrade.co.uk. 'You are more likely to be ripped off.' Biba can put you in touch with a specialist broker who will have access to a wide selection of products.

But Mrs Bloom does not feel specialists offer a solution. She says: 'I am suspicious of the specialists. I think they load the premiums.' One agreed to insure her for a four-day holiday in France - for £140.

Pre-existing conditions do tend to push up the cost of cover. Premiums will depend on the condition and how old you are. Which ? magazine says to try mainstream insurers first because they may cover you at no extra charge. Failing that, it advises you to persevere. 'One man with mild angina was first offered a £10,000 policy excess, then a premium of £600 before finding one for £40.'

You can complain to the Association of British Insurers via their website. The association is currently consulting to produce a set of guidelines on the disabled for the insurance industry.

Don't exclude yourself

Mediquote in Chichester, which says it does not believe in exclusions and will endeavour to find you insurance as long as your condition is 'stable' and suitable for your proposed itinerary, has this advice for people with pre-existing conditions wanting to travel:

 Plan ahead - don't leave it until the day before you go away to look for travel insurance.

 Speak to your doctor to see if she thinks you are fit to travel.

 Get comparative quotes. Premiums vary a great deal.

 Avoid big policy excesses.

 Get the insurer to put in writing the terms under which your cover has been extended.

webTitle: Are residents' parking zones out of control?

fields.headline: Are residents' parking zones out of control?
fields.standfirst: Locals have very little say on restriction schemes, writes  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Locals have very little say on restriction schemes, writes Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
When Anne visits her father in Hampstead, north London, she usually waits until after 8pm, because parking restrictions in her father's road make it difficult for non-residents to park there until the evening.

If she goes earlier, he will give her a visitor's voucher. But Anne is not keen: 'It costs him money and then there is all the palaver involved.' Her father pays £82 a year for his permit from the borough of Camden and a minimum of 40p an hour for guests.

But going to see her mother in Golders Green is far easier. Instead of operating parking restrictions throughout the day, the borough of Barnet deters commuters from parking on residential roads by enforcing restrictions for just one hour in the middle of the day. This means that a commuter who used to leave the car all day near Golders Green station and use the Underground for the rest of the journey cannot do so any longer.

But shoppers and visitors who want to park for part of the day can still do so for nothing if they avoid the restricted hour. Anne's mother pays £20 a year for her permit - and she also gets a book of 10 free guest-parking vouchers.

Both these schemes have been in place for a few years. In that time many other controlled parking zones (CPZs) have been set up in towns and cities throughout the country, and many more are planned.

But surprisingly little is known about them. The Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR) is responsible for road planning but does not keep a record of the number of CPZs. And there appears to be no lobbying group to look after the interests of local residents and businesses.

Lobbying group Transport 2000, a fervent champion of the ordinary citizen, is basically very keen on parking controls. 'They are effective mechanisms in terms of controlling traffic,' says spokesman Steve Hounsham. 'We are in favour of charging people to park and using these sticks to encourage people to use public transport, walk and cycle.'

Local authorities are required under the Road Traffic Regulations Act 1984 to consult with the police, fire brigade, road-haulage industry and other interested parties if they are planning a CPZ. They are also encouraged by the DETR to consult local residents, but they could fulfil this statutory duty with a notice in the local paper. Most authorities do more than this, and are very likely to put notices up on the roads affected.

The London Borough of Haringey held open days staffed by local officials, with maps of the proposed schemes and a ballot box for people to cast their vote. But local government specialist Celia Cullen of solicitor Eversheds says: 'Councils have to consider objections but they don't have to act on those objections.'

The London Borough of Hackney has just introduced a controversial CPZ near Finsbury Park. Restrictions apply six days a week from early morning to mid-evening. Residents are charged £50 a year for a permit. Margot Sreberny, president of the Finsbury Park Action Group, says: 'They consulted with the people, who said, "No, we don't want it", and we got it immediately.' Few people complain about the £50 charge, she says, but it does disrupt ordinary life if visitors have difficulty parking.

Many local authorities will feel under pressure to follow suit if a CPZ is set up in an adjacent area. As Steve Hounsham of Transport 2000 says: 'It has to be done in a very co-ordinated and comprehensive manner. There is no point in having restrictions in one street if everyone can park in the next street.' This may be why some schemes do seem to be railroaded through. If people really want to challenge proposals, they can apply for a judicial review or complain to the Local Gov ernment Ombudsman (0845 602 1983). But the Ombudsman says nobody has yet complained.

But 'people power' does work sometimes. Michael Lewer QC led a successful campaign to keep his road out of the new Finsbury Park CPZ. He called a meeting of residents, who voted 31-1 against the scheme. The crucial factor seems to be that he persuaded a local councillor to attend the meeting and witness the vote. He says: 'Hackney could hardly deny the result because there had been a councillor there.'

Tempers can run high in consultations on CPZs. Vince Christie of the Local Government Association says: 'One of the problems is that there are large numbers of people who think they should get priority over others - taxis, buses, disabled drivers, residents, people using delivery bays and, in holiday areas, caravans. These pressures are always there and they are not getting any easier.'

CPZs aside, motorists could be faced with two new kinds of financial penalties within the next few years: congestion-charging schemes and workplace-charging schemes.

The DETR is gearing up to introduce these under the Transport Act 2000. Guidelines for local authorities are unlikely to appear before the end of the year: this is not the sort of issue the government will want aired before an election. Some schemes may start next year, but transport specialists expect it to be three or four years before they are commonplace.

London Mayor Ken Livingstone's plans for congestion charging on motorists who drive into the centre of London are well known. Schemes could be fairly easy to set up, especially in small cities with a limited number of entry roads to the centre.

Under workplace-charging schemes, local authorities will be able to charge employers a daily rate for each parking space they own. It will then be up to employers whether they pass on the cost to employees.

Neither plan is compulsory - and many local authorities will not introduce either. Authorities would need to get clearance from the DETR. There is no cap in the legislation on charges but Transport 2000 thinks £5 is a likely charge for both schemes.

As the DETR envisages it, local authorities would have to improve public transport first to give motorists an alternative if they no longer want to drive.

Many authorities are already increasing charges for ordinary car parks in a bid to force drivers to switch to buses. Authorities can always argue the environmentalist line if they need a moral defence.

Four wheels bad - two wheels smart

When God closes one parking bay, he sometimes opens another.

Under a scheme being considered by some city councils, people who are finding four-wheeled transport difficult could use community bicyles for free.

The scheme has been proposed by Adshel, the company that places advertisements at roadside bus shelters. Adshel has proposed 'SmartBike' schemes to Cardiff, Lincoln, Birmingham and some other city councils.

To use the scheme, you would apply for a free smartcard and then you could pick up a bike at one of several bike points around the city.

You could then cycle to your destination and drop the bike off at the nearest bike point. In return for providing the bikes, Adshel wants the local authorities to offer it free advertising spaces at the bike parks.

So far this has proved a stumbling block. The city of Cardiff, in particular, was very keen at one stage. Adshel is continuing to promote the idea. But if you want to use a smartbike now, you will have to go to one of the schemes that Adshel runs abroad - in Norway, Singapore or France.

fields.headline: Everything - except the kitchen sink
fields.standfirst: Anne Caborn  on  what 'fixtures and fittings' can involve in today's housing market
fields.trailText: Anne Caborn on what 'fixtures and fittings' can involve in today's housing market.
fields.body:
WHETHER you are buying or selling a home it's important to be specific about what is included in the deal.

The term 'fixtures and fittings' is open to interpretation. This has been argued in the courts over the centuries, but our modern-day obsession with home improvement may cloud the issue. A fitted kitchen is definitely a fixture, but television celebrity chefs have made free-standing units and ovens on wheels the latest must-haves. Likewise, plug-in lighting units and uplighters have usurped the traditional ceiling rose and light socket. They are not fixtures in the legal sense, but couldbecome a stumbling block to a sale.

'The trend for free-standing, rather than fitted, appliances and furniture has had an effect on the interior design and specification of city apartments,' said Angela South, sales and marketing director of city developer Nicholson Estates.

'Many of today's purchasers treat the fridge-freezer as furniture and prefer to supply their own favourite model. They do expect, however, to have fitted dishwashers, ovens and hobs. In all our apartments we have moved away from fixed ceiling lights and install designer wall lights that complement whatever free-standing lighting the purchaser might choose.'

According to Hugh Dunsmore-Hardy of the National Association of Estate Agents, items may appear fixed but the seller may wish to take them when they leave. A typical example might be bookshelves. If purchaser and seller agree that these can be removed, the deal should include any making-good, or the price should reflect the need for redecoration.

Attitudes to fixtures and fittings reflect the overall state of the property market, says Dunsmore-Hardy: 'When the market goes into a slacker period and people's price expectations are not being maintained, they are more likely to say "Well, in that case, I'm taking this, this and this with me".'

Items that are contained in the estate agents' particulars, such as made-to-measure curtains, would normally be seen as forming part of the deal and the price. But it always pays to check. This can be done through the solicitor handling the deal, who may be following the Law Society's Transaction protocol, which includes a contents list being supplied by the seller.

Another area to watch out for is the modern designer garden. This is a potential minefield, given the fashion for paved patios where plants are contained in smart and expensive pots.

The Government's Homes Bill, which is currently going through Parliament, paves the way for the introduction of a compulsory 'seller's pack' in 2003, designed to hold all pertinent details, such as the definitive list of what is included in the price, and even a survey. 'There's an old case that involved a tapestry being nailed to the wall and was therefore a fixture,' said solicitor Roger Wilson. 'If you go back enough years, even floorboards were loose so you could remove them.'

If as purchaser you are particularly attracted to an item it's worth asking if it is included in the price, or whether it can be purchased separately.

If it is not a fixture but an item that could be taken by the seller, negotiating a sep arate deal may make financial sense: stamp duty is payable at 1 per cent on a total house purchase price of more than £60,000. On properties that sell for more than £250,000 it is 3 per cent and and on sales exceeding £500,000 it is 4 per cent. Taking things like curtains out of the purchase price can make a significant tax saving if it brings you below the next tax level.

But Wilson warns against playing fast and loose with the fixtures definition. 'You can put a reasonable price on carpets, curtains and even curtain rails and the Inland Revenue will normally accept that. A typical figure would be £3,000-£4,000, although in London it may well be £10,000. But you invite questions if you just magic a figure simply to save tax.'

Another potential problem, which also reflects our current obsession with home style, is the lack of difference designer fixtures may actually make to the selling price.

They may affect a home's saleability, but the fact that you have chosen designer bathroom taps or restored the Victorian originals will not result in a higher sale price, according to Jeremy Leaf, housing market spokesman for the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors. A major renovation or extension may affect the price but you would still not recoup the actual cost.

When it comes to items that could be removed by the seller, more desirable items can be used as a way of maximising the selling price. The inference being that if the asking price is not paid, these items will be removed.

Using these fittings to smooth a sale may help the seller. The designer curtains in the lounge may not fit or match the intended colour scheme or ambience of their new home. The buyer still gets a bargain as these second hand items are a good deal.

'It may even be that you've always hated the Laura Ashley curtains in the lounge and can't wait to get rid of them,' said Leaf.

webTitle: Phoney war to real mortgage battle

fields.headline: Phoney war to real mortgage battle
fields.standfirst: Discounts are being slashed as things get serious, says  Tracey Boles
fields.trailText: Discounts are being slashed as things get serious, says Tracey Boles.
fields.body:
The mortgage price war, described as phoney by many lenders last week, is set to become a real battle. Several lenders, including Bristol & West, Portman and Birmingham Midshires, are withdrawing their most competitive discount mortgage deals ahead of a cut to their standard variable rates, according to mortgage brokers.

'Discounts are narrowing in order to reduce lenders' exposure if they get into the price war and cut their standard variable rates,' says Mark Harris of independent financial adviser Savills Private Finance.

Nationwide Building Society started the ball rolling almost two weeks ago when it trimmed its variable rate for existing customers from 7.09 per cent to between 6.49 and 6.99 per cent, depending on the size of the deposit.

The move was swiftly followed by Halifax, Britain's biggest mortgage lender, which cut its SVR from 7.5 per cent to 6.75 per cent.

Lenders are keen to hang on to existing customers and increase market share by bringing their SVRs into line with the more attractive ones offered to new customers. There has been speculation that the moves by Halifax and Nationwide would prompt a step away from special deals in favour of lower standard rates.

It is too early to tell how the market will shake down, but lenders have started to shave the discounts on some of their special deals.

Portman has repriced its stepped discount mortgage. It now starts with a discount of 3 per cent instead of 2.5 per cent. Bristol & West has pulled its discount mortgages as well as all its fixed- and capped-rate deals below a certain level.

Northern Rock opened up its whole product range to existing borrowers - but did not cut its SVR.

Woolwich has also tweaked its range but says this was in response to the Bank of England base rate reduction rather than manoeuvres by Halifax and Nationwide.

The rest of the market is now waiting to see how Abbey National responds before deciding whether to implement rate cuts of their own.

Ray Boulger of mortgage broker Charcol says: 'Abbey is key. It is the second-biggest lender and an old foe of the Halifax, so it will not want to take a back seat. If it cuts its SVR, it puts pressure on the other lenders to do the same. Cheltenham & Gloucester, another top-five lender, does not have the same reputation for aggressive pricing.'

An Abbey spokesperson says: 'We are committed to remaining competitive and reviewing our different options. We will not be forced into a knee-jerk reaction. We want to be sure any change is in the interests of our customers, intermediaries and shareholders.'

C&G says it is waiting for the market to settle before it makes a decision.

Although existing borrowers are set to benefit from the SVR cuts, it is not all good news. If you already have a discounted deal with Nationwide or Halifax, you won't be able to benefit from the new rates at all until the discount period is up.

Interestingly, borrowers do not seem to have swallowed the bait offered by Halifax and Nationwide. Figures from online mortgage broker moneysupermarket.com indicate that although the mortgage war has stimulated interest in mortgages and applications, it has not significantly affected sales of Nationwide or Halifax products. Most applications have been for discounted and fixed deals from smaller mutual lenders.

So if you have a home loan with a lender that slashes its standard variable rate, are you better off staying put or remortgaging to a discounted mortgage with a different provider?

Brokers say it is still worthwhile hunting for a new deal, as long as you are not going to be subject to a redemption penalty and your mortgage is more than £40,000.

'The changes will narrow the difference between rates on new and existing mortgages, but there is still a difference,' says Charcol's Boulger.

David Hollingworth of Bath-based London & Country agrees. He recommends Halifax's own tracker mortgage, which has a rate of 5.35 per cent at present for both purchase and remortgage. It also boasts free legal work and daily interest to boot.

There is no danger of competitively priced deals disappearing, according to Hollingworth. He says: 'Halifax still offer new borrowers an aggressively priced range and the others will have to keep doing likewise just to compete.

'If Halifax had scrapped the special rates for new borrowers, that would have heralded some sort of fundamental change. But it didn't.'

fields.headline: Should I shun cashback warranties?
fields.trailText: Should I shun cashback warranties?
fields.body:
Cashback warranties have caused a flood of complaints to the new Financial Ombudsman Service. It upholds a large proportion of such complaints, securing payouts for disgruntled warranty holders.

Cashback warranties are a type of extended warranty, designed to cover unexpected breakdown of appliances after the normal guarantee period is up. The cashback deals promise a refund of all premiums paid at the end of cover period if no claim has been made. This idea of 'no-claim, no-cost' is pushed heavily by sales people.

Around 10 per cent of complaints to the Financial Ombudsman Service are to do with extended warranties, because policyholders frequently misunderstand them and feel hoodwinked when they do not get their money back. The problem is that the cashback warranties include convoluted procedural requirements which the policyholder is expected to adhere to scrupulously, within strict time limits, before they can make a valid claim.

Typically, if you fail to register with the insurer within a specified period after taking out the policy you will not be entitled to claim the promised refund when it expires. And payments are often withheld from those who forget to claim their entitlement in the month after the cover comes to an end, usually five years later. Many people do not realise they have to follow the rules so closely.

'Our initial view is that such requirements may represent unfair terms,' says David Cresswell of the FOS. 'Especially where little or no effort has been made to draw the customer's attention to these complex requirements.' Sales assistants are not trained to explain the warranties.

Many complaints are settled before they reach the final stages of adjudication, with the provider agreeing to refund premiums, although the policyholder may not have followed the terms and conditions to the last letter.

If you feel short-changed by a cashback deal, your first port of call should be the shop or provider that sold you the policy. The FOS comes into the picture only when you cannot resolve a complaint this way. The FOS can be contacted on 0845 766 0902.

webTitle: Other options beyond money in the bank

fields.headline: Other options beyond money in the bank
fields.trailText: Gilts, investment trusts and with-profits bonds are all alternatives that might suit the more adventurous investor.
fields.body:
Gilts

Gilts are bonds or 'IOUs' issued by the Government when it needs to borrow. Each gilt, sold in denominations of £100, has a coupon that shows the rate of interest earned if held from issue to maturity.

Typical yield 5 per cent gross.

Advantages Can be bought easily and cheaply through the Post Office. You know exactly how much income you will get each year provided you hold the gilt until maturity.

Disadvantages On maturity you will be paid the nominal value of the gilt - £100. As most gilts are selling for more, you will inevitably lose some capital.

Better rates of interest are paid on bank and building society accounts.

Suitable for Investors who are wary of the stock market and want to know exactly what they will get in returns.

Recommendations Treasury 7.25 per cent 2007 (matures in 2007 and has a coupon of 7.25 per cent), which costs about £112 and has a redemption yield of 5.1 per cent. Treasury 7.5 per cent 2006, price £112, redemption yield 5.2 per cent.

Equity income unit trusts

Unit trusts and open-ended investment companies pool investors' money to buy a large number of shares. Unit trusts and Oeics are split into equal units or shares, which move in line with the value of underlying assets. Income funds tend either to invest in shares that pay a good dividend or in a mixture of bonds (for income) and shares (for capital growth).

Typical yield 3 per cent.

Advantages The value of the fund and your investment should increase over time, and the income generated should also rise. This is a much less risky route than buying the shares of a few companies with your own money.

Disadvantages Income is comparatively low. Equity income funds that advertise a much higher yield tend to invest in a more risky portfolio and are unlikely to produce any capital growth. Level of income not guaranteed.

Suitable for People beginning their retirement who can afford to accept a low income at outset but need their income to grow and keep pace with inflation.

Recommendations HSBC Income (yield 2.92 per cent), Newton Higher Income (3.62 per cent), Credit Suisse Income (3.33 per cent), ABN-Amro Equity Income (3.66 per cent).

Investment trusts

Investment trusts also pool the money of lots of investors to buy a wide range of shares. However, investment trusts are structured as companies, with a limited number of shares listed on the stock market, which increases risk. Investment trust shares can sell for less than the value of underlying assets - this is described as at a discount to the net asset value. This can be good for share buyers, who get more assets for their money.

However, investment trust shares designed to produce income are in great demand, so usually sell at a 'premium' to net asset value.

Typical yield: Typically 4 per cent; 10 per cent for average split-capital income shares.

Advantages: The lowest charges of any investment product. Many have no initial charge and a low management charge, about 0.2 per cent.

Disadvantages: Investment trusts can be hard to understand, income is not guaranteed, and share prices can be volatile.

Suitable for: Those who want a growing but slightly higher income than that from equity income unit trusts. Definitely not suitable for nervous investors.

Recommendations: Conventionalo: Invesco Convertible (yield 4 per cent), Friends Ivory & Sime Optimum (6.7 per cent), Perpetual Income & Growth (3.3 per cent). Split income shares: Dresdner RCM Income Growth (6.6 per cent), Jupiter Enhanced Income (8.1 per cent).

With-profits bonds

This is a single premium investment into an insurance company's with-profits fund. Every year the fund allocates an annual bonus. This is guaranteed and once added to your policy, cannot be taken away. Funds invest in equities, bonds and gilts, and property. To protect investors from stock-market volatility, the fund manager holds over some of the returns from good years to boost bonuses in poor years - smoothing. The insurer will also usually add a final or terminal bonus when the bond is cashed in.

Normally investors can make withdrawals of up to 7.5 per cent a year net of basic-rate tax without penalty, and the first 5 per cent can be taken without paying any extra tax - even by higher-rate taxpayers.

Typical yield 5 per cent net (plus a terminal bonus which can be regarded as growth).

Advantages A good way to benefit from equity returns without exposure to the full volatility of the stock market.

Disadvantages Encashment of a bond within the first five years can incur heavy penalties of up to 9 per cent of the amount invested. Encashment during or just after a market crash may result in the insurer applying a 'market value adjustor' or down- valuation to the investment. Non-taxpayers cannot re-claim tax paid.

Suitable for A cautious investor willing to tie up money for at least five years. Particularly attractive for higher-rate taxpayers who expect to be basic-rate taxpayers by the time their bond is fully encashed.

Recommendations Liverpool Victoria, Prudential, Norwich Union.

Distribution bonds

This is a lump-sum investment in an insurance fund managed for income. Your money is used to buy units in the fund, which are split into a capital portion and income earned on it. The income is siphoned off and paid out twice a year. Distribution funds invest in a mix of shares, gilts, property and cash, which provide income as dividends, interest and rent. The value of your investment can fluctuate depending on the asset mix chosen by the fund manager.

Like all insurance bonds, returns are taxed within the fund and basic-rate taxpayers have no further tax to pay on distributions. Charges vary, but most funds will have an initial charge or an estab lishment charge spread over five years of about 5 per cent in total and an annual management charge of 1 per cent.

Typical yield 4.5 per cent net.

Advantages Less risky than a pure equity-based trust, but likely to outperform a with-profits fund in a rising market.

Disadvantages Unlike a with-profits bond, value can fall according to the performance of the underlying assets. Neither the rate of income or return of capital is guaranteed. Withdrawal charges in the first five years.

Suitable for Fairly conservative investors.

Recommendations Sun Life (5.06 per cent net).

Guaranteed income bonds

A GIB is a lump-sum investment that guarantees a fixed rate of return during the life of the bond, plus return on capital provided you leave it for the agreed term. Investors should choose a bond purely on the basis of the income rate offered. Interest is paid net of basic-rate tax.

Typical yield 4.5 per cent to 5.2 per cent net, depending on amount and term.

Advantages Returns are guaranteed. Higher-rate taxpayers are liable to pay extra tax, but the calculation is based on net interest, unlike bank and building society deposit accounts, where it is based on gross interest. This means higher-rate payers incur less tax.

Disadvantages Tax can't be reclaimed by non-taxpayers.

Suitable for Cautious in-vestors needing level income.

Recommendations Three-year bonds offer best value. AIG pays 4.87 per cent net for £10,000 and 5.12 per cent net for £40,000.

* Yields quoted gross of tax unless otherwise stated

 Recommendations from: Baronworth Investment Services, Brooks Macdonald Gayer, Chartwell, Chase de Vere, David Aaron Partnership, Informed Choice, Nelson Money Managers.

Disadvantages Unlike a with-profits bond, value can fall according to the performance of the underlying assets. Neither the rate of income or return of capital is guaranteed. Withdrawal charges in the first five years. Suitable for Fairly conservative investors. Recommendations Sun Life (5.06 per cent net). Guaranteed income bonds A GIB is a lump-sum investment that guarantees a fixed rate of return during the life of the bond, plus return on capital provided you leave it for the agreed term. Investors should choose a bond purely on the basis of the income rate offered. Interest is paid net of basic-rate tax. Typical yield 4.5 per cent to 5.2 per cent net, depending on amount and term. Advantages Returns are guaranteed. Higher-rate taxpayers are liable to pay extra tax, but the calculation is based on net interest, unlike bank and building society deposit accounts, where it is based on gross interest. This means higher-rate payers incur less tax. Disadvantages Tax can't be reclaimed by non-taxpayers. Suitable for Cautious in-vestors needing level income. webTitle: Keep it coming: Corporate bond funds

fields.headline: Quality or junk - your IOU choice
fields.standfirst: Corporate bond funds
fields.trailText: Corporate bond funds.
fields.body:
Corporate bonds are IOUs issued by companies wanting to borrow money from investors.

Each bond promises a certain rate of interest to be paid every year until the bond is redeemed on a predetermined date.

However, just as all companies vary in their performance, financial strength and appeal to investors, so do their bonds.

Bonds issued by financially strong companies - which are unlikely to renege on their promise to pay interest and redeem their debts - are described as investment-grade.

They are more expensive and yield less income than those issued by new, small or financially weak companies, whose bonds may be rated as sub-investment grade or 'junk'.

Investing directly in corporate bonds is difficult for retail investors - the minimum purchase is £100,000. But many fund-management companies run unit trusts which invest in corporate bonds and other similar interest-bearing investments.

The choice of Funds is huge, ranging from those that concentrate on top-quality investment-grade bonds to funds that invest a large proportion of their portfolio in sub-investment grade - or junk - bonds

Typical yield 7.5 per cent.

Advantages Much higher income yield than equity funds. Bonds tend to be more stable in value than equities (although they have had their moments).

Disadvantages Unlikely to produce much in the way of capital growth.

Suitable for Investors who need a high, immediate income.

Recommendations Aberdeen High Yield Bond Fund (8.8 per cent), M&G High Yield Corporate Bond Fund (8 per cent).

fields.headline: A well-engineered retirement
fields.trailText: Investing for income in retirement.
fields.body:
Bristol pensioner David Parslow has been investing for income since he retired 12 years ago. A former manager in the aero-engines repair division of Rolls-Royce, he took early retirement at 54, leaving with a monthly pension of about £490. His wife Joyce retired two years later with a pension of about £180 a month.

He estimated they would need another £200-£300 a month to live comfortably, so invested £50,000 in the Prudential with-profits bond through a 'back-to-back' arrangement. This is where a portion of capital is used to buy an annuity to provide a regular and consistently high level of income for five or 10 years, while the rest is invested in a bond. The bond is left to grow during the five or 10 years, and by the time the annuity has finished paying out, it should have recovered the cost of the annuity. Income can then be drawn down from the bond or you can repeat the process of buying an annuity.

This provided Mr Parslow with the income he required, and the bond is now worth about £58,000.

Since his first bond investment, he has put another £80,000 into the Scottish Widows with-profits bond (which in addition to £4,000 income a year also produced a windfall payment of £20,000 when the insurer demutualised last year), £50,000 with Scottish Equitable (£2,700 income) and £50,000 with CGU (now Norwich Union) which should produce about £2,500 when the first lot of income is paid out.

Mr Parslow does not take out all the income available from his bonds, preferring to leave some growth to add to their value. He also invests through the Bath discount broker Chartwell because it rebates commission on the deal, enhancing the value of his investment.

In addition to his with-profits bonds, he has invested in several Isas and their precursors, Peps, all with the intention of generating income. He chooses corporate-bond funds because these are generally lower-risk than equity income funds. His portfolio includes bond funds from Legal & General, M&G and Norwich Union.

Most income funds offer two types of unit - one that pays out income and another that rolls the income up by buying new units at a very low 'creation' cost. However, Mr Parslow increases the value of his capital overnight by withdrawing all his income and reinvesting it via Chartwell in funds with no initial charge but which do pay commission. This means that not only is all his money invested on his behalf, but he also benefits from a commission rebate from the discount broker.

fields.headline: When safety comes first
fields.standfirst: Bank accounts
fields.trailText: Bank accounts.
fields.body:
Most people regard bank and building society accounts as the safest homes for their money. Building societies are normally taken over or merged if they run into difficulties, so savers' money is protected.

Banks rarely collapse, and even if they do, the deposit protection scheme will ensure you get 90 per cent of your money, up to a maximum of £20,000. To be on the safe side, restrict the amount you place with each bank to this amount.

However, rates of interest and terms on accounts vary so widely you really need to shop around. Be prepared to switch accounts when necessary to get the best deal, and make use of your annual cash Isa allowance to earn tax-free interest - up to £3,000 a year until 5 April, 2006. The best rates of interest tend to be paid on internet, telephone and postal accounts. Notice accounts, which require a certain number of days' warning before you withdraw your money, pay little or nothing extra for the delay at the moment - you are just as likely to find a good rate on a no notice account.

Typical yield Anything from 0.25 per cent to 7 per cent.

Advantages Your money is safe. Huge choice of accounts, so there's bound to be at least one that suits. You can get your money out whenever you want.

Disadvantages Rates of interest on most accounts are low. Even if you open an account paying a high rate, this may later be reduced, so you need to be alert. If you withdraw all the interest as income, the value of your capital will be eroded by inflation over time.

Suitable for Nervous investors and people who cannot afford to lose any of their capital. Everyone should have some money in a savings account that can be accessed immediately in case of emergencies.

Recommendations First Direct's cash mini Isa (0800 242424) pays 6.68 per cent gross.

Nationwide's e-Savings account is a no-notice account paying 6.7 per cent gross (5.36 net). This has to be operated via Nationwide's online current account, but you need not use this as your main current account.

fields.headline: Happy returns on the hop
fields.standfirst: In the final part of our fix your finances series,  Jill Insley looks at how to keep your income up as rates on your savings slide
fields.trailText: In the final part of our fix your finances series, Jill Insley looks at how to keep your income up as rates on your savings slide.
fields.body:
If you rely on investment income, you must feel like you're caught between a rock and a hard place.

The base rate has been below 6 per cent since the end of 1999, and most bank and building society deposit accounts have paid much less. At the same time, share income is low. The average gross yield produced by the FTSE All Share is 2.37 per cent. The cuts on with-profits bond annual bonuses is just salt in the wound.

However, as anyone who has read Cash 's guides to fixing your finances over the past eight weeks will know, it is always possible to make your money work harder. In the last of the series, we look at how a little rejigging of your investments can increase your income.

Most income investors are near or at retirement; your instinct may be to leave everything in a deposit account. That's fine if capital security is the most important thing to you, but make sure you are earning the best rate available. Check the Moneyfacts website for latest rates.

Janine Starks of Bath independent financial adviser Chase de Vere says your approach to producing income should be based on the amount you have to invest, your attitude to risk, and how long you are likely to need an income. If you have few savings, you cannot afford to lose any, and should stick to low-risk investments such as building society deposits and guaranteed income bonds. If the idea of investing on the stock market is going to keep you awake at night, don't do it. And if you are at the beginning of your retirement, you need to take care of your capital and ensure income keeps pace with inflation.

Ideally, you should aim for a mix - deposits and guaranteed income bonds to provide security, corporate bonds and gilts to provide a reasonable level of income, and equities (via unit trusts, Oeics and investment trusts) for capital growth. If that sounds like hard work, consider investments designed to satisfy all three needs through one professionally managed portfolio of assets, such as with-profits bonds and distribution bonds.

Organising a portfolio of investments for income can be tricky; if you don't want to do it yourself, employ an independent financial adviser. Some charge between £50 and £200 an hour but you should be able to negotiate a rebate of commission on any products you buy through them.

Finally, be realistic. Nelson Money Managers' David Hanratty says the level of income you are able to earn at the moment may seem low - about 5 per cent on many bonds and gilts - but then so is inflation - 1.5 per cent excluding mortgage interest rates. 'This gives you a real return [the amount after inflation] of 3.5 per cent,' he says. 'That's a good yield historically - the average real return for gilts since 1918 is 2.3 per cent. And you can earn that with absolutely no risk to your capital if you hold your gilt to maturity. Income investors have got it pretty good at the moment, all things considered.'

How to invest for success

 Register as a non-taxpayer. IFA Promotion estimates that £300m will be lost this year through unnecessary tax paid on savings accounts. If you are eligible to earn untaxed interest, ask your bank or building society for an R85 form.

 Watch the interest rate paid on your savings accounts. Many lenders offer a high headline rate only to drop it a few months later.

 Keep tabs on the performance of equity and bond investments. Make sure you know if one of your fund managers is changing jobs or has gone off the boil, and ask your independent financial adviser whether you should consider switching funds.

 Maximise use of your annual Isa allowance. You can put up to £3,000 in cash and £3,000 in stocks and shares mini Isas, or up to £7,000 in a maxi Isa each tax year. If you can't afford to invest new money, transfer existing unit trust and cash investments that are not protected from tax.

 Buy your investments through a discount broker or negotiate a commission rebate with your independent financial adviser. The commission rebate can usually be added to the value of your investment, increasing the amount you can earn.

 Use your capital gains tax allowance, particularly if you are a higher-rate taxpayer. If you need to receive a fixed amount of money on a certain date - to pay school fees, for example - consider investing in zero-dividend preference shares, which produce a predetermined capital return on a fixed date.

 Don't put all your money in one investment, even if it's paying a great income. Spread your cash and reduce the risk; it might not give the highest possible income at the outset, but it will protect your earnings in the long run.

 If your spouse is a non-tax payer or pays a lower rate than yourself, consider transferring some of your investments into his or her name.

 Try not to withdraw all returns from your investments in the first few years. The more you let them grow, the more income they will produce for you in the future.

 Consult an independent financial adviser. For a free list of IFAs in your area, call IFA Promotion on 0800 0853250 or visit the website at www.unbiased.co.uk .

fields.headline: Rock solid savings, rock bottom rates
fields.standfirst: National Savings
fields.trailText: National Savings.
fields.body:
Narional Savings is run and backed by the Government, so is very safe. However, this Government is reducing the amount of money it borrows, so the interest rates are not particularly attractive. Pensioners Bonds are designed to pay a fixed level of income over a set term to people aged 60 and over. You can withdraw your money early, on 60 days' notice with no interest paid on the amount withdrawn during the notice period. Immediate access incurs 90 days' loss of interest. Interest is liable to tax.

Typical yield Series three has a one-year term and pays 4.9 per cent, series nine has a two-year term and also pays 4.9 per cent, while series 18 runs for five years and pays 4.75 per cent.

Advantages Rock solid - you will not lose your capital.

Disadvantages Interest rates are average. Access to capital involves delays and loss of interest. Your capital will be eroded by inflation over the long term.

Suitable for Very nervous investors and people who cannot afford any loss.

Recommendations Not recommended at current rates.

webTitle: On the watch for nasty surprises

fields.headline: On the watch for nasty surprises
fields.trailText: Make sure you keep an eye on your investments if you want to see returns.
fields.body:
Once you have established an income-producing portfolio, you cannot afford to sit back and enjoy the returns. Fund managers often move, funds go off the boil, and income payments drop, so it's vital to keep an eye on your investments if you want to protect your standard of living .

George Jones, a retired watchmaker, and his wife Paula had to rearrange their investment portfolio after receiving a disturbing letter from the CGU (now known as Norwich Union) about their investment in the Commercial Union Monthly Income Plus fund last September. 'They wrote to us saying our supposedly low-risk investment was rapidly dropping in value.

'If we were receiving £50 a month in income, the letter told us, this would now be reduced by £10, and if we maintained the same level of income we would see the value of our capital erode,' says Mr Jones. 'There was no apology or anything - just a letter telling us to expect a drop of 20 per cent in our returns. I hadn't retired at the time so we weren't relying on the income but it was still a nasty surprise.'

The fund, a £1.1 billion corporate-bond fund, hit the bottom of the performance tables last year. It had a running yield of about 7.8 per cent, and was very popular with income-hungry investors. But half the portfolio was invested in preference shares - fixed-interest investments whose value took a battering from spring 1998 to the beginning of 2000.

Mark Gull, who has managed the fund since March 2000, says the fund's preference shareholdings have now been reduced to just 14 per cent of the portfolio, and the new running yield of 6.3 per cent has given him the flexibility to improve the quality of bonds he buys. The fund has now moved to sixth position out of 81 in its sector over three months.

But the experience unnerved the Joneses who, on the advice of their independent financial adviser, have now switched their money into the RSA Investment's Extra Income Bond fund, which currently pays 8.16 per cent a year.

Mr Jones has now retired and plans to draw income from the couple's corporate bond investments: 'I might do a little clock repairing on the side, but I've been working for 50 years and Paula and I have our own interests to pursue. As long as our investments pay enough to maintain our lifestyle without any nasty surprises, we'll both be quite happy.'
