webTitle: Better to have talked and lost than to merge in haste

fields.headline: Better to have talked and lost than to merge in haste
fields.trailText: It is never pleasant to be left at the altar, particularly when it happens twice in less than a year, so Peter Burt, chief executive of Bank of Scotland, can be forgiven for feeling a little depressed by Abbey National's abrupt termination of merger talks. He should not allow himself to wallow in it, however: hindsight may well suggest he has had a lucky escape.
fields.body:
It is never pleasant to be left at the altar, particularly when it happens twice in less than a year, so Peter Burt, chief executive of Bank of Scotland, can be forgiven for feeling a little depressed by Abbey National's abrupt termination of merger talks. He should not allow himself to wallow in it, however: hindsight may well suggest he has had a lucky escape.

Last week's results from Royal Bank of Scotland showed that NatWest would have been a prize worth having. Cost savings and new revenues are pouring in as the English clearer finally gets the hands-on management it had lacked for decades.

But Abbey is no NatWest. There is no huge pool of costs to which Burt and his team could have taken an axe - indeed, dressing the deal as a friendly merger means big cost savings were all but ruled out. Instead, the merger was predicated on revenue benefits from using Bank of Scotland's small business expertise in Abbey's branch networks and Abbey's mortgage and life insurance products through BoS's networks - although it was never quite clear how that squared with Burt's antipathy to the whole idea of bancassurance.

Even in the best mergers, revenue enhancements are harder to come by than cost savings. And there was a big risk that an Abbey/BoS combination would have been one of the worst of mergers.

We will never know whether the two banks could have agreed crucial details such as who did which management job, where the headquarters would be and even what the new bank would have been called: the deal was abandoned before any of these were disclosed. But all the signals suggested that the issues would have been fudged - there was talk, for example, of Burt being executive chairman to Abbey boss Ian Harley's chief executive.

But Burt has pointed to the contrast between the performance of insurance giants Royal and Sun Alliance and CGNU, following their respective mergers. In the first, there was so much doubt over who was running the show that it soon became clear no one was. The new boss who followed the inevitable management clearout has still not stabilised the business.

At CGNU, by contrast, not one but two mergers have been accomplished relatively smoothly, largely because key issues were settled very early on.

The merger talks between Abbey National and Bank of Scotland were looking dangerously like the former. There is still a chance that talks will be resurrected if Lloyds TSB's proposed bid for Abbey is blocked by the Competition Commission. It would make no sense to do so unless both parties are clear about how it will be run - and their views correspond.

In the meantime, City gossip says BoS is now a bid target - with anyone from Barclays to National Australia Bank mooted as predator. The Barclays rumour looks wide of the mark, and it is hard to see how the ambitions of NAB to expand in England would be furthered by adding its Scottish Clydesdale subsidiary to BoS - even assuming the competition authorities would wear it.

The truth is that BoS can stay independent for as long as Burt wants it to. The strengths of its business - including cost efficiency and revenue generation its rivals would die for - mean he is respected enough in the City not be bounced into a merger or takeover he does not want. The only concern is that, having failed twice, he will be so desperate to make it third time lucky that he will stumble into something even more misguided than an Abbey merger would have been.

The shares have recovered a bit since it was clear that the merger was doomed but still look good value. Buy.

Gene genius looking clever

The City seems to be constantly looking for things to complain about with Nycomed Amersham, which is soon to drop the Nycomed part of its name. Having got the promise of a partial flotation of its gene-mapping business Amersham Pharmacia Biotech, analysts are now worrying about whether the float can be achieved in the jittery US market. They are also fretting about the dull prospects for the imaging business that will be left behind.

Last week's results suggest there is nothing to worry about. The float is going ahead as promised, and recent reports about the complexity of gene interaction make its mapping business even more attractive.

The rest of Amersham managed to increase its profits by a respectable 14 per cent, despite delays in the launch of two products and the deferral of some sales into the current year. The APB flotation, still planned for the spring, should focus attention on the real value of the business. Buy now.

Sitting pretty in the 'sweet spot'

Spirent's shares have fallen 40 per cent from last October's peak on worries that its communications division, assembled through an aggressive acquisition programme over the past five years, would have fallen victim to the travails of the telecoms industry - as two of its US rivals have.

But the results for 2000 suggest that Spirent really has found the 'sweet spot' of the industry, as chief executive Nick Brookes claims.

Spirent's business is largely in network testing and performance monitoring equipment, the stuff telecoms companies have to invest in regardless of what is happening to demand or to the costs of third generation networks. This means profits from communications have more than doubled. This was partly through acquisitions, but organic growth was a more-than-healthy 73 per cent. Brookes says the growth has continued into this year - in sharp contrast with other telecoms companies, which are complaining of a rapid slowdown in demand.

Spirent's problems lie in the other parts of its business. Profits from the systems division fell by two-thirds as airline consolidation and rationalisation continued, and the sensing solutions business was hit by a long list of problems. Fortunately, the growth of the communications division means these are an increasingly small part of the business - indeed, Brookes hints they may even be sold.

The decline in its shares leaves it valued at 25 times prospective earnings for this year. That is not expensive for such a quality business, although they may not move much until the situation of the US technology industry becomes clearer.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Bond's bind
fields.body:
Bond's bind

Cast your mind back six months and the future was looking very good indeed for banking giant HSBC. With the 1998 Asian crisis a distant memory, bad debt levels dropping and the Far East showing signs of a partial recovery, chairman Sir John Bond could have been forgiven for thinking that the good times were rolling again. Factor in HSBC's headline-grabbing deal to target the most affluent customers with Merrill Lynch, and all sorts of new lucrative possibilities were on the cards.

But now with a cooling US economy causing fears of a global slowdown, Bond has been forced to concede that the outlook for his banking empire is 'challenging'.

Indeed it is. Broker Teather & Greenwood points out that 60 per cent of HSBC's profits come from Asia and North America, and is forecasting a 25 per cent increase in bad debt charges this year.

As HSBC, which stands on a price earnings ratio of 19 - the highest of any UK bank - is more exposed than most to emerging markets, it has a longer way to fall than rivals.

T&G is predicting a 7 per cent decrease in earnings per share for HSBC this year and argues that its shares, at 880p, are overvalued. For those who have the appetite for banking stocks with exposure to Asia, the broker recommends Standard Chartered.

Fighting fit

Health club chain Fitness First is limbering up for international expansion on the back of some athletic manoeuvring. The group, which operates 140 clubs across the UK and Germany, believes gym addicts in Asia and Australia are crying out for its services. It has recently secured a £100 million credit line and hopes to open 50 clubs by October.

Recent results beat analysts' expectations and, although its shares have factored in the potential upside, broker Old Mutual Securities believes a fair value would be 1400p. Buy.

Drink to Diageo

Drinks and food giant Diageo is in vogue with analysts at Merrill Lynch. The broker argues that there are few consumer companies around at the moment capable of promising the returns offered by Diageo. Merrill has upgraded its 2002 earnings per share estimate by 1 per cent, based on the belief that the company is capable of delivering on its strategy of growth, product development and efficiency improvements.

Admittedly, a slowing US economy is a concern. But, so far, the City hasn't detected a slowdown in its drink operations, which are set to receive a boost from the launch of Smirnoff Ice in the US.

There have been concerns, too, about the performance of Diageo's Burger King franchise, which was due to be floated this year. However, the City believes this will be shelved until Burger King's new chief executive officer, John Dasburg, who joins next month, has a chance to stabilise its performance.

Merrill argues that on a discounted cash flow basis, assuming earnings per share growth of 14 per cent over five years, Diageo's shares, currently trading at 723p, should be worth almost £10. Buy.

Energy-giving

If there's one company relishing the Californian electricity crisis it's Aggreko, the temporary power generator, which does more than 50 per cent of its business in the US. Analysts are confident the crisis will feed through to the company's bottom line.

Full-year results last week were in line with the top end of analysts' expectations. Pre-tax profits were £60.8 million, compared with £51.3m the previous year. Earnings per share growth for 2000 was a healthy 18 per cent.

At 444p on a current price-earnings ratio of more than 30, Aggreko doesn't look cheap, but UBS believes there is more upside to come and is setting a price of 460p. Buy.

fields.headline: Cartel that conceals its cutting edge
fields.standfirst: De Beers' new chief seems a nice guy, but he's hard as rock. Profile of  Nicky Oppenheimer by Paul Farrelly
fields.trailText: There is a story about De Beers, the diamond cartel now polishing a more friendly image, that needs to be told.
fields.body:
There is a story about De Beers, the diamond cartel now polishing a more friendly image, that needs to be told.

Several years ago, the BBC set out to make a hard-hitting documentary on the colourful and controversial history of the 130-year-old diamond cartel. The Diamond Empire was conceived as an update to Edward Jay Epstein's compelling 1982 book The Diamond Invention.

De Beers' least favourite book told how the Oppenheimers, white South Africa's richest and most powerful family, crafted an intrinsically worthless piece of crystallised carbon into one of the world's most desirable objects. It told, too, how De Beers dealt with the devil to retain its grip on its precious gem monopoly, even doing secret Cold War deals with communist Russia.

In the mid-Nineties, De Beers faced a formidable set of challenges: the collapse of the Soviet Union, whose Siberian mines are key gem suppliers, smuggling from war-torn Africa, an Australian rebellion against the cartel and the opening up of Canada's arctic wastes as a major new, rival producer.

Instead of broadcasting a penetrating insight into how De Beers confronted each threat, BBC producers watched aghast as the secretive diamond giant, which hated coming under any microscope, ruthlessly castrated the programme.

Through its peerless network of contacts the firm obtained a pre-broadcast copy of the series. Under siege from De Beers' lawyers, the BBC bureaucrats cut and cut and cut. Then, to frustrate the chances of even the pale shadow of a programme being aired outside Britain, De Beers threatened legal action anyway.

The then head of De Beers' Central Selling Organisation was Nicky Oppenheimer, son of the 'grand old man' of South African capitalism, Harry Oppenheimer, and grandson of De Beers founder Ernest Oppenheimer. Since then, the empire has changed a lot: the CSO has been rebadged as the more cuddly Diamond Trading Company; Harry died aged 91 last year; and Nicky, the 'diamond dauphin', has finally taken the throne as De Beers chairman. He is now planning to take the diamond firm private in a controversial £12 billion takeover.

Nicky is not quite a chip off the old patrician Oppenheimer block. Nicknamed 'the Cuban' for his raggy grey-black beard, he is engagingly self-deprecating. He has a penchant for odd, loud socks and is quite at home beating the tribal drum with De Beers' black workforce. He got the top job, he says, by choosing his parents carefully. Harry is still spoken of with a mixture of awe and respect. His father's lieutenant, Julian Ogilvie Thompson, chair of De Beers' sister company, Anglo American, is an aloof, old-school, colonial aristocrat. But Nicky, De Beers' friends and foes all agree, is an all-round nice guy, with easy-going charm and no trace of bully.

Anyone who believes, however, that De Beers' friendly new broom has lost the Oppenheimer hard edge should remember the BBC tale. Anyone who thinks, too, that De Beers has softened its control-freak determination to stay on top is sadly misguided. And anyone who believes Nicky is a reluctant heir to his father's mantle misjudges the man.

'Traditionally, he has been quite shy and not forthcoming,' one close associate says. 'When he comes to London and the City, he becomes almost inhibited. But he's a changed person when he gets back under that South African sky. Diamonds are his life. Nicky's family is very important to him and De Beers is part and parcel of the family.'

Born in Johannesburg in 1945, Nicky lives and breathes the modern diamond market. He was three when his father and a New York advertising agency coined the immortal slogan 'a diamond is forever'. By then De Beers, originally founded by Cecil Rhodes in 1888 and taken over by Ernest Oppenheimer in 1929, had been around for well over half a century. But last year, global sales were at a fraction of their £3.8bn peak, and it was Harry who fashioned the demand to soak up De Beers' growing, strictly monopolised supply.

Educated at a private English boarding school, then Harrow and Christ Church college, Oxford, Nicky spent much of the years from eight to 21 away from his beloved South Africa. He joined Anglo in 1968, learning the mining trade in the firm's diamond, gold and uranium divisions. In 1975, he moved over to De Beers, starting with a short stint at the cartel's ultra-secure London headquarters - home to its £2bn diamond stockpile - in Charterhouse Street, opposite the Smithfield meat market. When he returned to London in 1984 it was as De Beers' deputy chairman, second in rank to his austere English uncle, Sir Philip Oppenheimer.

Undoubtedly it was the sharp difference in personalities that first prompted talk that Nicky was not the man for the throne. He was more remarked on for his love of cricket and helicopters than for his business acumen. An avid sportsman, he runs his own cricket team in South Africa - his 'grand folly', he calls it. He regularly flies his own helicopter from the roof of Charterhouse Street to Antwerp, the hub of Europe's diamond trade. The pilot's licence is one of modest Nicky's few proud boasts: he is half colour blind and failed the pilot's test when he first took it in his twenties.

De Beers and Anglo are undoubtedly more collegiate now than in Harry's day. 'Gary Ralfe [De Beers' managing director] is the man in the wheelhouse, but Nicky is very much the captain on the bridge,' one insider said.

Also, since the end of apartheid, Anglo has, under Ogilvie Thompson, become bigger, more international and - following pressure from institutional shareholders - less of a family firm. It has switched its headquarters to London, and snapped up Minorco and Tarmac.

Following the current De Beers deal Nicky will step down as Anglo's deputy chairman, raising the prospect that he will be the first Oppenheimer not eventually to chair Anglo as well as De Beers.

'Commercial and financial reality are undoubtedly driving the changes,' one De Beers observer said. 'But don't underestimate Nicky's influence. He's very much up there in the driving seat, and smart enough not to swim against the tide.'

The De Beers' takeover, though, is pure Oppenheimer. Afterwards, Anglo and Central Holdings, the family firm that manages the Oppenheimer billions, will each own 45 per cent, and Botswana's state diamond company the rest. Management and control, however, rest with the family. Anglo, therefore, is effectively helping the Oppenheimers secure control of their diamond inheritance, while the family barely puts its hand in its pocket.

No wonder, then, that several institutions are hopping mad. Nicky may yet need to sweeten the price.

'Nicky bears a dynasty on his shoulders,' the De Beers watcher said. 'At Anglo and De Beers, the Oppenheimers have always had cross-shareholdings and control. The trouble is that for Anglo to grow, the cross-holdings must go and the family stake must fall. Diamonds and De Beers are Nicky's priority and this gives him control. But, in this day and age, why should Anglo be giving the Oppenheimer family such a generous helping hand?'

fields.headline: Vodafone eyes BT's Cegetel stake
fields.trailText: Mobile phone giant Vodafone is eyeing BT's 26 per cent stake in French telecommunications firm Cegetel. Analysts valued the holding at £7 billion earlier this year, but it could now be worth much less after the stock market's slump and concerns over telecoms firms' rising debts.
fields.body:
Mobile phone giant Vodafone is eyeing BT's 26 per cent stake in French telecommunications firm Cegetel. Analysts valued the holding at £7 billion earlier this year, but it could now be worth much less after the stock market's slump and concerns over telecoms firms' rising debts.

The former nationalised industry is being pushed to make disposals to cut its own £30bn debt mountain and it wants to sell its minority stakes in a number of Asian companies.

A source familiar with Vodafone's thinking said Cegetel was one of the three 'areas of mutual interest' that the company shared with BT. The others are BT's stakes in Spanish mobile phone company Airtel and Japan Telecom, which Vodafone bought into last week.

The source said the mobile phone firm was not involved in talks with BT about any of the three stakes, but things would change 'very quickly', providing the price was right.

BT is under fire from institutional investors concerned at what they perceive as the company's lack of strategy. Larger shareholders have called for the resignations of the chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield and chairman, Sir Iain Vallance. Privately, several have said they would support a rights issue to offset BT's debt crisis only if the two men resigned.

BT has publicly ruled out the prospect of an imminent rights issue, so it must now find alternative ways of paring down its debt. The company has until April to submit plans to credit rating agencies, or risk having its debt rating downgraded.

The company plans to float 25 per cent of BT Wireless, its mobile phone division, later this year, but given the disappointing listing of Orange last month, investors may have lost their appetite for telecom stocks.

BT's woes over the flotation of its subsidiary have been compounded by the fact that Deutsche Telekom and KPN Telecom of the Netherlands also plan to list their mobile phone divisions this year.

A question mark also hangs over the flotation of Yell, BT's Yellow Pages arm. BT had originally planned to list 25 per cent of it, but a long- running review by the Office of Fair Trading has now prompted the company to explore other options. One possibility being considered by BT's new finance director, Philip Hampton, could be a full demerger of Yell.

The source said the mobile phone firm was not involved in talks with BT about any of the three stakes, but things would change 'very quickly', providing the price was right. BT is under fire from institutional investors concerned at what they perceive as the company's lack of strategy. Larger shareholders have called for the resignations of the chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield and chairman, Sir Iain Vallance. Privately, several have said they would support a rights issue to offset BT's debt crisis only if the two men resigned. BT has publicly ruled out the prospect of an imminent rights issue, so it must now find alternative ways of paring down its debt. The company has until April to submit plans to credit rating agencies, or risk having its debt rating downgraded. The company plans to float 25 per cent of BT Wireless, its mobile phone division, later this year, but given the disappointing listing of Orange last month, investors may have lost their appetite for telecom stocks. BT's woes over the flotation of its subsidiary have been compounded by the fact that Deutsche Telekom and KPN Telecom of the Netherlands also plan to list their mobile phone divisions this year. A question mark also hangs over the flotation of Yell, BT's Yellow Pages arm. BT had originally planned to list 25 per cent of it, but a long- running review by the Office of Fair Trading has now prompted the company to explore other options. One possibility being considered by BT's new finance director, Philip Hampton, could be a full demerger of Yell.

fields.headline: 'Bogus invoices' found at glass maker
fields.trailText: Police are set to be called in to the collapsed Ravenhead glassware company following the discovery of financial irregularities.
fields.body:
Police are set to be called in to the collapsed Ravenhead glassware company following the discovery of financial irregularities.

The administrators, Begbies Traynor, believe the company raised £500,000 through allegedly fictitious invoices to ease a cashflow crisis before its crash last December.

Ravenhead, owned by Belgian tableware group Durobor, is Britain's biggest maker of beer mugs and wine glasses. The St Helens-based firm made 130 workers redundant after the collapse; the remaining 200 jobs are set to go by within a month unless a buyer is found.

Begbies Traynor has discovered two invoices for allegedly fictitious orders, which were presented to finance house NMB-Heller for 'factoring', a form of advance payment of customers' bills. The finance firm has since recovered the money and suffered no loss.

'The administrators have a duty to report possible criminal offences to the proper authorities, which they will do. The police will have to be informed,' a spokesman for the administrator said.

This weekend Ravenhead's former general manager and company secretary, Don Cooper, who has since left the firm, declined to comment.

Ravenhead has an eventful history. Established in 1892, it was owned by United Glass, part of Distillers, until 1987. Then it went through two buyouts, until it was bought by Durobor in 1993.

Durobor is ultimately owned by the Belgian state-run fund Société Regionale d'Investissement de Wallonie. There is no suggestion that the Belgians were aware of the alleged irregularities.

Ravenhead lost £1 million on sales worth £20m last year and had 30 million glasses in stock when it collapsed. The crash was caused by the strong pound, which left the company nursing heavy losses on export contracts priced in euros.

Unsecured creditors including employees, owed nearly £10m, are unlikely to receive anything. To compound staff misery, the administrators have also found a £5m shortfall in the £30m pension fund, though no wrongdoing is suspected.

Ravenhead's collapse leaves just one British supplier of beer and wine glasses to pubs and brewers - Chesterfield-based Deema Glass, itself bought out of receivership last year.

webTitle: Golf not coal is the future for RJB property portfolio

fields.headline: Golf not coal is the future for RJB property portfolio
fields.trailText: RJB Mining, the rump of the privatised British coal industry, will this week unveil its strategy to become a major national property player. The move could see the company operating golf courses and industrial estates along with deep and opencast mines.
fields.body:
RJB Mining, the rump of the privatised British coal industry, will this week unveil its strategy to become a major national property player. The move could see the company operating golf courses and industrial estates along with deep and opencast mines.

The company, which last week said goodbye to its chief executive Richard Budge, the abrasive entrepreneur who bought British Coal assets from the Government in 1994 and used his initials to name the company, will publish the results of a review of its 55,000-acre property portfolio when it reports its annual results next week.

RJB's property covers areas where deep and opencast mining take place as well as disused sites and plots bought in the unrealised hope of gaining planning permission for mining.

Analysts are hoping the review of the portfolio, carried out by surveyors Fuller Peiser, will indicate unlocked value. One RJB watcher said property assets alone could be worth 80p a share - or £122 million undeveloped - more than the current value of the whole operation. RJB shares closed on Friday at 80p. Sources close to the company indicated the figure may be close to that, but slightly lower.

Meanwhile, it has emerged that Budge received more than £700,000 as a payoff, comprising a year-and-a-half of his £320,558 salary, a 25 per cent bonus and pension entitlements. Previous estimates had been considerably lower. Management, led by chairman John Robinson, hopes he will not sell down his stake in the company, although he has made millions from doing so in the past.

RJB has also written to employees assuring them that all current mining operations will be kept open for two years and that there will be no job losses.

Executives believe emphasising the value of the property assets is a sensible way forward for mining businesses, which often collect large portfolios. They see little prospect of growth in the UK. There are overseas precedents - Drummond in the US and Bisichi of Nigeria both exploit property portfolios. Options for the RJB land, most of which is brownfield, include sale - although the Government would claw back part of any gains - development as either as industrial or leisure parks, or joint ventures, potentially with housebuilders.

Much of the land is in South Yorkshire, Derbyshire and Nottinghamshire, with potential development close to the M1 motorway.

RJB is expected to announce pre tax profits for last year of £10m, and to raise its final dividend by 4p to 11p.

fields.headline: Overreaction? No chance
fields.trailText: The Bank of England has come to the rescue of people agonising about how to address the Governor now that he has been knighted. The answer can now be exclusively revealed. When the Governor makes speeches, or appears before the House of Commons Treasury Committee, he is Sir Edward George. But when he chairs meetings of the Monetary Policy Committee and signs the minutes, he is plain Eddie George.
fields.body:
The Bank of England has come to the rescue of people agonising about how to address the Governor now that he has been knighted. The answer can now be exclusively revealed. When the Governor makes speeches, or appears before the House of Commons Treasury Committee, he is Sir Edward George. But when he chairs meetings of the Monetary Policy Committee and signs the minutes, he is plain Eddie George.

In his capacity as Eddie George, the Governor led the 9-0 vote in favour of a quarter-point cut in interest rates last month; or, rather, he did not lead it, because, unlike his counterpart Alan Greenspan at the US Federal Reserve, the Governor votes last on these occasions. But when it comes to gauging the sense of such meetings, George has no peer. The minutes state: 'The Governor invited members to vote on the proposition that the Bank's repo rate - that's central bank-speak for interest rate - should be reduced by 25 basis points to 5.75 per cent. The committee voted unanimously in favour of the proposition.'

Last Tuesday, in his capacity as Sir Edward George, the Governor appeared with five fellow MPC members before the Treasury Committee. It was a vintage performance. One of the parliamentarians quizzing them said afterwards: 'We didn't get very far. The trouble is their record is so good.'

Yet central bankers are cautious people, and academics who join central banks usually acquire the habit. When criticised because the inflation rate had turned out to be below target for 22 months running, Mervyn King, the joint deputy governor, replied: 'It was at or above for 21 months before.'

King said the average inflation rate since the inception of the MPC had been 2.4 per cent - not bad, you may think, when the target is 2.5 per cent. For those who wish to attack the MPC for 'undershooting', one of its members pointed out that, given the time lags in the workings of monetary policy, the new body may not have had much impact on the outturn in the first two years anyway.

And Eddie - sorry, Sir Edward - said: 'Anyone who thinks that you can persistently keep inflation at 2.5 per cent does not understand the problem.' He added later that being close to the target might generate expectations that this would always be the case, 'and it won't'.

This is interesting, because the caution and frankness of MPC members in this regard are slightly in conflict with another point members occasionally make: that the MPC will have proved a success if people believe it will take action to ensure that, when inflation strays, it will come back towards target.

The following day, at a well attended meeting in the City, Tim Congdon of Lombard Street Research and Roger Bootle of Capital Economics debated the question: 'Is inflation still dead?' Congdon is one of the few people left who can be expected to answer in the affirmative to the question, 'Are you now or have you ever been a member of the Monetarist Party?' He presented worrying monetary statistics for the US, the UK and the Eurozone, and ended up by warning fund managers that 'inflation of 2.5 to 5 per cent is the medium-term reality for the investment and business decisions in the next few years'.

Bootle won the vote with an impressive reminder of how the monetarists' equations collapsed all over their computers during the Eighties, and listed many factors - including intense global competition, the collapse of union power, and the thrust of economic policy - which are now keeping inflation low.

For good measure, across the Atlantic later that day, Fed chairman Alan Greenspan said monetary targets were 'of no use whatsoever' to the Fed in setting monetary policy.

Of course it does not take long for the value of money to be reduced, even with an inflation rate of 2.5 per cent a year. But this brings back memories of how one was always taught that, after the deflation of the Thirties, a little inflation was a good thing: it encouraged growth and made it easier for 'relative ' prices to change: profits and wages in expanding industries could expand fast, while those in declining businesses would gradually lose out, where it was considered difficult to introduce wage cuts.

Economic consultant Malcolm Crawford reminded the City audience of past instances where, under zero inflation and falling prices, corporations suffered losses in their inventories and went bankrupt.

Although the Treasury is proud of the 'symmetry' of the current inflation target - the MPC is obliged to boost economic growth if inflation looks like being below 2.5 per cent for a sustained period - Sir Samuel Brittan describes it as an 'inflation target version of monetarism'. Achieving full employment is not the central aim of the policy, but an incidental one.

This differs from the US sit uation, where the Fed has to aim for maximum employment and price stability.

But has the Fed failed to prevent the imbalances created by the recent boom from getting out of hand? The chief economist of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Ignazio Visco, seems to side with Congdon in worrying that the Fed risks 'overreacting to the slowing of economic growth' and squandering its gains against inflation.

American inflation may have been disguised to some extent by the strong dollar, cheap imports and the vast and unsustainable balance-of-payments deficit. But I am not sure that a couple of half percentage point reductions in US interest rates are an overreaction. They may be more like a finger in the dyke in the face of the adjustment that seems to be following the recent boom.

Meanwhile, let us never forget that it was not New Labour but the Conservatives, under Norman Lamont, who introduced inflation targets to the UK. Last week, after talking about the euro following the Bootle/Congdon debate, the former Chancellor was to be seen opening a briefcase and selling copies of the full story for cash.

webTitle: Treasury on the spot over tax breaks for movie makers

fields.headline: Treasury on the spot over tax breaks for movie makers
fields.trailText: The future of Britain as a film production centre could be threatened if the Treasury moves to reform valuable tax breaks, due to expire in July next year, writes Nick Mathiason.
fields.body:
The future of Britain as a film production centre could be threatened if the Treasury moves to reform valuable tax breaks, due to expire in July next year, writes Nick Mathiason.

Tax incentives encouraged a record £750 million worth of films to be produced in Britain last year, including Hollywood blockbusters such as 102 Dalmatians. But the Treasury believes the system has been widely abused and is expected to deliver its conclusions in the Budget. In a modern reworking of Oscar-winning Mel Brooks' comedy The Producers, the Treasury believes unscrupulous film producers have used the breaks to make money on films destined to flop.

Michael Grade, chairman of Pinewood Studios, said: 'Where you get new legislation offering tax relief, there are always fertile minds working out a purpose other than that for which it was originally designed. It would be a blow to the British film industry if the arrangement ended.'

Tax write-offs of 100 per cent for films costing up to £15 million and 33 per cent for those costing more were introduced in 1997. They encouraged rich individuals to form consortiums to back a portfolio of films.

fields.headline: Everyone's talking about...
fields.standfirst: Nathaniel Parker, the BBC's dazzlingly posh new cop
fields.trailText: With his coal black hair and beautiful, roughly hewn features, Nathaniel Parker is most familiar as a costume drama dazzler. Fans of historical dramas will have seen him as the gambler Rawdon Crawley in Vanity Fair and Gabriel Oak in Far From The Madding Crowd .
fields.body:
With his coal black hair and beautiful, roughly hewn features, Nathaniel Parker is most familiar as a costume drama dazzler. Fans of historical dramas will have seen him as the gambler Rawdon Crawley in Vanity Fair and Gabriel Oak in Far From The Madding Crowd .

Next week he plays a modern hero as Elizabeth George's Inspector Lynley in a new BBC1 two-parter. The 38-year-old son of former British Rail chairman Sir Peter Parker and his GP wife Jill, Parker is convincing as the posh cop who provokes everyone's prejudices. 'I've had the same sort of thing, even though I'm not as posh as Lynley is. I can get that upper-class feeling across, and some of the baggage that goes with it. I can also do a convincing rugby tackle and knock a few heads together if called upon,' he says.

Parker went to Leighton Park public school outside Reading. He then took a three-year drama course at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art. Six months after leaving he won a two-year stint with the RSC playing six juvenile leads, and work has been steady since.

He is married to actress Anna Patrick and they have two daughters aged four and two. The couple were with other partners when they met and some pursuing was involved: 'Feeling that your destiny is on the other side of the room in someone else's arms is a very frustrating position to be in.'

His co-star is the glamorous Scottish actress Sharon Small who is cast against type. She wears baggy clothes and no make-up, and there will be no romance between the pair.

The Inspector Lynley Mysteries - A Great Deliverance is on 12 and 13 March, BBC1

Five things you need to know about Nathaniel Parker

1. He makes a five-figure sum each year from betting.

2. His TV debut was in a drama about World War II pilots.

3. He thinks women are lucky to have babies.

4. He wants to own a stud farm.

5. He once spent £600 a week ringing his wife from Broadway.

webTitle: Pack up your truffles in your old kitbag

fields.headline: Pack up your truffles in your old kitbag
fields.trailText:
Chocolat (121 mins, 12) Directed by Lasse Hallström; starring Juliette Binoche, Lena Olin, Johnny Depp, Judi Dench
The Gift (112 mins, 15) Directed by Sam Raimi; starring Cate Blanchett, Keanu Reeves, Hilary Swank, Giovanni Ribisi
The Tao of Steve (87 mins, 15) Directed by Jenniphr Goodman; staring Donal Logue and Greer Goodman
fields.body:
Chocolat (121 mins, 12) Directed by Lasse Hallström; starring Juliette Binoche, Lena Olin, Johnny Depp, Judi Dench
The Gift (112 mins, 15) Directed by Sam Raimi; starring Cate Blanchett, Keanu Reeves, Hilary Swank, Giovanni Ribisi
The Tao of Steve (87 mins, 15) Directed by Jenniphr Goodman; staring Donal Logue and Greer Goodman

Sweets were rationed when I was eight years old and I celebrated the day rationing ended 11 years later in 1953 by buying several pounds of chocolates and gorging until I got sick in my room in Aldershot. Fellow subalterns assumed my hangover was booze-induced and I was too ashamed to disabuse them. Just as a reformed alcoholic would have revisited his guilty past seeing The Lost Weekend, I was reminded of this experience by Chocolat, a film version of Joanne Harris's winsome novel about a catalytic chocolatière in a small town somewhere between Bordeaux and Toulouse in the late Fifties.

This is a fable, a fairy tale set 15 years after World War II in a community seemingly untouched by the return of De Gaulle, the birth pangs of the Fifth Republic and the Algerian war. Television is unknown and the only touch of popular culture comes from the newly arrived young curé who sings Presley's 'Hound Dog' as he weeds the churchyard. It's also a very Anglo-Saxon affair - better than 'Allo 'Allo or Toujours Provence , more like Pagnol à l'anglais e - performed by a cast of Brits, Americans and Swedes, with just the translucently beautiful Juliette Binoche to provide an authentic Gallic touch. All the dialogue, apart from an occasional bonne journée, is in English, and when the narrator speaks of the town being devoted to tranquillité, this is immediately translated as 'tranquillity' for those at the back of the class.

Binoche plays Vianne Rocher, the magical chocolatière who arrives with her little daughter at the beginning of Lent, and rents a shop to sell magical confectionery based on ancient Mayan recipes. By Easter Sunday she's won over the hearts, minds and stomachs of this repressed, pious Catholic community. Her liberating pagan spirit works through the town's ill-treated women. She separates the lovely Lena Olin from an abusive husband (Peter Stormare), provides a sex-starved wife with chocolate aphrodisiacs for her husband, revives her lusty old crone of a landlady (Judi Dench), and so on. Her chief opponent is the xenophobic Comte de Reynaud (Alfred Molina) who is the local seigneur, the mayor and co-author of the priest's sermons. Incapable of confronting the choc of the new, the count declares 'a holy war' on chocolate' and subsequently stirs up a campaign against a party of riverborne travellers led by Johnny Depp (in his traditional outsider role and specifically his gypsy from last year's The Man Who Cried).

'It isn't easy being different,' remarks Binoche at one point, but in fact everything comes easy in this movie - love, reconciliation, redemption, re-creation and even death. It's also an easy film to enjoy, like most of Hallström's neatly turned, bittersweet movies about happy adjustments within disturbed families. But it's not one to think about too much or for long, and much inferior to Babette's Feast, the Danish film. The town, by the way, doesn't have a gendarme or a doctor but, Mon Dieu, it's going to need a dentist.

webTitle: UK fails to close gap on productivity

fields.headline: UK fails to close gap on productivity
fields.trailText: The productivity gap between Britain and the US has widened dramatically since New Labour came to power, despite numerous Government efforts to close it.
fields.body:
The productivity gap between Britain and the US has widened dramatically since New Labour came to power, despite numerous Government efforts to close it.

New data shows that measures taken by Gordon Brown have so far had no significant impact on Britain's productivity performance, a key determinant of increased living standards and prosperity. Addressing the country's woeful productivity levels has been at the heart of all the Chancellor's four Budgets.

Mary O'Mahony, a leading expert at the National Institute for Economic and Social Research, who has updated the figures she used for the Treasury's policy paper on productivity, said: 'The gap has widened by nearly a third.'

The news comes as Brown makes final preparations for Wednesday's Budget, which will contain further measures to bridge the gap, such as more tax credits. O'Mahony says one average working hour in the US economy in 1999 - the latest year for which figures are available - was nearly 38 per cent more productive than one in the UK. In 1996, just before Labour came to power, the gap was around 28 per cent.

The gap with Europe has not improved either, sticking at around 30 per cent. The figures exclude the public, health and education sectors.

Although the figures will disappoint Brown, the Treasury believes his measures will start to feed through to the system. Officials liken the UK's situation to that of the US in the mid-Nineties, when performance picked up after economic stability and high employment worked their way through the system.

News of the widening gap comes as the main employers' and employees' organisations join forces to find solutions to the problem. Urged on by the Chancellor, the CBI and the TUC will today issue an unprecedented joint call for such measures as extending tax credits for research and development, improvements to regional development funding, reforms to the climate change levy, and public funding for training all adults to GCSE level.

Digby Jones, CBI director-general, said: 'It is time to stop talking about the productivity gap and start doing something about it.'

TUC General Secretary John Monks added: 'By working in partnership with the CBI and others, we have a golden opportunity to secure a long-lasting improvement in our productivity record.'

 City economists are split on the outcome of this week's Bank of England Monetary Policy Committee meeting. Many are waiting to see what the Chancellor will do in the budget.

Those questioned for a Reuters poll gave a 65 per cent chance of 'no change' in interest rates on Thursday, but a majority believed there would be a cut by May.

webTitle: Frankly, the bull's well out of it

fields.headline: Frankly, the bull's well out of it
fields.standfirst: Jann Parry on Joaquin Cortés' flamenco fusion show
fields.trailText: Jann Parry on Joaquin Cortés' flamenco fusion show
fields.body:
Pura Pasion Peacock Theatre, London WC2, to 17 March

Richard Alston Dance Theatre Marlowe Theatre, Canterbury, on tour to 4 April

Flamenco stars Joaquin Cortés and his uncle Cristobal Reyes are hoping to replicate the Riverdance recipe. They are trying out a flamenco fusion show, Pura Pasion, in London before setting up 'multiple companies to serve the five continents'.

Their mission is to spread updated flamenco to non-specialist audiences around the world. They have started modestly in the Peacock, with a bare stage and colour-saturated lighting.

The fusion concept is an incoherent one. Flamenco is already a crossover mixture; its harsh, hoarse singing and guitar music are influenced by Arabic and Indian traditions, as are the sinuous arms and stamping feet of its dancers. Three choreographers - Cortés, Reyes and Dagmara Brown - have added ballet, African and contemporary dance to the melting pot. The composers - Jesus Bola and Diego Carrasco - have created a Spanish-tinged world music score, hugely amplified.

Onstage drumming drowns the sound of the footwork, useful for less expert dancers but a grave miscalculation for Cristobal Reyes. He is the saviour of the show, reserving himself for the penultimate number (Cortés does not perform in it, apart from a brief appearance at press-night curtain calls).

Reyes is a consummate dancer who does not stray far from pure flamenco in his solo. He is followed, however, by an 'African' finale of crass vulgarity, marginally worse, even, than an earlier 'Hindu' number for a woman in a sari and a vaguely Arabian corps de ballet with undulating midriffs.

In between comes an erotic bullfight between a priapic bull and a pert-bottomed girl matador. He kills her but the male gypsy spectators can't bring themselves to butcher him. The far more macho female corps dance a farruca, wearing identical scowls and trouser- suits. Best of the leading women is Rafaela Carrasco, glowering in a perpetual rage at being involved in this farrago. A major mistake is the series of solo spots for Lola Greco, an ageing Isadora Duncan tearing the Spanish soul to shreds in a white shift, hair loose, eyes wild. Not so much contemporary flamenco as old-fashioned tosh.

The title of Richard Alston's new work for his touring company, Fever, promises fiery passion. He was inspired by a modern recording of Monteverdi madrigals that accentuates the music's voluptuousness. In the programme, he reproduces figures from Michelangelo's Sistine Chapel ceiling, writhing and tumbling over each other, moves that materialise on stage. The dance is a low-level fever, however, only flaring fitfully into pow erful feeling. Alston is stronger on troubled relationships than ecstatic ones. He uses unequal numbers of dancers in his work so that someone is usually left without a partner. Indeed, Fever reads like a prequel to the 1999 piece that follows it, A Sudden Exit , in which the soloist, Martin Lawrance, is abandoned by his friends - or chooses to reject them. In Fever , the outsider figure is David McCormick. Even when he finds a mate, their post-coital duet ends in separation as they walk away in opposite directions.

A vein of melancholy runs through both works. The movement is luscious, continuous, responding to the tug of the music. Nobody goes to extremes; no breast-beating or foot-stamping, no violent leaps or vertiginous lifts.

At the close of Fever, all passion spent, intertwined couples lie coiled together, solicitous rather than tortured. They haven't attained the heights of love and each is ultimately alone.

webTitle: If you can hum it, I'll shoot it

fields.headline: If you can hum it, I'll shoot it
fields.standfirst: The Barbican hosts a unique collaboration between composers and film directors
fields.trailText: The Barbican hosts a unique collaboration between composers and film directors
fields.body:
Only Connect: Sound On Film Live Barbican, London EC2

'We have,' declared John Tavener from the Barbican stage, 'to pray our way into a new artistic form.' Britain's most celebrated living composer was introducing a performance of his latest creation, a rich, meditative score for a short film by Werner Herzog, but he could as easily have been describing an evening when music and cinema resumed their long partnership in fresh guise.

On offer were a quartet of 15-minute films, each a collaboration between a composer and a director, with two of the scores performed live. Prefaced by onstage interviews with the creators, the event was a fanfare for the Barbican's Only Connect season which includes Asian Dub Foundation sonically remixing the gritty French flick La Haine, and the avant-jazz of Ornette Coleman played against a screening of The Naked Lunch .

The results of artistic experiment are always as likely to end in catastrophe as miracle, and last Thursday's exercise in cultural cabbalism veered between the empty, the overblown, the terrifying and the near miraculous. Director Hal Hartley's The New Math(s) was the most disappointing. What was signified by its images of a modern-day Eve munching an apple and a quarrelling pair of mathematicians is anyone's guess, though the music of Louis Andriessen, performed by the female quartet Electra, was savoury enough.

The partnership of trip cinema and trip hop represented by Nicolas Roeg and Portishead's Adrian Utley promised and delivered more with The Sound. Never lacking ambition, Roeg used his quarter-hour to encapsulate the entire process of human conception, birth, life and death - as played out by Everywoman Claudia Schiffer. As galaxies and planets bled into shots of Schiffer tumbling through water and space, it seemed we were watching The Supermodel Who Fell to Earth, while the black obelisk that recurred throughout was clearly homage to Kubrick's 2001. Then we were back to the silent era with Schiffer draped on a chaise longue while Mary Pickford leered over her shoulder. Utley, meanwhile, provided a shifting and evocative collage of sound and speech.

The contrast between Roeg's colour-drenched film and the crepuscular black and white of the Quay Brothers' In Absentia could not have been greater. But then the identical twin animator-directors were working to a troubling score by Karlheinz Stockhausen, one evoking an inmate of a 1920s German asylum writing endless love letters to her husband. Stockhausen's thunderous, screeching dissonance was well matched to images that seemed plucked from both dementia and the surrealist dreams of the 1930s. 'We couldn't skate over the music, we had to submit to it,' said the Brothers. We, too, had to submit to a pummelling, unsettling experience.

While the garrulous Werner Herzog assured us that he and John Tavener represented 'an instant accord of hearts', their respective takes on the theme of Pilgrimage seemed divergent. Herzog's images of self-tormenting Mexicans shuffling to a shrine on their knees were voyeuristic, and at odds with the calm compassion of Tavener's orchestral score. This featured the sopranos of the Westminster Cathedral Choir and a performance of extraordinary power from Iranian singer Parvin Cox which recycled just two words; one Greek, one Sanskrit (amusingly, the imposing Tavener couldn't recall either). What the bookend shots of Christmas Island's shoreline had to do with pilgrimage (Herzog admitted they were offcuts from another project) remained opaque. Though not all the connections clicked into place on this odd, alchemical night, the sense of adventure remained palpable to the last.

Sound On Film is screened on Thursday on BBC2 at 11.20pm. Only Connect runs to 9 April

webTitle: Australia looks back in allegory at its inglorious past

fields.headline: Australia looks back in allegory at its inglorious past
fields.standfirst: Deyan Sudjic on Australia's new National Museum, "an architecture of intelligence and anger, of imagination and obsession"
fields.trailText: Deyan Sudjic on Australia's new National Museum, "an architecture of intelligence and anger, of imagination and obsession"
fields.body:
National Museum of Australia Canberra

Australia marks a century of nationhood next Sunday when its Prime Minister, John Howard, opens the new National Museum in Canberra. While you can find Donald Bradman's cricket bat and the van that ferried Australia's first mobile television film unit around the outback, the museum is anything but a mindless celebration of the lucky country.

It does not shrink from addressing the history of its treatment of the Aboriginals. There is graphic material on the massacres carried out by whites well into the nineteenth century. You can see the pistols and metal clubs that colonists used to murder women and children when Tasmania's first Australians were exterminated.

But nothing on display is more controversial than the architecture itself. The architects, Melbourne-based Ashton Raggatt McDougall, have deliberately chosen to house those sections devoted to the Aborigines in a replica of Daniel Libeskind's celebrated museum of Jewish history in Berlin. The scale is slightly reduced and the materials are different. Walls are made from black concrete, puckered to look like rubber, rather than the zinc sheet Libeskind used. But the plan is an exact copy of the lightning-flash zigzag that Libeskind created by breaking a five-pointed star of David, except that Howard Raggatt prefers to call it a quotation rather than a copy. Libeskind is angry.

'It's shocking, banal and plagiarism,' he told Sydney journalist Anne Suskind. But for Raggatt, it is a legitimate strategy, put to work to make a comparison between the plight of the Aboriginals and the horror of the Holocaust. It is a comparison that has made Ashton Raggatt and McDougall almost as unpopular with some of the more conservative members of the Australian government as they are with Libeskind. After all, John Howard is the Prime Minister who has refused to apologise on behalf of white Australia to the Aboriginals for their maltreatment.

But determined to avoid a public row that would overshadow the opening of the museum, the government is standing back. 'Its just an argument among architects,' says an official spokesman. But privately, Ministers are unhappy about the association, especially since it was never made explicit in the submission that Ashton Raggatt and McDougall made to the architectural competition which they won to secure the project.

The £50 million museum certainly manages to press a lot of buttons in a way that suggests a rare ability to make architecture matter. It's not how the building looks that counts for once, but what it is saying. With a remarkable site in the heart of Canberra, overlooking Lake Burley Griffin, and aligned directly on the giant flag pole that crowns Parliament House, the museum is richly inventive and genuinely serious. It forms a long ribbon, strung out along the waterfront and turning back on itself in a wide arc to create at its heart a sheltered garden of Australian dreams.

It's filled with a fragmented map of Australia pockmarked with the names of massacre sites and battlegrounds. The building is a series of fragments, seamlessly and surreally joined one with another with the smoothness of a computer simulacrum. It's not just Libeskind's Jewish museum that provides the source material. There are so many quotations that you sometimes feel that Australia has built a national museum of architecture rather than one dedicated to its own social history. On one part of the site is a reworking of Le Corbusier's Villa Savoie, but the smooth, white skin of the original has turned fuzzy black and it crashes into a vivid-red, flattened, cut-out of the façade of the Australian parliament, used to provide a suitably important looking home for the institute for Aboriginal studies. It looks across a sweep of grass toward the Australian version of the Berlin building that, in turn, morphs into a central entrance hall in which Raggatt has painstakingly recreated fragments of the brown glass and the window mullions used in the Sydney Opera House. Along the way, there is a little souvenir of James Stirling's Stuttgart Staatsgallerie and an Aldo Rossi building.

It could be a would-be high-culture version of Las Vegas, and the themed architecture typified by the casinos, but it isn't. Raggatt has created a building that is more than a collage of postcards. It is a building that amounts to a book, even if it is written in a language that most people will have trouble reading. Ashton Raggatt and McDougall don't content themselves with using buildings as words - they have also covered their building with words, to provide another, all but incomprehensible layer of meaning. The aluminium skin is pitted with regular patterns of dimples, giant Braille characters used as a form of decoration. It's a language that very few sighted people can make sense of, and which is out of reach of the fingers of those blind visitors who might be able to read it. Raggatt, however, is happy to translate as he leads you around. 'Who are my neighbours?' he asks, pointing at one strip of aluminium on the sculpted skin. 'She'll be right, mate,' he interprets, pointing to another.

It doesn't stop there. The colours tell their own story. Fragments of the exterior are painted black and red to reflect the Aboriginal flag. Another slice is buff and blue, the colours of the uniforms worn by the convicts in the early penal colonies. And if that wasn't enough, the architects have wrapped the entire thing in yet another metaphorical layer, one that is enough to make your head spin. It seems the conceptual starting point of the museum was to turn the grids that define Canberra into threads, and then knot them to make a building defined by the form created by the knot, suggesting the shared destinies of all Australia's peoples.

Getting to grips with this museum on its architect's terms isn't easy, even if it is possible to experience it simply as a physical sensation devoid of the intellectual content. But it doesn't matter if you don't get it all first time around. There is no Rosetta Stone provided by the architect to unravel all the meanings, just a few broad and not so broad hints. It is an architecture of intelligence and anger, of imagination and obsession, with an ambition not just to redefine Australia's sense of itself, but architecture too.

webTitle: The play's set in an asylum. Naturally, we're watching from padded seats

fields.headline: The play's set in an asylum. Naturally, we're watching from padded seats
fields.standfirst: Susannah Clapp sees a compelling new production of Marat/Sade in an old factory.
fields.trailText: Susannah Clapp sees a compelling new production of Marat/Sade in an old factory.
fields.body:
Measure for Measure The Tobacco Factory, Bristol
Marat/Sade Arcola, London E8
Les Justes Gate, London W11
Under the Doctor Comedy, London SW1

More and more it seems the best theatre is happening outside theatre buildings. Take the company called Shakespeare at the Tobacco Factory. Just over a year ago its artistic director Andrew Hilton commandeered an industrial building once central to Bristol's financial prosperity. He has drawn on another rich resource of the city: young actors fresh from the Bristol Old Vic Theatre school. He is eliciting luminous performances, producing forceful, distinctly articulated Shakespeare.

A big cast in a small bare space: there's intensity but also expansiveness in Hilton's direction of Measure for Measure, played in Elizabethan costume with scant props and scene changes signalled by a dipping of lights and a few trumpet trills. The production, set in the round in a low-ceilinged, iron-pillared room, is near enough to be watched by the audience as a series of close-ups.

Many of these have to do with women's faces. In the opening moments, a nun, reluctantly admitting a visitor to her convent, twists and turns away from him as he tries to see her features - like a butterfly flitting from a collector's net. In the closing sequence, as Lucy Black's taut, concentrated Isabella is claimed by the Duke in marriage as by right, she looks at him not with docile pleasure but bleakly, as if suddenly realising she's been betrayed; you can almost see the colour draining from her face.

It's hard not to regard Isabella as a bit of a pill. It would be satisfying to see the scene when she refuses to accede to the seduction which might save her brother from death - 'More than our brother is our chastity' - played so that the audience are free to groan at her. Hilton doesn't do this, but he does capture the pervasive iciness which steals through the play. John Mackay's Angelo, with measured tread and swivelling eye, is so locked up in himself that he barely knows whether he's being hypocritical or not: at his moment of greatest agitation he merely tightens the vicarish clasping of his hands. To strike a restaurantish note, my companion, who arrived full of grumbles at a play he considered preposterous, left in tears.

Another city, another factory, another far-sighted transformer. Mehmet Ergen, the founding artistic director of Southwark Playhouse, has moved east and taken over a disused clothing factory in Dalston, where, he claims - what with the shops never closing and the streets alive around the clock - 'It's just like Broadway out there.'

The audience perch on (mercifully padded) benches, made from old cutting-tables. The low but wide performance space, overhung with looping cables, has few fixed features. It's wonderfully well used in the Arcola's first big production. Peter Weiss's Marat/Sade was first performed in Britain, directed by Peter Brook, in 1964.

Its central debate - are human beings set free by the pursuit of individualism or by social revolution? - went down a storm. As did its framing anti-rationalistic device: watched by a suave Marquis de Sade, the events leading up to the death of Marat are acted out by the inmates of a lunatic asylum; their riotous abandon comes to engulf their play, and in doing so, stakes a claim for power going to the people.

There's an element of Bedlam-gazing in all this: the inmates, not endowed with inner lives, are wincers, lollers, grinners and tremblers. The arguments are pretty broad-brush. But under Michael Cabot's direction the performances are inflected, and the play has a compelling, natural movement: the horde of white-gowned and strait-jacketed figures gather and scatter and surge, swelling into song or protest as if whipped up by an unseen wind.

A striking design, by Geraldine Bunzi and Fiona Hankey, drapes white curtains through the dusky performance area so that the entire space seems to be encased in a winding-sheet; in the distance a solitary figure sits without moving - to give an impression of infinite recession. This asylum can appear to be the inside of a brain, beset by warring impulses.

A not dissimilar debate is being waged at the influential Gate, which has a new artistic director. Erica Whyman - like Ergen, an imaginative former director of Southwark Playhouse - has gone in with a plan: to run a season of plays which discuss the subject of freedom in the twentieth century. The first of these, Camus's Les Justes, had an evocative design from the gifted Soutra Gilmour, a strong performance from Ruth Lass and far too much arid spouting by Albert Camus. The next, a brand-new Canadian piece called Belle , opens this week.

Meanwhile the traditional West End can be sampled at its tacky worst in Peter Tilbury's laborious French farce. The misnamed Comedy Theatre is given over to can-can music, a crude drawing of the Eiffel Tower, a blonde in frilly knickers, a husband caught in adultery, and a playwright caught in puns of staggering feebleness. The cast, who include Peter Davison and Anton Rodgers, valiantly perform as if in a production that wasn't terminally ill - but the diagnosis is that Under the Doctor will shortly be out on its ear.

fields.headline: Nile desperandum
fields.standfirst: Aida at the Albert Hall has no audible words but slaves and sphinxes galore...
fields.trailText: Aida at the Albert Hall has no audible words but slaves and sphinxes galore...
fields.body:
Aida Royal Albert Hall, London SW7

Turandot Royal Opera House, London WC2

After one of the first performances of Aida, a dissatisfied member of the audience, on his train going home, heard others enthusing about the work's genius. He went to see the opera a second time, hoping his mind would be changed. It was not. He then wrote to Verdi and asked whether, in the circumstances, the composer would reimburse him for the cost of two tickets, two rail fares and two 'disgustingly bad dinners at [Parma] station'.

Verdi paid the bill (but not for dinner, 'which could have been eaten at home') and advised the man to keep away from future performances of his music, lest 'spectres haunt him'. The canny composer, a national hero, then arranged for the correspondence to be published in the press. The opera-goer was immediately threatened by an angry pro-Verdi mob and hardly dared leave home for fear of decapitation.

Despite this early and localised dissent, with which I confess to sympathise, Aida has achieved enormous popularity. It has all the criteria of grand opera - elaborate spectacle in four or five acts, with rousing choruses and a ballet - combined with the drama of a love triangle. The sumptuous, cumulative music of the triumphal scene, shifting from massed trumpets to choral outburst, grand march to Moorish dance, has a majesty matched only by Wagner in Die Meistersinger. No wonder Raymond Gubbay, maestro of arena opera, chose it for his latest venture to mark Verdi's centenary year.

Wisely, he remained loyal to the team which brought him success with Madame Butterfly and Tosca, with David Freeman as director, David Roger as designer and Peter Robinson as conductor. Even their combined experience, however, could not entirely overcome the uneasy stop-start nature of Verdi's 1870 work, completed a year after ships first sailed down the Suez Canal. Though I once travelled all the way to Egypt to see horses and camels gallop through the temple of Luxor in the triumphal scene, and to witness the temple priests invoking Osiris in the 'Banks of the Nile' scene, Nile in the background, moon and stars overhead, I still had reservations, but I guess some people are just hard to please.

The piece whispers into action, the muted strings so hushed that you cannot be certain the performance has started. Within minutes, the Egyptian Radames bursts into 'Celeste Aida', a hymn to the Ethiopian slave with whom he is in love. This aria has an emotional intensity usually found at the crux of the action rather than at its start, with no character established (nor any chance for the singer's voice to warm up for the famous high B flat ending).

The pace builds slowly towards the crowd scenes, which, in arena performance, tends to be the bit we're all waiting for. In the intimate third and fourth acts, the chorus is almost dispensed with, though the music at this point becomes far more beguiling and complex, the action clearer.

Freeman and Roger opted for a traditional look, with hundreds of handsome Ethiopians, Egyptians and Assyrians semi-clad in the garb so familiar from tomb paintings. A circular floor design inspired by the magnificent gold and lapis zodiac ceiling at the temple of Dendera dominated the arena. The avenue of 10 sphinxes (made in fibreglass in Shepperton) and an eight-metre-high statue of Ptah, God of Creation, raised spectacularly from supine to upright position, brought a flavour of Upper Egypt to Kensington Gore. The ballets were played as slightly chaotic ritual dramas and the triumph scene played without excess. As Freeman noted in his entertaining programme essay: 'Elephants can't act, so we've left them out.'

On the first night, technical problems with the amplification made it impossible to hear any words in Amanda Holden's new translation. Since much of the action in Aida (and it's not so critical in all operas) depends on knowing what is being said, this was a blow. Would the original Italian and surtitles have been more effective on this occasion? The cast, one of three, with Tamsin Dives as Aida, John Keyes as Radames (in a woefully unflattering costume) and Renata Skarelyte, are not blessed with stunning voices but held the stage well enough. The BBC Concert Orchestra, positioned at one end of the arena, with another level of action on a narrow stage behind them, played with assurance, and Peter Robinson marshalled his various forces with skill. Should you go? Of course. But read the synopsis first and remember that intimacy and spectacle are equal partners in this problematic but cherished piece.

Despite the lightly-veiled portrait of Italian politics beneath the surface of Aida, Verdi worked hard to create Egyptian colours in his score. But old habits die hard and otherness mostly gives way to noises of loud Italians on a trip to the Pyramids. Puccini's sound world in Turandot is more consistently exotic. Andrei Serban's well-loved (and only slightly well-worn) production at the Royal Opera House, with Sally Jacobs's imposing crimson and black recreation of ancient China, is somehow more spectacular than most Aidas. Quality voices without amplification, including the stupendous Jane Eaglen and her compact Calaf (Dennis O'Neill), move the spirit in this barbarous tale.

Turandot 's recipe of emperors, trials, ceremonies and executions, plus the aria of arias to round it off, seems right for promotion in the arena. 'Nessun Dorma' would fill the Albert Hall in every sense. Messrs Gubbay and Freeman are probably planning it as I write.

fields.headline: There's no smoke without satire
fields.standfirst: He's still big on roll-ups and parody, but Huey has axed the lounge lizard act
fields.trailText: He's still big on roll-ups and parody, but Huey has axed the lounge lizard act
fields.body:
Fun Lovin' Criminals Olympia, Dublin

Brows are frequently furrowed in the music world over the mystery of the Fun Lovin' Criminals' status in Britain and comparative lack of it back in old New York. But this is as nothing beside the devotion they command in Dublin, where they have a bigger following than the Pope.

The Olympia Theatre was crammed to its ornate upper circle with over-revving fans, chanting for Huey like football supporters, as the Criminals sauntered on stage for the first gig of three in the city. If admirers of the first two albums had entertained a few doubts about the super-smooth late-night lounge flavour of the last one, Mimosa, then the new release, Loco, will have everyone reassured; the Criminals have returned to the energetic hybrid hip-hop/rock/soul sounds and often jokey lyrics that marked the early material, while keeping the slick Seventies jazz-funk influence prominent in songs such as 'Half A Block' and 'She's My Friend'.

But it's the swaggering, playful side that marks the Criminals' stage shows, together with their uncanny ability to produce a much bigger live sound than you'd expect from a three-piece band - an effect achieved largely through volume and liberal use of distortion pedals on Huey's Les Paul, but helped along by Fast's knack of swapping neatly between keyboard, bass and flugelhorn, or even playing them all at once. Huey occasionally managed to play two guitars at the same time, most notably a slide solo in the Leonard Cohenesque 'My Little Song', when his free hand wasn't busy with what we'll generously identify as a roll-up cigarette.

The Criminals launched the set at a furious pace with the magnificently titled hillbilly parody 'Dickholder' from the new album, and immediately you could see that you were in the presence of serious devotion: the album was only released last week and the entire audience knew all the words. Perhaps it was the venue, but in spite of their enthusiasm the fans remained touchingly respectful, dancing politely in neat rows in the stalls as if the seats were still there. Yet the atmosphere was charged, the furious energy of the drum beats matched by the crowd's excitement, and it's this that makes the Criminals such a popular live act.

The band's line-up changed when original drummer Steve Borovini (as in 'The cops gave chase/ But my man Steve's an ace') ran off to Peru after the second album, and his successor, Maxwell 'Mackie' Jayson, had a chance to let rip with some of the heavier numbers from the first albums, such as 'Fun Lovin' Criminal', '10th Street' and 'Bombin' The L'.

Mackie entered the stage with the most panache, in a white Tom Wolfe suit and panama, but it was Huey who bantered with the audience, playing up his Noo Yark mobster charm and even raising a cheer with the creaking old joke about the racehorses and the talking dog - though this paled beside his re-creation of the duel between Darth Vader and Obi Wan Kenobi as enacted by Robert De Niro and Al Pacino (with real light sabres).

The set reflected the new album's stylistic diversity, from the casual funk of the title track to the quasi-punk thrashing of 'Where the Bums Go' ('Hell's Angels really love this song,' Huey announced), and balanced the tempo between the likes of rap-influenced 'Swashbucklin' in Brooklyn', the melodic 'Korean Bodega' and the hard rock 'Southside'. But although convention dictates that one's best-loved number one hit should be saved for the encore, the brilliant 'Scooby Snacks' was slipped nonchalantly into the mix after 'Bump' - a slick Latino-style song whose chorus runs: 'I met the finest girl of my life, that night/ On Gay Night' - and the Barry White tribute 'Love Unlimited'.

They closed the first set after nearly an hour and a half on stage with the jazzy 'Half A Block', drawing it out to a big showy finale with a proper, old-fashioned prog-rock guitar solo and Fast adding some mellow brass behind it. The band stayed backstage for so long that the audience almost stopped their shrieking applause and began to look nervous, but they needn't have worried.

Springing back on stage and clearly in more relaxed mode, Huey told his fans that the Criminals feel as at home in Dublin as they do in New York (though 'Down on O'Connell Street' sadly doesn't scan so well), and the band dived into 'Minibar Blues', their bouncy rock 'n' roll jibe at the rock 'n' roll life.

The encores lasted almost another hour, though, oddly, they played 'My Little Song' twice. Not that the crowd seemed to mind; this is the kind of exuberant music you expect from the Fun Lovin' Criminals and it's a kick to see them back on form.
