fields.headline: It's all done with sound-mirrors
fields.standfirst: Tacita Dean goes down to the sea again to find inspiration for her films and drawings
fields.trailText: Tacita Dean goes down to the sea again to find inspiration for her films and drawings
fields.body:
Tacita Dean: Recent Films and Other Works Tate Britain, London SW1 until 6 May

On a strand of white beach, far across the ocean, stands the strangest house ever built on shifting sands - a giant bubble of fibreglass, resting perilously close to the brine. It ought to be a figment, this folly by the sea, but Tacita Dean has discovered and filmed it.

Her camera takes you through the space-age doors and deep into its deserted chambers. Water drips from the gaping roof. Lagoons collect on the floor. Light seeps through narrow windscreens. Just as you are wondering what befell the owners, the camera swivels out towards the sea. In less than a minute, a distant storm races the waves to the shore, lashing against this wreck of a long-lost future.

Time and tide wait for no man, especially when he's in prison, like the owner of this futuristic fantasy on Cayman Brac. Does the convict dream of it in his cell, this desolate house by the shore? Does he wonder what happens when he isn't there?

The owner gradually becomes an absent presence in Dean's film, as she shows you what he can only imagine. By the time her camera has moved slowly through its seven-minute scope, the scene is fixed in your imagination. The house, waiting forever by a turquoise tide, has become a place in the mind. This sense of expectation, of isolation and imminent nostalgia, belongs to the art of Edward Hopper, to whom Dean, at 35, has already been compared. Like him, she originally trained as a painter. At Tate Britain, you can see her early images of ships billowing in the night like ghosts, drawn in ephemeral chalk on blackboard. She also has Hopper's fascination with lighthouses, lone eyes searching the wilderness for life. But Dean doesn't have the painter's genius for condensing cinema into singular pictures. She works by spooling time through semi-static images.

Sound Mirrors opens with a still shot of a coastline at evening. A Martello tower looms like a monolith in the silvery twilight. Before it lies a dark and motionless inlet. Framed by bulrushes, the whole landscape looks as though it's been worked in shadowy monochrome. And then a breath of wind shivers the painted waters.

On cue, the film drifts to the 'sound mirrors' - concrete dishes used by the army as a primitive early-warning system in the 1920s. In the dying light, these bizarre prototypes rise up like massive heads before fading into a darkness pierced only by the beam of a lighthouse. Dean's 16mm film picks up the flutter of late birds and the continuing buzz of the tiny plane that took off in the first image. War still hovers, anticipated on this strand of English coast, even though the defences - lighthouse, dishes, tower - now look as archaic as Easter Island statues.

This is a marvellous piece, moving through the ever-present past at exactly the mind's pace. Everything marks time, from the trailing biplane to the film stock, with its antique tones, ticking through the aged cine-projector stationed at the centre of the room. These contraptions are more than a technical necessity. They add a further soundtrack, with their murmuring narrative, and they often echo, in their motion, the very images projected.

So the waves in Delft Hydraulics , an experiment in confined turbulence, ribbon through their glass tank as ceaselessly as the spooling film. In Disappearance at Sea, the lighthouse lamp revolves between black clouds and sunset in slow accord with the reels of the projector. The film ends when the sky - and thus the celluloid - fades to blackness. These circular connections run right through Dean's show. The sun rises in Berwick and sets in Berlin. The tiny plane lifts above Kent and descends on Cayman. Walk among these rooms, radiating from a central jukebox that plays ambient sounds from around the world on a 24-hour clock, and you are always aware that the same tide eventually washes up on each shore.

Dean's fascination with coastal relics isn't always fully enacted in her films. Not far from the Bubble House, for example, lies the wreckage of a trimaran. Again, Dean's camera witnesses its bleached and sea-worn shell, watching the brine drip through its ruined structure. But the boat itself is not a haunting spectacle. You need to know what the film cannot evoke, namely, that this is the Teignmouth Electron, in which Donald Crowhurst tried to sail the world singlehanded in 1969, faking his log book and eventually throwing himself overboard when the pressure of maintaining his deception became overwhelming.

Dean's films thrive best when they aren't underpinned by prior knowledge and their wonders are allowed to unfold at the slow pace of her camera. Two recent films in this show fully merit their respective lengths - one takes 44 minutes; the other lasts for more than an hour.

Fernsehturm is set in a revolving restaurant at the top of a tower. It begins as the waitresses set the tables and ends as they clear away the remains of the day. Guests arrive, take their seats, watch the panorama through the windows. The day slips through its seasons, from blue morning to golden evening, crimson sunset to night. As the lights come up across the city, the scene turns inward; smoke drifts beneath the lamps, people bend to twinkling glasses, an organist plays 'The Blue Danube' to the diners of Berlin. The editing is syncopated to twin diurnal rhythms - the decline of the day and the progression of dinner. The restaurant is a clock to both, but the film has its own time, a series of short scenes in which people come and go, food is cooked and eaten, conversation rises and fades away. Each scene is a miniature version of the film in its entirety, just as the film describes a whole day in less than an hour.

This is, of course, what naturally happens during the passage of a solar eclipse. Dean's film of this event is surely her masterpiece, an exquisitely subtle portrait of time. The art is all in the patient selection and editing of images: cows lying silent in darkening pastures, ships fading on the horizon, cocks crowing in the afternoon as if it were sunrise. Blackness finally fills the screen like an abstract painting. When the sunlight returns, seen through a canopy of leaves, it ripples through the static image, bringing the trees - and the picture - back to life.

fields.headline: Charmed and embalmed
fields.standfirst: Frozen in timeless glamour, Horst's immaculately rendered subjects range from the gorgeous to the ghastly
fields.trailText: Frozen in timeless glamour, Horst's immaculately rendered subjects range from the gorgeous to the ghastly
fields.body:
Horst Portraits: 60 Years of Style National Portrait Gallery, London WC2 until 3 June

Horst's photo of Jean Cocteau in Venice brings to mind James Joyce's advice on portraiture. 'Never mind my soul,' he told the painter Patrick Nuohy in 1924. 'Just be sure you have my tie right.' It doesn't matter that by 1947 Cocteau was a grand old enfant terrible of French letters. What matters is that Horst got his tie right. And he also got the lapels of his jacket, the collar of his shirt and the texture - a well-washed linen - of his face.

This is the advantage of the photographic over the painted portrait. If nothing else you're going to get the tie right. And since getting the tie right is relatively easy, maybe that means you have plenty of energy left for the soul-searching.

Or maybe there's more to getting the tie right than one might think. Maybe the soul is in the tie. Or perhaps - and this is the big one - there is only the tie. But that's a wild exaggeration of course: there's also the dress.

Horst photographed ties, dresses and their occupants for 60 years. He was born into a wealthy family in Germany in 1906. At 23 he moved to Paris where he met George Hoyningen-Huene, chief photographer for French Vogue. Horst became his protégé and assistant and began taking his own photographs for French, British and - after an initially unsuccessful engagement - American Vogue.

The roles of fashion photographer and society portraitist went hand in hand, especially once models started to emerge as proto-celebrities in their own right. Some of his most famous portraits are of models like Lisa Fonssagrives (swooning, Marat-like in a radiant bath of light) only in a nominal sense. They're about the creation of glamour. Their real subject - certainly the main source of their fascination now - is the camera's capacity to transform certain people into the photographer's ideal conception of themselves. The fact that Horst's style of baroque romanticism accentuated the paraphernalia involved - elaborate sets and lighting - did nothing to diminish its almost alchemical allure: the tools of glamour were also its ornaments.

Horst's pictures drip money. Even the light is extravagant. The catalogue accompanying an exhibition of his portraits at the National Portrait Gallery speaks of the 'timeless elegance' of his work, but this version of timelessness has specific temporal roots. Horst's classic pictures from the 1930s were being made at the same time as Walker Evans's documentary images of the great Depression. The contrast, however, is not as extreme as one might think. Evans's attitude to his subjects was as aesthetic as it was moral. A colleague was struck by the way Evans 'kept his white gloves on' while photographing the slums of Alabama.

Horst kept his gloves on too in the sense that there is no sex in his pictures. There's not any desire. It's been frozen - like hair fixed by mousse - by glamour. This makes the photos not less but more interesting.

Many of the theatrical tableaux, especially if they're in colour, are nothing short of ghastly. His 1964 photograph of The Duke and Duchess of Windsor is a royal premonition of Diane Arbus's fascination with the grotesque: they're like figures in a wax museum.

Horst developed close working relationships with his female models but one rarely feels they might actually live in the clothes they are displaying. Some of his more elaborate shots are like those booths where you put your head through a hole and appear, on film, as an eminent Victorian or - as in his 1935 shot of Martinez de Hoz - a pierrot. Horst exploits this in a picture of Olivia de Havilland in which she leans through a picture frame or mirror. The frame is there in the exhibition so that we too can inhabit Horst's world-view. It also means - quite literally - that we see through the Horst glamour-frame. This alerts us to a tackiness that, once it is no longer held in check by lush monochrome, tends cheeseward, in the direction of drag queens, glam rock and Duran Duran (photographed by Horst in 1986!).

More broadly, the embalming legacy of glamour made a reaction against it in the form of radical feminism almost inevitable. Seen in this light his weird colour image of the Duchess of Windsor in 1947 is like one of Cindy Sherman's reworkings of the art historical past. Conversely, the images which now seem most 'timeless' are the less contrived, more natural ones, of Eliette von Karajan in the countryside, for example.

A caption for the neighbouring photo recalls that when her husband Herbert got in a taxi at Salzburg the driver asked, 'Where to?' 'It doesn't matter,' replied the maestro. 'I've got business everywhere.' Horst's portrait of Karajan is consistent with this in that he is apparently speeding along in a sports car with his eyes shut.

A photo of Maria Callas suggests the diva was permanently in character, playing Aida even in the privacy of her own apartment. Horst recalls he 'was lucky to get out of there alive'. A 1947 image of Rita Hayworth is justly iconic but she looks, also, as if she is watching telly, possibly a re-run of Only Angels Have Wings.

Horst spent his career photographing the rich and famous, but one wonders what pictures he would have made had he turned his lens on the less perfectly manicured. We get a hint of this in his picture of the ageing W.H. Auden. Marooned in a sweater almost as baggy as his face, Auden is the only person in the book who doesn't care what he looks like. This is not surprising. As he wrote in 'I am not a Camera', 'Lovers, approaching to kiss,/instinctively shut their eyes before their faces/can be reduced to/anatomical data.' Horst wouldn't have wanted to get that close, but Auden's eyes are shut all the same. Not that it matters: Horst got the sweater anyway.

fields.headline: The prince of darkness
fields.standfirst: His surreal songs speak of sin, lust and betrayal. He survived a nervous breakdown. And now he calls himself Bonnie Prince Billy. What more could you want from a cult singer-songwriter?
fields.trailText: His surreal songs speak of sin, lust and betrayal. He survived a nervous breakdown. And now he calls himself Bonnie Prince Billy. What more could you want from a cult singer-songwriter?
fields.body:
Towards the end of my late-night transatlantic phone conversation with singer-songwriter Will Oldham, which has already veered off on various surreal tangents, courtesy of a thought process that redefines the term lateral, I hear a loud snap followed by a yelp. It transpires that Oldham has absent-mindedly picked up 'a live mouse trap' and 'damn near snapped my finger'.

Unperturbed, he picks up the threads of a sentence that began five minutes and several conceptual leaps earlier. In it, he has ranged from the contemplation of infidelity as 'a positive, enhancing experience' to the method acting that underpinned the recorded duets of Conway Twitty and Loretta Lynn, the king and queen of the cheating ballad genre which the singer has reinvented to powerful effect on his new album, Ease Down the Road.

Talking to Oldham is not unlike listening to one of his songs: you head off on a seemingly traditional narrative, only to find yourself on a hairpin bend that takes you into strange and often disturbing territory which, in turn, gives way to even more surreal terrain. Which may be why the thirtysomething Kentuckian has, for the last 10 years or so, been the most singular songwriter to emerge out of the fragmented alternative American music scene. He is now in a league of one, his singularity of vision matched by a growing and obsessive global fan base that makes every release, every performance, an event of devotion and intensity.

A few years back, having recorded a series of effortlessly ramshackle and intermittently inspired albums under various guises - Palace, Palace Music, Palace Songs and Palace Brothers - he conferred on himself the title Bonnie Prince Billy - 'it's kind of regal and it has Billy the Kid connotations' - and released I See A Darkness, one of the most extraordinary, and overlooked, albums of recent years. (The title song, a tender ode to male friendship, has just been recorded by Johnny Cash, the most public acknowledgment yet of Oldham's songwriting skill.)

With the name change came a sea change in his music, a movement from the wilfully broken aesthetic of old to a more serene, crafted though still surprising sound. 'Basically, I created Billy and I let him take care of the work, the performing. I mean, it's a thin distinction between me and him, but it's enough to be liberating. Basically, Will talks to his girlfriend, Bill sings to his audience. It's a personal/creative separation born out of the illumination that it's not me, Will Oldham, who gets up on the stage and sings. Music is, or should be, transformative so I kind of took that to its logical conclusion and transformed myself too.'

This has yielded surprising results: you could not imagine, for instance, the old Oldham recording a song like the sublime 'After I Made Love To You', possibly the most intimate and guilt- free celebration of illicit sex since Marvin Gaye's 'Let's Get It On'. The whole album drips unbridled sensuality, with the notion that sin - one of Oldham's recurring obsessions - is synonymous not just with damnation - another of his abiding themes - but with transcendence. There are songs here about lust, infidelity, oral sex and, on the closing 'Rich Wife Full Of Happiness', a dream union of man, woman, shark and dog, that ends with the couplet: 'I lick you dry until you're laughing/My fingers in your behind'. (Oldham songs are not for the faint-hearted.)

'That song is a kind of Jungian free association all about the mythological, symbolic connotation of fucking,' he explains, haltingly, his voice high and almost breathless. 'But it's a very carnal record which is unsurprising, I suppose, given that sex is something I've always been motivated by, and maybe obsessed with, but not in a perverse way.' He pauses, a conceptual hairpin bend approaching. 'I think sex is something that's too absent from songs and too present in movies. Except in Russ Meyer's movies where it's kind of intense and real as well as utterly cartoonish and unreal. I think he gets pretty close to the real revelatory experience, and that's sort of what I was trying to do. It's a tightrope walk though.'

Will is into his stride now: 'I found myself in a familiar space writing this record, then it dawned on me I was entering Loretta Lynn and Conway Twitty territory - sin, betrayal, lust. Then again, I'm writing about an actual incident from the point of view of an active participant. I don't think Loretta's songs had much to do with her real life. She doesn't strike me as that sort of girl.'

Nor could you countenance Loretta and Conway wrapping their gilded tonsils around a song called 'You Have Cum On Your Hair And Your Dick Is Hanging Out', which surfaced on 1996's Palace Music album Arise Therefore.

Though he might appear at times to be a backwoods boy with an almost primal aesthetic that harks back to the roots of the American folk and country traditions, Oldham is also a post-modern chameleon, creating and disregarding personae at will, hiding behind his own carefully created and maintained cult status. He stumbled into music after a fitful career as an actor, having studied drama in his home town of Louisville, Kentucky. In 1987 he landed the lead role in John Sayles's film Matewan, a sprawling epic about America's beleaguered coal-mining communities, in which he played a born-again child preacher whose old testament sermonising prefigured the later intensity of his best songs.

By the early Nineties, having grown 'tired of speaking other people's words', he fled the film industry, though he appeared fleetingly, as a dancing nurse in a mental asylum, in his friend Harmony Korine's Julien Donkey-Boy, and is rumoured to have a bigger part in Korine's next, as yet untitled, film. There followed an uncertain period when Oldham roamed America, pitching up in Cape Cod where he suffered a breakdown, tentatively referred to in an old interview as 'fantastic internal trouble'.

Out of this crisis came a series of elliptical, self-questioning songs like 'I Am A Cinematographer', on which he sang: 'I walked away from everything that's good/And I walked away from everything I leaned on/Only to find it's made of wood.'

Oldham's reticence about his personal life is legendary and is matched with an aversion to the relentless self-promotion that attends the making of music these days. In an age when rock musicians, with a few notable exceptions, have surrendered whatever integrity and dignity their tarnished form still possesses for the the trappings of showbusiness style self-aggrandisement, Oldham has ploughed a straight and dedicated path at odds with the prevailing mood of the times.

Through constant name changes, wilful invisibility, and a dedication to letting his music enter the imagination unhindered by the distractions that even minor celebrity brings, he has created a body of work that is unique in both its preoccupations and its methodology. Earlier albums like Viva Lost Blues and Joya were recorded on impossibly low budgets in a matter of days; he speaks without irony of the luxury of having five weeks in the studio to make the new record.

Like his friend and mentor, the young guerrilla film maker Harmony Korine - who contributes backing vocals and 'shouting' on the new album - Oldham has become, through his reticence and elusiveness as well as his single-mindedness, a major cult figure.

'I guess that's OK,' he says after a long pause, 'because the way I have chosen to work seems to have engendered a strong, discerning audience for the songs. People enter the songs and kind of know what to expect now. They know each song is a journey and that when I'm writing it I'm not even sure where it's going. That's the magic.'

I ask if he sabotages a song if it threatens to becomes too traditional, either in structure or subject matter; if disruption, in fact, is an abiding aesthetic? 'I don't think of it as sabotage,' he replies, perhaps offended, 'I think of it as rescue. I don't like to start a song already there. I mean, what's the point of that? I like to get there during the song, and that often means shouting to the musicians and myself, "Turn here! Turn here!" or "Reverse!" Then, if it works out, everybody goes, "Wow, look at the view from here!"

'That's the thing you see - the view's nearly always better when you don't really know where the road is leading.'

The new Bonnie Prince Billy album, Ease Down the Road, is released on Domino Records on 12 March. He will tour Britain this summer.

webTitle: Don't call me - email my butler

fields.headline: Don't call me - email my butler
fields.standfirst: Are you a whizz at work but hopeless at home? You could do with a lifestyle manager
fields.trailText: Are you a whizz at work but hopeless at home? You could do with a lifestyle manager
fields.body:
It is curious that people who are paid lots of money to be efficient and dynamic at work can be completely incompetent at home. They have To Do lists that never get done. They pride themselves on their organisational skills, but can't get round to fixing the leaking tap in the downstairs loo or remember their mother-in-law's birthday. These people need a personal butler.

And now they can have one. At least three companies have recently set up in the UK providing what they like to call 'lifestyle managers' to those for whom home is where the paperwork is. For something over £1,000 a year, the rich, successful but domestically challenged young executive (most clients are in their late twenties and early thirties and many are in the City and new technology businesses) can acquire a PA for the home. These lifestyle managers are charged with ensuring that the harassed exec never again has to sit on the end of a phone listening to plinky-plinky music while waiting to be connected to the gas company.

The butlers, uniformly bright and breezy, handle between 15 and 20 clients each, many of whom speak to, or email, them every day. For most of us the thought of investigating the best washing machine for our budget, purchasing it, arranging delivery and waiting in for it to arrive (or not), is likely to induce feelings of deep depression. But give this task to a lifestyle manager and they will react as if you had just offered them an exciting holiday.

With the same professionally enthused and upbeat demeanour, they will organise builders, check out the cheapest place to buy a mobile phone, get you pushed up the waiting list for the latest Porsche and send flowers to your best friend. Their clients, or 'members', pay for services as and when they receive them, over and above their joining fee. The companies take a cut from the suppliers, 'but we guarantee that as a member, you don't pay more', says James Hickman of Liberate365 (membership: £1,200 per year) which was set up in November 1999 and now has 24 staff serving 200 individuals.

It is certainly true that if Liberate were to book a villa, the company could get a travel agent's discount that wouldn't be available to an individual. There are also economies of scale as the companies put business the way of their favoured suppliers. But Sarah Ewing, a 25 year-old journalist and client of Ten (Time Energy Network) UK - £1,175 a year - the longest-established and largest of the companies in this country, accepts that 'services are sometimes slightly more expensive'.

'I asked Mark, my account manager, to get me a cleaner. My boyfriend, who lives in the East London suburbs, pays £4 an hour. I live more centrally and pay £6 an hour, but the cleaning is impeccable, so it's still value for money,' she says.

James Hickman suggests that Liberate can even pass on discounts. 'We import cars from abroad for our members, who get a better deal without hassle. And we guarantee the quality of work carried out by our suppliers: we check their books, their references, their quality and value for money, their courtesy. We keep on checking. And despite our stringent requirements, suppliers are now coming to us.'

This is beguiling sales talk: a plumber who turns up on time, does the job properly and doesn't rip you off? Too, too marvellous.

Alex Cheatle, one of two half-brothers who set up TenUK in 1998, acknowledges that his company has had its work cut out 're-educating the service sector' and admits that 'there is no such thing as the platonic plumber'. The difference, he says, is that TenUK will sort out any problems.

Cheatle, a former brand manager for Oil of Ulay, had the idea for TenUK when he was in Peru having a six-month sabbatical 'with a laptop and a rucksack' (personal trainers for your lifestyle tend to be good at stories). He claims not to have known of the US versions - which were a couple of years ahead, and call themselves concierge companies. They are in any case, more like website versions of the Yellow Pages: 'They have all gone down the mass market, technological route, acquiring tens of thousands of members very quickly.' (TenUK also now has a cheaper, website-based service, which is mainly used as a corporate perk).

The full butler service costs £1,000, and has 1,000 members assigned to 50 account managers, who range from ex-midwives to former managers at Starbucks. These 'bright young professionals, with whom members can have a peer relationship' are united by their determination to find you the right person to put together your flatpack furniture when you're too lazy or incompetent to do it yourself, and are just longing to wangle you into the perfect country house hotel for a last-minute dirty weekend. And if you want the best tantric sex teacher in London, they can put you in touch immediately, because they've had that one before.

William Tyler, 29, runs a company that mounts exhibition displays, and is a client of Entrust, which was set up by five former posh hoteliers (the Savoy, Claridge's, the Mandarin Oriental) in August 1999. The £150 a month he pays for the attentions of his account manager, Jonathan Wallace, 'definitely make life easier at home'.

'I work very hard and there are times with my girlfriend when I really need to pull a rabbit out of the hat. Once when I needed to do something special, Jonathan got us into the Ivy at really short notice. He called at 4pm and we had a table at 8.15.

'For Valentine's night, I didn't want to go out, so he arranged to have delicious food delivered to the door. My girlfriend is only aware that Entrust is responsible for about half of it. She thinks I'm very thoughtful, and I put a lot of time and effort into our social life. And in an ideal world, I'd like to.'

Getting you into booked-up restaurants is a staple of the lifestyle managers. They don't promise they can always get you into the Ivy, 'but you might make one call and be told no. We often know the person in charge of reservations. We'll call two or three times a week, schmooze, remind them we're still here and we'd love to have the table,' says Jonathan Wallace.

Some clients call their account manager twice a day; others a couple of times a week. Most of the jobs they want doing involve mundane domestic maintenance, but occasionally, the butlers will be presented with a challenge. 'We had one client who hated going to the dentist,' says James Hickman. 'We managed to find one who offered virtual reality glasses so that our client could watch a movie while he was in the chair. Someone else's wife had seen a bracelet in a jewellery shop in the main square in Rhodes old town that he wanted to track down. It turns out there are 60 jewellery shops in that square.' Photographs were dispatched across cyberspace, and they did it.

By the time your lifestyle manager has put you in the Wimbledon ballot, emailed you with news of opera tickets that happen to be going spare, and told you about this chic new hotel that's just opened in Paris, my guess is you could end up spending quite a lot more money. But these services are, after all, for cash-rich, time-poor people.

Admittedly, by the time you've emailed your account manager about the leaking tap, you could have called someone to fix it. But it's nicer dealing with Natasha from Liberate, and she'll guarantee that the plumber's OK, and arrange to let him in. And while she's about it, she'll remind you it's your mum's birthday next week, and she likes lilies rather than roses.

The rise of the personal butler reflects the fact that running a home is scarcely less onerous than running a business and that, these days, there's often no one to do it. But if remembering family birthdays is so far down our list of priorities that we have to employ someone to do it, what does that say about us? Well, for one thing, that we have a very worshipful and warped attitude to paid work.

Liberate365 020 7820 8211 www.liberate365.com

Ten UK 0700 101999 www.tenuk.com

Entrust 0870 908 8008 www.entrust-net.com

webTitle: How can we stop this other woman?

fields.headline: How can we stop this other woman?
fields.trailText: Two years ago my husband, who is 70, started an affair with a woman 18 years his junior. After three months he was 'found out' and promised it was over. They continued it but, when I threatened a divorce, he finally ended it.
fields.body:
Two years ago my husband, who is 70, started an affair with a woman 18 years his junior. After three months he was 'found out' and promised it was over. They continued it but, when I threatened a divorce, he finally ended it.

We set about rebuilding our relationship (we have been married 43 years and love each other). All seemed well but trust is a hard thing to put back in place. Then I discovered she had been leaving letters and flowers by a bench on a walk they had used. He tore them up. But she still regularly leaves flowers and has even carved their initials on the bench.

My problem is that this walk is a favourite of ours and seeing the flowers greatly upsets me, as the message seems to be: 'I am still waiting'.

He never told her the affair was over. I have no doubt he had strong feelings for her and doesn't want to hurt her. But should we just ignore them, as he suggests? What else can we do to stop her?
S. E. of Herts

Never underestimate the capacity of a man's ego to absorb flattery. They soak it up like blotting paper and the source is often more or less incidental.

By assuming your husband had strong feelings for this woman and is reluctant to hurt her, you are dignifying his affair in a way it does not merit. You are projecting your own womanly feelings on to him, unaware that your warmth and loyalty are gender-specific emotions, beyond the reach of a man in his farmyard cockerel mode. It may not be much comfort to you to know how lightly he sacrifices your peace of mind to his own vanity.

The person for whom he reserves his love is himself. Probably he preens in front of his bathroom mirror, thinking he is no end of a lad, having two women fighting over him, and at his age too. You should stop betraying your hurt, for he feeds on that. Be very low-key on the subject, as if it is a trivial matter and bores you. An imp of darkness suggests to me a little mischief. It would be prudent in the long term, and helpful in the short, to be more independent. Get out of the house; don't feel you are bound to do everything with your man. Now and then, leave him to fend for himself. I don't suggest you neglect him, but he should relearn that marriage is a two-way affair and that his rewards come in proportion to his responsibilities.

Your husband is being weak and insensitive. Is it the behaviour of someone who respects you to promise an affair is over, and then continue it? He is not only upsetting you he is upsetting the other woman too. It seems from her behaviour that she will need closure on this affair; she evidently feels the door has been left open.

If he had ended the affair properly, she could have moved on, mended her heart and maybe even found a new love. He has to tell her it is over. If he does not, you must demand a divorce.
K. M. of London

This 'other woman' sounds as though she may be mentally ill. Doesn't it seem strange to you that she has nothing better to do than leave flowers, letters and even carve her name in a park bench at the age of 52? How sad can you get?

I understand that you are feeling vulnerable, so why not treat yourself? A new hairstyle? A new dress or three? Book a nice holiday in Spain for both of you? Live life to the full.
P. W. of Powys

Until recently I had a good friend living with me who has all his mail sent to my address. He is now staying elsewhere until he can find a place to live. He is about to be made bankrupt and I am concerned because it will be at my address. To protect myself, I have been opening his mail. But he is furious. Am I morally justified?

fields.headline: Kandy will be no sweeter
fields.standfirst:
Second Test preview

Observer special report:England in Sri Lanka
fields.body:
Here's a surprise. The best bowling figures ever achieved in a Test match in Kandy were produced by a chap named Muttiah Muralitharan. The groundsman at Galle, the old Sri Lankan off-spinner, KPJ Warnaweera, has already been dispatched to Kandy to oversee the preparation of the Test wicket and I doubt whether he will be demanding that the mower blades should be raised a notch or two. Expect the pitch to be slow and to turn. Hope Nasser Hussain wins the toss. Admittedly the last time Sri Lanka played at Kandy - against South Africa a year ago - the pitch had different characteristics to the one England encountered in Galle. It was sufficiently damp at the start for Arjuna Ranatunga to insert the opposition upon winning the toss. South Africa won a thriller by seven runs as the bounce became increasingly uneven and low. 40 wickets fell in the match. Four South African wickets were taken by Sri Lankan seamers; four Sri Lankan wickets were taken by South African spinners. Do not anticipate those conditions being repeated when the second Test starts. England have several psychological barriers to overcome; paranoia about the umpires has to be banished; in charge next week are BC Cooray and Rudi Koertzen, neither of whom have impeccable credentials. England's middle order have to fathom a way to score runs against the spinners. And then comes the problem of capturing Sri Lankan wickets. Oddly enough, England were not too disappointed about how they played Murali in the first Test. The little magician did take seven wickets but he had to bowl 97 overs to get them. Marcus Trescothick was the only batsman to score off him with anything approaching freedom, but the most of the rest managed to blunt him for long periods. The problem lay against the other bowlers, most notably Sanath Jayasuriya. They had hoped to score more freely against them. They couldn't for a variety of reasons. Facing such a large first innings total, the batsmen were shackled by the need to save the game; Jayasuriya's unassuming darts were well directed and by the time he was bowling, the pitch was unreliable. And some of England's batting against him was inept and timid.

As usual, the prime cause of concern is the form of Hussain and Graeme Hick. Hussain obviously continues in the team, though he will have spent much of this week agonising over how best to counter the spinners. In the past he has sought to be aggressive early on to establish his authority at the crease. But this method failed him in Pakistan where eventually he opted to graft. He tried that in Galle but was scuppered by Murali in both innings. Meanwhile, the pressure to drop Hick mounts. In the long term England need Michael Vaughan established in the team when the Ashes series starts. In the short term the tour management may feel bound to stick with the hairline decision they took before the Galle Test. They might argue that Hick was betrayed by the umpire in one innings in Galle and there's no doubt that they value their reputation for giving those initially selected a fair go. If they stick with Hick, which is the most likely outcome, it is essential that he risks taking the game to the Sri Lankan spinners rather than defending dourly. Someone should hoodwink Hick into thinking it's a one-day game. After Galle the confidence of the bowlers is no more buoyant than that of Hussain and Hick. The pacemen crave life in the wicket; the spinners crave bowling on a third day pitch. Neither can be guaranteed. Even so England's bowling attack, despite their impotence in Galle, is likely to remain the same. Jason Brown has been gently ostracised, while Andrew Caddick will probably be retained ahead of Matthew Hoggard. The Sri Lankans are far more likely to change their side. The left-arm seamer, Nuwan Zoysa is fit again and will replace that virtual spectator in Galle, Dilhara Fernando. Kumar Dharmesena may give way to the left arm-spinner Dinuk Hettiarchchi. This is the time to change the side - when you're winning.

 Second Test Kandy, starts Wednesday (Sky Sports 2 from 4.15am daily)

fields.headline: Unappealing, but nothing new
fields.standfirst:
Inclement pitches and dubious decisions are part of the game and England are not the only victims

Observer special report:England in Sri Lanka
fields.trailText: Inclement pitches and dubious decisions are part of the game and England are not the only victims.
fields.body:
The prime emotion in England after the Test defeat in Galle seems to be one of outrage at incompetent umpiring, over-zealous appealing and a doctored pitch. But here in Sri Lanka there is just sympathy and of course tea from our hosts. The Sri Lankans we meet in shops, taxis and restaurants, while delighted by their team's victory, all preface their remarks with 'I'm sorry about the umpiring' as if it was their fault. Objectivity is a strain, so first some facts. Out of the 20 English wickets to fall in the first Test, 12 had to be adjudicated by the umpires. Four of those decisions (Stewart and Hick in the first innings, White and Croft in the second) were demonstrably wrong once the TV replays were consulted. Half a dozen were debatable - most lbws are - and because of previous howlers they came under unusually intense scrutiny. This may seem an abnormally high ratio of dismissals requiring the umpires' intervention but on turning dustbowls this is often the case. Batsmen are rarely bowled in these conditions; nor are there straightforward edges into the slip cordon. Everything happens in a flurry around the wicket. It's much easier to umpire in Perth, with its fast, bouncy pitch, than it is in Galle. Undoubtedly the Sri Lankans were noisier in the field than the English - 'over-zealous' is the modern euphemism - though one contributory factor for that is plain to see. When England were in the field during the first two days the ball hit the middle of the bat so frequently that there was limited scope for appeals of any sort. When England batted it was a different matter. The question is: have the Sri Lankans - toughened up during the past decade by their former captain and Observer columnist Arjuna Ranatunga - dragged the game to new depths? For those with limited experience of overseas Test matches, especially in the subcontinent, this is the inescapable conclusion. But it's not mine. Forgive a brisk and fairly random dart into the past where parallels are not hard to find. In 1982-83 when England were in Australia I was mildly chastised for revealing in The Cricketer that the England camp had discussed how they went about their appealing. We concluded that we were not aggressive enough. I wrote 'When appealing, the Aussies make a statement; we ask a question.' We tried to change tack. On the next two winter tours there were plenty of controversies similar to those provoked by the Galle Test. In Pakistan in 1983, the umpiring and appealing rankled with the English tourists, which led to an almost surreal 'dressing down' of the most gentlemanly of cricketers, Bob Taylor, in the pavilion in Lahore. David Gower, newly appointed captain, was instructed by the management to read the riot act to Taylor, who had shown dissent. Gower just avoided smiling throughout the charade and it was a rebuke no more stinging than those delivered by John le Mesurier in Dad's Army . In 1984, in Bombay, England felt betrayed by the umpiring of the gigantic Swaroop Kishen and much frantic Indian appealing. After debate the team concluded that they had to grin and bear it rather than descend into paranoia.

And so it goes on; mayhem in Pakistan in 1987-88 on Mike Gatting's tour. Fast forward to 1998 in Adelaide where Mike Atherton suffered a similar dismissal to the one in the second innings in Galle. Atherton was far more certain that Mark Taylor had failed to take the catch at slip than he was about the 'catch' to Sangakkara in Galle. The press-box reaction in Adelaide, having studied the replays time and time again, was instructive. To a man, the Aussie section all thought the ball had carried to Taylor; the English camp all thought it hadn't. So much for objectivity.

Nor should we fall into the trap of thinking that England are the only victims of dubious umpiring and appealing. I hesitate to mention it, but my first Test wicket at a crucial moment in the Headingley Test of 1982 may have been - how shall I put it? - dodgy. The Pakistanis certainly thought so. Think how the South Africans suffered at Headingley in 1998 or Wavell Hinds throughout the series last summer. My point is that there is nothing new in excessive appealing or umpiring errors. These may not be palatable elements of the game, but they have always happened. Even Wally Hammond remained certain to his dying day that Don Bradman had caught him on the half-volley in the opening Test of the 1946-47 series.

What has changed, thanks to the advance of technology, is that many decisions can now be proven to be wrong - so it seems increasingly daft not to use that technology when it can help. Once umpires are proven by the camera to be making bad decisions, it is only natural that players - from any country - opt to make ever more outlandish appeals in an attempt to redress the balance. This week Alec Stewart, who has no problems with antics of his Sri Lankan counterpart behind the stumps, spelt out his policy with commendable frankness: 'If I think I've got a chance of getting a decision, I'll appeal.' Not, you notice, 'If I think it's out, I'll appeal.' Duncan Fletcher has suggested an ingenious 'referral system' which would allow each side to refer three debatable decisions taken in the middle in each innings to the third umpire One of its strengths is that it should encourage the players themselves to police the game because incorrect appeals, if pursued, would be penalised with the loss of one of the three referrals per innings. Why not experiment with this system? Demonstrably bad umpiring is the spark for the excesses. When those excesses occur, a fine is a waste of time - you're never sure who pays them anyway - and suspension is the only worthwhile sanction.

I'm afraid I also take the 'unpatriotic' line when assessing the pitch in Galle. Yes, it suited the home side perfectly, but there is nothing new in that either.The quality of a pitch should be measured by how it plays, not how it looks. Given that five wickets had fallen in the match by lunch on the third day it is tricky to condemn the one in Galle. I do not subscribe to the view that England would have won the match if they had won what was admittedly a crucial toss. They would probably have avoided defeat. Moreover the English are not in a position to bleat about the state of the pitch in Galle (not that the management has done so in public). Consider all the recent three-day Tests at Edgbaston and Headingley on surfaces that have been ideally suited to England's strength, their seam attack. Those pitches may not have been wittingly prepared to aid the home side, but that is not a distinction that visiting sides are likely to make. England deserve sympathy after Galle. But self-pity and outrage are misplaced. To be fair to the tourists they appear to be avoiding that trap as the days trickle by before the Kandy Test. What they would like in Kandy is some reliable umpiring and some pace in the pitch, which gives all of their bowlers a chance to influence the game. Both may be forlorn hopes.

webTitle: Cricket: Arjuna Ranatunga on cricketing fair play

fields.headline: Forget bias - bat better
fields.standfirst:
Too much has been made about the quality of umpiring in the last Test. Let's face it, England deserved to lose, says Arjuna Ranatunga

Observer special report:England in Sri Lanka
fields.trailText: Too much has been made about the quality of umpiring in the last Test. Let's face it, England deserved to lose, says Arjuna Ranatunga.
fields.body: Too much has been made about the quality of umpiring in the last Test. Let's face it, England lost because they didn't play enough positive cricket. The bowlers concentrated on containment and the batsmen - Trescothick apart - on survival. That is no way to win. In my 20-year international career I was many times the victim and beneficiary of umpiring error. The results pretty much evened out, but I can see how a young player may feel their career threatened by an unfavourable decision. Still, all a batsman has to do to stop himself falling to umpiring error is to hit the ball with the middle of the bat. Umpiring error all too often merely compounds cricketing error. Where the umpires in the first Test went majorly wrong was in not cracking down as soon as they saw they the possibilities for frenzied appealing. If an umpire is to be anything more than a sweater-and-sunglass holder it has to be by way of the authority they exert on the field. They can and should control the tempo and conduct of a game. Anything beyond their immediate solution can be referred to the match referee via the radio-link or in between sessions. Yes, punishments should be more severe. Professional players should all be party to an authorised code of conduct. The passing of the great Bradman reminds us of a time when every cricketer in the world seemed to be united by a love of the game. Few were in it for the money. A Sri Lankan attitude too. It has amused me greatly to see the British press reaction to the events in Galle. I have been a keen supporter of twin neutral umpires in Tests and one-day internationals for a long time, because nothing galls me more than the insinuation that my team's victory was helped by even a hint of local bias or incompetence. Former players who are now correspondents know that fielding sides always send out a few appeals early on to test the parameters of an umpire's judgment and patience. We push it as far as it goes. It's not gamesmanship, it's professional cricket. It's life. To which cricket is a mirror. Englishmen who have never played competitively and yet still write about it tend to overlook the game's origins from well before the time of WG Grace and his gamey antics, Bodyline and the patronising bigotry of the cricketing establishment ever since. fields.headline: Observer books letters
fields.standfirst: Last week in World of Books, Robert McCrum made the case for the ten writers who should be taught in schools. Here are some of your responses. You can also read the original articles here The Canon
fields.trailText: Your responses to Robert McCrum's canonical list of ten authors who should be taught in schools.
fields.body:
I particularly support your stance on Shakespeare - but Milton, Pope, Woolf? We're talking about 14 to 16-year-olds for GCSE, and it's very difficult to envisage many of them coping in any meaningful way with such difficult writers. Joyce? - Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man perhaps - but certainly not Ulysses!

If we pitch the level so far above youngsters' ability and experience, they'll soon detest the very idea of reading. Enjoyment of more accessible fare (please consult some teachers or your children's literature reviewers!) will lead to tackling some of those mentioned - probably after A levels!
Rod Evans

 Writing from Canada - backwaterish despite British admiration and Booker lavishments for some of its writers - it is still something of a surprise to learn that the 'flower of English literature' must leave Americans to wilt among the weeds. At the very least room should be made for Melville. The greatest English novel of the 19th century may well be Middlemarch; the greatest novel in English of the 19th century is Moby-Dick. And why do the English still refuse to recognize Faulkner?
Karim Mamdani
Canada

 I'd have few grumbles with your canonical list (apart from the inclusion of Stevenson, Wilde in preference to Yeats, and the Brontes - those Woman's Weekly writers - as a possible alternative to Dickens, for heaven's sake!). But the chalk-face practicalities are against you.

For many years now, the young - even at A-level - have been simply unable to cope with the length, syntactical complexity and breadth of reference that they find in writers like Milton, Pope and Dickens. The cultural threads have been cut and one might as well give them some Pharaonic or Sumerian text to look at. For the young, the appeal has got to be pretty instant. Great writing demands patience. Why bother with Dickens when everything around them is screaming "Now! Now! Now!"?
Peter Sampson
Suffolk

 Normally my hackles would rise, but I can only be grateful that you actually forgot the existence of Wales in your pointless top ten exercise. It wasn't so much that you didn't choose any Welsh writers - on a canonical list of ten English-language writers I think that's probably fair enough. But you ignored Wales entirely. I think the two Thomases (RS and Dylan) at least deserve consideration, particularly Dylan for Under Milk Wood and maybe Deaths & Entrances.
Stevie Krayer

 I thoroughly enjoyed this engaging Top Ten with lots of irksome omissions. It is a vital antidote to the kind of philistinism inherent in a debates that's come to be caricatured in terms of kicking Shakespeare off the syllabus.

But there is also a danger here of trivialising a pernicious trend. The suggestion, as I understand it, is not merely to replace Shakespeare with Media Studies: the plan is to do away with the whole canon of literature in English. It isn't simply a case of developing a more popular and accessible syllabus - more black writers, women writers, living authors and contemporary themes. The report in The Guardian suggested that neo-Gradgrinds advising the DfEE advocated replacing classic fiction with 'applied' communication skills of temporary relevance to potential employers like 'Information Management'.

If those with the opportunity to influence attitudes to the teaching of literature fail to highlight the real issues in this debate, in thirty years only the narrowest of academic elites will be able to challenge the Literary Editor's top ten. But the less fortunate majority will be at least be able to express his dilemma over the inclusion of Pope, Sterne or Johnson in the form of an elegant flow-chart.
Andy Hedgecock
Nottingham

 A twenty-nine year old friend of mine has just discovered Shakespeare. He didn't do much at school and from the age of sixteen was a drug-addict and alcoholic. He has recently emerged from a long period of rehabilitation and joined our local amateur drama society where he discovered a talent for acting which had lain dormant for years.

His first part was Algernon in The Importance of Being Earnest in which he gave a remarkable performance. As carefully as possible I began to introduce him to Shakespeare. At first he was hostile, having the received street-wisdom that Shakespeare is crap, but I persevered and gave him a tape of Henry IV Part 1, together with the text. He read and listened. He has hardly ever read a book. I also gave him a copy of Just So Stories, to please me he read it and loved it, even reading The Butterfly That Stamped to his girlfriend in hospital.

I persuaded him to come down to London with us where he saw the RSC do Henry IV. He was absolutely bowled over. The rest of the week he saw Playboy of the Western World, The Importance, Six Characters in search of an Author, Merrily We Roll Along, and Mouth to Mouth. He's now in the process of learning audition pieces for drama school, one of which is a speech of Hotspur's. He can hardly believe the change in himself. I am so delighted for him.

It may be the theatre that has begun the magic transformation, or Shakespeare, or simply the wonderful power of words wielded by writers of genius. The finest literature is a unique combination of words and content - but I believe it's the words first that work the magic with their sounds and cadences, not politically correct messages fashionable for the times.
Michael Harvey
Blackpool

fields.headline: A shotgun wedding
fields.standfirst: Phil Mitchell might soon meet his maker - and he did meet his match in Sheila Hancock - while another former EastEnder tried to show his dark side
fields.trailText: Phil Mitchell might soon meet his maker - and he did meet his match in Sheila Hancock - while another former EastEnder tried to show his dark side
fields.body:
EastEnders BBC1
In Deep BBC1
Nearly Popstars ITV
Langan Behind the Lines BBC2
The West Wing C4

Who shot Phil Mitchell? So many people have strong motives it could even turn out to be JR, but just as with the Dallas shooting, the smart money is on the least interesting and most dispensable character (who remembers Kristin anyway?): yup, it just has to be Dan.

It was vintage EastEnders all week, culminating, of course, in the wedding of Steve and Mel, perhaps E20's most blindingly star-cross'd couple yet. Still, they know how to put a brave face on despair in Albert Square, so the prospect of even the grimmest nuptials is also an opportunity to wear a nice frock. Even desperate Lisa, Phil's ex-squeeze, who had spent Monday and Tuesday looking like a suicide risk, scrubbed up remarkably well for Mel's hen night, sparkly décolletage and all.

I wish Lisa would do something about those eyebrows, though - a pair of acute-grave caterpillars punctuating her face like the panstick crosses favoured by sad mimes. She's a pretty girl but there's something about those brows which scream 'victim'. No excuse for Phil to be quite so vile to her, of course ('Mel's got something you haven't, the ability to satisfy a man,' he hissed. 'But we had something special,' whined Lisa. 'No. You had something special. I had something convenient...'), but she really should pop up west and treat herself to a self-esteem-boosting professional pluck.

Martin Kemp's mum is Sheila Hancock! Gatecrashing the wedding (lovely registry office; surely not in the neighbourhood?) and wearing black with a magnificent hat, she looked just like Camilla Parker Bowles and sounded like Mystic Meg. 'So, tell me, do you know the bride?' she asked Phil, who'd also crashed and to whom, naturally, she took an instant shine. 'And, by the way, your lucky numbers are 7 and 11, your lucky colour is red and the winning Thunderball ticket is in the tea caddy.'

She and Phil made a great pair, and if Phil survives the shooting I hope they will go on to launch a suitably evil joint business venture - stealing dalmatian puppies, perhaps. In the meantime, however, Phil's got his hands full dealing with a long overdue karmic comeuppance for which there are really only two possible outcomes: Phil dies or, in hospital, he loses a lot of weight and turns into Keith Allen. Ooh, scary!

Until In Deep, ex-EastEnder Nick Berry, Mr Nice Guy, Housewives Fave, had never (to my knowledge) played a tortured soul and he isn't playing one now, to be honest. But I can see why, after a thousand years in Heartbeat and that dreadful bit of business by the seaside, he would want to stretch himself, slam a few doors, crease his pretty brow, run around with a shooter and sleep with women other than his wife, just as Ant and Dec will at some point want to appear at the Donmar in Waiting for Godot directed by Sam Mendes. Anyway, if Berry's inner turmoil remains just that - etched only on his insides - his undercover cop partner, Stephen Tompkinson, is distressingly hairy and anguished on the outside and surprisingly good at tortured. Then again, he's got even more emotional baggage than Berry, what with Ballykissangel.

Last week's undercover plot was a sordid though timely trawl through an internet paedophile ring. The Gretel Club was masterminded by Donald Sumpter (right up there with Frank Finlay as the very incarnation of smooth, silver-haired menace), his son and the local GP, while the female officer in charge of cracking the case announced she 'wouldn't settle for less' than life sentences for this lot of sleazebuckets, which was noble but naïve - hadn't she followed the Wonderland trial?

These days, there are far too many dramas relying on paedophiles to drive the plot. You can see why, but even when handled by Nick Berry with kid gloves - and no kids - it's not really a suitable subject for light entertainment, surely. And if the rabble who, last summer, conducted vigilante attacks on paediatricians can get it so wrong, what hope for the likes of Sumpter? Perhaps the News of the World might like to publish an at-risk register for all the poor jobbing thesps who have to play scum of the earth.

Though marginally less horrible than being a jobbing paedophile, life as a fading 'flopstar' still looks pretty grim. We caught up with the nation's favourite failures in Nearly Popstars, the same week that Hear'say (why didn't they just call the band Popstars and have done with it?) made their live debut (with an awful lot of backing singers) at the Brits. Anyway, the hilarious Darius (the tabloids' 'pain in the arius') is still full of it - 'Fame is like a drug. It's a dangerous thing and it has to be handled carefully' - while Claire of 'the unconventional image' (though the only unconventional thing about being fat is, surely, using the word 'unconventional' to describe it) now has herself a manager and a small part in an independent film, but has also declined the advances of established record labels in favour of starting her own (very bad move, Claire).

Sliding yet further down the slippery snake of the poptabulous fame game were Ian, Gary and David who had made the last 20 in Popstars but were now being stalked by Tam, a fat (unconventional?) manager who had two other lads waiting on the sidelines in order to construct a boy band destined for swift and profound failure.

Happily, the three flopstars recognised this and escaped, though unfortunately Ian - the one rejected by Nigel Lythgoe for looking too much like a used-car dealer - decided to go solo. He is now managed by a man called Andy who runs 'north Norfolk's first record label' from a caravan park and who quickly hauled Ian off to a high street photographer for some publicity pics, accessorised by a hubcap. 'Some facial shots,' instructed Andy, who is hoping to get sponsorship for Ian from local second-hand car dealers. I don't hold out much hope for Ian's facial shots or his pop future, but there is undoubtedly a great deal of comedy mileage to be had from Andy's career and I hope we'll be seeing much more of him.

While so much TV foreign correspondence is of the rather earnest, po-faced 'I've got a flak jacket and I'm going to use it' school of reporting, BBC2's Langan Behind the Lines was deeply entertaining and therefore compulsive viewing. Sean just isn't a flak-jacket type of guy which, at times, made his journey through the Middle East (from Afghanistan to Gaza, via Iran and Iraq) a bit like a moveable chat-show rather than a self-consciously improving documentary strand. I've known Sean for years, so initially I had no intention of reviewing Behind the Lines, but then it turned out to be best thing buried in last week's late-night schedules so it would have been churlish not to. Perhaps BBC2 was slightly embarrassed by the show's shameless accessibility, but it really should have been on at eight.

Langan was a guest on Wednesday's Midweek on Radio 4, during which Libby Purves mentioned that he was a former style journalist (the unspoken inference being that a former style journalist was highly unlikely to bring very much in the way of gravitas to a documentary series on the Middle East, though presumably plenty of pithy, if fluffy, observations on Islamic dress codes). Maybe Langan perceived this as a slight (he certainly ignored it) but he needn't have worried: I thought he managed to combine deep gravitas while reporting on the Taliban's trouser-wearing trends with a deft levity when it came to, say, the Gaza Strippers - though of course I would say that, given as I'm a fluffy style journalist whose interaction with the Middle East extends about as far as driving past Regent's Park mosque on the way to the office.

At last! In The West Wing, not only has Martin Sheen's First Lady returned from executing good Democrat deeds in Pakistan - or wherever it is she's been hiding in plot purdah for the last few weeks - but she turns out to be the magnificent Stockard Channing, too. I'm not sure if Hillary was encouraged to show off quite as much heaving embonpoint as Channing revealed during Thursday's awkward state dinner for the Indonesian President, but I love Mrs Bartlet's political style (a Badgley Mischka frock and Manolo Blahnik shoes). But then I would, wouldn't I?

webTitle: Observer review: Faking It by Nigel Planer

fields.headline: Two men and a little holistic therapy...
fields.standfirst: Nigel Planer takes a wry look at contemporary masculinity in his second novel, Faking It
fields.trailText: Nigel Planer takes a wry look at contemporary masculinity in his second novel, Faking It
fields.body:
Faking It
Nigel Planer
Hutchinson £9.99, pp184

When Andrea Fox, the apex of the love triangle at the heart of Nigel Planer's second novel, is found dead in a New York hotel room from a drugs overdose with a coarse pepper grinder intimately inserted in her, the two men in her life find themselves obliged to re-evaluate their own lives. For this is a novel about men in a society that has tried to redefine their role and reprogramme their intellect but can never override their genetic legacy.

Oliver Verbier, Andrea's much younger 'life-space-partner', is the epitome of all that twenty-first century middle-class men are expected to strive towards. An osteopath with a private practice who runs a self-awareness men's discussion group on Tuesdays and has devoted most of his adult life to eating organic food and sublimating his baser desires, Oliver is shy and well-meaning and ought to feel a sense of achievement in having raised his masculinity to a higher plane. So why does he feel such a guilty sense of relief at Andrea's death, and why can't he walk past a knicker advert without the inconvenience of a ferocious erection, and why on earth does he keep the phone number of a woman who likes to be spanked for money hidden in a biscuit tin?

At the other end of the spectrum is Barry Fox, Andrea's ex-husband and a thoroughly unreconstructed grubby columnist who owes thousands in back rent, cheerfully believes that women like to be objectified, and whose bloodstream is clotted with alcohol, nicotine, cannabis, cholesterol and pure self-loathing which finds its expression in fierce scathing anger at the STUPIDITY of the rest of the world, who are categorised variously as 'POOFTERS', 'BUTT-PLUNGING PISSANTS' or, worse still, 'frigging OSTEOPATHS'.

The two are drawn to each other in the aftermath of Andrea's death; Barry because he realises the Clapham house in which Oliver resides is still nominally his and is now worth £800,000, and Oliver because he's too weak to tell Barry to get lost. But when Barry drinks his way to a heart attack after a spectacular performance at Oliver's Tuesday club, and Oliver takes him in to recuperate, a kind of understanding develops as both begin to recognise their own deficiencies.

Although Planer's characters appear at first glance to be drawn according to easily recognisable types, his use of free indirect style, together with his acute ear for well-timed comic dialogue, allows them to accumulate psychological depth. Barry, in particular, is a magnificent comic creation with a fine arsenal of verbose and withering insults, and the polarisation of the two men gives Planer the chance to offer subtle apologetics for hard-wired male behaviour, and to watch both move towards what Oliver would call a more 'holistic' masculinity by hilariously adopting some of the other's traits.

Planer combines the novel's sustained humour with often tender insights into the confusion of men's emotions, but the comedy has the upper hand; Barry's night at the men's group is a perfectly paced comic scene balancing slapstick and wit, in the tradition of Kingsley Amis's Jim Dixon and his Merrie England lecture.

webTitle: Phone giants' brave new world still disconnected

fields.headline: Phone giants' brave new world still disconnected
fields.standfirst: They wax lyrical about third-generation mobile technology - but where is the must-have service, asks  Heather Connon
fields.trailText: They wax lyrical about third-generation mobile technology - but where is the must-have service, asks Heather Connon
fields.body:
Third generation mobile-phone services will transform our lives say the telecoms operators, painting a vision of a world in which we can switch on our central heating, order a pizza, download a film and invite our friends around to share them with us from the top of a bus on the way home from work.

The vision is alluring, but that is all. The techno-wonks will wax lyrical for hours on end about the possibilities of 3G. But so far, none of the mobile-phone companies has spelled out exactly what 3G services they will be offering, never mind how much we will pay for them.

Given the scale of investment in 3G, it is a worrying gap. Between them, Vodafone, Orange, BT and the European operators such as Deutsche Telecom and Telecom Italia will spend around €120 billion (£75bn) buying the licences alone.

Add in the costs of building the networks for 3G services - masts, switches and the like - and the cost soars to more than €300bn. So far, the focus has been on how the industry will finance that investment. But the key issue is now becoming how they will make a return on it.

'The costs of the network are not the critical things for the operator,' said Mike Grant, head of the mobile communications division at consultants Analysys , one of the advisers to the British government on the sale of 3G licences. 'What is critical is the amount they will have to spend on developing the services - marketing them, subsidising the move to new handsets and so on. You have to look at what you think that will cost per customer per year to attract and keep them, and what you can generate from them.'

Analysys's calculation sounds daunting. On its models, the average revenue per user (ARPU) has to rise by between 60 and 100 per cent in real terms over the next 10 years to give the operators a return of between 20 and 25 per cent on their investment. Given that ARPU has been declining for three years as more and more people take up cheaper pre-paid services, and that competition is forcing rates down even further, it looks like a tall order.

Analysys does expect the industry to fall into loss over the next four to five years. But, adds Grant, the ability to offer services such as betting, videogames and other entertainment over handsets means there is more than enough in the pie to generate that kind of revenue. He points to the success of i-mode, the data service launched by NTT DoCoMo in Japan, to support his case.

By the end of February, i-mode had 19.6 million subscribers, double the number just six months ago. Its recent results show that 10 per cent of its revenue is now coming from these new data services, which has meant its ARPU has stopped falling and is now flat.

Others dismiss the i-mode example, saying the Japanese are technophiles who take to new gadgets with far more enthusiasm than the rest of us. But Grant points out that much of i-mode's revenue comes from customers downloading ringing tones and logos of their favourite comic character, which they can then send on to their friends.

As any rail traveller will testify, everyone loves a personalised ringing tone. In Finland, for example, 10 million were downloaded last year - a cost of around £1 a shot - in a population of just 3 million.

But 3G must be about more than just making your phone sound like waves breaking on a tropical beach. Where is the killer application, the service that will make a 3G phone a must-have for every mobile user? So far, noone seems to have come up with the answer.

Mark James, telecoms analyst at Nomura, said there was 'very little discussion of services' at the 3G congress held last month in Cannes. Some are debating whether it is possible to emulate the runaway success of text messaging by combining it with something like AOL's Buddy system, which tells you when friends are online.

Even that, however, has been inconclusive.Text messaging has been one of the unexpected successes of the mobile phone era. Dismissed initially, it now provides more than 5 per cent of revenues and usage is growing rapidly.

Stephen Pentland of Spectrum Consulting, which has advised a number of governments on 3G licence auctions, says there is 'an enormous degree of excitement about the potential' of text messaging. They could be used, for example, to remind you when your favourite soap opera is on, or to give you a preview of it; to give you the football results; or as an interactive tool allowing you to vote on the ending to a film.

But he questions whether the operators are doing enough to realise that potential. Few are talking to television or sports companies about ways of packaging the services to make them attractive to users. 'They are trying to develop their own portals. But they need a willingness to learn what makes the content interesting to users,' he said.

The operators themselves seem to have only a vague idea of what they will actually be offering. Vodafone, for example, said: 'We hope to become a global supermarket, not just a distributor of products and services. We want to make it possible for people to control and run their lives from their mobile devices.'

When pressed on exactly how that will happen, however, he simply points to Vodafone's internet portal, Vizzavi. Intel, the US electronics giant, attributes the lack of progress partly to the lack of a common standard, or platform, around which software providers can work. That, he says, is what revolutionised the personal computer market. 'If your PC only had the applications which were on it when you bought it, the popularity would not be as broad as it is today,' said Intel's Leif Persson. 'It is the fact that you can add services to it that makes it popular.'

Intel is interested in selling its personal internet client architecture but, even so, Persson has a point. The mobile industry needs to encourage an army of software developers to devise products we can use on our phones in the hope that one of them becomes the 'killer' application that will persuade us to fork out not just for the handset but for the kind of services that will make 3G a respectable investment.

James' forecasts, which do envisage a decent return on 3G investment eventually, are based on everyone in Britain having a phone - at the moment, around 60 per cent of us has a mobile - and spending 3 per cent of their income on its services, up from the current 2 per cent. But he points out that the service is not perfect - interrupted calls are the norm, phoning anywhere outside the country is tedious and text messaging numbs the fingers.

The industry has some way to go to convince us that it can make a go of the next generation.

webTitle: The juggling unicyclist who changed our lives

fields.headline: The juggling unicyclist who changed our lives
fields.trailText: Claude Shannon, who has died at 84, was little known outside his field. But every time we make a phone call, play a CD or connect to the net we incur a debt to him, because we are using technologies that derive from his pioneering insight into the nature of information and the process of communication.
fields.body:
Claude Shannon, who has died at 84, was little known outside his field. But every time we make a phone call, play a CD or connect to the net we incur a debt to him, because we are using technologies that derive from his pioneering insight into the nature of information and the process of communication.

The very argot of the wired world, with its talk of megabits per second, sampling and bandwidth, was first articulated by Shannon in an epoch-making paper, 'The Mathematical Theory of Communication', published in the Bell System Journal in 1948.

It was, as one expert put it, 'the Magna Carta of the Information Age'. Shannon changed the nature of communications theory - from guesswork to science.

He defined information in terms of reduction of uncertainty; he transformed the process of communication into something that could be empirically studied; he proposed quantitative measures of the effectiveness of com munications systems; and he inspired the data compression and error correction methods which make digital communications so much more reliable than their analogue predecessors, and enable our modems to talk to the net with such assurance.

More than that, wherever one looks into the early history of computing and the net, one finds Shannon's fingerprints. In the Thirties at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, for example, he worked with Vannevar Bush and Norbert Wiener on the first analogue computers.

He went on to collaborate with Bush on the information retrieval machines which led Bush to conceive Memex, the device which the world first heard about in 1945 and which became the inspiration for the invention, 45 years later, of the world wide web.

Shannon's intellect was like an exceedingly powerful searchlight, illuminating everything it touched. As a young student he wrote a master's thesis which was later described (by an eminent historian of technology) as 'one of the most important master's theses ever written... a landmark in that it helped to change digital circuit design from an art to a science'. (He received his master's and doctoral degrees at the same ceremony.)

His 1949 paper on 'Communication Theory of Secrecy Systems' caused such a radical upheaval in the way spooks thought about their tools that it was itself a classified document.

Yet visitors to MIT or Bell Labs who expected a fiercely austere mathematician were invariably discombobulated by the man himself. Shannon retained the restless curiosity of a bright puppy. He was an accomplished juggler and unicyclist (and could conduct both activities simultaneously); he was also a passionate inventor of clever but spectacularly useless devices.

For example, he designed a petrol-powered pogo-stick, several early chess-playing machines, a maze-solving mouse, a two-seated unicycle, a 100-blade jack-knife, a machine to solve the Rubik cube and a computer that calculated in Roman numerals.

But Shannon's pride and joy was his 'Ultimate Machine', which was based on an idea of Marvin Minsky, and described by Arthur C. Clarke in Voice Across the Sea. 'Nothing could be simpler,' wrote Clarke. 'It is merely a small wooden casket, the size and shape of a cigar box, with a single switch on one face.

'When you throw the switch, there is an angry, purposeful buzzing. The lid slowly rises, and from beneath it emerges a hand. The hand reaches down, turns the switch off, and retreats into the box. With the finality of a closing coffin, the lid snaps shut, the buzzing ceases and peace reigns once more.

'The psychological effect, if you do not know what to expect, is devastating. There is something unspeakably sinister about a machine that does absolutely nothing except switch itself off.'
