webTitle: Observer Focus: Is theatre a rip-off?

fields.headline: Will the cost turn drama into a crisis?
fields.standfirst: After director Richard Eyre branded theatre a rip-off, Vanessa Thorpe went out to see if audiences agree
fields.trailText: After director Richard Eyre branded theatre a rip-off, Vanessa Thorpe went out to see if audiences agree.
fields.body:
The audience at London's Old Vic theatre on Friday night had come along to witness the claustrophobic discomfort of the bourgeoisie in Yasmina Reza's new hit play, Life x 3. In fact, they need only have looked around them. Standing in the grand foyer, the assembled theatre-goers were a study in self-conscious gentility.

'Oh, good! It's got Imelda Staunton in it! I haven't ever seen a duff play here so I hope this one is OK too,' said one woman. 'Is it going to be one of those depressing plays you have to go out and have several bottles of wine to recover from, I wonder?' asked another.

The sentiments echoed comments by Sir Richard Eyre, former artistic director of the Royal National Theatre. At a conference last week he chose to come clean about the 'head-burning, ball-breaking, bowel-churning' badness of much of British theatre. He didn't mean it in a nice way either. He went on to suggest there should be a radical change in the way theatre is looked at in this country. He called on the Government to make tickets much cheaper and to promote drama in schools.

Eyre's words come at a sensitive time for theatre. For a start, the row he has started deliberately heralds the announcement this Thursday of the Arts Council of England's funding grants to regional theatres. This will be the first part of an extra £25 million promised to theatre by government last year and it is to go, in the main, to producing theatres, touring theatres, black theatre and children's theatre. It will also disappoint several companies struggling for survival.

Last Wednesday Tony Blair was visited at Downing Street by a 'think-tank' of creative talent who hoped to impress upon him the importance of standing up for the arts. The group of 15 leading figures, including John Tusa of the Barbican, theatre director Jude Kelly and Nicholas Serota of the Tate, argued that it should not be electorally embarrassing for a politician to admit to enjoying a bit of Ibsen.

'To have the arts off the passionate agenda is simply not good enough,' said Kelly, the outspoken and Olivier award-winning director of the West Yorkshire Playhouse, as she criticised New Labour for only associating themselves with theatre behind closed doors and 'among consenting adults'. 'The greatest achievements in the arts are a mixture of extraordinary technique and visionary imagination. That can be hard to achieve and hard to understand,' she said.

Then, the very next day, Eyre - one of their own - broke ranks and branded the art form a high-brow 'rip-off'.

On Friday night the punters at the Old Vic were certainly aware of the cost. 'I need a programme and I am going to get one,' announced one patron, 'but if it's a rip-off, I won't buy one because I don't like being ripped off.' He came back without a £3 programme.

In London, theatre-going is certainly an expensive hobby. With a booking fee, programmes and drinks, an evening for two will set you back in the region of £70. At the end of Reza's play, which follows her phenomenally successful Art, the audience were philosophical about the cost. Margaret Crawford, a 30-year-old financial manager, said it was not that much in comparison with the cost of a night spent clubbing: 'I might not have paid this much when I was younger, but I think if you really want to see something you can save up £32.50,' she said.

The prices are about the same around the West End. Jane Doyle, 35, and her husband Joe had paid £32.50 each to see Amanda Donohoe as Mrs Robinson in The Graduate, but Mr Doyle was disappointed by the production. In the rest of Britain a visit to the theatre makes less of a hole in your wallet. A ticket to the acclaimed (and subsidised) Traverse Theatre in Edinburgh is £9, while at Kelly's Leeds base, the best seats are £22. The Bristol Old Vic has a top price of £20.

Last year when the chairman of the Arts Council of England, Gerry Robinson, called for new theatre funding and won the promise of extra cash, he argued that subsidised theatre was the lifeblood of the more popular work that ends up in the West End.

Yet Thursday's new allocation of funds will mean the end of two or three small theatres. Among those threatened are The Swan in Worcester, the Gateway in Chester, The Theatre Royal in York and The Warehouse in Croydon. While they may have had hopes raised by the talk of new money, the Arts Council has not prioritised their needs.

Instead, there will be special support for new writing, as more than 200 theatre organisations receive increases from £10,000 to £450,000. A focus on ethnic minority theatre and on children is to be reflected in the grants too. Theatre Rites, a company that produces high quality drama for children and families, is likely to receive £120,000. Touring has also been given priority, with an extra total investment of £4.3m for 85 companies. English Touring Theatre is to receive £656,000 by 2003/04.

Shadow arts minister Peter Ainsworth believes the whole existence of the Arts Council should be questioned in the run-up to the general election. 'At the moment the organisation is really Blair's poodle,' he told The Observer. 'We need a radical re-think of arts funding. It is very odd to have an organisation that exists solely for the purpose of handing out money.'

Ainsworth believes there will continue to be a major problem with regional theatre funding and with the weight of bureaucracy imposed by layers of different grant-giving bodies. 'Theatre needs less control, not more,' he said. 'The current system is shabby and tries to make artists conform to government ideas. That is never a good thing. Politicians should not be concerned with deciding what is good art and what is bad art. We should support the venues and arts education instead.'

Those who visit subsidised theatre will know that the ticket prices can be just as high as they are in the West End, although the experience is often considerably less comfortable.

A cheaper evening spent in the cinema may seem more appealing, but, as the Arts Council points out, most of our favourite film stars were actually trained in subsidised theatre: Dr Hannibal Lector, aka Sir Anthony Hopkins, was a member of the Phoenix Theatre company in Leicester.

Back in 1963 Sir Derek Jacobi, last seen on the big screen as a Roman senator in Gladiator, performed with the lowly Chichester Festival Theatre in Shaw's Saint Joan; the Oscar-winning Dame Judi Dench has worked with the Nottingham Playhouse and enjoyed three seasons with Oxford Playhouse; and Helen Mirren made her theatrical debut at age 18 as Cleopatra in Antony and Cleopatra at the Old Vic in 1965.

It has not been lost on some that as the Government puts together its arts policy document for the election, the most difficult play to get tickets for in London is Feelgood, at the subsidised Hampstead Theatre. It is a satire about New Labour spin-doctors.
fields.bodyText: The audience at London's Old Vic theatre on Friday night had come along to witness the claustrophobic discomfort of the bourgeoisie in Yasmina Reza's new hit play, Life x 3. In fact, they need only have looked around them. Standing in the grand foyer, the assembled theatre-goers were a study in self-conscious gentility. 'Oh, good! It's got Imelda Staunton in it! I haven't ever seen a duff play here so I hope this one is OK too,' said one woman. 'Is it going to be one of those depressing plays you have to go out and have several bottles of wine to recover from, I wonder?' asked another. The sentiments echoed comments by Sir Richard Eyre, former artistic director of the Royal National Theatre. At a conference last week he chose to come clean about the 'head-burning, ball-breaking, bowel-churning' badness of much of British theatre. He didn't mean it in a nice way either. He went on to suggest there should be a radical change in the way theatre is looked at in this country. He called on the Government to make tickets much cheaper and to promote drama in schools. Eyre's words come at a sensitive time for theatre. For a start, the row he has started deliberately heralds the announcement this Thursday of the Arts Council of England's funding grants to regional theatres. This will be the first part of an extra £25 million promised to theatre by government last year and it is to go, in the main, to producing theatres, touring theatres, black theatre and children's theatre. It will also disappoint several companies struggling for survival. Last Wednesday Tony Blair was visited at Downing Street by a 'think-tank' of creative talent who hoped to impress upon him the importance of standing up for the arts. The group of 15 leading figures, including John Tusa of the Barbican, theatre director Jude Kelly and Nicholas Serota of the Tate, argued that it should not be electorally embarrassing for a politician to admit to enjoying a bit of Ibsen. 'To have the arts off the passionate agenda is simply not good enough,' said Kelly, the outspoken and Olivier award-winning director of the West Yorkshire Playhouse, as she criticised New Labour for only associating themselves with theatre behind closed doors and 'among consenting adults'. 'The greatest achievements in the arts are a mixture of extraordinary technique and visionary imagination. That can be hard to achieve and hard to understand,' she said. Then, the very next day, Eyre - one of their own - broke ranks and branded the art form a high-brow 'rip-off'. On Friday night the punters at the Old Vic were certainly aware of the cost. 'I need a programme and I am going to get one,' announced one patron, 'but if it's a rip-off, I won't buy one because I don't like being ripped off.' He came back without a £3 programme. In London, theatre-going is certainly an expensive hobby. With a booking fee, programmes and drinks, an evening for two will set you back in the region of £70. At the end of Reza's play, which follows her phenomenally successful Art, the audience were philosophical about the cost. Margaret Crawford, a 30-year-old financial manager, said it was not that much in comparison with the cost of a night spent clubbing: 'I might not have paid this much when I was younger, but I think if you really want to see something you can save up £32.50,' she said. The prices are about the same around the West End. Jane Doyle, 35, and her husband Joe had paid £32.50 each to see Amanda Donohoe as Mrs Robinson in The Graduate, but Mr Doyle was disappointed by the production. In the rest of Britain a visit to the theatre makes less of a hole in your wallet. A ticket to the acclaimed (and subsidised) Traverse Theatre in Edinburgh is £9, while at Kelly's Leeds base, the best seats are £22. The Bristol Old Vic has a top price of £20. Last year when the chairman of the Arts Council of England, Gerry Robinson, called for new theatre funding and won the promise of extra cash, he argued that subsidised theatre was the lifeblood of the more popular work that ends up in the West End. Yet Thursday's new allocation of funds will mean the end of two or three small theatres. Among those threatened are The Swan in Worcester, the Gateway in Chester, The Theatre Royal in York and The Warehouse in Croydon. While they may have had hopes raised by the talk of new money, the Arts Council has not prioritised their needs. Instead, there will be special support for new writing, as more than 200 theatre organisations receive increases from £10,000 to £450,000. A focus on ethnic minority theatre and on children is to be reflected in the grants too. Theatre Rites, a company that produces high quality drama for children and families, is likely to receive £120,000. Touring has also been given priority, with an extra total investment of £4.3m for 85 companies. English Touring Theatre is to receive £656,000 by 2003/04. 'At the moment the organisation is really Blair's poodle,' he told The Observer. 'We need a radical re-think of arts funding. It is very odd to have an organisation that exists solely for the purpose of handing out money.' Ainsworth believes there will continue to be a major problem with regional theatre funding and with the weight of bureaucracy imposed by layers of different grant-giving bodies. 'Theatre needs less control, not more,' he said. 'The current system is shabby and tries to make artists conform to government ideas. That is never a good thing. Politicians should not be concerned with deciding what is good art and what is bad art. We should support the venues and arts education instead.' Those who visit subsidised theatre will know that the ticket prices can be just as high as they are in the West End, although the experience is often considerably less comfortable. webTitle: Comment: revenge is among the motives for Afghan vandalism

fields.headline: 'Heritage terrorism' is a way of sticking two fingers up at West
fields.standfirst: Neal Ascherson says revenge is among the motives for Afghan vandalism
fields.trailText: Neal Ascherson says revenge is among the motives for Afghan vandalism.
fields.body:
Smashing images is as old as human hatred. Anyone inclined to priggishness about the Taliban's mass execution of statues in Afghanistan need only visit the Lady Chapel at Ely cathedral. There, Puritan hammer-men obliterated the heads of saints, prophets and angels. That chapel remains one of the most heartbreaking sights in England. But in Europe as well as Asia and Africa, the loaded word 'idols' has covered countless crimes.

Sometimes it is a monotheist religion like Christianity or Islam which demands the destruction of sacred effigies. The Old Testament is full of idols wrecked by righteous Jewish prophets. The Reformation unleashed popular violence against tens of thousands of Madonnas and saints. Pious Hindus remember still how Islamic raiders wrecked the images in the mighty temple of Somnath, Gujerat, in the 10th century.

Political hatred also massacres statues. When American troops captured Koblenz in 1945, they spent a lot of ammunition shelling down the gigantic statue of Emperor Wilhelm I of Germany. In 1871, the revolutionaries of the Paris Commune demolished the statue of Napoleon on the Vendôme column. As a spectator, I will never forget the frantic Moscow festival in 1991 as the colossal bronze figure of Feliks Dzerzhinsky, founder of the first KGB, was executed outside the Lubyanka.

What the Taliban are doing has two aims. One is nationalist as much as religious. It is to invent a completely new, completely untrue past for Afghanistan, in which no trace of any other religion or empire or regime apart from their own can be found. Afghanistan will soon never have been Buddhist, never have formed part of a semi-Greek Bactrian empire, never have become a subject territory of Britain and Russia, never have been a 20th-century kingdom setting off along the path of Third World development. An Afghan will now see only a Taliban eternity.

The second motive is a mixture of revenge and reproach. The Taliban leaders are hurt by the West's disgust with them. They know the rich West cares desperately about the archaeological heritage of Afghanistan; this is a way to hit back. In this sense, the two Buddhas of Bamiyan, now being executed, were the tallest hostages in the world.

An Indian archaeologist said to me: 'This is raising two fingers to the West. It's heritage terrorism; it's about holding objects to ransom rather than about appropriating them.'

The Taliban, however, are not the only Afghans to find the outcry hypocritical. The warlord Ahmed Shah Masood, still fighting the Taliban, asked on Friday why the West was so upset about statues but cared nothing for the misery of the Afghan people. Others pointed out that the countries protesting most loudly - Japan, for example - were those whose collectors were most eagerly snapping up the torrent of stolen antiquities which has been pouring out of war-torn Afghanistan for 20 years.

A British Museum conference yesterday heard shocking descriptions of the looting of sites. Robert Knox, director of the Department of Oriental Antiquities, gave the latest news on the demolitions, and pledged the British Museum to take part in any international programme to save what remains of Afghanistan's heritage.

Related story
Idols are reduced to rubble

webTitle: Croats vote to secede from Bosnia

fields.headline: Croats vote to secede from Bosnia
fields.trailText: The biggest threat to the structure of the peace treaty which ended the bloody carnage in Bosnia was delivered yesterday when a rebel assembly of Bosnian Croats voted to unilaterally secede from the precarious federation which Croatians in Bosnia pledged to share with Muslims at the Dayton treaty of 1995.
fields.body:
The biggest threat to the structure of the peace treaty which ended the bloody carnage in Bosnia was delivered yesterday when a rebel assembly of Bosnian Croats voted to unilaterally secede from the precarious federation which Croatians in Bosnia pledged to share with Muslims at the Dayton treaty of 1995.

The language of the communiqué that followed a congress of the party affiliated to the late Croatian president, Franjo Tudjman, bears all the hallmarks of that which sparked the wars that tore ex-Yugoslavia apart, and especially that between the erstwhile Croatian and Muslim allies, which it echoes exactly.

In the still divided and symbolically charged city of Mostar, with a rain-drenched crowd of thousands cheering outside, the Bosnian branch of Dr Tudjman's HDZ party resurrected their wartime demand for autonomy, setting themselves on a collision course with Western leaders and ratcheting up the rising tension in the Balkans by yet another notch.

Ante Javelic, leader of the dominant HDZ in Bosnia, said that unless electoral changes were made to the federation's constitution and electoral system within 15 days, the Croats would form their own 'inter-cantonal' system of government - effectively ripping up the Dayton treaty, spurning the Sarajevo government and returning to the demands of the Bosnian Croat army that fought the Muslims throughout 1993.

Both the language and tactics of the announcement exactly echo some of the darkest days of the Bosnian war.

Javelic's sudden proclamation also coincides with a revived hard-line nationalism within Croatia and mass demonstrations in the coastal port of Split, with tens of thousands protesting against arrests by The Hague tribunal of leading figures under president Tudjman's regime.

The electoral changes the HDZ seeks are those which draw constituency lines irrespective of ethnicity, which dilutes the power of nationalist parties and favours reformist and multi-ethnic ones.

Mr Javelic said the threat of self-rule was a 'temporary' one, but that the party - which dominates the Croatian area of Herzegovina - had in mind to rewrite Dayton to organise Bosnia into a canton system based around the three ethnic groups. The council would assume legislative, judicial and executive powers.

Western diplomats indicated yesterday they would not tolerate the Croatian plan. One US State Department official who has monitored Bosnia for a decade said: 'It looks like the wheels are turning again. It just cannot and will not happen.'

Wolfgang Petritsch, the West's top peace overseer in Bosnia vested with sweeping powers, told Bosnians in a personal message on Friday that he would not tolerate 'activities aimed at undermining the legal institutions'. Those engaged in illegal activities would be liable to sanctions, he added.

The Croatian daily Vecernji List, quoting an unnamed Sarajevo-based Western diplomat, said the West was preparing a set of stiff sanctions, including a ban on foreign investment in Croat territories, closure of foreign companies' branches there and a block on the accounts of HDZ-controlled companies.

fields.headline: Astonish us, Mr Brown
fields.standfirst: The Chancellor should be bolder
fields.trailText: The Chancellor should be bolder
fields.body:
Under the chancellor's watch Britain has enjoyed four years of growth, low inflation and employment generation. He has quietly distributed more income to the bottom 10 per cent than any other Labour chancellor, and is set to launch a period of sustained investment in public services unmatched since the war. If Labour can survive a succession of small scandals with its opinion poll lead undented, it is largely due to Mr Brown's stewardship of the economy - which he will seal with his fifth budget on Wednesday.

A mark of his success is that the Conservatives now set their policies within his agenda. Gone are Tory promises of across-the-board tax cuts or scaremongering about Labour's tax bombshells. Instead Mr Hague has promised to match Labour's spending plans on health, education, transport and crime trying to emulate Mr Brown's targeted approach to tax cuts.

Mr Brown will continue in the same vein on Wednesday. Despite sniping from the IMF, which worries insanely that it is improper for governments to borrow to finance capital investment, the Chancellor has an embarrassment of riches. His surplus this year will match last year's £16 billion, allowing him scope to cut taxes or raise spending by up to £5bn next financial year and still meet his own rules of fiscal probity.

He is expected to produce a balanced package, focusing on additional help to children and pensioners while promising a build-up of social investment in Britain's depressed cities and towns. All this will be widely welcomed and will come on top of a substantial £14bn spending programme aimed at children, poorer families and pensioners, based on decisions he took last year. The effects of all this will be felt this this year. Why not use the £5bn to make a real difference by focusing all of it on one or two agenda-setting projects?

Here are some suggestions. The Chancellor could commit to reducing class sizes in primary schools to the best in the world (£3bn) while launching a five-year programme of urban regeneration to rebuild Britain's poorest 10 cities (£2bn per annum). Or he could bring forward his ambitions to halve child poverty by 2010 to 2005 (£2.5bn a year) and increase the state pension by £5 a week (£2.5bn a year). Or he could follow the example of America's 120 billionaires and come out strongly in favour of inheritance and capital gains tax, raising sufficient to finance all four spending programmes. We expect the more cautious package - but we would be delighted to be surprised.

fields.headline: The price of pain
fields.standfirst: Justice should not bow to greed
fields.trailText: Justice should not bow to greed.
fields.body:
Anger and puzzlement have quite naturally greeted the award of £330,000 to a retired police officer in compensation for the 'late onset' of post-traumatic stress after the Hillsborough football disaster in 1989. It is 100 times more than awards received by the families of those who died and by surviving victims. It far exceeds the niggardly £8,100 given to nursery nurse Lisa Potts who heroically protected children in her care from a machete attack. The policeman's lot, after all, is not supposed to be an altogether happy one: it includes exposure to unpleasant and shocking things.

The dangers of a burgeoning compensation culture, driven by lawyers, are becoming apparent. Applications to employment tribunals have soared, from about 50,000 in 1989 to more than 160,000 last year, and the trend is being accelerated by the Human Rights Act. The change is partly mechanistic, a response to new legislation, but partly cultural. Britain's conservative approach to damages began to break down in the 1980s and the revolution has lately gathered pace. Lawyers now solicit business on a 'no win no fee' basis, while advertisements on buses and trains, by inviting us to consider whether we have any potentially remunerative grievances, offer a legal lottery ticket.

Along with much of our popular culture, we are importing American litigiousness where minor grievances, like burns from scalding coffee, can attract ludicrous awards. The right to fair and reasonable compensation for a genuine wrong is an inviolable right, but a mania for going to law to right flimsy wrongs is highly undesirable. It enriches the legal profession but subverts society, turning it into a kind of gaming house where justice is tainted by greed.

fields.headline: Good knight out
fields.standfirst: There's more to him than hot Eyre
fields.trailText: There's more to him than hot Eyre.
fields.body:
When Sir Richard Eyre stepped into the limelight to complain about the 'head-burningly, ball-breakingly, bowel-churningly' work he regularly comes across on Britain's stages, many theatregoers must have wondered exactly which productions he had found quite so involving or, at least, what the good knight had been drinking during the interval.

Demoralised and neglected, reduced to relying on tired revivals, most regional directors would love the chance to 'churn' up some bowels with 'head-burning' new plays. The Arts Council grants to be announced this week will allow some of them to do this, thereby securing a training ground for the inspirational film and stage stars of the future.

Sir Richard's own towering performance has also set an example to his thespian colleagues. He has energised the debate and reminded sceptics that purchasing a ticket for the theatre is potentially as rewarding, or painful, as a punt on a horse in the Grand National. His dramatic monologue is a reminder of the talent we have in this country and of what old-fashioned passion can do to an audience.

webTitle: Letters: Where is compassion in mental health care?

fields.headline: Where is compassion in mental health care?
fields.trailText: Magnus Linklater (Review, last week) presents a vivid account of what has been wrong with mental health care but leaves the impression that nothing is happening to put it right.
fields.body:
Magnus Linklater (Review, last week) presents a vivid account of what has been wrong with mental health care but leaves the impression that nothing is happening to put it right.

In fact, a transformation of services in England is under way. The NHS Plan made mental health one of three clinical priorities and committed new money to tackle the problems that have plagued community care. New services will offer prompt treatment for young people becoming ill for the first time, prevent vulnerable and high-risk patients from drifting out of contact, provide the single, constantly available point-of-access that patients and their families need to head off a crisis, and allow home treatment as an alternative to hospital admission. But a comprehensive service also needs decent wards and there are plans to ensure that hospitals offer both modern treatment and old-fashioned sanctuary.

Your editorial was wrong in implying that the Government is interested only in public protection.
Professor Louis Appleby
National Director for Mental Health in England
Manchester

 We have been through most of the agonies highlighted in Magnus Linklater's article. Our daughter suffered from schizophrenia and committed suicide some years ago at the age of 21. It was a great help to see all this put into perspective and to try to still come to terms with all the injustice. It is worth noting that coroners are prevented by law from bringing a verdict of 'lack of care'. Suffice it to say we continue to battle for better treatment and care for sufferers of mental illness.
Carol and John Schiller
Barnstaple
North Devon

 Magnus Linklater's article eloquently describes watching a loved relative suffering from manic depression and seeing how current services fail to provide the help both his son and his carers need.

Having said that, he cannot get away with his attack on the policy of community care. The old long-stay institutions did not provide a setting where people with long-term mental health problems were cared for with compassion. These were squalid places that further disabled those who, with proper care, could lead more valued lives in the 'normal' world.
Jeremy Ross
London SW16

 Thank you to Magnus Linklater for his deeply felt account of the decline of NHS psychiatry services over the last decade. The period he describes happens to cover my own professional career in child and adolescent psychiatry and I echo his feelings. We need more and more writers like Mr Linklater to tell us this in plain language and with outrage until we wake up and realise that what we have all complacently taken such (increasingly sentimental) pride in is becoming an embarrassment, and we decide to do something radical about it.
Dr Jonathan Green
Department of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry
Booth Hall Children's Hospital, Manchester

Read the article
A tale of ordinary madness

It was a great help to see all this put into perspective and to try to still come to terms with all the injustice. It is worth noting that coroners are prevented by law from bringing a verdict of 'lack of care'. Suffice it to say we continue to battle for better treatment and care for sufferers of mental illness. Having said that, he cannot get away with his attack on the policy of community care. The old long-stay institutions did not provide a setting where people with long-term mental health problems were cared for with compassion. These were squalid places that further disabled those who, with proper care, could lead more valued lives in the 'normal' world. The period he describes happens to cover my own professional career in child and adolescent psychiatry and I echo his feelings. We need more and more writers like Mr Linklater to tell us this in plain language and with outrage until we wake up and realise that what we have all complacently taken such (increasingly sentimental) pride in is becoming an embarrassment, and we decide to do something radical about it. webTitle: Anti-racists take on Hong Kong's secret shame

fields.headline: Anti-racists take on Hong Kong's secret shame
fields.trailText: When Harinder Veriah had an epileptic fit more than a year ago, no one realised it would trigger a chain of events that have helped expose Hong Kong's great 'dirty secret'.
fields.byline: by Steve Vines in Hong Kong
fields.body:
When Harinder Veriah had an epileptic fit more than a year ago, no one realised it would trigger a chain of events that have helped expose Hong Kong's great 'dirty secret'.

On 2 January 2000 Veriah, known to her friends as Hari, died. Shortly before, she told her husband, the British journalist Martin Jacques, that she was at the 'bottom of the pile' at the hospital where she was being treated. She meant her skin colour and Indian race were responsible for a lack of attention.

Today an unusually large coalition of 12 organisations, including Indian, Filipino, Thai and Nepalese groups, is holding a memorial for Veriah and meeting to campaign for anti-racial discrimination legislation.

Vandana Rajwani, a lawyer who is one of the meeting's organisers, says they have been inundated with people wanting to participate.

This is something new. Campaigners had been finding it very hard to raise public awareness of the problems facing the ethnic communities that make up about 4 per cent of the population. However Veriah's death has given new life to the campaign. Ravi Kidumal, another organiser of today's meeting, said: 'This was such an emotive issue, such a personal issue, that it raised our consciousness.'

Local newspapers had published the story of how this bright, Malaysian-born lawyer had suddenly died in circumstances which do not usually cause death. It was a deeply personal story of a love affair shattered by death, of a mother leaving behind an infant son and of a potentially brilliant career suddenly terminated.

An inquest at the end of last year did not accept allegations that Veriah's death was related to neglect stemming from racial discrimination and found that she died of natural causes. Jacques is unhappy with the verdict and remains convinced that racial discrimination was a factor.

'Hari's case moved people,' says Christine Loh, a former legislator who unsuccessfully battled for two years to introduce laws against racial discrimination. 'It was because Martin, a white person, was prepared to stand up and say there is a great dirty secret in Hong Kong that people listened'.

'In a society where they do listen to whites but don't listen to people with darker skins, I was able to do something,' says Jacques. His insistence that his wife's death was linked to discrimination encouraged members of ethnic minorities to write to newspapers about their experiences. 'Hari's case has become a catalyst,' says Jacques.

Kidumal insists that racism is a big problem but that 'the affected people are very cautious about doing anything about it'. He says that Indian business organisations shy away because they do not want to be associated with controversy. Yet they represent the biggest minority group in Hong Kong.

Ethnic Indians like Kidumal, who are born and bred in Hong Kong, cannot obtain passports issued by the Hong Kong government because it follows Chinese nationality law which denies citizenship to those who are not of Chinese race. According to the government racism is not a problem. Kwan Wing-wah, the Deputy Secretary for Home Affairs, says: 'Hong Kong is a tolerant and cosmopolitan society where persons of every race, colour and nationality live together in a remarkable degree of harmony'.

Loh says people are denied housing, jobs and school places on grounds of race and that casual racism pervades Hong Kong culture.

webTitle: Pre-teen puberty is a myth, claim doctors

fields.headline: Pre-teen puberty is a myth, claim doctors
fields.standfirst: Meanwhile, scientists reignite debate on when girls become women
fields.trailText: Claims that the age of puberty is plummeting among girls in Western nations have been challenged by a group of senior US scientists. The researchers say the age of onset of female sexual development has not changed for decades.
fields.body:
Claims that the age of puberty is plummeting among girls in Western nations have been challenged by a group of senior US scientists. The researchers say the age of onset of female sexual development has not changed for decades.

Their intervention challenges several recent research projects which have alleged that increasing numbers of primary school girls are becoming capable of having sex and babies. Half of all girls in this country reach puberty by the age of 10, it has been claimed. Even six-year-olds are developing sexually, it has been said.

Factors ranging from environmental pollution to the influence of explicitly sexual TV shows have been blamed for this effect, which has been greeted with horror and alarm by many commentators and education experts.

But according to eight senior US endocrinologists, writing in the journal Pediatrics, the phenomenon of early female sexuality is in fact a myth. 'It is premature to conclude that the normal age of puberty is occurring earlier,' they state.

Indeed, the scientists argue that such claims are not only wrong but dangerous. They warn that doctors who examine girls who start developing sexually at six or seven might miss medical problems - such as cancer or genetic disorders which can cause early puberty - if they assume this early onset was normal.

'You don't just dismiss a child in that age range. It is potentially medically dangerous,' said Dr Laura Bachrach, of Stanford University School of Medicine, who recalled a six-year-old who had come to her clinic with pubic hair and severe acne. The girl, she said, 'turned out to have a very large malignant adrenal tumour'.

In addition, a report in yesterday's New York Times revealed that two key professional societies in the United States, the Endocrine Society and the Lawson-Wilkins Pediatric Endocrine Society, have both issued public warnings that plunging puberty ages were not an established fact.

'All recognise that the age at the first period, which I think is the most critical event, has not changed, which would suggest to me that the tempo of puberty has not changed,' said endocrinologist Edward Reiter, president of the Lawson-Wilkins society.

This point is supported by Dr Russel Viner, an endocrinologist at Great Ormond Street hospital, in London. 'The average age for the onset of puberty in girls is still between 10 and 11, when the first bodily changes start occurring, while menstruation begins at 13,' he told The Observer .

'Those ages have come down dramatically since the turn of the century, when menstruation began at around 17, and the main cause for that drop was probably improved nutrition.'

However, since the Sixties official figures have remained more or less stable, and there is not yet any solid medical evidence that more children are hitting early puberty, he added. 'However, we're hearing a lot more stories of girls starting their periods in junior school. There's certainly a rise in concern among teachers and parents.'

Such worries were given solid support in 1997 when Dr Marcia Herman-Geddes, of the University of North Carolina, published data which suggested it was now normal to see the first signs of puberty in girls as young as six. And a Children Of The Nineties study in Bristol last year found one in six eight-year-old girls were reaching puberty.

Until these studies were published, textbooks had indicated that girls who developed sexually before the age of eight should be subject to medical investigation. In the wake of the new findings, doctors began to argue that sexual development in six and seven years should now be seen as normal.

Reiter said he now worried paediatricians were taking the age of six as 'a magic number' for the onset of sexual development. These girls 'need to be individually monitored, individually followed' he said, adding that doctors 'should not be saying: "Don't worry about it. It's normal".'

webTitle: DNA twist to mystery of villa murder

fields.headline: DNA twist to mystery of villa murder
fields.trailText: DNA tests on blood found at the scene of a murder of a wealthy widow have reopened one of the most baffling criminal cases in French history.
fields.body:
DNA tests on blood found at the scene of a murder of a wealthy widow have reopened one of the most baffling criminal cases in French history.

In 1991, the body of Ghislaine Marchal was found in the boiler room of her luxury villa in Mougins on the Cte d'Azur. She had been repeatedly stabbed and beaten about the head with a piece of wood. On a door above her corpse the words 'Omar m'a tuer' ('Omar has killed me') were written in blood - a reference to her Moroccan gardener, Omar Raddad.

In 1994, Raddad was jailed for 18 years for Marchal's murder on the basis of circumstantial evidence. He has always denied killing his former boss. He was granted a partial pardon by President Jacques Chirac in 1996 and was finally released in September 1998.

Ever since, Raddad, now 38, has worked as a butcher in Marseilles and has been fighting to clear his name.

Earlier this year he agreed to undergo DNA tests to see if his blood matched samples found at the murder scene. The results show that Marchal's blood had been mixed with the blood of a man. But the male blood was not Raddad's, and this finding has thrown the 10-year-old murder case wide open.

One thing that had always perplexed those involved in the case is that the bloody message was written in grammatically incorrect French. Instead of using the past participle, 'tué', whoever wrote the message used the infinitive 'tuer'. It has become the most famous spelling error in French criminal history.

Investigators initially suggested that Marchal wrote the words herself. But they soon dismissed the theory. She was highly educated and was good at crossword puzzles and so unlikely to make such an elementary error. Eleven graphology experts compared crosswords left by the victim with the writing on the door and concluded they were not written by the same author.

Raddad, by contrast, was illiterate and spoke hardly any French at the time, so he would have probably been unable to write the message himself, nor is it likely he would have been able to force Marchal to do so.

One possibility is that racist investigators learnt that his French was poor and so wrote the grammatically inept message on the wall to implicate him. After Raddad's trial, his lawyer Jacques Vergès said that his client had been convicted because he was a maghrebien (a North African Arab).

Last week Raddad said he had been amazed at the ineptitude of the investigation. 'There wasn't just one error, but dozens. Why, for example, have we had to wait so long for DNA tests on the blood? Why, at first, did the police not take prints from the cellar? Why did three doctors make a "mistake" over the date of Marchal's death? Why was the body cremated so quickly? I hope to know one day.'

Raddad believes that the DNA evidence shows that he did not commit the crime and now wants a retrial. France's highest appeal court is expected to decide in the next four months whether there is enough new evidence.

But, if Raddad did not do it, who did? 'They should at least take into account the fact that the DNA is perhaps the assassin's,' said Vergès. 'They have to compare that sample with the DNA of people who could have left prints at the murder scene - say people who were part of Marchal's entourage.'

But lawyers for Marchal's son said the new evidence proves nothing either way. They, at least, are still convinced that Omar Raddad is the killer, and so far there is no other suspect.

webTitle: Why it must be wrong to keep old sweats in reserve

fields.headline: Why it must be wrong to keep old sweats in reserve
fields.trailText: Michel PlatiniI, Bryan Robson and Ossie Ardiles all had one thing in common before they became world-class players - they were told they would never make it.
fields.body:
Michel PlatiniI, Bryan Robson and Ossie Ardiles all had one thing in common before they became world-class players - they were told they would never make it.

They were all late developers physically who went on to prove those sceptics wrong, but I think we discard too many players, too young. The drop-out rate is enormous.

One reason is that clubs are now more selective, not surprising when you consider it costs them tens of thousands of pounds for each boy to go through the youth academy system, with his education, salary, coaching costs, kit, treatment and lodgings.

But more youngsters are getting back into football now that the FA have implemented exit trials for those boys who are not going to be taken on at the end of their academy courses. Last week at Lilleshall we had the first wave of 130 boys from the 30 Premiership clubs, and later there will be another series of exit trials for those Nationwide clubs with academies.

Crystal Palace were one of around 40 clubs represented, and our chief scout has recommended two boys from Premier League clubs in the North that we will be taking on trial. So far around 60 per cent of last week's boys at Lilleshall have been offered trials with other clubs, so the system is working - they are getting another chance.

This is their only realistic way of getting back into top-flight football unless they are very lucky. Writing to ask for a trial no longer works. No club that I know of holds open trials, which were common when I started out. In those days, most clubs would give a trial to youngsters or players from non-league who wrote in, but it just doesn't happen now.

It is an indictment of our system that sometimes you can get an international player from Europe cheaper than from the Conference - and on lower wages.

No wonder the days of players rising from non-league to the top have gone - such as Geoff Horsfield at Birmingham. He's among the a dying breed. You look at players like Chris Waddle, Stuart Pearce and Les Ferdinand, who rose from non-league football to play for England. Ian Wright was another, and he was one of several at Palace during the late Eighties - Andy Gray, Alan Pardew, Tony Finnegan and Stan Collymore were others. I bought Simon Rodger from Bognor for £50,000 10 years ago and he is now in his testimonial season. I can't see any others doing that.

I'd estimate only around 15 per cent of those rejected as teenagers continue to play at any decent level, especially those from the big clubs. They tend to lead such a cocooned and privileged life that they often cannot cope with the rejection and are so disillusioned that they pack up.

I am amazed at the number of young players I have seen from the likes of Arsenal, Chelsea and Tottenham who simply disappear off the football map once they are released. That is another reason why I fully support the FA's technical department in their view that we should restructure the age ranges at youth level and limit reserve team football to under-21s.

At the moment we have under-17s, under-19s and then no age limit. I would prefer to to see youth football split into under-16 and under-18 levels and restrict the reserves to under-21s. Then we could keep some of the trainees a year longer and not discard them at 19 - after all, anyone who says they know themselves at that age is either naive or stupid.

It is different on the continent. I watched the Spanish under-21 side destroy England last week - not one of their players was a first-team regular in the Primera Liga, and as there is no reserve football in Spain, were all allowed to develop longer.

With so many clubs having big senior squads, the reserves are often the only place to play for those who don't make the first team. But it is changing slowly - clubs like Arsenal and Chelsea, for example, rarely play any senior players in the reserves now, largely using games to bring young players along.

So let's bring in an under-21 age limit and not discard our youngsters too early. After all, the next Michel Platini may be waiting to emerge.

webTitle: Second chance for Premiership 'failures' as the scouts line up at Lilleshall

fields.headline: Second chance for Premiership 'failures' as the scouts line up at Lilleshall
fields.trailText: Last Wednesday, 18 of the nation's finest footballers played at the highest level of the game in Sven-Göran Eriksson's opening 3-0 England win over Spain at Villa Park. On the same day, less than 20 miles away in rural Shropshire, 63 Premiership wannabes, parading in freezing conditions, were fighting for the right to earn a living in the game - having been rejected by their clubs.
fields.body:
Last Wednesday, 18 of the nation's finest footballers played at the highest level of the game in Sven-Göran Eriksson's opening 3-0 England win over Spain at Villa Park. On the same day, less than 20 miles away in rural Shropshire, 63 Premiership wannabes, parading in freezing conditions, were fighting for the right to earn a living in the game - having been rejected by their clubs.

Young men with the same dreams and ambitions as David Beckham, Sol Campbell and Michael Owen lined up in front of scouts from more than 40 foot ball clubs from Britain - and abroad - to prove they are worth another chance. This was last chance saloon at Lilleshall.

The players were all coming to the end of their scholarships with Premiership clubs but had been told that they were not going to be retained next season. Some of the kids looked in better order than others. Understandably. While some had been warned some weeks ago that they were not going to be kept on, others assembled here had only just found out in the past few days. Tears had been shed and cats kicked. Everything they had imagined and dreamt about in the game was now on the line.

Two Liverpool boys stood out. Both have worn England's colours as schoolboys or youths and must have thought they were on the way. Goalkeeper Peter Crookes, just 18, is a former schoolboy international and has played for the under-19s and reserves at the club under the scrutiny of coach Joe Corrigan. 'It was not about feeling rejected,' he insisted. 'At first it was more, "What am I going to do next?" I talked to the coaches here and they made me realise that this is a step sideways to go forward.'

While ambitions remain as strong as ever to play at the top, there is an acceptance about their situations. And more realism among this current group about their chances of making it as a first-team player than in the past.

Crookes's club-mate, eight-cap England youth international midfielder Stephen Torpey, said: 'Liverpool are a big club. They can go out and buy international players. Years ago, it was not uncommon for players to stand outside the manager's office at the end of of the season waiting to hear his verdict. Many would depart a minute later having been told: 'Sorry son, we are not keeping you for next season. All the best and - on your way out - send the next one in.'

Dave Askmas, head of USL league in the United States, is looking for likely players to take up football scholarships. fields.headline: 'Johnny B Goode' takes his revenge
fields.standfirst: Piano player rescued from obscurity by Keith Richards battles Chuck Berry for royalties from the birth of rock 'n' roll
fields.trailText: Piano player rescued from obscurity by Keith Richards battles Chuck Berry for royalties from the birth of rock 'n' roll.
fields.body:
In the annals of rock'n'roll he is not as well-known as Little Richard or Chuck Berry but Johnnie Johnson may be about to get his dues.

Later this month, the 76-year-old boogie-woogie pianist behind songs such as 'Maybelline', 'Carol' and 'Sweet Little Sixteen' will be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

He will be presented with the honour by Rolling Stones guitarist Keith Richards, who has played no small part in rediscovering the man who for more than 30 years was Berry's writing partner and was the inspiration for 'Johnny B Goode'.

But Johnson never received credit or writing royalties and has lived most of his life in poverty. Now he is to challenge Berry's contention that he was only a supporting player. He has filed a lawsuit against Berry seeking co-authorship of more than 50 songs.

The complaint, which seeks unspecified damages, alleges that Berry took advantage of Johnson's alcoholism and lack of business acumen. '[Johnson] was unable to appreciate the value of his contribution,' says his lawyer Mitch Margo. 'Berry misled him into believing he was only entitled to a studio musician's fee.' If he wins the case Johnson will be entitled to half the royalties from the songs.

Berry's supporters say this is an attempt to rewrite history. 'Mr Berry knows there's no basis in fact for this suit and is disappointed that it has been filed,' says Berry's attorney, Joe Jacobson.

As far as Johnson is concerned, his argument with Berry is not about money but recognition. 'Money has its value but I'm not a money fanatic,' he said in New York on tour last week. 'Back in the Fifties only the artist's name got on the record. At the time it didn't bother me, I was just happy to be playing.

'The lawsuit is just to set the record straight. Chuck's been getting credit for more than what he did. Take the song 'Wee Wee Hours'. That was my song and my lyrics but he took the credit for it.'

Berry was an unseasoned player when he joined Johnson's group, the Sir John Trio, in late 1952. Berry adapted Johnson's self-taught hillbilly style to his guitar and emerged as frontman of the renamed Chuck Berry Trio. Johnson collaborated with Berry on more than 100 songs but by the Seventies the pair had all but ceased working together and the pianist was trapped in a world of menial jobs and alcoholism.

Before he died in 1985, Stones pianist Ian Stewart asked Keith Richards to find Johnson and help him out. Richards, who found Johnson working in a St Louis steel works, says the first thing he noticed was his thick fingers. 'Like sausages,' Richards says. 'But of course, it's what they do with the keys that clinches the deal.'

Richards's patronage rekindled interest in Johnson but he couldn't sustain a comeback. In 1990 he collapsed while playing with Eric Clapton at the Royal Albert Hall. 'I was getting up with a drink and going to bed with a drink,' Johnson says. 'When I had that scare in London I stopped it all cold turkey. I haven't had a drink since.'

Three years later Johnson was hired by George Turek, a Houston-based medical services magnate, to play at his wedding. Although Turek thought he was hiring Jimmy Johnson, a Chicago blues guitarist, the pair became friends and Turek began a campaign to win him his place in music history. Turek says : 'When you really listen to Berry's music it's really Johnnie Johnson's music. He gave it that pounding beat.'

Turek says Johnson never understood that because he wrote the music, he was entitled to half the songwriting credits. 'In many ways he's very simplistic. He was under the impression that because he did not have the ability to write the notes down on paper he didn't really write it and couldn't take credit for it.'

Turek's second battle was to get Johnson recognised by the Hall of Fame. A long campaign supported by Richards and Clapton, as well as Little Richard, Etta James and Bo Diddley, ensued. Last year the organisation created a 'Sideman' category to recognise pioneers who were not stars in their own right.

Johnson says he will be honoured to receive the citation on 19 March. 'I love playing music. My fingers may no longer be as fast as I'd like them to be but I still get by. The more I play the more I enjoy it.' And he adds philosophically: 'I guess it's who you know and not what you know that gets you ahead.'

fields.headline: McLeod's quiet ride into town
fields.trailText: Celtic supporters would be much more stimulated on Friday afternoon by the presentation to Martin O'Neill of an unprecedented third Bank of Scotland Manager of the Month award than the introduction, an hour later, of the club's new chief executive.
fields.body:
Celtic supporters would be much more stimulated on Friday afternoon by the presentation to Martin O'Neill of an unprecedented third Bank of Scotland Manager of the Month award than the introduction, an hour later, of the club's new chief executive.

Directors have never held much appeal for fans except in those black days when perilous financial mismanagement leads to the decline of the team and there is an urgent need of someone with the acumen to restore stability and former glories.

Celtic have had enough bad times in the past dozen years or so to have made previous boardroom appointments of deep interest; media people arriving at the stadium for the unveiling of the latest would encounter such crowds as to create the impression it was a match day.

But, to the club's followers, the true Messiah has been at Parkhead since May, O'Neill's transformation of the team regarded as miraculous. Becoming the first manager to win three monthly awards in one season merely underlines the Irishman's status as The Man.

When Ian McLeod, a 42-year-old Tiree-born but Glasgow-raised executive director of Wal-Mart, was revealed as Allan MacDonald's successor on Friday, this change in the perceived importance of his appointment was marked by the total absence of anxious faces, waiting for an address which would encourage the belief that a new, golden age was imminent.

In that respect, McLeod should already be indebted to O'Neill. Unlike MacDonald - and the general manager before him, Jock Brown - the new man will not have to confront the almost daily ritual of explaining to a prickly press why the manager/coach he has appointed is clearly a dud and the team appears to be going backwards.

McLeod appears to be aware of his good fortune, revealing that the manager's achievement was crucial to his seeking the job. He will certainly have been persuaded during his negotiations with chairman Brian Quinn and the Celtic plc board that the position is no longer a bed of nails.

'Martin has done a fantastic job,' said McLeod. 'He's one of the reasons I joined the club. Coming from the largest retailer in the world - by next year Wal-Mart are likely to be the largest company in the world - shows what a big decision it was for me. The emotional pull of being involved with a club like Celtic back in my home town was too great to resist.' Without the progress made on the field under O'Neill, the lure would have been much more easily shrugged off. McLeod supported Celtic as a boy and took the opportunity to become a season ticket holder 'about three years ago', when another new stand raised the stadium capacity.

Whether a support currently basking in the reversal of the established order in Scottish football - three victories out of four meetings with Rangers, an apparently decisive lead in the Premier League, a place in the CIS League Cup final and still in the Tennents Scottish Cup - cares or not, McLeod's performance will have an impact on O'Neill's prospects of continuing the progress.

Given the club's structure, McLeod will not be a chief executive in the all-powerful sense of the word. In practice, he will be the sales and marketing director, the essence of his job to increase turnover by expanding merchandising and commercial enterprises.

When pressed on the matter of his autonomy and authority, he admitted that it had not been at the forefront of his discussions with the board. 'My autonomy will evolve over time,' he said. 'How much of it I will have wasn't really touched on during negotiations.'

With debts of £25 million, Celtic will continue to exercise prudence, but, as McLeod confirmed, the figure is neither insurmountable nor a cause for concern. Celtic have yet to conclude a multi-media partnership - an offer of £31 million from their present shirt sponsors, NTL, is on the table - which could eradicate the liabilities virtually overnight.

Quinn emphasised that no media partnership has yet been formed because there was no need for Celtic to rush to accept the first offer. 'Those to whom we have presented our media plan have told us it was the best presentation they had seen from a football club.' the chairman said.

Quinn confirmed that Celtic have not given up on the proposed northern European League and revealed that they are not in favour of plans to turn the Uefa Cup into a Champions League-style format. 'Why should we endorse a format that has done nothing to bridge the gap between clubs from smaller countries and those from the larger, richer countries?' he said.

But, with Rangers having apparently abandoned the notion of a league involving clubs from Scotland, the Low Countries, Portugal and Scandinavia and having declared their approval of the new format for the Uefa Cup, the old idea is now surely beyond revival.

fields.headline: The Celtic divide in Belfast
fields.trailText: Neil Lennon was not the first Catholic footballer to receive harsh verbal treatment from his own supporters at Windsor Park, nor will he be the last, but whether or not the Celtic midfielder has a future with Northern Ireland is almost an incidental issue.
fields.body:
Neil Lennon was not the first Catholic footballer to receive harsh verbal treatment from his own supporters at Windsor Park, nor will he be the last, but whether or not the Celtic midfielder has a future with Northern Ireland is almost an incidental issue.

As is so often the case, there is a bigger picture to consider and at least one informed observer believes that the treatment handed out to Lennon during Wednesday's humiliating 4-0 defeat by Norway will be to the detriment of football generally in Northern Ireland.

Brian Kerr, the Football Association of Ireland's (Republic) technical director, said: 'I could not understand the logic of what I heard at Windsor Park on Wednesday night. I knew Anton Rogan used to get some stick but I thought things had moved on from those days. Obviously not. 'Northern Ireland don't have many class players and I didn't even know some of the names on the team sheet for the game against Norway, but they still gave Neil Lennon, a class player, so much abuse.'

As Kerr recalls, defender Rogan, who hails from the Republican estate of Lenadoon in Catholic West Belfast, was routinely abused by supporters during his 18-game international career in the late Eighties. His 'crime', like that of Lennon, was not that he was one of the numerous Catholics to have played for the North, but rather that he was employed by Celtic. Even goalkeeper Allen McKnight was not forgiven for being a Celtic player by Northern Ireland supporters, despite his being a Protestant.

Lennon had fanned the flames of the issue before the Norway match. In an interview he gave his backing to the idea of a '32-county', ie an all-Ireland, national team - a sacrilegious notion to Northern Ireland's Protestant fans. Significantly, experts believe there is emphatic evidence that since the Good Friday Agreement of April 1998, sectarianism has worsened considerably in Irish sport. Yet it is easy to forget that the famous 1982 side who beat Spain bridged the divide. Protestant manager Billy Bingham, it was said, chose Catholic Martin O'Neill as much for the 'balance' it gave to the team as for his motivational powers. The tradition of Catholics appearing for the North has continued unabated and the divide shown by the Lennon case is as much about the divide in Glasgow football as it is in Irish history.

Of course, the two are related, especially in Northern Ireland where clubs' supporters are still divided along sectarian lines even if, as has been the case in Glasgow, discrimination has ceased with regard to signing players. There is also no doubt that the Northern Ireland national team are deprived of a large number of Catholic supporters, disenchanted by sectarian songs from a predominantly loyalist following. It was the hardcore loyalists who turned on Lennon last week.

Former Middlesbrough and Manchester City centre-half Alan Kernaghan, Yorkshire-born, Ulster-raised and a Northern Ireland schoolboy international, played senior football for the Republic. He can testify to the depth of the problem. Kernaghan was singled out for violent abuse by the Belfast crowd as the South picked up the 1-1 draw that took them to the 1994 World Cup Finals. It was an image that still lives in the mind of the then manager, Jack Charlton. 'I never imagined the emotions and the feelings that were stirred up in the ground that night,' said Charlton. 'It was nasty, it was unhealthy, and something I would never like to see again.'

It seems hard to believe but Neil Lennon's problems are minor compared to those of another footballer suffering becasue of politics. Bixente Lizarazu, the France World Cup winning fullback, has been living under 24-hour police protection since Basque separatists sent a threatening letter to his parents in Hendaye, the border town between France and the Basque country.

The World Cup winner is of pure Basque blood but ETA, the terrorist group, view him as a traitor because he plays for the French national team, and France hands over ETA members to Spain.

ETA insisted Lizarazu should donate all the money he has made from playing for France to them as a revolutionary tax to help their fight for independence. When Lizarazu declined, French Prime Minister Lionel Jospin intervened and offered armed protection round the clock.

Lizarazu, who plays for Bayern Munich, has a similar arrangement with the German police. All this has only added to speculation in the French press about why, some years ago, he left Athletic Bilbao prematurely. Lizarazu refused to explain his reasons, and now ETA are being blamed.

His 'crime', like that of Lennon, was not that he was one of the numerous Catholics to have played for the North, but rather that he was employed by Celtic. Even goalkeeper Allen McKnight was not forgiven for being a Celtic player by Northern Ireland supporters, despite his being a Protestant. Lennon had fanned the flames of the issue before the Norway match. In an interview he gave his backing to the idea of a '32-county', ie an all-Ireland, national team - a sacrilegious notion to Northern Ireland's Protestant fans. Significantly, experts believe there is emphatic evidence that since the Good Friday Agreement of April 1998, sectarianism has worsened considerably in Irish sport. Yet it is easy to forget that the famous 1982 side who beat Spain bridged the divide. Protestant manager Billy Bingham, it was said, chose Catholic Martin O'Neill as much for the 'balance' it gave to the team as for his motivational powers. The tradition of Catholics appearing for the North has continued unabated and the divide shown by the Lennon case is as much about the divide in Glasgow football as it is in Irish history. Of course, the two are related, especially in Northern Ireland where clubs' supporters are still divided along sectarian lines even if, as has been the case in Glasgow, discrimination has ceased with regard to signing players. There is also no doubt that the Northern Ireland national team are deprived of a large number of Catholic supporters, disenchanted by sectarian songs from a predominantly loyalist following. It was the hardcore loyalists who turned on Lennon last week. Former Middlesbrough and Manchester City centre-half Alan Kernaghan, Yorkshire-born, Ulster-raised and a Northern Ireland schoolboy international, played senior football for the Republic. He can testify to the depth of the problem. Kernaghan was singled out for violent abuse by the Belfast crowd as the South picked up the 1-1 draw that took them to the 1994 World Cup Finals. It was an image that still lives in the mind of the then manager, Jack Charlton. 'I never imagined the emotions and the feelings that were stirred up in the ground that night,' said Charlton. 'It was nasty, it was unhealthy, and something I would never like to see again.' It seems hard to believe but Neil Lennon's problems are minor compared to those of another footballer suffering becasue of politics. Bixente Lizarazu, the France World Cup winning fullback, has been living under 24-hour police protection since Basque separatists sent a threatening letter to his parents in Hendaye, the border town between France and the Basque country. The World Cup winner is of pure Basque blood but ETA, the terrorist group, view him as a traitor because he plays for the French national team, and France hands over ETA members to Spain. ETA insisted Lizarazu should donate all the money he has made from playing for France to them as a revolutionary tax to help their fight for independence. When Lizarazu declined, French Prime Minister Lionel Jospin intervened and offered armed protection round the clock. Lizarazu, who plays for Bayern Munich, has a similar arrangement with the German police. All this has only added to speculation in the French press about why, some years ago, he left Athletic Bilbao prematurely. Lizarazu refused to explain his reasons, and now ETA are being blamed.

fields.headline: Gorillas face doom at gunpoint
fields.standfirst: As rival militias swarm over a nature park in Congo, butchering and eating the animals, a rare primate is being brought to the edge of extinction
fields.trailText: It is one of the largest stretches of natural habitat left in Africa, and until recently it was home to one of the world's rarest creatures, the eastern lowland gorilla.
fields.byline: by James Astill, Kahuzi-Biéga and Robin McKie, London
fields.body:
It is one of the largest stretches of natural habitat left in Africa, and until recently it was home to one of the world's rarest creatures, the eastern lowland gorilla.

But disturbing evidence has emerged from the vast Kahuzi-Biéga park in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) that thousands of its most precious inhabitants have been slaughtered.

Undercover game rangers who have spent the past few months surveying the park have found that the country's civil war - financed by international trade - has now brought one of mankind's closest cousins to the brink of extinction.

Their reports point an accusing finger at the West, and particularly America, over its voracious appetite for coltan - a mineral, unique to the area, used in nuclear reactors, the aviation industry and electronics manufacture. It is this $1 billion export that has funded the country's civil war and has led to the near annihilation of its gorillas, say analysts.

As the head of the Kahuzi-Biéga park, Kasereka Bishikwabo, told The Observer last week: 'This is a coltan war now.'

The trade, and its resulting devastation, has infuriated conservation agencies, which last week called for an international boycott of the country's coltan, as well as gold and other minerals mined in the park.

'The civil war in the DRC has been driven by armies fighting for the country's mineral wealth, but there is no point in the West pointing a finger at the slaughter there when we are buying up the proceeds,' said Greg Cummings, executive director of the Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund, the conservation group set up by the late primatologist. 'We have got to stop buying this stuff, and end the flow of money to these people.'

This point was backed by Ian Redmund of the international group Ape Alliance. 'What is the point of declaring the Kahuzi-Biéga park a world heritage site, as Unesco has done, when we do nothing to stop the destruction of its most precious component. Indeed, we are actually encouraging it by buying up the park's minerals.'

Of the world's three main types of gorilla, there are about 100,000 western lowland gorillas; a few hundred endangered mountain gorillas in Rwanda; and until recently about 8,000 eastern lowland gorillas, the largest of the sub-species. Typically, a male of the eastern lowland gorilla - or Gorilla gorilla graueri - has an average standing height of up to 5ft 9in and can weigh as much as 25 stone.

Until the mid-1990s, the eastern lowland lived in relative tranquillity in the Kahuzi-Biéga. Then the Interahamwe, the Hutu militia fighters responsible for the 1994 genocide in neighbouring Rwanda, fled their native land and took refuge in the park's uninhabited forests. They were promptly pursued there by their Rwandan enemies: the Tutsis, and the Congolese Rally for Democracy (RCD). A nationalist militia, the Mai Mai, has also joined battle with both sides. Initially, this three-way conflict wreaked mayhem. But now signs are emerging that all three groups have begun to collude with each other to pillage the park's vast mineral wealth.

According to Kasereka Bishikwabo, his undercover game rangers found that 'where there used to be gorillas, elephants, chimpanzees, they now found villagers. These people said they'd eaten elephant for two years but hadn't seen a track for six months. They also said they'd eaten a lot of gorillas and couldn't find any more, but they thought there might be a few left.'

Bishikwabo's agents spent two months in the park, fearful of being identified by the soldiers of the three different armies. They reported that more than 10,000 villagers had moved into the park to mine its lands but had brought no livestock with them and had planted almost no crops. Instead, they had relied almost entirely on bushmeat, the flesh of the local wildlife.

'They were hunting further and further from their villages every day until they stopped finding trails,' said one ranger. 'The villagers were mostly shooting the animals with Kalashnikovs provided by the park's armies.'

Bishikwabo concludes that all the park's 3,700 elephants must now have been slaughtered, and is not much more hopeful about the fate of the gorillas - a pessimism that is shared by Ape Alliance. 'There is a small area of Kahuzi-Biéga - about 10 per cent of the whole park - that is still controlled by wardens,' said Ian Redmund.

'Of the 258 gorillas that used to live there five years ago, only 110 are now left alive. In other words, more than half have been killed by the conflict - and that is in an area that is guarded by rangers. In the rest of the park, which is utterly lawless, we can only conclude there has been an uncontrolled massacre. Thousands of gorillas have been killed, I am sure of that.'

As a result, conservationists fear the eastern lowland gorilla has now been reduced to a rump of a few hundred animals, a number so low as to leave the species vulnerable to any outbreak of disease or slight climate change.

Nor is there any sign that the protagonists who have initiated this carnage show any signs of leaving. Coltan - or colombo-tantalite, as it is also known - is a precious hardening agent for metals used in a host of hi-tech industries. Africa has 80 per cent of the world's supplies, and of these, three-quarters are found in the Kahuzi-Biéga park and neighbouring land.

Dozens of dealers have clustered in the area, and are controlling exports sent out on Russian-built Antonov planes. These buzz the skies above the once tranquil park as they take off for Rwanda. From there, the coltan is bought by dealers in Europe and the United States.

'The people that deal in coltan, they're buying cars, building houses. It can make you rich,' said one dealer. 'It's abundant and easy to sell and here it is worth more than gold.'

Great news for dealers - but a tragedy for the eastern lowland gorilla.

fields.headline: Stock answer
fields.trailText: I can't speak for Bob Kiley (Business, last week), but I suspect he is well aware of the public sector borrowing limits and does not agree with them.
fields.body:
I can't speak for Bob Kiley (Business, last week), but I suspect he is well aware of the public sector borrowing limits and does not agree with them.

Until 1956, Britain's nationalised industries were allowed to raise new capital by floating an issue on the stock exchange. There is no reason why we should not return to these rules, and bring Britain into line with the rest of the world.
Rex Hora
Reading

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Bangladeshi kidnappers 'ready to release Briton'
fields.body:
Bangladeshi kidnappers 'ready to release Briton'

Bangladeshi kidnappers have indicated that they will release Briton Tim Selby, 28, and his fellow engineers Torben Mikkelsen, 48, and Nils Hulgaard, 64, from Denmark, tomorrow.

Kalparanjan Chakma, the Bangladeshi government minister leading the negotiations, said they have been able to establish contact with the kidnappers. A tribal mediator was reported to have met the abductors in their forest hideout in Rangamati, a south-eastern region of hills and dense forests.

The three were snatched as they worked on a road project. The bandits placed a £1.1 million ransom on their heads.

Earlier, Selby's brother Jon expressed fears that the authorities were planning military action.

He said: 'Military action scares us a great deal, I'm afraid.'

OAP runs over wife twice

A woman, aged 78, was seriously ill in hospital in Slough, Berkshire, after her husband, 84, twice drove over her by accident. He had been reversing his car in a shopping centre car park when his foot slipped off the brake on to the accelerator. He was treated for shock.

Bygraves's old Rolls on sale

The 1982 Rolls-Royce Silver Spirit which Max Bygraves, above, used for 14 years has gone on sale in Weymouth with an asking price of £12,000. Bygraves, 78, sold it five years ago and the garage hopes the connection will add to its value.

Custody cry

A dozen men demonstrated outside the house of High Court Judge Christopher Tyrer yesterday. They claim the divorce system discriminates against men, with custody of children going to women in nine cases out of 10.

Dome auction raises £3.5m

The auction of items from the Millennium Dome raised nearly £3.5 million. The last-minute withdrawal of more than 1,000 items dented the original estimate of £5m.

Train murder

A murder inquiry has been opened after a man aged 21 died after a fight on board a train from Newcastle to Manchester early yesterday. He was found at the foot of an embankment in Durham and was pronounced dead in hospital.

Happy return

Stephen Downing today celebrates his 45th birthday with his family, his first as a free man since being wrongly jailed for murder 27 years ago in Bakewell, Derbyshire. He is due to start work at a local hotel.

Log on, it's just the job

Education Secretary David Blunkett, above, will this week unveil WorkTrain, an internet jobs bank carrying a third of the vacancies from Job Centres throughout the UK. Its address is www.worktrain.gov.uk

Cindy Jackson - an apology

The Observer apologised in open court on 1 March for publishing an article on 18 July 1999 which, together with a caption to a photograph, alleged that Ms Cindy Jackson, a well-known adviser on cosmetic surgery, recommended to her clients surgeons who had been negligent. The Observer said that it had not intended to convey that meaning, and accepted that the allegation was without foundation. The newspaper apologised for the distress caused to Ms Jackson and has paid substantial damages to Ms Jackson together with her legal costs.

fields.headline: Women lose out
fields.trailText: Dr Les May (Letters, last week) states that pensions are unfair because women are likely to draw them for longer than men. What he forgets is that women's pensions are likely to be considerably smaller than men's.
fields.body:
Dr Les May (Letters, last week) states that pensions are unfair because women are likely to draw them for longer than men. What he forgets is that women's pensions are likely to be considerably smaller than men's.

Most women will have taken time out from work to raise families; when they return to full-time work they will be earning a lot less than men, and therefore any contributions to Serps, company or private pensions will be that much smaller.
Jacquetta Benjamin
Hove
W Sussex

fields.headline: German health
fields.trailText: It is not true that high earners in Germany are barred from the social (public) health insurance system (News, last week).
fields.body:
It is not true that high earners in Germany are barred from the social (public) health insurance system (News, last week).

In fact, Germans with gross incomes above £25,000 a year must choose to stay in the social health insurance system or opt out and take up private health insurance. The overwhelming majority (between 75 and 80 per cent) choose to stay in the social health insurance system.
Sarah Thomson
London School of Economics and Political Science
London WC2

fields.headline: Natural enemy
fields.trailText: Circa 1450, the following order was made in England: 'We command that no bocher sell noo beestis of moren, ne no roten Schep'. The myth of a disease-free, localised, 'organic' farming idyll of the past (Focus, last week) is just hogwash.

From the rampant 'murrain' to the Irish potato famine, pestilence and plague stalked all pre-modern agriculture, while cattle were walked, spreading disease, from Scotland to London. It is to the great credit of modern farming that a cheap food supply has been maintained under the constant attack of Nature, black in tooth and rot.
Philip Stott
Professor of Biogeography
SOAS, University of London
