fields.headline: Genome benefits
fields.trailText: I would like to clarify my statement to  The Observer (News, 18 February) that current advances in genomics will not be of immediate benefit to devel oping country populations.
fields.body:
I would like to clarify my statement to The Observer (News, 18 February) that current advances in genomics will not be of immediate benefit to devel oping country populations. The application of simple, low-cost technologies and interventions such as anti-malarial and anti-TB drugs, condoms, oral rehydration therapy, insecticides and bednets are more urgent and relevant compared to the hype surrounding gene therapy. At the same time, long-term solutions to these diseases will benefit from scientific advances in the post-genomics era.
Dr Tikki Pang
Director, Research Policy & Cooperation, World Health Organisation
Geneva
Switzerland

webTitle: Paris ready to overthrow its ancien regime

fields.headline: Paris ready to overthrow its ancien regime
fields.standfirst: For the first time since 1871, the French capital is turning left - and set to welcome a gay mayor
fields.trailText: For the first time since 1871, the French capital is turning left - and set to welcome a gay mayor.
fields.body:
Paris has always been gay. But later this month it will become even more so when Socialist Party candidate Bertrand Delanoë is elected as mayor. He will become the most powerful openly gay man in the world.

The latest opinion poll suggests that Delanoë has 62 per cent of the Paris electorate's support, compared with just 28 per cent for his closest rival, the leading right-wing candidate Philippe Séguin.

Delanoë's election will be the first time that the Left has controlled the French capital since the Paris Commune in 1871. It will bring to an end two decades during which Jacques Chirac's Gaullist RPR party and its allies have held sway, making the city clean, efficient - and just a little bit bourgeois and boring.

From 1977 to 1995, Chirac himself was Paris's mayor, building up a huge power base that gave him a springboard into national politics. For the past five years his successor, Jean Tiberi, has made a mess of being mayor, miring himself in corruption scandals.

Worse for the Gaullists, who are likely to be humiliated in Paris's two rounds of municipal elections on 11 and 18 March, Chirac's heritage as mayor has been tarnished. The French President has been targeted in revelations that his party activists were paid from the public purse for non-existent jobs, and that contracts were awarded only in return for kickbacks.

The stink of RPR corruption has had two consequences. First, Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, the Socialist candidate for next year's presidential election, has taken the lead over his rival Chirac in the opinion polls. Second, it has enabled Delanoë to present himself as a new broom, who will sweep out all corruption from the H�circ;tel de Ville.

Transparency, in fact, is his most prominent policy plank. 'For 24 years, there has been a system with fictitious jobs and phoney electors,' Delanoë says. 'I've been fighting against this system. My first act as candidate has been to define and impose a drastic moral code.'

Delanoë's message is most clearly put on his website: 'The choice is between a wet firework and a democratic explosion.'

In an attempt to steal Delanoë's thunder, though, the RPR selected former party chairman Philippe Séguin as its candidate. A burly man with a rich baritone voice, Séguin at least had the advantage of being well-known compared with his Socialist rival.

But, embarrassingly for the Gaullists, Tiberi is standing for re-election on an independent ticket, bitterly moaning that Séguin has stolen his best ideas on crime and security - two of the top campaign issues here, along with pollution and transport. Though Tiberi is the true wet firework in the campaign, his candidacy is likely to split the right-wing vote, making Delanoë's chances of election stronger.

What kind of man is Delanoë? On Thursday night, he appeared before 3,500 party faithful in the north of Paris in his last rally before polling day. It should have been a triumphant evening. There were messages of support from Ken Livingstone, as well as the mayors of Geneva, Barcelona, São Paulo and Vienna. But Delanoë hardly milked this crowd, telling his workers instead that they must not be deflected from their campaign. He has had something of a charisma by-pass. True, he may have led 100,000 through Paris last year in a Gay Pride march, but Delanoë is more grey than gay.

He came out only two years ago, a move greeted by Gallic shrugs rather than Anglo-Saxon hysteria. Sophisticated Parisians may well vote for Delanoë because he is gay rather than despite it.

In profile he has a long ski-jump of a nose that recalls Bob Hope's, but otherwise there is nothing funny about Bertrand Delanoë. He is close to Jospin and is of the same austere, intellectual stamp. Just as the biggest slur against Jospin in France is that he is too upstandingly Protestant to have a mistress, so Delanoë hardly has a flamboyantly public sexual persona.

Born in 1950 in Tunis (also Séguin's birthplace), he studied in Rodez and Toulouse, before working his way up through the Socialist Party machine. He was first elected a Paris councillor in 1977 - the same year Chirac became mayor - and quickly became a leading member of the '18th arrondissement gang' with Jospin and current Interior Minister Daniel Vaillant, still close confidants. In 1999, after years of blameless municipal service, he wrote For The Honour of Paris, a book that set out his anti-cronyist message for the city. His policies are sensible. Delanoë calls for better policing, more green spaces, fewer cars and better public transport, and more council provision of crèche spaces.

He has been dubbed le Renard de Marais (the Fox of the Marais, the fashionable gay and Jewish quarter of central Paris), and indeed the cunning modesty of his proposals has caught the imagination of Parisians. Here, many electors think, is a man they can trust - or at least trust not to fill his party's coffers with public money, or set his family up in luxury apartments at the city's expense.

This month's French municipal contests will give a strong indication of the outcome of next year's presidential election. According to Libération: 'It is the twilight of the Chirac system. Will Jacques Chirac lose the presidency in these municipal elections?' If he does, the man who brings him down will be Bertrand Delanoë.

He will become the most powerful openly gay man in the world. The latest opinion poll suggests that Delanoë has 62 per cent of the Paris electorate's support, compared with just 28 per cent for his closest rival, the leading right-wing candidate Philippe Séguin. Delanoë's election will be the first time that the Left has controlled the French capital since the Paris Commune in 1871. For the past five years his successor, Jean Tiberi, has made a mess of being mayor, miring himself in corruption scandals. The French President has been targeted in revelations that his party activists were paid from the public purse for non-existent jobs, and that contracts were awarded only in return for kickbacks. First, Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, the Socialist candidate for next year's presidential election, has taken the lead over his rival Chirac in the opinion polls. Second, it has enabled Delanoë to present himself as a new broom, who will sweep out all corruption from the H�circ;tel de Ville. Transparency, in fact, is his most prominent policy plank. fields.headline: Blind prejudice
fields.trailText: In the squib of mine 'Killed in Crossfire' (Books, 18 February), I quoted a diary entry by Victor Klemperer in 1934 in Hitler's Germany. Klemperer noted that Zionists 'are just as offensive as the Nazis'.
fields.body:
In the squib of mine 'Killed in Crossfire' (Books, 18 February), I quoted a diary entry by Victor Klemperer in 1934 in Hitler's Germany. Klemperer noted that Zionists 'are just as offensive as the Nazis'. He also noted that in their racist thinking 'they are altogether a match for the National Socialists'. I am surprised that none of those who wrote to your paper protesting against my lines attempted to grapple with the heroic Klemperer's stated views. I am also surprised that none of them felt able to condemn what Israel is doing to the Palestinians.

The response of Neville Nagler, writing on behalf of the Board of Deputies of British Jews, is particularly feeble. He makes a simple equation between Jews and Israelis - as if all Jews automatically support whatever actions any Israeli government takes. He also - impertinently and ignorantly - suggests that I should examine my own attitudes 'towards the Jewish people and the state of Israel'.

If he knew anything of my published work - my review, for example, of Anthony Julius's study of T.S. Eliot's anti-semitism which I published in the London Review of Books, which drew attention to the way in which Julius's indictment of Eliot had been almost totally ignored - he might have thought better before making his foolish suggestion. What is so galling is that people like Nagler think they can insinuate anti-semitism and leave it at that. I am a philo-semite, and I repudiate his letter with contempt.
Tom Paulin
Hertford College
Oxford

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Amsterdam plans for runways
fields.body:
Amsterdam plans for runways

Amsterdam's Schiphol airport wants to increase the number of its runways to seven by 2020 to cope with a forecast doubling in flights.

The number of flights is expected to rise to 800,000 from 430,000 now, with passenger numbers almost tripling. But a fifth runway due to open in 2003 will only increase capacity to 600,000 flights, according to a press report.

Hotel workers to strike for tips

A strike planned by hotel workers in Nepal from 15 March to demand a 10 per cent service charge on hotel bills will cripple the kingdom's tourism, an official said. Hotels already charge 10 per cent VAT and a 2 per cent tourism development levy.

Commuters die in stampede

A stampede in a stairway at a railway station in Johannesburg killed seven people and injured eight others. Commuters were trying to catch a train for Mafikeng, although the platform gate had already closed.

Pan-African plan endorsed

African leaders ended a two-day summit in Libya by endorsing a plan by Muammar Gadaffi, above, for an African Union. Libya's plan will not be put in place until it is ratified by two thirds of the 53 members of the Organisation of African Unity. Gadaffi first floated the idea in 1999, arguing that it offered the best chance of escaping poverty and powerlessness.

Chechen 'slave' freed at last

Russian media reported that Ukrainian Anatoly Fabritsyn, 51, has been freed from 10 years of forced labour in a remote village in separatist Chechnya.

He was invited there in 1990 to work as a builder but on arrival was held.

Fabritsyn dug trenches, tended cattle, and carried rebel arms and explosives between bases.

He said he never had enough to eat, had no idea the Soviet Union collapsed or that Ukraine was independent. 'They treated me like a dog.'

Estrada faces judgment day

The Philippine government will decide by tomorrow whether to try former President Joseph Estrada for graft and economic plunder, offences punishable by death. The Supreme Court has ruled that Estrada is not immune from prosecution and that Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, who replaced him last month, is the legitimate President.

177 rescued from forced prostitution in Bosnia

A night raid by Bosnian police, coordinated with UN police monitors, migration officials and Nato-led peacekeepers, freed 177 prostitutes, mostly from Romania, Moldova, Ukraine and Russia, from clubs across Bosnia.

The UN mission said it was 'the most significant coordinated police action taken to date by the police in Bosnia and Herzegovina to address the serious problem of human trafficking and forced prostitution'. The raids brought to more than 400 the number of victims found in Bosnia in the past two years.

fields.headline: Hot Gough boils over
fields.standfirst: Observer special report:England in Sri Lanka
fields.trailText: The setting was spectacular, but the mood was tetchy, fraught even. Perhaps it was the early start (the team set off from Colombo at 7am) or the heat bouncing off 'Elephant Rock', that overshadows the ground, but there were moments yesterday when it looked as if the tour was starting to implode, hardly the obvious conclusion you might draw after glimpsing the scorecard and noting an emphatic eight-wicket victory against the Colts XI.
fields.body:
The setting was spectacular, but the mood was tetchy, fraught even. Perhaps it was the early start (the team set off from Colombo at 7am) or the heat bouncing off 'Elephant Rock', that overshadows the ground, but there were moments yesterday when it looked as if the tour was starting to implode, hardly the obvious conclusion you might draw after glimpsing the scorecard and noting an emphatic eight-wicket victory against the Colts XI.

The two English protaganists in yesterday's match were Darren Gough and Marcus Trescothick, with Nasser Hussain playing a bit part role in both dramas. Gough obviously got out of the wrong side of his Colombo bed as the sun was rising. Yesterday he was involved in an unseemly contretemps with one of the Sri Lankan players and the umpire, TM Samarasingh, not what this tour needed given the tension and controversy of the Galle Test match.

At the start Gough had given the impression that he was none too enamoured to be playing in this game rather than Andrew Caddick even though this was the solitary day's cricket between the Tests. Even so he did his level best with the new ball. Then in his second spell there was an 'incident' similar to the one between Gough and Roshan Mahanama in that controversial one-day game in Adelaide two years ago.

A delivery to Indika de Saram ended up trickling along the popping crease. The Sri Lankan batsmen set off for a quick single; Gough set off for the ball. Very soon Gough collided with De Saram and ended up in a heap on the pitch. On another day he might have found it all very amusing. He didn't yesterday. He marched back down the pitch, his finger pointing at De Saram and delivered a few choice words (De Saram recognised only one of them); he then appeared to do the same to the umpire before storming off to his fielding position for the next over. He was pursued by Hussain and after a quick word from his captain, Gough left the field though not before speaking again to the umpire. He returned five overs later so that he could bowl at the end of the innings.

Soon a written statement emanated from the English camp, always a bad sign. In it Gough explained: 'I was upset because I felt that the batsman had intentionally impeded me as I was going for a run-out. I asked the umpire to warn the player because I did not want get into a dispute with him and I was also concerned that I might be involved in a collision and sustain an injury that could put me out of the tour. Although it may have appeared otherwise, I can honestly say that Nasser Hussain did not send me off the field. I was suffering from a stiff back and needed to get some treatment.'

End of story as far as the England management was concerned. They received no complaints from the umpire though the Colts coach intended to report the incident to the Chief Executive of the Sri Lankan Board. It shouldn't quite be the end of the matter. Gough has not committed a heinous sin in Kurunegala. But in the current climate a public reprimand would have been in order whether the opposition or umpires had complained or not.

The tale of Trescothick is briefer. Twice in the morning he left the field, limping and in pain after twisting his knee. Alarm bells rang for Trescothick is suddenly a key man. It was assumed that he would not bat, if only as a precaution, but out he came. He didn't tax his knee too much through running, cracking 13 boundaries in a crisp and carefree 85 from just 68 balls. Hussain was more circumspect but by the end of his innings of 73 he was timing the ball sweetly, albeit in benign conditions and against very undemanding, unMurali-type spinners. The target of 249 was always a canter for England, who finished the day far happier than they started it. Graeme Hick and Graham Thorpe had a gentle net at the end. All the Sri Lankan wickets were taken by Yorkshiremen. Jason Brown at last had a bowl - five innocuous overs - and super-sub Stewart held three catches.

Hussain was unequivocal in his support for Gough. 'You boys [the press] would be barking up the wrong tree if you had a go at Darren Gough,' he said. 'He bowls his heart out for England. Give me 10 Darren Goughs any time.'

Ten might be stretching it surely? Who would open the batting? On the subject of the batting order for the Test match Hussain said that he was always thinking of ways to improve the team. Therefore he had not ruled out dropping down the order himself, which is a slight change of tack. But the chances are that he will still be at three on Wednesday in Kandy, which really will be a fraught occasion.

fields.trailText: Jon Snow tried to lecture ITV on current affairs (Books, last week).
fields.body:
Jon Snow tried to lecture ITV on current affairs (Books, last week). However, readers should be reminded that Mr Snow's most recent high-profile foray into this area involved interviewing that well-known deep throat, Monica Lewinsky, who trousered £400,000 from Channel 4, plus this Clintonesque tribute from Mr Snow: 'She wanted to put the record straight and let the world know who the face, the lips, the teeth, the big hair and the beret really is. I was impressed with her, yes.'
Steve Anderson
Controller of News, Current Affairs, Arts & Religion, ITV
London WC1

fields.headline: Hurt Gers go with Flo
fields.standfirst: Rangers win comes at a price.
fields.trailText: Rangers win comes at a price.
fields.body:
What began as a hard shift for Rangers ended as a routine, largely untroubled collection of three points, due largely to the precision, powerful heading of the goals scorer, Tore Andre Flo, and the foolishness of the Hearts captain, Colin Cameron, ordered off for a second caution seconds before the break.

Despite reducing the gap between themselves and Celtic to 10 points, however, it was a bad day for the champions, by far the most disappointing aspect being that the comeback of Giovanni van Bronckhorst - returning after a five-month absence with a serious groin injury - lasted a mere 23 minutes.

The Dutchman's breakdown was confirmed when he had to be replaced by the Finn, Jani Kauppila, who would himself be replaced at half-time by Kenny Miller. Van Bronckhorst had a few minutes earlier gone down in a tackle with Cameron - the Hearts midfielder incurring the booking that began the process towards dismissal - and it appeared likely that his problem was a recurrence of the old trouble.

Van Bronckhorst has been arguably Rangers' most significant long-term loss during a trying season in which they have harvested injuries in bunches. He has been missing for so long that even a return to fitness and form would probably be too late to rescue the championship, but second place (with its qualification for the Champions League) and the Tennents Scottish Cup remain worthwhile objectives.

In truth, Van Bronckhorst had looked no more effective than any of his team-mates while he was on the field, but a certain blandness on his part was understandable. In the 35 minutes that preceded the first of Flo's goals, the Ibrox side were once again notably without menace. Indeed, for the first quarter of the match, they encountered severe difficulty in breaking out of their own half.

The fact that Dick Advocaat had four central defenders in the team - one of them, Bert Konterman, in midfield - and Sergio Porrini in the unaccustomed left wing-back position was no aid to achieving creativity, harmony and fluency. But, more worryingly for the home support, before they gained a one-man and one-goal advantage, too many Rangers players seemed to lack ambition.

Hearts, fresh from their 7-1 thumping of Dunfermline a week earlier, were much more committed in attack, but they were no more threatening than their opponents. Apart from a weak header from Scott Severin and a shot from Andy Kirk that Stefan Klos tipped wide (it seemed to be missing the target in any case) they did not look capable of exploiting their ascendancy.

Their difficulty deepened when Cameron was sent off. The midfielder appeared to be quite properly punished with a second yellow card for a foolish challenge on Barry Ferguson, taking the Rangers midfielder from behind after he had played the ball back to his goalkeeper.

By then, Rangers already held the lead, Flo having towered over Austin McCann to reach a long, high cross from Billy Dodds on the left and send a simple header to the right of Roddy McKenzie from six yards.

The only other opportunity Rangers had in the first half came a little fortunately, when a free-kick by Lorenzo Amoruso deflected straight to Craig Moore. The big defender's low drive from close range was blocked and then cleared by the alert Severin.

These were no consolation to Hearts, but they did at least spare the Tynecastle side's hard-working 10 men a defeat by an embarrassing margin.

Despite reducing the gap between themselves and Celtic to 10 points, however, it was a bad day for the champions, by far the most disappointing aspect being that the comeback of Giovanni van Bronckhorst - returning after a five-month absence with a serious groin injury - lasted a mere 23 minutes. The Dutchman's breakdown was confirmed when he had to be replaced by the Finn, Jani Kauppila, who would himself be replaced at half-time by Kenny Miller. Van Bronckhorst had a few minutes earlier gone down in a tackle with Cameron - the Hearts midfielder incurring the booking that began the process towards dismissal - and it appeared likely that his problem was a recurrence of the old trouble. fields.headline: Boro face nervous run-in
fields.standfirst: Fifth draw in six games will worry supporters.
fields.trailText: Fifth draw in six games will worry supporters.
fields.body:
Dean Windass' move from Bradford City to Middlesbrough will undoubtedly improve his chances of playing Premiership football next season, but he shouldn't bank on a future among the elite.

Boro's fifth draw in six league games marginally extended the gap to the bottom three, but this was a performance to worry supporters who dread another relegation season.

It is hard to envisage them surviving unless they can improve in nine crucial matches which will provide Venables with the biggest challenge he has faced as a coach.

They did show belated aggression in the final stages when Sasa Ilic saved with his legs from Alen Boksic, but Charlton were always more assured and should have departed with only their third away win of the season.

Alan Curbishley's talented side also created the only chances of note. The first one was the best. With only two minutes gone, Radostin Kishishev's cross presented Jonatan Johansson with a glorious opportunity which he headed wide.

Johansson was the creator of another opening minutes later for Claus Jensen, who failed to connect cleanly as he met the cross near the penalty spot.

However, they were to prove the highlights of a shapeless first-half, where the poise and intelligence of Charlton's Scott Parker was in contrast to so much happening around him.

Parker's forward surges twice ended in off-target shots, while Shaun Bartlett was close at the climax of a slick move in the 11th minute.

Charlton coped easily defensively, knowing that Boro lacked the pace to hurt them. It is a failing that Windass won't eradicate.

The frustration of the crowd was evident and the opening moments of the second-half did nothing to alter that mood.

Charlton would have been ahead within a minute if Shaun Bartlett's touch had been as accomplished as his slide into the snow bank behind the goal after he met a cross from Johansson.

With Boro in disarray, even Charlton's defenders got in on the act. Richard Rufus' header drifted wide and Middlesbrough keeper Mark Schwarzer had to deal smartly with a shot hooked inside the post by Fish.

This was a grim spell for Venables when those heady early days of his Riverside reign suddenly seemed to be a long, long time ago.

fields.headline: Dan's so deadly
fields.standfirst: Dispiriting home defeat leaves City in deep trouble.
fields.trailText: Dispiriting home defeat leaves City in deep trouble.
fields.body:
A week is a long time in football, 25 years considerably longer. Only two days after Manchester City 'celebrated' the twenty-fifth anniversary of their last trophy success, they managed to undo the good work of last weekend's victory at Newcastle with a dispiriting home defeat by Southampton.

City started impressively though - purposeful and confident against a Southampton team who had, remarkably, not conceded a Premiership goal since Anfield on New Year's Day and who had only allowed two in the last eight league games.

It was easy to see why. Glenn Hoddle, fast rebuilding his reputation after the ill-fated time managing the national team, has his side well-organised in defence, fluid, if unspectacular, in attack, and the Saints dealt relatively comfortably with what the home side threw at them in the first half.

The closest City came to ending Saints' run of five consecutive clean sheets came when Darren Huckerby darted to the left-hand by-line in the 13th minute and crossed to the far post where Shaun Goater should have done better with a header that Paul Jones kept out well.

While Huckerby, playing up front with Goater, frequently pulled into the wide left position, Andrei Kanchelskis was operating, with reasonable effect, as a more orthodox right-winger. Only his tendency to over-elaborate prevented City testing Jones further.

Kanchelskis sent a third-minute shot skidding wide of the goal, Huckerby was denied when Jones caught his shot on the turn from the edge of the area and the keeper held a 35-yard free-kick from Danny Tiatto. But, these sporadic moments of promise aside, the quality of City's attacking play did not match their unquestionable commitment.

German striker Uwe Rosler, a firm favourite at City during their last Premiership spell, was afforded a hero's welcome by the home fans both before the game and when he came on as a 29th-minute substitute for the injured James Beattie.

His entrance seemed tailor-made for one of those quintessential Maine Road moments - part tragedy, part farce - that have blighted the club over the past quarter century. Rosler's arrival certainly saw the visitors pick up their attacking momentum.

The German's understandable keenness to excel against his former club - he did not leave Maine Road on the best of terms - had the necessary effect on his team-mates and, having weathered a bright but unproductive start to the second half by the home side, Southampton took the lead.

Tahar El Khalej's long throw-in was helped square across the area by the head of Dean Richards and Dan Petrescu volleyed in emphatically from 16 yards to increase the possibility of City playing First Division football next season.

fields.headline: Bent finish sees justice done
fields.standfirst: Blackburn enhance promotion prospects.
fields.trailText: Blackburn enhance promotion prospects.
fields.body:
On paper, this should have been a difficult match against another of the division's better sides. In practice, the only real doubt was whether Blackburn would score and win, or not and draw. In the end Marcus Bent's simple strike ensured the former.

For Graeme Souness's side this was an eleventh win in 16 games and cemented the belief around these parts that Rovers are soon to return to the top flight. They have certainly left themselves in a position to do so, although today they will seek some assistance from an unlikely source.

After spending the whole season cursing their incessant success and waiting in desperation for signs of weakness, Blackburn will be desperate for Fulham to win today. Should Bolton lose at Craven Cottage then Rovers, with two games in hand, would be ready to pounce on the second promotion spot.

It took Blackburn just 49 seconds to fashion their first chance, only for Damien Duff to shoot weakly at Russell Hoult. Within minutes, Duff combined with Eyal Berkovic to set up first Matt Jansen, then David Dunn, and it seemed that victory would be secured without undue duress. But the visitors gradually came into the game, and it was the home fans who fell quiet first.

West Brom have promotion hopes of their own, having occupied a play-off position for most of the season. But their cause here was not helped by suspensions to Neil Clement, who missed his first game of the season, and top-scorer Lee Hughes. With Jason Roberts forced by injury to start on the bench, their threat was never great.

Having accomplished their first-half mission by stemming the flow of home chances, West Brom fell behind within 90 seconds of the restart. Berkovic, on his home debut, was the creator, running to the byline and pulling back to leave the unmarked Bent with a simple finish.

This time the flow was not so easily stopped, and after Alan Mahon and Dunn had both come close, Bent should have extended his side's lead. But his poor control let him down when through on goal, allowing Hoult to clear. Roberts rose from the bench almost immediately afterwards, adding some much-needed vigour to the away attacks. Their best chance, though, fell to Bob Taylor but he could only miskick with Brad Friedel closing in.

fields.headline: Kirkland keeps it clean
fields.standfirst: Hartson aggressive but Coventry are tame.
fields.trailText: Hartson aggressive but Coventry are tame.
fields.body:
John Hartson may not be the most elegant or athletic footballer in the business, as Gordon Strachan pointed out in his programme notes, but he doesn't half ruffle feathers.

Marcel Desailly, world and European champion with France and one of the greatest defenders of the modern era, was the latest centre-half to discover what playing against Hartson is all about.

For 35 minutes or so, Desailly had brushed away most of Coventry's half-hearted attacks with the ease and arrogance he displayed while winning European Cups.

But then he failed to control a ball and conceded a throw-in 30 yards from his own goal. As he chased the ball onto the cinder track and bent over it, presumably in a bid to pick it up and waste time, Hartson appeared from nowhere and bundled Desailly over as he beat him to the ball.

Desailly's not inconsiderable frame went crashing into the advertising hoardings while Hartson took a quick throw to set up an attack which ended with him shooting just wide of the Chelsea goal.

It did not end there. Desailly, his pride more bruised than his body, eventually staggered back into the fray only to be told by Hartson in no uncertain terms that the Welshman was his assailant - and what did he wish to do about it?

Desailly spent the rest of the half waving his arms in disbelief and astonishment, and it clearly affected his game and first David Thompson and then Craig Bellamy sped past him almost without challenge. So it was no great surprise to see him replaced at half-time by John Terry.

Hartson's aggression, however, was in contrast to the almost mild-mannered approach of most of his team-mates, who let Chelsea create the better chances and then squandered the few that came their way. Thompson was guilty of the worst miss, volleying wide from 12 yards with the goal at his mercy after good work from Bellamy and John Eustace.

Coventry's goalkeeper, Chris Kirkland, was on fine form in the second-half, keeping out fierce shots from Gronkjaer and Hasselbaink, and when he was finally beaten, by a late free-kick from substitute Gianfranco Zola, the ball struck the woodwork.

Coventry also had good chances, with Thompson having a shot cleared off the line by Terry and a free-kick well saved, as well as Hadji going close with a similar effort.

Carlo Cudicini's best stop came in the final minutes when he prevented an own goal by tipping the ball away.

When Mario Stanic chipped a great chance over the bar, Chelsea's best chance of ending their 11-month barren away win in the league was gone - but a point was not much use to Coventry.

fields.headline: Families visit crash site
fields.trailText: The families of five of the 10 victims of the Selby rail crash visited the site yesterday, including the two sons of freight train driver Stephen Dunn. Andrew, 12, and James, nine, with their mother Mary, placed flowers and messages by the bridge near where Gary Hart's Land Rover plunged onto the track at Great Heck on Wednesday, precipitating the two train pile-up.
fields.body:
The families of five of the 10 victims of the Selby rail crash visited the site yesterday, including the two sons of freight train driver Stephen Dunn. Andrew, 12, and James, nine, with their mother Mary, placed flowers and messages by the bridge near where Gary Hart's Land Rover plunged onto the track at Great Heck on Wednesday, precipitating the two train pile-up.

The notes read: 'To Daddy, I know we had our fall outs but we still loved each other. I promise I will do my best to help mum. I will see you later, love Andrew.' The second read: 'Roses are red, violets are blue, I really, really love you. See you in Heaven, love from James.'

Angie Hill, the wife of Andrew Hill, the co-driver in the freight train who survived, laid flowers in the mangled cab. A memorial service will be held today at Hensall parish church, two miles from Great Heck.

Police said they would not know the final death toll until all the wreckage has been removed and examined. Four of the dead have not been named.

Police have talked to Hart, of Strubby, Lincolnshire, who has been described as 'inconsolable' with grief. They stressed that he has not been arrested.

The wreckage of the GNER 125 train which was derailed by Hart's car is expected to be cleared today. The freight train that ploughed into it, killing its driver, will then be moved. Police will return the site to Railtrack on Monday.

fields.headline: Healthy mind 'is weapon against illness'
fields.trailText: It's what New Age healers have known all along: the mind does matter.
fields.body:
It's what New Age healers have known all along: the mind does matter.

A study has shown that a positive state of mind can be almost as effective as drugs at fighting serious disease.

Researchers found that therapy can significantly reduce the amount of HIV virus in gay men suffering from the disease. It is the first to show that counselling can have such a dramatic impact.

'From now on every single doctor treating HIV - and many other serious diseases - should think hard about helping patients with their mental health, so the outcome of the treatment will be better. It's not enough just to give people pills,' said Dr Alberto Avendaño, director of HIV services at the University of Maryland's Department of Family Medicine.

Earlier research has suggested a link between grief and a weakened immune system. Doctors also know that stress can exacerbate many illnesses.

However, the study, published in the Journal of Human Virology , is the first to show how actively giving therapy to people can lead to an immediate improvement in their physical health.

More than 100 gay men who were HIV positive and had lost a partner from Aids in the previous six months were split into two groups. One set was given grief therapy and the other sent on a community programme. The therapy encouraged crying and venting, figuring out how to face the future, and learning ways to deal with stress.

Blood tests were given before and after the 10 sessions, and it was found that the therapy significantly reduced the amount of the HIV virus in men. The changes reflected a marked improvement in the patients' physical wellbeing.

webTitle: Horrors grow in Britain's violent jails

fields.headline: Horrors grow in Britain's violent jails
fields.standfirst: Bullying regimes and a breakdown of respect for authority have led to a staggering increase in violence at young offender institutions
fields.trailText: Bullying regimes and a breakdown of respect for authority have led to a staggering increase in violence at young offender institutions.
fields.body:
The teenager looked the prison governor in the eye. Jailed for a series of petty crimes, he was due to be released the following day. But he was not a reformed character. Nor was he scared of the governor.

'I get out tomorrow,' the youth calmly informed Danny McAllister, who took charge of the Brinsford Young Offenders' Institution, regarded as the most violent jail in Britain, last April. 'Before I go,' the inmate added, 'I'm going to smash up my cell. And there's nothing you can do.'

McAllister told the story last week to illustrate his extreme frustration. 'This young man went off and did just what he said he would. And he was right: there was nothing I could do.'

Last week McAllister was praised for his attempts to turn Brinsford around in an otherwise damning report from Chief Inspector of Prisons Sir David Ramsbotham. But he admits he is swimming against a tide of drug-fuelled violence and the total breakdown of respect for authority. 'We are not dealing with a cross-section of society here,' Ramsbotham said. 'This is a distillation of young men in crisis who have been failed by family, schools and the community. It is very strong stuff.'

Three further horrifying reports into young offender institutions (YOIs) are due to be released shortly. They demonstrate what senior members of the prison inspectorate are now beginning to call 'a culture of penal pessimism', with little hope for the young men described in the Brinsford report as 'the detritus of long-standing social exclusion'.

The reports focus on:

 Stoke Heath, Shropshire: It is alleged the now suspended governor had allowed a regime of bullying to develop. When inspectors examined records they were 'horrified' to discover more than 1,000 assaults in a year.

 Feltham 'B': The over-18s wing of the prison described by Ramsbotham as 'rotten to the core' is branded as 'still appalling'. Older prisoners have been neglected while improvements have been made for juveniles .

 Portland: Inspectors have discovered little improvement at the Hampshire institution renowned for its 'militaristic' regime. Police are investigating 35 cases of alleged assault by officers.

Director of the Prison Service Martin Narey last week brushed aside Ramsbotham's calls for root-and-branch reform of YOIs.

The Chief Inspector has called for the closure of the worst YOIs and the appointment of a single senior figure to take responsibility for young offenders. Narey has said changes in management at Brinsford and other YOIs have already brought about considerable improvements.

But senior figures within the prison inspectorate have warned Narey not to ignore the growing crisis that has afflicted the system since the abolition of the Borstal system in 1980. Some, it is believed, are urging a return to the public school-based Borstal model of self-improvement for young prisoners.

McAllister, like many of his colleagues, blames the Government's new detention and training orders (DTOs) for the staggering rise in the assault rate among juvenile offenders. The new sentences, in which the offenders automatically spend half their sentence in prison and half in the community, prohibit staff from adding extra days as a punishment. McAllister believes that this has led to a collapse in discipline.

'It always used to be the case that prisoners became better behaved towards the end of their sentence. With these new sentences it is the complete opposite.' He points to a graph showing the sharp rise in assaults since inmates on DTOs were introduced to the prison last May. In April there were five assaults by juvenile prisoners; a month later the number had more than quadrupled to 23 and has remained high ever since. In 10 months, there have been more than 200 assaults.

McAllister claims there is a 'gentler feel about the jail' since he took over, but he remains fatalistic about the endemic violence: 'When you get 500 young men in a school or an army barracks or a prison you get bullying. It's the human condition.'

When Ramsbotham visited Brinsford, a 500-inmate, modern, red-brick warehouse just outside Wolverhampton, last June he described the level of neglect as 'breathtaking'. His report was finally released by the Home Office last week after an eight-month delay. Ramsbotham said it was one of the most disturbing inspections he had ever carried out and led him to coin a chilling phrase for the practice of YOIs such as Brinsford - 'institutionalised child abuse'.

At Brinsford, staff and inmates alike agreed that detention and training orders were making the prison unmanageable. While the number of hours prisoners spend in 'purposeful activity' such as education or sport has increased by 58 per cent, teachers working at the prison said this had been matched by a similar rise in violent behaviour among the younger inmates, who had developed a 'big, bad gangster culture'. Art teacher Mark Johnson said he had been threatened with violence on several occasions: 'In the run-up to release, the juveniles refuse to do any work and it just disrupts everything you try to do.'

The four students working at clay models in Johnson's classroom can't be named for legal reasons, but they all agreed that Brinsford was a 'stitch-up' jail, where prisoners spent little or no time outside their cells. 'I heard about this place before I came here,' said one wide-eyed 16-year-old. 'I heard that it was bad but it is really horrible. Everything that the papers have been saying about this place is true.'

Martyn Carless and Andrew Doyle, both 19, said that heroin and crack cocaine were at the heart of the prison's bullying problem. 'The heroin addicts come in here and they start to cold- turkey and that makes them easy to pick on,' says Doyle. 'And then they can't afford to pay for tobacco, and that's when they get into real trouble.' Around a fifth of the inmates of Brinsford test positive for drugs.

Carless and Doyle, who have been in Brinsford six and seven times respectively, said that crime was the only way they knew to make money and the same went for most of the people they knew. 'You see the same faces over and over again,' said Carless. 'One day they've been released and the next day they're back in here again.'

Meanwhile, the assaults go on. In the segregation unit, renamed the Intervention Assessment Unit by the new governor, 19-year-old John Davies is being held as a punishment for attacking a guard. He says he 'lost it' after he was refused permission to go to the library with other prisoners. Davies, who has to wear a special blue and yellow uniform after he escaped from Portland YOI, claims he was grabbed by the throat by a prison officer and set upon by three others. His complaint is under investigation by local police. 'I don't want to be here,' says Davies. 'I just keep on getting into trouble.'

Local MP Sir Patrick Cormack, who was visiting the prison at the same time as The Observer, said he had demanded a meeting with Prisons Minister Paul Boateng to discuss the problem of young offenders and, in particular, detention and training orders. 'I am deeply impressed by the present governor at Brinsford. But the problem is with the system itself. Ministers have to stop ignoring what Sir David Ramsbotham is saying.'

Harry Fletcher of probation union Napo said: 'The Home Secretary and the head of the Prison Service need to recognise that there has been 20 years of neglect, underfunding and lack of vision.'

Danny McAllister is already making a difference at the jail: anti-bullying and anti-racist strategies have been introduced and work with addicts has led to a fall in positive drug tests. But he says he is concerned that Britain was creating a hardened criminal class on the American model by locking up increasing numbers of young people. 'It is important to remember that most young men stop offending by the age of 25. In California they spend more money on prisons than education. As a citizen I think that is wrong. Society has a right to be protected from having their car stolen or being assaulted, but we also have a duty to these young men.'

fields.headline: £30,000 'lure' in scramble for pilots
fields.standfirst: A drastic shortage of pilots is forcing airlines to pay record salaries to keep their planes airborne in an expanding industry
fields.trailText: A drastic shortage of pilots is forcing airlines to pay record salaries to keep their planes airborne in an expanding industry.
fields.body:
A combination of phenomenal growth in low-cost airlines and the lack of in-house training schemes has sent carriers into a panic as they compete to find flyers. Some airlines are exploiting legal loopholes to employ foreign pilots trained outside the EU, causing concern over the safety implications. Others are bumping up pay scales to stop staff being poached and to attract crews.

No-frills carrier easyJet is offering pilots up to £30,000 as a one-off 'golden hello' to join its fleet. The Luton-based operator is also advertising top salaries of almost £70,000. Its Irish competitor, Ryanair, which is to buy 13 aircraft to add to its fleet of 36, has unveiled impressive pay packages of up to £100,000 a year, with another six-figure sum in share options for employees who choose to stay in the job for five years.

The shortage of pilots is a problem set to escalate as Boeing has predicted that there will be 28,000 commercial aircraft in service across the world by 2005, double the number now. If the ratio remains at 40 per cent of flights to long-haul destinations, the demand for flight-deck crew within that timespan could reach 200,000 pilots required globally. There are now 80,000 commercially trained pilots worldwide.

The British Airline Pilots' Association has completed a report on the crisis which will be handed to employment Ministers. A spokesman said: 'The problem is that the airlines are being myopic. No one is thinking long term. Nobody is training; everybody is just poaching.'

Balpa points to 300 pilots who have licences but need an airline to sponsor the 1,500 air hours they need to qualify fully in the commercial market. All pilots need around a month's training before they can switch from one aircraft to another.

One flying instructor said: 'People can come and learn to fly, but to fly for a living you are looking an at an almost impossible financial hurdle.'

Additional reporting by Claire Rigby

webTitle: Help at last for suicidal young men

fields.headline: Help at last for suicidal young men
fields.standfirst: More males in their twenties die by their own hand than in car crashes. MPs are demanding action to stem the tide
fields.trailText: More males in their twenties die by their own hand than in car crashes. MPs are demanding action to stem the tide.
fields.body:
The soaring suicide rate among young men, which means they are now more likely to die by their own hand than be killed in a car crash, will this week be confronted by a new parliamentary committee set up to investigate the scale of the tragedy.

The suicide rate for young men has doubled since the early Eighties, while for women it has almost halved. Suicide is now the biggest single cause of death of men aged 25 to 34, who are more than five times likely to take their lives as women of the same age, according to figures from the Office for National Statistics. The All Party Group on Men's Health is so alarmed that in its inaugural meeting it will press for measures to ensure that suicidal young men can find help. The launch is being supported by Public Health Minister Yvette Cooper. Howard Stoate, chairman of the men's health group, said: 'It's the commonest cause of death among young men. It's an important issue and is under-recognised - most people have no idea it is so high - but the statistics are shocking.'

Overall, suicide has overtaken car accidents as a cause of death among men. Each year about 3,600 men take their lives, compared to 1,200 women. Dr Ian Banks, chairman of the Men's Health Forum, which advises the Government, said: 'If this rate of death among young men was an infection, there would have been a lot more attention paid to it.'

The new measures will come too late to help Mike Whitaker, who seemed to have everything to live for. He was in his last year of a chemistry degree at Bath University and was expected to get a first. He had a job lined up, a girlfriend and was captain of the clay pigeon shooting team. 'He was very successful at whatever he did.' said his mother, Jenny Whitaker.

But one morning at the end of the Christmas break, Jenny awoke to find the car gone, while her husband found the back door open. Then they saw a one-line handwritten note against the bedroom door of Mark's younger brother: 'Sorry bro - look after Mum and Dad.' Half an hour later the police found him in the car with a pipe from the exhaust to the window.

'We were astounded. We knew he was upset about a university project, but we had no idea he was that ill.' said his mother. 'He was a perfectionist and did keep things to himself. He hadn't spoken to anyone about being desperately distressed.'

Simon Armson, chief executive of the Samaritans, said that this refusal to talk about problems is a key reason why men are more likely to kill themselves than women. 'They are more likely to internalise feelings until it gets too big a burden to bear, and then it leads to self-destruction. The British culture of stiff upper lip still reigns supreme,' he said. The Samaritans has tried to target men by advertisements on beer mats and in changing rooms.

Declan Curran, 13, hanged himself from a door with a guitar strap. He had been sexually abused and had no one he could talk to. 'As a lad you have to be tough, and if you're not you're a bit of an outcast,' said his brother Liam. There is a huge range in suicide rates among different groups of men. It is far higher - and rising - among unskilled men than among professional men. Men are more likely to kill themselves if they are from ethnic minorities, unmarried or gay.

Psycholgists say that the rise in suicide among men is a result of their loss of a role in society. Dale Peters, a market trader selling plants and flowers, hanged himself at 25 after splitting up with his girlfriend. 'He found it difficult to see where he was going. He was ticking over with a small business, but he wasn't doing particularly well - he didn't see a future for himself,' said his father, John Peters, who teaches psychology and works for the self-help group Survivors of Bereavement by Suicide. 'Many men have expectations they should be providers, and for a small percentage they don't live up to it.'

Males are falling behind females at school and university. The loss of unskilled jobs has hit men with few educational qualifications particularly hard. 'Young men cannot see what their role is, and often their parents cannot see what their role is,' said Peters. 'The men can be perfectly sane in coming to that decision. For so many it is a very determined act.'

More women than men attempt suicide each year, but are less likely to succeed. They usually choose methods such as an overdose of pills which can often be tackled in casualty wards, and are often seen as pleas for help. Men tend to choose violent, decisive methods, such as hanging, jumping off buildings, crashing a car or shooting themselves.

'There's fatalism about the whole thing. People say they're going to do it anyway, but that's just not true,' said Banks. 'There are many practical things we can do. Changing men's attitudes to themselves is a long-term job, but it's not impossible.'

anthony.browne@observer.co.uk

Samaritans helpline: 08457 90 90 90

Survivors of Bereavement by Suicide helpline: 0870 241 3337

Shadow of Suicide helpline for bereaved parents: 0117 953 9639

webTitle: Internet twins could return to US within weeks

fields.headline: Internet twins could return to US within weeks
fields.trailText: The custody battle for the twins at the heart of the internet adoption scandal was mired in new controversy last night when it emerged that they could be sent back to authorities in the US within weeks.
fields.body:
The custody battle for the twins at the heart of the internet adoption scandal was mired in new controversy last night when it emerged that they could be sent back to authorities in the US within weeks.

Legal experts believe that continued court battles in the US will force British authorities to pass judgment on the twins' case within weeks, handing them to American officials 'within a month'.

The Welsh couple Alan and Judith Kilshaw, who claim they rightfully bought the twins from an American internet adoption agency, await the judgment of Birmingham High Court over their application to become the twins' guardians.

But last week a court in St Louis, Missouri, ruled that the twins should be returned to the country of their birth where two court battles - in Arkansas and Missouri - over their adoption are continuing. It is now up to the judge in Birmingham to send the twins back.

'The likelihood is that they will return to the US,' said Deborah Cullen, an adoption lawyer and legal spokesperson for British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering. 'Unless there is some subtle argument for the the Kilshaws being granted custody, Birmingham High Court will hear the case within weeks and you could see them move to the US within a month.'

Judith Kilshaw admitted yesterday that she and her husband were not going to win the Birmingham court case, the next hearing of which is scheduled for 19 March, adding that the decision had, in her opinion, already been taken against them at 'higher levels'.

'There's a political agenda' she said. 'If I won, it would say that it is all right to adopt from the US.

'I wouldn't call [the latest] US court decision a judgment - it's more a request. I think the twins should be sent back to Arkansas - that's where the paperwork and the judges are. I don't want them to go back to Tranda [Wecker, their birth mother]. [She made] allegations that I smell. I put perfume on and we bathe like normal people.'

The likelihood of yet another move for the twins will anger campaigners who believe that their repeated moving between foster parents and social services has unnecessarily added to the disruption the eight-month-old girls have experienced. The twins could leave the care of British social services, to be passed to another temporary foster family in the US, before being found a final foster home.

This would give the girls five sets of foster parents in a matter of months.

Recriminations and controversy continue to surround the battle for the twins. Judith Kilshaw claimed that Tina Johnson, who sold the girls to both the Kilshaws and another couple in California - Richard and Vicky Allen - through her internet adoption agency, was now being offered film and book deals for her story.

Richard Allen has subsequently been charged with sexually abusing two other girls. He denies the charges.

webTitle: Drugs edge out drink as road danger

fields.headline: Drugs edge out drink as road danger
fields.trailText: One in 10 young motorists has driven after taking illegal drugs, the first government study of drug-driving reveals. Police fear that drug-driving is now more common than drink-driving among the under-40s.
fields.body:
One in 10 young motorists has driven after taking illegal drugs, the first government study of drug-driving reveals. Police fear that drug-driving is now more common than drink-driving among the under-40s.

Ministers ordered the most detailed study of its kind after figures revealed that the number of crash victims testing positive for illegal drugs has risen sixfold in the past decade. Traces of illegal drugs are found in one in five of those killed on the road.

The study, carried out by researchers at System Three and by scientists at Glasgow University, found that 9 per cent of drivers had driven after taking drugs ranging from cannabis to cocaine. More than half had done so in the previous six months.

One third of drug-drivers said they had taken cannabis before driving, while others said they had abused stimulants, hallucinogens, opiates and suppressants, including LSD, ecstasy and cocaine.

Men aged 20 to 24 were more likely than women to abuse drugs and drive, the researchers found. Many of the representative sample of a thousand 17-to-39-year-olds believed that cannabis did not affect their driving. Some even thought it improved it.

A huge 87 per cent said they had accepted a lift in a car driven by someone they knew had used drugs.

Drug use was most widespread among 16-to-30-year-olds going to clubs. One in two said he or she had driven within 12 hours of using an illegal drug. Among drug-drivers, 72 per cent had driven after taking cannabis, 43 per cent drove after taking ecstasy, 25 per cent had used amphetamines, 11 per cent cocaine and 8 per cent LSD. One-third said that they drove after taking drugs 'most weeks'. Most drug-drivers did not know that they could receive a six-month ban for driving after smoking cannabis and a one-year ban if they took to the wheel after taking Class A drugs. Most believed that charges could only be brought if they were driving recklessly.

The research has prompted calls for the police to be given new powers to tackle drug-driving. Senior officers want to introduce breathalyser-type roadside tests for all motorists suspected of drugs offences. At present, officers have to take suspects to a police station for blood tests.

John Vine, of the road policing committee of the Association of Chief Police Officers, said: 'Roadside tests will enable officers to detect more offenders.' Strathclyde Police have experimented with saliva swabs and wipes to test sweat for signs of illegal drugs and new equipment is being developed that can identify 200 different drugs.

The public backs new police powers. An RAC survey found that 90 per cent of drivers believe that police should be able to carry out roadside drug tests.

A spokesman for the Home Office described the survey as 'worrying'. Ministers are planning to fund an advertising campaign to highlight the risks of drug-driving.

Professor Neil McKeganey, director of the Centre for Drug Misuse Research at Glasgow University, who co- ordinated the research, said there is 'a clear need to provide much wider information on the legal consequences of drug-driving. We need to try to change public attitudes.

'Over the last few years there has been a dramatic reduction in the number of people arrested for drink-driving. Driving under the influence of alcohol has come to be seen as socially unacceptable. The same needs to happen in relation to illegal drug use.'

The study, funded by the Government, was based on two research projects. System Three Social Research carried out a survey of more than 1,000 drivers aged 17 to 39, while the Centre for Drug Misuse Research at Glasgow University surveyed people at nightclubs and interviewed 500 drivers stopped in the early hours of the morning.

john.arlidge@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Deep male voices are the best for falling asleep to

fields.headline: Deep male voices are the best for falling asleep to
fields.trailText: Mothers still bear responsibility for most of the world's childcare, but when it comes to bedtime stories they are simply not as well equipped as fathers.
fields.body:
Mothers still bear responsibility for most of the world's childcare, but when it comes to bedtime stories they are simply not as well equipped as fathers.

Deep male tones are preferred by both children and adults for reading aloud - women's voices are often perceived as less likely to aid restful sleep.

Research into the valuable skill of story-telling shows that most of the country's favourite voices belong to men. A two-week, online survey conducted by the internet entertainment site bol.com has revealed that the actor Alan Rickman has Britain's favourite bedtime reading voice.

His rich, dark timbre was chosen by 1,316 voters. The softer voices of some of the country's most accomplished actresses were at the bottom of the charts.

More than 8,000 voters registered their views on the subject after a shortlist of contenders had been drawn up by a panel of celebrities, including writer Jilly Cooper, broadcaster John Peel and actress Joanna Lumley.

The highest polling woman in the survey was broadcaster Mariella Fros-trup, with 884 votes. Adored by many for her provocative huskiness, she came in behind Stephen Fry, who scored 896.

The next highest woman in the poll was Dame Judi Dench on 738, but the rest of Britain's famous female voices languished in the 600s. Juliet Stevenson earned 679 votes, Lindsay Duncan 614 and Prunella Scales 602.

Cooper said she suspected the problem with women's voices was that they sound unconvincing in male roles. 'I am afraid I do have a problem with women readers putting on gruff voices and pretending to be men,' she said.

She picked the actors William Franklyn and Sam West, Prunella Scales's son, as her ideal bedtime readers. They have she said, 'incredibly sexy, soothing voices, so it would be a lovely thing to fall asleep to'.

Despite the clear bias in favour of sex appeal in the survey results, all the panellists believe a good reader has to have more than a sexy voice to make a story come alive.

Lumley said she loved Martin Jarvis's voice. 'It has just enough characterisation - and the late Michael Williams was fab.' Jarvis won 719 votes.

Peel nominated his wife, Sheila, as the one he would most like to read him to sleep and the presenter of Woman's Hour, Jenni Murray, chose the voice of her Radio 4 colleague, Today presenter Sue MacGregor. 'Her voice is soothing, melodious and utterly reassuring. I'm used to being woken up by her, gently, in the morning on the Today programme. I'm sure she would send me to sleep just as effectively, feeling all was well with the world.'

Historically, male speaking voices have been much more regularly celebrated. From the Welsh tones of Richard Burton to the idiosyncratic style of sports commentators John Arlott and Dan Maskell.

Mothers, however, are still on at least an equal footing with fathers when it comes to singing lullabies.

www.bol.com

fields.headline: Briton conquers city of style
fields.standfirst: The commercial fashion capital of the world, Milan, has invited gifted Luella Bartley to show her designs - while London let her down
fields.trailText: The commercial fashion capital of the world, Milan, has invited gifted Luella Bartley to show her designs - while London let her down.
fields.body:
Lasr season, Luella Bartley, the fashion journalist turned designer, showed her collection in a tiny studio in west London. The fashion press and photographers crammed into a tiny space to watch the models, including Bartley's friend Kate Moss, show off the clothes from a makeshift catwalk.

But things change quickly in the fashion world. On Tuesday, Bartley's label, called simply Luella, will be the centre of attention in the world's commercial fashion capital, Milan. She was offered a venue in the city for free. And that's an offer no British designer can refuse.

London Fashion Week simply doesn't attract the buyers and the international fashion press - something the ex-Vogue and London Evening Standard journalist knows only too well. Now that Alexander McQueen has signed away 51 per cent of his company to Gucci, it seems highly probable that he too will move his own show - the highlight of London Fashion Week - to Milan.

And Sir Paul Smith, who was in Milan last week to open his first Italian store, has suggested that shifting his womenswear show to the city may be inevitable. 'We are considering coming to show in Milan,' he told The Observer .

'You just don't get the quantity of press and buyers in London: It still costs you £150,000 to put on a show. It might cost you £175,000 in Milan, but you're more likely to get an extra £25,000 worth of press and business.'

His own business is now worth £220 million.

A graduate of Central Saint Martins College of Art and Design in London, Antonio Berardi, moved his show from Britain to Milan two years ago. For him it has made all the difference. He is now expanding from a solid manufacturing base in Italy.

His clothes attract more attention from international buyers in Italy than he would have dreamt of in London. John Richmond, who has a shop in Milan, and Rifat Ozbek, who is backed by the Italian manufacturer, AEFFE, also show in Milan.

The all-powerful Italian fashion industry is fuelled by British talent.

Behind the scenes, the design teams for every major fashion house - from Giorgio Armani to Prada - are handpicked each year from students of the Royal College of Art, Kingston University and Central Saint Martins.

British graduates churn out designs and research collections from the stalls of London's Portobello Market.

And it's not just our designers. British photographers and stylists produce some of the coolest advertising campaigns in Italy. Miuccia Prada is a great fan of London's cutting edge photographers, including Robert Wyatt and John Akehurst. The designer Missoni, meanwhile, has just signed up the London duo, Mert Alas and Marcus Piggott, for its next campaign.

The leather house, Bottega Veneta, has become one of the hottest labels on the planet, thanks to a British team, the designer, Giles Deacon, and his friend, Katie Grand, who, as the label's creative consultant and stylist, recommended him for the job three seasons ago.

'It's four hours door to door from London to Milan,' says Deacon, who commutes between the cities.

Gucci recently bought a two-thirds stake in Bottega Veneta, simply because the Brits have made it hip. The new collection is unveiled tomorrow evening and, along with Gucci's head designer Tom Ford, is the hottest ticket in town.

Of course, it's not what you know that counts in the fashion industry, but who you know. Grand, who edits Pop, the new biannual magazine from the publishers of The Face, also consults on Luella's collection. The two have been close friends since meeting in the early Nineties. Bartley is part of the Grand gang - she was on the cover of the magazine's first issue, alongside Stella McCartney and the model, Liberty Ross. It was through Grand that Bottega Veneta invited Luella to show in Milan. There are now rumours flying that Luella, with her sassy brand of London style, is next on Gucci's shopping list. The chances are, Luella is in Milan to stay.

fields.headline: No sex please - we're knackered
fields.standfirst: Love has become the latest casualty of the long hours culture, with 50 per cent of Britons claiming work-related tiredness affects their private lives
fields.trailText: Love has become the latest casualty of the long hours culture, with 50 per cent of Britons claiming work-related tiredness affects their private lives.
fields.body:
It's the end of a long day at the office. You struggle on to the bus, pick up a takeaway, stagger back home. What is the last thing on your mind? Sex, according to a new survey.

Research to be published tomorrow shows that more than half the people who work more than 48 hours a week simply don't feel like it when they get home.

The results come from two investigations into the effects of long hours by the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development, which says over 50 per cent of the people surveyed reported their sex lifes were suffering because partners working long hours were too tired.

'Nearly a third admit that work-related tiredness is causing their sex life to suffer, and 14 per cent report the loss of, or reduced, libido or sex drive in the last 12 months,' says the report.

The latest findings indicate that British love lives are suffering more because of long hours than was previously thought. A recent survey by the Work Life Balance Centre found that 10 per cent of people returning home late were too tired for anything other than snoring in bed.

However, nurses are more badly affected than most: two thirds of them said the hours they worked in hospitals were ruining their sex lives. Even TV's Naked Chef Jamie Oliver owned up to not having having the energy to sleep with his wife Jules after a gruelling day at the stove.

The worst problems hit those who both work long hours - known as TINS couples - Two Incomes No Sex, but it appears that love fatigue affects all types of workers from lorry drivers to white-collar managers.

At the same time, affairs in the office are growing. US author Shere Hite claims in her book Sex and Business that 71 per cent of men and 62 per cent of women have had an affair with someone they work with, and that more and more people are meeting their partners at the workplace.

In the UK, 35 per cent of people in full-time work in Britain admitted to having had affairs, and a further 36 per cent to feeling sorely tempted.

The research suggests long hours are a key factor. British workers clock the longest hours in Europe, outstaying German, French and Italian counterparts. Part of the reason is the high levels of overtime they put in. EU figures show British workers spend an average of 43.6 hours a week at their jobs, compared with an European average of 40.4 hours, and 38.4 hours in Belgium, which has the lowest weekly figure.

The situation has got dramatically worse in the UK over the years. In 1984, 2.8 million people were working more than 48 hours a week. By 1998, this figure had risen to more than four million.

Working long hours also causes tension between partners, with 20 per cent saying they had had arguments because of it in the CIPD survey, which combined interviews with 291 people and another representative sample of UK workers. Nearly half said their children complained that they did not see enough of parents who worked hard, and 27 per cent said they didn't always put their children to bed or help them with homework.

Meanwhile, most who work long hours feel they have struck the wrong work/life balance - 56 per cent of those surveyed by CIPD said they put too much emphasis on work. The survey also found that longer working hours had a bad effect on performance at work, and made accidents more likely, both at work and away from it. More than a third said they had made mistakes, from bad people management to property damage and personal injury.

Report author Melissa Compton-Edwards said: 'While working long hours doesn't necessarily lead to marriage breakdown, it can put a strain on relationships with partners, children and friends. The Faustian pact seems to be that while they would rather their "long hours" partner worked shorter hours, this is considered a price worth paying if it guarantees a decent standard of living.'

John Monks, the general secretary of the TUC, said: 'UK employees work the longest hours in Europe. This long hours' culture is as bad for business as it is for people's home lives.

'Employers should realise that the happiest, most productive workers are those who have time to enjoy a life outside work.

oliver.morgan@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Football stars slam transfer reforms
fields.trailText: They some of the wealthiest sports stars in the world. But now Britain's leading footballers, who earn more in a week than most people make in a year, have launched a furious attack on an unlikely target: the union boss who is trying to make them even more money.
fields.body:
They some of the wealthiest sports stars in the world. But now Britain's leading footballers, who earn more in a week than most people make in a year, have launched a furious attack on an unlikely target: the union boss who is trying to make them even more money.

In their first comments about the shake-up of soccer's transfer system, players such as England stars Martin Keown and Ray Parlour and Wales winger Ryan Giggs have condemned the activities of Gordon Taylor, the £400,000-a-year leader of the Professional Footballers Association.

The players, who earn up to £30,000-a-week each, have criticised plans championed by Taylor that would give them even bigger pay packets and significantly more power over the clubs they play for. They claim Taylor does not speak for the majority of players and that his proposals would force smaller clubs to close and cost many lower-division footballers their jobs.

Manchester United star Giggs warned that changes to the transfer system being pushed by Fifpro, the international grouping of players' unions which Taylor also heads, would ruin the game. 'The only players to gain from this situation are a greedy few and in the minority,' he said. 'It is the players in the lower leagues that are in the majority and they along with their clubs would lose the most if the transfer system as we know it collapses.'

Giggs also savaged Fifpro's push for players to be able to tear up their contracts and walk out on their clubs. His warning that this would threaten the existence of smaller clubs was backed by fellow stars such as Arsenal's Ray Parlour, Aston Villa's Gareth Southgate, Lucas Radebe of Leeds United and Sunderland's Michael Gray.

Fifpro says footballers should be able to give three months notice to quit, like most other employees. But soccer's governing bodies - Fifa, Uefa and England's Premier League - want players to have to honour at least three years of the contracts they sign. They want the European Union to agree that stars who do not do that can be banned from playing for up to a year.

Some of the game's biggest names argue that while Fifpro's plans may benefit a minority of top stars, the majority of players, who are in the unglamorous lower divisions, will lose the security of the existing system. They claim that if players can terminate contracts at short notice, clubs will do the same thing to unload players who have been injured, lost form or fallen out of favour with the manager.

The players' intervention will spark a civil war within the PFA. All of them complain they have barely been consulted by either the PFA or Fifpro. Many said they had never even heard of Fifpro, despite its claiming to speak on their behalf with the EU.

The top players' views are expressed in a poll conducted by the Premier League among club captains and PFA representatives. Its officials, and many chairmen in the top division, are furious that Taylor has allegedly done a U-turn over transfers. Last autumn in The Observer he castigated the EU's plans. Now Fifpro is urging Brussels to abolish transfers altogether. If that happens, multi-million pound transfer fees will instead go to players in the form of higher salaries.

The poll comes a day before football's leaders and the EU meet in Brussels to try again to thrash out an agreement.

Last week Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger criticised fellow bosses such as Manchester United's Sir Alex Ferguson for not doing enough to fight the EU's drive to scrap transfers. Wenger believes managing a club side will become impossible if the EU gives footballers far greater freedom of movement, because team-building will be undermined by the number of players arriving, staying briefly and then leaving, probably to earn more money elsewhere.
