'It is the players in the lower leagues that are in the majority and they along with their clubs would lose the most if the transfer system as we know it collapses.' Giggs also savaged Fifpro's push for players to be able to tear up their contracts and walk out on their clubs. His warning that this would threaten the existence of smaller clubs was backed by fellow stars such as Arsenal's Ray Parlour, Aston Villa's Gareth Southgate, Lucas Radebe of Leeds United and Sunderland's Michael Gray. Fifpro says footballers should be able to give three months notice to quit, like most other employees. But soccer's governing bodies - Fifa, Uefa and England's Premier League - want players to have to honour at least three years of the contracts they sign. They want the European Union to agree that stars who do not do that can be banned from playing for up to a year. Some of the game's biggest names argue that while Fifpro's plans may benefit a minority of top stars, the majority of players, who are in the unglamorous lower divisions, will lose the security of the existing system. They claim that if players can terminate contracts at short notice, clubs will do the same thing to unload players who have been injured, lost form or fallen out of favour with the manager. The players' intervention will spark a civil war within the PFA. All of them complain they have barely been consulted by either the PFA or Fifpro. Many said they had never even heard of Fifpro, despite its claiming to speak on their behalf with the EU. The top players' views are expressed in a poll conducted by the Premier League among club captains and PFA representatives. Its officials, and many chairmen in the top division, are furious that Taylor has allegedly done a U-turn over transfers. Last autumn in The Observer he castigated the EU's plans. Now Fifpro is urging Brussels to abolish transfers altogether. If that happens, multi-million pound transfer fees will instead go to players in the form of higher salaries. The poll comes a day before football's leaders and the EU meet in Brussels to try again to thrash out an agreement. Last week Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger criticised fellow bosses such as Manchester United's Sir Alex Ferguson for not doing enough to fight the EU's drive to scrap transfers. Wenger believes managing a club side will become impossible if the EU gives footballers far greater freedom of movement, because team-building will be undermined by the number of players arriving, staying briefly and then leaving, probably to earn more money elsewhere.

fields.headline: Reds put to bed
fields.trailText: A season of high hopes, silver dreams and many, many matches is catching up with Liverpool. Bereft of sufficient energy to take the game to Leicester, and punished by Ade Akinbiyi and Muzzy Izzett's clinical finishing, their relentless schedule poses a serious threat to their aspirations.
fields.body:
A season of high hopes, silver dreams and many, many matches is catching up with Liverpool. Bereft of sufficient energy to take the game to Leicester, and punished by Ade Akinbiyi and Muzzy Izzett's clinical finishing, their relentless schedule poses a serious threat to their aspirations.

Given Liverpool's renaissance - their Worthington Cup triumph is seen on Merseyside as a prelude to more success in the Uefa Cup, FA Cup and an upwardly mobile surge into the top three of the Premiership - Leicester were hoping their opponents might suffer from fatigue. Frankly, they looked drained.

Liverpool's torpor, coupled with a workmanlike performance from Leicester, made for a first half generously described as forgettable. There was a flash of early promise when Nick Barmby and Emile Heskey combined to release Christian Ziege, whose rifled shot was well parried by Simon Royce. After that there was precious little incident until the half-time entertainment. This just about sums up the mood: Robbie Savage unleashed a shot that stung an executive box and woke Liverpool from the slumbers enough for a forward break. Barmby's astutely clipped pass found Heskey, but, on his return to Filbert Street, the young striker could only fire over.

It was cat and mouse as both sides appeared content to give nothing away. Liverpool enjoyed early possession without end product and City began to probe, but found the red rearguard tough to crack, until the lively Dean Sturridge created their best first-half chance for himself. He hared forward to win a one-on-one chase with Sander Westerveld, only to see the ball bounce unkindly, and drift narrowly wide.

Sensing the game was there to be seized, Leicester emerged the brighter after the interval. When Andrew Impey's threatening cross was intercepted at the last by Stephane Henchoz, there was danger in the air. A minute later City were ahead.

Izzett fed Sturridge, who dashed into the box and produced a tantalisingly low cross to pick out Ade Akinbiyi. The Nigerian international, bought to replace Heskey, nipped in front of Jamie Carragher to confidently turn in his eighth goal of the season.

Gérard Houllier responded with a reshuffle, sending on Michael Owen, so disgruntled to be unused during last weekend's Cardiff final, to join Robbie Fowler and Heskey up front. Suddenly Liverpool had a positive impulse. Fowler's drive was cleared off the line by Matt Elliott and Ziege's follow-up effort was punched clear by Royce.

Liverpool swarmed forward but the firm Leicester defence resisted, the platform for Izzett to finish the visitors off in injury time, sweeping the ball coolly past Westerveld.

With two quarter-finals in the next seven days, away at Porto and Tranmere, Liverpool need every spare minute to rest those tired legs.

fields.headline: Unsworth makes amends
fields.trailText: A striker spurned can be an angry animal, particularly if he has not scored for four months. The fact that Alan Shearer was out of action for half that time did nothing to lessen his displeasure when going down under the penalty-box challenge of his rival captain David Weir. The referee, David Elleray, was equally adamant about his decision not to award a spot kick.
fields.body:
A striker spurned can be an angry animal, particularly if he has not scored for four months. The fact that Alan Shearer was out of action for half that time did nothing to lessen his displeasure when going down under the penalty-box challenge of his rival captain David Weir. The referee, David Elleray, was equally adamant about his decision not to award a spot kick.

Shearer would have been even more aggrieved had Francis Jeffers done justice to the through pass from Kevin Campbell, which played him clear of the Newcastle defence a minute later. Jeffers, with plenty of time to steady himself, placed his shot too near Shay Given, who saved with his legs.

It was the start of a rotten first half for Everton, who wasted other chances and had two players carried off. The first was Gary Naysmith who seemed to be caught by Andrew Griffin after pulling the ball back from the baseline to Campbell, who knocked a golden opportunity wide of the far post.

In first-half stoppage time Alex Nyarko went down awkwardly and was also replaced immediately. David Unsworth and Idan Tal were the two men introduced, with Walter Smith reluctant at this stage to bring on Paul Gascoigne, back in the squad for the first time since early November after surgery.

Campbell was unable to make use of a more difficult chance which Weir created by hoisting a long ball into the box. Campbell made contact with his head but could only direct the ball straight at Shay Given. There was another vigorous protest, this time from Scot Gemmill who claimed that his volley was deflected behind by the hand of a Newcastle defender. Nothing doing, ruled Elleray again.

Shearer rose well to test Paul Gerrard with a header from Nolberto Solano's cross, and shortly before Nyarko's departure Gerrard was fortunate to see Michael Ball tidy up after his one-handed deflection of a cut-back from Shola Ameobi came loose inside the six-yard box.

Newcastle's goal came a minute into the second half. Shearer, chasing what looked like a lost cause, closed down Xavier and when the former England captain's low-angle shot was pushed out by Gerrard the ball struck Unsworth and rebounded into the net.

Everton drew level six minutes from time when Unsworth went some way to compensating for his error by converting a penalty after Campbell was fouled by Steve Caldwell.

fields.headline: Santos doubles up as a striker
fields.trailText: George Santos, one of the league's most versatile players, boosted Sheffield United's play-off hopes yesterday.
fields.body:
George Santos, one of the league's most versatile players, boosted Sheffield United's play-off hopes yesterday.

This did not seem likely at QPR when Michael Ngonge gave the home team a deserved lead. But Shaun Murphy equalised just after half-time and Santos, who is usually deployed as a central defender but can also operate as a midfielder or striker, scored twice to give United a 3-1 win.

Preston also maintained their First Division promotion chances with a 2-0 win at Crystal Palace. They took only eight minutes to breach the Palace defence, with Jon Macken providing the decisive pass and David Healy the finishing touch. Graham Alexander added the other with a 24th-minute penalty, following a foul by Steve Thomson on Mark Rankine.

In contrast, Nottingham Forest, who started the day above both United and Preston on goal difference, slumped to a 2-0 defeat at Wolves.

To a great extent, they cut their own throats; they had Andy Johnson sent off for punching the Wolves captain, Kevin Muscat, and this was followed by an own-goal by Gareth Edds. Wolves' other goal came from Adam Proudlock. To make matters worse for Forest, they had another player sent off, Marlon Harewood, in the last minute.

At the other end, Tranmere returned to the bottom through their 3-1 defeat at Crewe and Huddersfield's 2-0 victory over Norwich. Tranmere, whose league results have contrasted so sharply with the ones they have produced in the FA Cup, were given a boost when Andy Parkinson put them ahead on the stroke of half-time. But Crewe hit back with goals by Steve Macauley, Ron Hulse and Colin Little.

The applicants to succeed Roy McFarland at Cambridge United included a supporter who described himself as being a brilliant PlayStation manager.

It is tempting to suggest that, had Cambridge given him the job, it would have been only marginally more controversial than their decision to bring John Beck to the club.

Beck, of course, is renowned (or should it be notorious?) for his crude long-ball tactics, and extreme ideas to gain a psychological edge on opposing teams. Thus, despite his record of lifting struggling teams, at Cambridge, Preston and Lincoln, his image is largely negative. He acknowledged the point himself last week in an interview with the local Evening News.

Beck, out of league football for two years, said: 'There were and still are a lot of lies told about what we did here (when he was manager from 1990-1992). But I accept that some of the things did not go down well with some people and it probably rebounded on me.'

This time around, he has promised to encourage a more appealing style of play. 'If I can blow my own trumpet a bit, I am capable of coaching any type of football,' he said.

'I played the passing game at QPR and learned from people such as Terry Venables and Harry Redknapp. We are not going to play the long-ball game or the short-ball game, we are going to play the right-ball game.'

But, as a great believer in scientific methods, and especially those relating to sports psychology, he warns that the players are in for some surprises, if not shocks. 'I believe an unpredictable style of management is necessary to keep the players motivated,' he explained.

For the time being, though, they seem wound up enough. Having lost their three previous league matches, all against teams below them in the table - they had a 2-0 win over Oldham.

fields.headline: Strupar double beats Spurs
fields.trailText: Sir Alan Sugar may have wandered into the distance with his millions but, even under new owners, it was the same old Tottenham away from White Hart Lane. In their first match under new chairman David Buchler, Spurs suffered their tenth Premiership defeat away from home.
fields.body:
Sir Alan Sugar may have wandered into the distance with his millions but, even under new owners, it was the same old Tottenham away from White Hart Lane. In their first match under new chairman David Buchler, Spurs suffered their tenth Premiership defeat away from home.

Derby, celebrating the 100th competitive match to be played here, soon gave Enic an early idea of what they have let themselves in for when they took the lead in the 12th minute. Craig Burley's corner was flicked on by Rory Delap for Branko Strupar to volley home from four yards at the far post. It was the Belgian's first goal since September in what has been an injury-interrupted season.

Back on the goal-scoring trail, Strupar hit the target again within 20 minutes, this time from the penalty spot after Alton Thelwell had bundled Malcolm Christie to the ground when the striker was moving away from danger.

New owners had clearly not brought Spurs any better luck on the injury front with star striker Sergei Rebrov ruled out after a training-ground accident. That was reflected in Spurs' lack of any cutting edge during a first-half when Derby's stand-in keeper Andy Oakes was rarely troubled.

But Derby's players had obviously not been reading manager Jim Smith's programme notes in which he complained that far too often this season his side have sat back in the later stages of matches, happy to soak up pressure, because that is exactly what they proceeded to do.

The longer the match went on, the deeper Derby defended. They were given a wake-up call in the 55th minute when Andy Booth forced a good save out of Oakes with a header and another, 11 minutes later, when the on-loan striker fired just wide.

But when Spurs did make the breakthrough, in the 70th minute, it was in the most bizarre circumstances. Sol Campbell hoisted a high ball into the penalty area which was so lacking direction that Les Ferdinand hardly bothered to challenge for. He did not need to because Taribo West did his job for him, heading the ball over Oakes into the net.

As own goals of the season go it is a sure-fire winner and surely not the way in which Oakes ever imagined conceding his first Premiership goal for six hours and 12 minutes.

By now, Tottenham had such a tight grip of the match Derby could barely get out of their own penalty area. But they held on.

fields.headline: Wonderful Wiltord sinks Hammers
fields.trailText: It was a result ready to happen. Arsenal, pride stung by the 6-1 tennis score at Old Trafford that made it game, set and match to Manchester United in the title stakes, retorted as indignantly as expected and a weakened West Ham United duly folded as of yore.
fields.body:
It was a result ready to happen. Arsenal, pride stung by the 6-1 tennis score at Old Trafford that made it game, set and match to Manchester United in the title stakes, retorted as indignantly as expected and a weakened West Ham United duly folded as of yore.

A first-half hat-trick by Sylvain Wiltord, cutting through a poor, porous West Ham defence, effectively ended the contest, if it could be said to have begun. Wiltord's haul will have cheered Arsène Wenger at least after last week's humiliation; the manager's record £13 million siging had scored only twice previously in the Premiership this season.

Arsenal were keeping some powder dry ready for Tuesday's crucial Champions League game at home to Spartak Moscow, with Thierry Henry left on the bench. The welcome news for them, though, especially in light of last Sunday's events at Old Trafford, was the return after a back injury of their captain, Tony Adams, with the hapless Igor Stepanovs omitted. In addition, Lee Dixon returned at right back in place of Oleg Luzhny. Silvinho was on international duty with Brazil.

The West Ham side were a hotchpotch and a disappointment for the neutral. Paulo Di Canio was suspended, Frédéric Kanouté and Joe Cole injured; clearly no risk was being taken ahead of next Sunday's FA Cup quarter-final at home to Tottenham Hotspur. They looked there for the taking and it didn't take Arsenal long to take them.

Adams signalled the intent after only seconds with a thumping clearance and his side soon took their cue. From another clearance, Stuart Pearce could only head the ball into the path of Robert Pires, who beat West Ham's offside trap with a through ball to Wiltord and the Frenchman tucked the ball neatly past Shaka Hislop.

Pearce suffered more from the curse that seems to afflict recipients of Carling awards, in his case the player of the month, and minutes later Arsenal were two goals to the good. Dixon's ball forward found Wiltord in space in the inside-right channel and he promptly turned inside Igor Stimac and Pearce before steering a left-footed shot into Hislop's right corner.

West Ham were a mess, with poor Frank Lampard in midfield surrounded by defenders filling in and unable to wrest control of the game's tempo from Patrick Vieira, again the fulcrum of all Arsenal movement. It was all the more lamentable as Arsenal did look occasionally indecisive in defence, their confidence clearly damaged.

But with West Ham lacking the wherewithal to exploit it, Arsenal enjoyed a comfortable ride and always looked likely to score. The inevitable third goal arrived when Freddie Ljungberg threaded another pass through a static West Ham defence and Wiltord stabbed the ball through the legs of Hislop to complete his hat-trick.

West Ham turned their back three more into a five for the second half and it brought Hislop some respite, though he was grateful to see Bergkamp's trademark curling shot from the inside-left position land on the roof of the net and two vicious drives from Ljungberg both fly just past his right post.

To his stifled disgust, Wiltord was replaced on the hour by Henry with Wenger perhaps deeming that the sight of his leading scorer might scare West Ham into conceding again.

It was largely going-through-the-motions stuff, however. Arsenal were sated, West Ham well beaten, though finally, with two minutes to go, getting a shot on target through Svetoslav Todorov, David Seaman grateful for the exercise on such a chilly day.

fields.headline: St Mirren misery deepens
fields.trailText: St Mirren's hopes of Premier League survival were left in tatters yesterday as they crashed to a 4-0 defeat in their bottom-of-the-table clash at Dundee United.
fields.body:
St Mirren's hopes of Premier League survival were left in tatters yesterday as they crashed to a 4-0 defeat in their bottom-of-the-table clash at Dundee United.

Charlie Miller, who had looked the player most likely to get the first goal, did just that after 32 minutes with a stunning shot from 25 yards. Three minutes later, David Hannah made it 2-0. United finally destroyed St Mirren with two goals in the last 11 minutes from Derek Lilley and Jim Hamilton.

It was also a good afternoon for Dundee, who overcame St Johnstone 3-2 with a late goal from Javier Artero.

St Johnstone, who went ahead after 13 minutes, then found themselves 2-1 down, appeared to have salvaged a point 12 minutes from the end when Paul Kane converted a penalty. In addition to that late winner by Artero, the other blow for them was that Gary Bollan, scorer of their first goal, was sent off.

Dundee player-manager Ivano Bonetti said: 'In recent weeks I have been happy with our performances, especially against Rangers, but the difference is that today we took our chances.'

However, St Johnstone's manager, Sandy Clark, insisted: 'Our defensive mistakes were horrendous, we gave the game to them.'

Charlie Miller, who had looked the player most likely to get the first goal, did just that after 32 minutes with a stunning shot from 25 yards. Three minutes later, David Hannah made it 2-0. United finally destroyed St Mirren with two goals in the last 11 minutes from Derek Lilley and Jim Hamilton. It was also a good afternoon for Dundee, who overcame St Johnstone 3-2 with a late goal from Javier Artero. St Johnstone, who went ahead after 13 minutes, then found themselves 2-1 down, appeared to have salvaged a point 12 minutes from the end when Paul Kane converted a penalty. fields.headline: Rovers hang on for point
fields.trailText: So much promise and so much effort, but only a point a piece to show for it. Judging by Rovers' time-wasting tactics and their reaction at the end, however, they seemed quite happy with the outcome. And every point is sacred at this end of the table when jobs, careers and reputations are on the line.
fields.body:
So much promise and so much effort, but only a point a piece to show for it. Judging by Rovers' time-wasting tactics and their reaction at the end, however, they seemed quite happy with the outcome. And every point is sacred at this end of the table when jobs, careers and reputations are on the line.

Garry Thompson became the latest to find a seat on the managerial merry-go-round when he was confirmed as manager of Bristol Rovers last week. Rovers must be hoping he can have a similar impact to the one Joe Kinnear has had since jumping on at Luton four weeks ago.

Luton had won four of their five games under Kinnear's leadership before yesterday, and this was only his second home match. Understandably, therefore, Luton's players, like their manager, stepped on to the pitch feeling like winners and started playing like them, too.

Rovers initially struggled to get out of their own half against positive Luton tactics. The young Irish striker Liam George shot across the face of goal after only three minutes and captain Paul McLaren struck a looping volley against the crossbar a minute later.

Luton remained the better team for much of the first half, but Rovers fought their way back into it and Nathan Ellington hit the woodwork seconds before the interval. As Kinnear had warned, Luton clearly were not going to be gifted with the home win they crave.

Luton again looked like sure-fire winners at the start of the second half and defender Julian Watts headed narrowly over from a 51st minute corner. But this time Rovers were better prepared to respond to Luton's threat and although chances were a rarity at either end suddenly they looked the team more likely to score.

They very nearly did, through Ansah Owusu in the 66th minute. Kinnear responded by throwing on a fresh striker in the form of Stuart Douglas. As the seconds ticked away, both teams went flying forward in search of a winner Rovers had a Scott Jones effort disallowed and George missed a great headed chance for Luton.

The atmosphere was particularly tense during the four minutes added on at the end of normal time, but it is likely to get far worse for both sets of fans as the season draws nearer to an end. There is every chance, though, that Luton and Rovers will be celebrating a reprieve by then.

fields.headline: Munich mugged
fields.trailText: German champions Bayern Munich missed out on the chance to regain top spot in the Bundesliga after suffering a shock 3-2 defeat at Hansa Rostock. Second-placed Bayern's seventh league defeat of the season allowed Borussia Dortmund, who hammered Eintracht Frankfurt 6-1 on Friday, to maintain pole position by one point.

Second-placed Bayern's seventh league defeat of the season allowed Borussia Dortmund, who hammered Eintracht Frankfurt 6-1 on Friday, to maintain pole position by one point.

Olympique Lyon, who host Bayern in the Champions League on Tuesday, recovered to beat title rivals Girondins Bordeaux 2-1 at home. Bordeaux lost for only the third time in 21 matches.

fields.headline: Why winners stand to lose
fields.standfirst: Even the most admired companies face eventual failure unless they are willing to risk mistakes, writes Simon Caulkin
fields.trailText: Even the most admired companies face eventual failure unless they are willing to risk mistakes, writes Simon Caulkin
fields.body:
To the usual fanfare, Fortune magazine last week published its annual table of most admired companies. For the fourth year running, General Electric (GE) heads the list. Indeed, nine of the top 10 are the same as last year, the only newcomer being Charles Schwab, which is in at No 8.

So far so boring? Not if you turn it around. The real story is what happens when companies stop being admired. In this case, the company written out of history in 2001 is Lucent Technologies, No 10 last year. Its dramatic humbling shows only too clearly that being admired in the past is no guarantee of success in the future - or even the present. In fact, being most admired should probably be taken as a danger sign; and the longer the successful run lasts, the louder the alarm bells should ring.

The fact is that admiration is a truly terrible proxy for success. If you have trouble with that, consider the fate of a British 'most admired' award in the early Nineties, which was apologetically abandoned because the same company was monopolising it every time.

The name of the perennial winner? Marks & Spencer. One reason M&S fell from grace was precisely that it was most admired, confirming senior managers in their belief that they were in possession of all the answers, which they could impose from the top. Diametrically wrong.

Their strategies and competences just happened to fit the environment of the Eighties. When it changed, they were sunk.

As with M&S, companies are admired for embodying the conventional wisdom about what makes for success. Yet today's conventional wisdom is tomorrow's recipe for disaster (just ask any dotcom). By reinforcing that wisdom retrospectively, admiration just makes the mistakes catastrophic when they do break the surface.

This is because learning is not about being right, or 'admirable'; it's about being wrong. Not for nothing do we call it trial and error. This is how science advances; this is how infants, children and adults learn; how innovation works. You try lots of things, eliminate the bad ones and keep the good until they too - as they always do in the end - turn bad.

But not companies. Despite the hype, the 'learning organisation' is the Loch Ness monster of management: endlessly hunted and fantasised over, but never actually sighted. The reason is simple: Companies don't fail enough.

Counterintuitively, being wrong has a lot going for it - if you know how to use it. Think of it this way: Firms exist at the intersection of two basic laws. Revans' Law (after the great management maverick Reg Revans, father of action learning) says that to survive, an organisation must learn at least as fast as its external environment is changing.

At the same time, Sturgeon's Law (coined by the science fiction author Theodore Sturgeon) decrees that 90 per cent of everything is crap (there's no guarantee about the other 10 per cent, by the way). One manifestation of Sturgeon is that nine out of 10 start-ups fail; and in normal times only one or two out of 10 venture-capital investments pays off big-time.

More soberly, Soichiro Honda, founder of the Japanese car firm, puts it this way: 'Many people dream of success. To me success can only be achieved through repeated failure and introspection. In fact, success represents the 1 per cent of your work which results only from the 99 per cent that is called failure.'

The key is that you can't have one without the other: in management, as in films, novels or poetry, the sublime emerges from, and is partly defined by, the accumulated experience and experiment of the ridiculous. It follows that to amplify the sublime, you also have to increase the volume and incidence of failure. As Tom Peters says: 'We need lots more of it. We need faster failure. It is fair to say that if we can't increase the gross national failure rate, we're in for a very rough ride indeed.'

Of course, this kind of failure is not the same as common or garden sloppiness. The point is to learn. For constructive failure of this kind to occur it must, in Peters' formulation, take place 'above the waterline' (that is, it won't sink the firm) and it must be accompanied by 'introspection' and immediate modification of product, processes or behaviour. This is the real definition of knowledge management - managing and learning from error.

You don't have to be a student of management to see what happens when it doesn't occur: you just have to travel by rail, look at the state of the British countryside, or spend a day in one of those countless companies where people are managed by the book or driven by fear from the top.

In all these organisations, because even small failures are inadmissible, they are hushed up or ignored - or people fiddle the figures. Managers perpetuate the deception to meet their targets; actions based on inaccurate data become policy; not only does no learning take place, but at each stage the deception becomes more institutionalised and harder to address.

Finally, at board level, it is simply unacknowledgeable. As researcher Chris Argyris has noted, even though in every case of corporate disaster, managers can clearly see it approaching, no one can break the conspiracy of silence, let alone take action.

Thus do multiple unimportant, even benign, failures end up as one huge and exceedingly malign one. This is what happened at IBM and Xerox, and at M&S, which were once among the world's most admired corporations.

Could it happen to GE, perhaps the most revered company in history? It could, and almost certainly will, eventually. GE has formidable management strengths. But to go on courting admiration, it must take risks below - not above - the waterline.

Thus if absorbing the $45bn bulk of Honeywell goes awry, new chief executive Jeffrey Immelt will not be around to learn from the experience. Where the norm is 90 or 99 per cent failure, putting yourself in a position where you can't afford to fail seems less admirable and more, well, foolhardy.

webTitle: Tomorrow's world is all too human

fields.headline: Tomorrow's world is all too human
fields.standfirst: Forget computers. People with a yearning for learning will be firms' real assets, says Jim Pollard
fields.trailText: Forget computers. People with a yearning for learning will be firms' real assets, says Jim Pollard
fields.body:
The work we do and the places we do it in are changing faster than at any time since the industrial revolution. Nobody knows exactly what the long-term effects of this will be, which can make secure career planning difficult. But are we worrying about the wrong questions? If you need to earn a living in the working environment of tomorrow, the key question is not 'how will globalisation and new technology alter it' but 'what skills will I need to survive in it'.

That is the question some businesses are beginning to address. The Talent Foundation, for example, which brings together employers as diverse as British Airways, the BBC, the police, the army and Accenture (formerly Andersen Consulting), is clear that people, not machines, are the future.

'Human skills are the essential foundations for success in the e-economy,' says the Foundation's Kinga Kowalewska. Richard Reeves of the Industrial Society, agrees: 'Corporate headquarters will probably continue to grow over the next 10 years. But another growing group will be the so-called new nomads - freelances with portfolio careers taking their skills from company to company. But whether you go this route or retain the security of a single employer, the skills you'll require are pretty similar.'

So what are these skills? Both Reeves and the Talent Foundation pinpoint not so much the technical or vocational as the very, very human - the sort of things computers can't do, in fact.

'Relationship management, by people both inside and outside of the company structure, will become key,' says Reeves.

He is referring to a form of networking that is about more than just mingling amiably at the office party. 'More and more organisations will be focusing on their core activity and sub-contracting out the rest,' he says. 'This won't just be the office cleaning, but also knowledge-rich types of work such as PR or human resources.

'In this environment, the effective worker will be the one with the capacity to retain contact with a wide range of people in a wide range of organisations across a wide range of locations.'

He makes a distinction between 'hot' networks, which include people and companies that are going places, and 'cold' ones - which are not. Hot networks constantly refresh themselves as people move in and out.

'Technical skills are becoming increasingly disposable,' he says. 'The computer system you're using now will probably be useless in three years. It will be crucial to develop the ability to recognise when your skills are obsolete and have the confidence to move on. In fact, your existing vocational skills are less important than your ability to learn new ones.'

Reeves believes that because of this we will increasingly pursue jobs that afford us the opportunity to learn - a need that, according to the Talent Foundation, many employers can't yet meet.

'Most organisations would agree that they need people who can learn quickly, who can solve problems without being told to and can come up with creative ideas without waiting for others,' says Kowalewska.

'But today's training strategies have a critical blind spot - the learner's motivation to learn. Without appropriate readiness to learn, training investments are destined to fail.'

The Foundation's research suggests emotional intelligence and motivational courses to help staff to develop this capacity to learn.

'In our study last year, more emotional intelligence participants perceived learning to be fun - 88 per cent compared with 64 per cent in the control group,' says Kowalewska. 'They also had higher self-awareness (62 compared with 43 per cent) and knew what to learn in order to succeed (71 compared with 61 per cent).'

She wants to see more of this sort of training: 'Organisations often attribute their loss of competitiveness and innovation to not having the right people,' she says. 'But investment is not insufficiently focused on developing human skills.'

So how strong is your readiness to learn? Reeves' advice is to develop your emotional capacity for it. 'Study what you want to study. What you learn may become out of date or irrelevant, but the capacity to learn and the desire to do it will not. If you like history, study it. Learning for learning's sake is the new modern thinking. It is vocational training that's out of date.'

Managers will need new skills, too. Indeed, some will need to reassess their role completely. 'It's easy to manage bums on seats,' says Reeves, 'but the management model that says that staff sit at their desk for X hours doing Y to earn Z is outdated. Time isn't money as in the industrial era; increasingly it's ideas that are money, and good ideas are like buses - nothing for ages and then three come along at once.

'Managers need to focus on tasks and outputs, not time. It's what staff produce, not when and where they produce it. If a worker is meeting targets why should you, as manager, care whether he emails his wife or books holidays from the office computer?'

He argues that managers need to stop drawing a line between work and play because it no longer really exists. 'Email snooping, for example, is trying to use new technology to prop up an old model of management,' he says.

If you're looking for an employer to help you develop your skills for the future, you could do worse than check out the 20-plus organisations that have signed up to the Talent Foundation's e-talent declaration (www.talentfoundation.org/declaration.html). These companies pledge that they will give priority to 'flexibility and adaptation through learning to learn, inspiring innovation and holistic thinking'. They also promise to feed employees' self-esteem, confidence, motivation, self-awareness and self-management and to develop collaboration, leadership, creativity, risk-taking and knowledge-sharing.

We used to complain that companies wanted us to be machines; in future the successful ones will want the exact opposite.

webTitle: Can I be made to do different work?

fields.headline: Can I be made to do different work?
fields.trailText: I have been very happy in my job for the past seven years, but my boss now wants me to take on duties which are totally unrelated to the work I do for about 10 per cent of my time. Can I refuse?
fields.body:
I have been very happy in my job for the past seven years, but my boss now wants me to take on duties which are totally unrelated to the work I do for about 10 per cent of my time. Can I refuse?

A lot depends on your individual circumstances, but it would probably be unwise to refuse outright. Tribunals tend to take a practical view of such disputes. If you worked for a small employer, an employment tribunal might expect you to be more flexible, so that your employer could keep up with changing times.

Asking you to change your duties for 10 per cent of your time might be judged to be reasonable. It could be a different matter if the proportion were 30 or 40 per cent.

But an employer might be deemed within their rights to ask a word processing secretary to take on Excel spreadsheets. Or if you worked for a charity as an administrator and were then asked to take on some fund-raising responsibilities, that might also be seen as reasonable.

Negotiation is probably the best way out here.

Another option is filing a grievance against your boss. This would get the issues reviewed by other people in the organisation. But it should be a last resort, since it can be damaging to your relationships with colleagues as well as with the person you file the grievance against.

But an employer might be deemed within their rights to ask a word processing secretary to take on Excel spreadsheets. Or if you worked for a charity as an administrator and were then asked to take on some fund-raising responsibilities, that might also be seen as reasonable. Negotiation is probably the best way out here. Another option is filing a grievance against your boss. This would get the issues reviewed by other people in the organisation. But it should be a last resort, since it can be damaging to your relationships with colleagues as well as with the person you file the grievance against.

fields.headline: Speak in public
fields.trailText: 1 Take a few simple steps to avoid the squeaky voice syndrome that is associated with inexperienced speakers. 'When you get rid of tension, your voice becomes more powerful,' says Maxina Pattison of London-based Corporate Voice Communications. Standing in the right way will encourage your body to relax.' Shrug your shoulders out,' she adds. 'Get your neck released, stand centred, avoid locking your knees and don't thrust your hips forward.'
fields.body:
1 Take a few simple steps to avoid the squeaky voice syndrome that is associated with inexperienced speakers. 'When you get rid of tension, your voice becomes more powerful,' says Maxina Pattison of London-based Corporate Voice Communications. Standing in the right way will encourage your body to relax.' Shrug your shoulders out,' she adds. 'Get your neck released, stand centred, avoid locking your knees and don't thrust your hips forward.'

2 Give some thought to your voice, and consider some training if you are going to do a lot of public speaking. Margaret Thatcher's voice got deeper - a sign of authority in a male-dominated world - when she became Prime Minister. Few people make it to the top if they speak in a high-pitched gabble. In a less male business world, deep voices are losing some of their cachet: a voice that can express emotion and range is, in reality, a bigger asset than a Barry White imitation.

3 Start getting practice in making the odd short speech. You are better off having your first attack of nerves asking a question in a departmental meeting than when you suddenly have to address a conference. Knowing how to say 'a few words' is a confidence booster for anyone. Many people who say they will never speak in public are, effectively, limiting their career to the bottom rung.

4 Make your speech sound spontaneous. Apart from the occasional star, most people need to plan carefully. You get extra brownie points if you speak without notes, but you then need a firm structure. Your performance can be raised several notches if you practise and almost know your script by heart.

5 Try to gear what you are saying to the audience. People nod off in pews when they do not relate to the sermon. At the other end of the spectrum, Bob Monkhouse is still a highly popular business speaker, not least because he learns the names of the executives in each company he address so he can weave them into his jokes.

6 Keep your speeches short and remember you have to entertain. Gordon Brown's Budget speech on Wednesday is not likely to produce belly laughs, but most other politicians (particularly William Hague, a first-rate speaker) will start, finish and embellish their addresses with jokes. You have to let your audience know that you are on their side. You help keep them awake by giving opportunities to laugh, applaud, raise their hands or boo their enemies.

webTitle: Look sharp - or your face may not fit

fields.headline: Look sharp - or your face may not fit
fields.trailText: How you look is becoming increasingly important at all levels of the labour market, according to the Industrial Society's latest report. In a survey of hotels, restaurants and bars, 85 per cent of employers placed personal presentation and appearance above initiative, communication skills and even ability to follow instructions.
fields.body:
How you look is becoming increasingly important at all levels of the labour market, according to the Industrial Society's latest report. In a survey of hotels, restaurants and bars, 85 per cent of employers placed personal presentation and appearance above initiative, communication skills and even ability to follow instructions.

The report's author, Chris Warhurst, says: 'Aesthetics have always been important to certain groups - politicians, managers, professionals and City types. What is startling is the application of such values in the wider job market. Adverts for the hospitality and retail sectors regularly ask for people who are 'stylish', 'attractive', 'trendy' or 'well-spoken'.

The danger is that people without these attributes will be denied work. The report cited such discriminatory cases as the supermarket check-out worker told to shave her legs so she wouldn't 'put customers off', and the male off-shore oil worker dismissed for being too fat.

As the Industrial Society's Richard Reeves puts it: 'Style is becoming the new substance.'
